title: Arts, Briefly
description: For FX, war is heaven. The series premiere of "Over There," the Iraq war drama whose stars include Keith Robinson, below, brought in 4.1 million viewers on Wednesday. It was one of a number of big draws on cable last week in Nielsen's estimates. Lifetime's original movie "The Dive From Clausen's Pier," in which a young woman (Michelle Trachtenberg) ditches her fianc after he becomes paralyzed, attracted an audience of 4.2 million last Monday. The second season premiere of MTV's "Laguna Beach" (3.6 million), also on Monday, was the night's most-watched show in the 12-to-34 demographic on all of television. It was also the most popular program of the summer among teenage girls. On HBO, which has 28 million subscribers, the July 24 episode of "Entourage" scored its highest ratings ever, with 2 million viewers. The numbers for the soon-to-conclude "Six Feet Under" have improved since it moved from Mondays back to Sundays. The July 24 installment brought in an audience of 2.5 million. But year-over-year, the family drama is still suffering: the equivalent episode in 2004 drew 1.3 million more viewers. KATE AURTHUR

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Human Head Found In Garden
description: A badly decomposed human head was found in a garden in Bedford-Stuyvesant on Saturday evening, four days after a torso was found a few miles away, the police said yesterday. The head, wrapped in a black garbage bag, was discovered about 6 p.m. on a pathway inside a community garden at MacDonough Street and Stuyvesant Avenue. title: Bad to the Last Drop
description: London - IT'S summertime, and odds are that at some point during your day you'll reach for a nice cold bottle of water. But before you do, you might want to consider the results of an experiment I conducted with some friends one summer evening last year. On the table were 10 bottles of water, several rows of glasses and some paper for recording our impressions. We were to evaluate samples from each bottle for appearance, odor, flavor, mouth, feel and aftertaste -- and our aim was to identify the interloper among the famous names. One of our bottles had been filled from the tap. Would we spot it?

description: A Lower East Side man was charged yesterday with criminal possession of marijuana and attempting to bribe a police officer, law enforcement officials said. Police officers, responding to reports of a dispute, said they were overwhelmed by the smell of marijuana in an apartment on Essex Street. They said the occupant, Sami Chartouni, 31, had dozens of plastic bags filled with the drug. After one of the officers arrested Mr. Chartouni, he offered the officer a bag filled with thousands of dollars, the police said. The police said they seized about 150 pounds of marijuana and $375,000 in cash. Jennifer Medina (NYT)

title: Ice-Bound Hearties Endure Antarctica and One Another
description: No scientist or explorer, Mr. Johnson did grunt work over five summers and two winters at McMurdo Station, the largest of the three permanent United States scientific bases on the continent. He scraped pots in the cafeteria kitchen, drove forklifts, rolled barrels of frozen human waste out to the dump when the wind chill was below minus 50 degrees. If his tales of life at the bottom of the organizational chart contrast starkly with government-stamped depictions, they also have a mordant ring of truth.

description: Van AMBURG--Dr. James E. We, the Board, faculty and staff, and the entire community of the Dwight-Englewood School, mourn the loss of a visionary educator, outstanding educational leader, and friend. From 1984-1998, Jim's leadership, as the school's headmaster, enhanced the school's reputation and national recognition for its curricular innovations such as the award-winning Senior Focus Program and the Upper School integrated Math/Science/Technology (MST) curriculum. During his tenure, Jim oversaw the merger with the Bede School, resulting in a preschool-12th grade program. His committment to diversity at DwightEnglewood and to the school's support of the New Jersey SEEDS program has changed many lives and strengthened our community. We will miss him, but his legacy lives on.

title: Young Suburbanites Publish a Hip-Hop Magazine
description: Remy Ma was running on hip-hop time. That meant at least a 15-minute delay in the singer's appearance the other day in her Midtown Manhattan hotel suite, decorated in blood-red, her favorite color. The off-the-clock rhythms of music industry folk were nothing new for Devin and Cameron Lazerine, who were interviewing Ms. Ma for their magazine Rap-Up, which they bill as the first hip-hop magazine for teenagers. As they waited, Devin fiddled with his laptop, which contained their prepared questions, and put off whoever was on the other end of his cellphone. Meanwhile, Cameron asked his big brother to check the schedule for the other interviews they'd lined up for their magazine.

description: A Brooklyn man who lost control of a car he was driving and crashed into a parked car was charged with assault and reckless endangerment after one of his passengers died, the police said. The man, whom the police identified as Desmond Barton, 22, was driving a Nissan Maxima east on Snyder Avenue in Farragut with four passengers just after 1 a.m. Saturday, the police said. As he tried to pass a car, according to the police, he swerved into oncoming traffic, hurtled through a fence and crashed into an unoccupied car parked in a driveway on Snyder Avenue. One passenger in the Maxima, Anthony Small, 29, was pronounced dead at Kings County Hospital Center, the police said. The three other passengers were treated at the hospital and released, the police said. Kareem Fahim (NYT)

title: Arts, Briefly; 'Crashers' Lands on Top
description: In a first for an R-rated film in its third week of release, "Wedding Crashers" (New Line) swapped spots with the reigning No. 1 film. The sex comedy starring Owen Wilson, left, and Vince Vaughn took in almost $20.5 million over the weekend, pushing "Charlie and the Chocolate Factory" (Warner Brothers) to No. 2 with its $16.4 million in three-day ticket sales, according to Exhibitor Relations, which tracks box-office performance. Other films that have moved into the top spot after opening at No. 2 include "Elf" (New Line) in 2003, in its second weekend, and "The Santa Clause" (Buena Vista) in 1994, in its third weekend; both were rated PG. (The R-rated comedy "There's Something About Mary," from Fox, moved to No. 1 in its eighth week of release in 1998 after opening at No. 4.) Rounding out the top five were three films that opened in wide release this weekend: the PG-rated, family-friendly adventure-comedy "Sky High" (Buena Vista), with Kurt Russell and Kelly Preston, at $14.6 million; the action film "Stealth" (Sony), about fighter pilots and starring Josh Lucas, Jessica Biel and Jamie Foxx, at $13.5 million; and the romantic comedy "Must Love Dogs" (Warner Brothers), with Diane Lane and John Cusack, at $13 million. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FEDER, DR. STUART
description: FEDER--Dr. Stuart. 75, of Manhattan, died July 29, 2005. Predeceased by his beloved and cherished wife Carol. Dear and devoted father to Susanna, Adam, and Aaron. Caring father-in-law to Colleen. Loving grandfather to Katlyn and Allison. Devoted friend to his companion Charlotte. Dr. Feder was a deeply creative man, infusing himself into all that he did. Dr. Feder will be remembered as a gifted psychoanalyst, psychiatrist, and outstanding teacher. He authored several important biographical works on Charles Ives and Gustav Mahler exploring the connection between psychoanalysis and music. Dr. Feder grew up in Brooklyn, attended Erasmus Hall High School, received his BA from Johns Hopkins University, and obtained a Masters Degree in music from Harvard University. He earned his medical degree from Albert Einstein College of Medicine and completed a residency in Psychiatry at Mt. Sinai Medical Center. He is a graduate of the New York Psychoanalytic Institute where he became a member of the faculty. Until his death Dr. Feder was Clinical Associate Professor of Psychiatry at Albert Einstein College of Medicine and Attending Psychiatrist at Beth Israel Medical Center where he was honored by his students as "Teacher of the Year" for 2005. In addition to being a scholar and physician, he was a chef for all occasions, a passionate gardener, and a Yankee fan. He was dearly and deeply loved by his family and close circle of friends and will be profoundly missed and lovingly remembered. Services will be held on Monday, August 1, at 11:45 AM at "The Riverside," 76th and Amsterdam.

A Death in Sudan
description: John Garang became Sudan's first vice president three weeks ago, on July 9. More than a million Sudanese showed up to salute him when he joined his old enemy, President Omar Hassan Ahmad al-Bashir, to sign a new constitution. Mr. Garang's ascendance, along with the peace deal it brought, was hailed as a rare success story in Africa, one that could mark the end of more than two decades of war. There was also hope that the unity government between the largely Christian and animist south and the Muslim north might eventually be able to extend the newly cobbled-together peace between the north and south to the western territory, which includes Darfur.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Bail Is Denied For Beating Suspect
description: A white man charged with beating a black man in what prosecutors said was a racially motivated assault in Howard Beach in June was denied bail yesterday. Nicholas Minucci, 19, left, has been held without bail on charges that he chased the victim down, shouted a racial epithet and beat him with a baseball bat. Justice John Latella of State Supreme Court ruled that the judge who refused to set bail after Mr. Minucci was arrested in June had not abused her discretion. Mr. Minucci has denied the charges. Outside the court, his mother, Maria, 48, charged that prosecutors had fed a media frenzy and were "hanging my son for their own political gain." Corey Kilgannon (NYT)

description: The government accused an 86-year-old Ukrainian immigrant of being part of a Nazi-run police unit that terrorized Jews and sent them to death camps in World War II. title: Metro Briefing | New York: Old Brookville: Horse Dies Of Encephalitis
description: A horse died here last week of eastern equine encephalitis, a rare disease that can also kill humans, Nassau County's health commissioner, Dr. David M. Ackman, reported yesterday. The virus is spread by mosquitoes, which contract it from biting infected birds and then pass it on by biting other animals. This case is the first ever in Nassau and the only recent one in the state, according to state officials. The state has had only two human deaths from the disease, in 1971 and 1983. Crews will spray pesticides here to kill mosquitoes, officials said, and they urged residents to eliminate standing water where mosquitoes breed. Bruce Lambert (NYT)

title: WORLD BUSINESS BRIEFING | ASIA: Japan: Wages Rise for 3rd Month in a Row
description: Japanese workers' average monthly salary pay rose 0.3 percent in June, to 254,875 yen ($2,266), government data showed, marking the third consecutive month of increase. The preliminary data from the Ministry of Health, Labor and Welfare comes after increases in the Japanese base salary in both April and May, reversing a run of declines stretching back over four years. The rebound in income, coupled with continued improvements in employment figures, added to hopes that consumer spending would increase, bringing Japan's economy closer to self-sustained growth after years of overdependency on exports.

Paid Notice: Deaths   BELKIN, GARY
description: BELKIN--Gary. His friends, who are his family, mourn his death. Gary lost his battle with emphysema Thursday July 28. His comedy writing career spanned close to 60 years from New Yorker Cartoons to Emmy Award TV writing for Sid Caesar. He wrote for Danny Kaye, Johnny Carson, Anne Bancroft, Frank Sinatra and eight years for the Carol Burnett Show. He wrote for serveral sitcoms, ghostwrote much of the poetry attributed to Cassius Clay (AKA Mohammed Ali), and speeches for several politicians including John Lindsay. Gary wrote the award winning script for the PBS ground-breaking sex education show VD Blues. When slowed by his illness he devoted his efforts to mentoring emerging young comedians and being a generous and incomparably loyal friend to many of us. He bound us together by challenging us to be smarter, funnier, and angrier at injustice. We will miss him.

title: WORLD BUSINESS BRIEFING | ASIA: Japan: Profit at Mizuho Financial Rises
description: The Mizuho Financial Group, Japan's largest bank by assets, said first-quarter profit rose 15 percent as it increased investment banking fees and cut costs by integrating computer systems. Net income in the three months ended June 30 climbed to 173.3 billion yen ($1.54 billion), or 15,980 yen a share, Mizuho, which is based in Tokyo, said in a statement. Revenue rose 8 percent, prompting the bank to raise its half-year profit forecast. Japan's banks are increasing fees from asset management and securities underwriting to become more competitive with global banks like Citigroup, which has a market value four times that of Mizuho. Profit from lending has lagged as Japan's central bank kept interest rates close to zero since 2001 to combat deflation. "Mizuho and other banks generated sufficient profit by cutting costs and increasing fees even in such a tough environment," said Yoji Takeda, who helps manage $250 million as head of Asian equities at RBC Investment Management (Asia) in Hong Kong.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Russia: Slaughter As Bird Flu Hits Siberia
description: Russia ordered the slaughter of chickens and other poultry in several regions in Siberia, hoping to contain an outbreak of the A(H5N1) strain of avian influenza virus that has swept Asia in the past two years, according to news reports. title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Plea Deal For Car Dealer
description: A politically powerful Bronx car dealer, Richard Gidron, pleaded guilty in State Supreme Court yesterday to violating the terms of his probation. He acknowledged using a scheme to defraud nine people of a total of $70,000 to $100,000. That is the value of car loans that Mr. Gidron, 66, admitted he took over and failed to properly repay. Under the terms of the plea agreement, Mr. Gidron must repay the loans if he is to receive one to three years in prison when he is sentenced next month. In addition, Mr. Gidron owes about $800,000 in unpaid state and federal taxes incurred during his recent probation violations. A spokesman for the State Department of Taxation and Finance, Tom Bergin, said that Mr. Gidron owed more than $13 million in unpaid taxes, but would not say how much he had repaid, citing privacy laws. State tax collectors have closed Mr. Gidron's four car dealerships, he said. A number of powerful New Yorkers went to court to support Mr. Gidron yesterday, including former Mayor David N. Dinkins. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

title: WORLD BUSINESS BRIEFING | ASIA: Thailand: Inflation Rises as Fuel Subsidies End
description: Thai inflation accelerated to 5.3 percent in July from a year ago, more than a six-year high, as higher fuel prices made transportation more expensive. Consumer prices were up from 3.8 percent in June. The Bank of Thailand has raised its benchmark interest rate six times since August to curb inflation and stem the baht's decline. The central bank governor, Pridiyathorn Devakula, left, wants to keep increasing rates to dampen rising consumer prices and attract overseas funds to finance a widening current-account deficit. Thailand began reducing diesel subsidies on June 1, and on July 13 eliminated the remaining fuel price support, ending 18 months of efforts to protect the economy from rising oil prices that had cost the country 92.1 billion baht ($2.2 billion) since January 2004. The retail price of diesel, used in trucks and buses, has increased 58 percent this year.

title: Arts, Briefly; CBS Uses 'Mars' In a Tube Test
description: In a synergistic experiment on Friday, CBS showed two repeat episodes of "Veronica Mars," starring Kristen Bell, below, providing its Viacom sibling UPN with a larger platform for the cult-favorite series. The pilot, which set up the mystery for the show's first season, drew 3.47 million viewers, a larger audience than any original episode all last season on UPN. The 9 p.m. "Veronica Mars" did nearly as well, with 3.21 million viewers. But NBC won the sleepy Friday Nielsen race in total viewers, and ABC placed first among adults 18 to 49: CBS was No. 3 in both categories. That night, Fox was also trying to build an audience for its critical hit "Arrested Development" by broadcasting two hours of episodes. Fox finished Friday in fifth place. title: Zimbabwe Drops Treason Case Against Mugabe Opponent
description: Without explanation, the government dropped its treason case against Morgan Tsvangirai, the leader of the main opposition party, scrapping a two-year-long prosecution on charges that carried a potential death penalty. Mr. Tsvangirai was charged with treason after he organized demonstrations against President Robert G. Mugabe in 2003. Prosecutors claimed the protests were an attempt to overthrow the government. In October, Mr. Tsvangirai was acquitted of a separate charge of plotting to kill Mr. Mugabe. At a news conference yesterday, Mr. Tsvangirai thanked supporters for their efforts "during the period of relentless persecution" by the government. Sharon LaFraniere (NYT)

title: WORLD BUSINESS BRIEFING | ASIA: Japan: Losses Narrow at Mitsubishi Motors
description: Mitsubishi Motors said its losses narrowed sharply in the April-June quarter from a year earlier, when it booked big special losses related to reorganizing steps. The Japanese carmaker posted a group net loss of 21.65 billion yen ($193 million) in the three months ended June 30 as its vehicle sales in Japan and North America remained in a slump. But that was an improvement from its 54.69 billion yen loss in the year-earlier quarter, as it trimmed its sales promotions and other costs. "We got off to a better start toward achieving our goal for fiscal 2005," Hiizu Ichikawa, above, the chief financial officer of Mitsubishi Motors, said at a briefing. Mitsubishi's group sales fell 13 percent, to 485.83 billion yen, in the quarter. It posted a group operating loss of 13.78 billion yen, smaller than its year-earlier operating loss of 31.71 billion yen.

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Egypt: Deaths From Torture Climb
description: The Egyptian police fatally tortured 22 prisoners in 2004, a marked increase from the 8 prisoners reportedly tortured to death a year earlier, according to a report by the Egyptian Organization for Human Rights. The report also said that security forces were increasingly employing mass punishments -- rounding up large numbers of people for arrest and questioning, including 3,000 people detained after the October bombing attack on a Red Sea resort in the Sinai. Gasser Hussein Abdel Razek, the editor of the report, said the number of torture-related deaths might be even higher and was generally tolerated in cases involving Islamists. "There has been a government policy of tolerance for police brutality," he said. "The numbers will increase until there is a policy decision that torture won't be tolerated." Michael Slackman (NYT)

Michael O'Leary, the chief executive, said rivals' higher ticket prices were driving customers to discount airlines and giving Ryanair room to raise average fares. description: An index of British retail sales stayed near a 25-year low in July, adding to evidence of a persisting decline in consumer spending in England, Europe's second-largest economy. Forty-seven percent of the 125 companies surveyed said sales volumes fell from a year earlier, while 29 percent said they had posted a gain, the Confederation of British Industry lobby group said in London. That produced a balance of minus 18, after June's minus 19, which was the lowest since the survey began in 1983. The index has been negative for five consecutive months. "The deterioration in retail sales volumes is continuing," said Digby Jones, the director general of the group. "When considered alongside the weakness in order books in the manufacturing sector and the depressed state of the housing market, a marked slowdown in the economy is clear to see."

Paid Notice: Deaths   ZANKEL, ARTHUR
description: ZANKEL--Arthur. The Board of Trustees of Skidmore College and the entire Skidmore family deeply mourn the death of Arthur Zankel, father of Skidmore graduates, trustee emeritus, generous benefactor, loyal friend, and honorary degree recipient. As a trustee, Art brought a wealth of experience, a quick wit, and an incisive mind to bear on the challenges facing the College. As a member of our investment committee, he helped us to build and invest our resources wisely, fueling an unprecedented period of growth in the College's programs and reputation. That same passion and wisdom was evident in his philanthropy at Skidmore, which included significant contributions to provide scholarships and to underwrite programs such as the summer residency of the Boys Choir of Harlem. In addition, he endowed a professorship--the Zankel Chair in Management for Liberal Arts Students, which reflected his belief that liberal arts majors often end up practicing much more management and business than they expect--and a lecture series--the Zankel Lectures, which serves as a forum for the discussion of business issues from a broader societal and ethical perspective. Art leaves an impressive legacy of generosity, commitment, and integrity that will inspire and empower generations of Skidmore students and faculty. He will always be a part of the fabric of our community and we send our deepest condolences to his wife, Judy; his sons, Kenneth (Class of 1982), James (Class of 1992), Mark, and Thomas; his brothers, Martin and Jeffrey; and his grandchildren. Suzanne Corbet Thomas '62 Chair, Board of Trustees Philip A. Glotzbach President

description: SHAMBAN--William. The officers, board and staff of the American Technion Society (ATS) mourn the loss of our devoted friend William Shamban of Santa Monica, Calif. A Technion Guardian who, with his wife, Sophia, reached the highest level of commitment to the ATS, the Technion and Israel, Mr. Shamban served on the ATS Board of Regents and the Southern California Chapter board. After graduating from MIT with a degree in chemical engineering, he founded the aerospace engineering company W.S. Shamban Co., and later PolyMod Technologies, Inc., which pioneered numerous advances in the aerospace industry. Devoted supporters of the Technion and its research programs in aerospace and tribology, the Shambans sponsored the William and Sophia Shamban Micro - Tribology Student Teaching Laboratory and the William and Sophia Shamban Chair in Aerospace Engineering, and also provided support for the Institute of Catalysis Science and Technology. In recognition of his outstanding dedication,Mr. Shamban was awarded a Technion honorary fellowship in 1997. We extend our condolences to Sophia, children Dr. Ava T. Shamban, Karl S. title: WORLD BUSINESS BRIEFING | Russia: Crude Oil Output Slows
description: Russia's average daily oil output rose at the slowest annual pace this year, as higher taxes and the government's dismantling of Yukos Oil discouraged investment in Russia, the world's second-biggest oil supplier. Crude oil production increased 1.2 percent from the year-ago period, rising to 9.45 million barrels a day, or 39.97 million tons, according to the Energy and Industry Ministry. In June, Russia raised crude oil output 1.8 percent, to 9.43 million barrels a day, compared with the year-ago period. Oil investments have slowed after Russia levied $28 billion in back tax claims against Yukos, the nation's largest oil exporter last year, and confiscated the company's biggest production unit.

description: A 39-year-old woman suspected of having killed nine newborn babies whose remains were found this week in a shed in Brieskow-Finkenheerd, on the Polish border, told investigators that she was alone during the deliveries and could not specifically remember all the births because she got drunk as soon as she went into labor. Prosecutors suspect that the woman, identified as Sabine H., a dental hygienist who has been unemployed for years, killed the infants soon after giving birth to them between 1988 and 1999. Their remains were discovered by an acquaintance of the woman who found small human bones in a sand-filled aquarium and several flower pots and boxes in the shed. A state prosecutor said it was still unclear how the infants had died. News reports said the woman is the mother of four living children, ages 20, 19, 18 and almost 2, and is pregnant again. title: Apophis and Us
description: While the shuttle is in space and our attention is tilted upward, it's worth thinking about what else is up there, especially an asteroid named 99942 Apophis. When this object -- a little more than a thousand feet across -- was first discovered last year, astronomers estimated that it had a distant chance of striking Earth in 2029. After closer observation, it seems likely that this asteroid will still pass very near our planet, but without striking it. There is still a possibility, however, that as it swings by it may hit a gravitational "keyhole," shifting its orbit far enough to make it strike Earth in 2036.

title: Arts, Briefly; Record-Breaking Chess
description: Susan Polgar, below, a chess grandmaster who is the No. 2-ranked female player in the world, set a new record Monday for playing games simultaneously. She also set a record for playing the most games consecutively. Starting at 10:30 a.m., Ms. Polgar played 326 games at the Gardens Mall in Palm Beach Gardens, Fla. She won 309, tied 14 and lost 3. Many of her opponents played her more than once, and by the time the exhibition ended at 3 a.m. on Tuesday, Ms. Polgar had played 1,131 consecutive games against 551 opponents, winning 1,112, tying 16 and losing 3. The previous record for simultaneous games was 321, set last year by Andrew Martin, a British international master. The previous record for consecutive games played was 1,102 by Anna-Maria Botsari, a grandmaster from Greece. She set her record last year. DYLAN LOEB McCLAIN

description: BROOKS -- Donald. The Trustees, faculty and staff of The New School and the Board of Governors of Parsons The New School for Design express their sadness at the passing of Donald Brooks, distinguished fashion designer, Parsons alumnus, Honorary Board member, Honorary Degree recipient, and mentor to students. As a Designer Critic in the Fashion Design program for 40 years, Mr. Brooks played a direct and meaningful role in shaping the education and professional direction for scores of students. He was awarded the Parsons Medal for Distinguished Achievement in 1974 and an Honorary Doctorate in Fine Arts in 1985, and, in 2003, his work was celebrated in an exhibition. Though saddened by his passing, individuals throughout the Parsons community will continue to feel the influence of his work and be inspired by his accomplshments and his lifelong commitment to excellence in design. Also named in the lawsuit, first reported in The Boston Globe, are St. Martin's Press, which published the book in July 2002; the book's editor; and Mr. Burroughs's literary agent. The lawsuit contends that portions of the book concerning the Turcotte family, whose name in the book is changed to Finch, are fictional and were written to sensationalize it and improve its marketability. The lawsuit contends that Mr. Burroughs, above, has publicly identified the Finch family as the Turcottes. A spokesman for St. Martin's said that the company could not comment on a matter in litigation. Mr. Burroughs said in an e-mail message that he could not comment either. EDWARD WYAT

title: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Kohl Testimony Helps Aide Escape A Charge

Mr. Pfahls admitted at the start of his trial in June that he had accepted bribes of nearly $2.4 million to secure the deal. "I have no indication of outside influences," Mr. Kohl told the court. "I was never bribeable and never will be." He said he had approved the sale himself after making a secret personal pledge to Secretary of State James A. Baker III in the fall of 1990. "The Americans wanted us to help the Saudis," he said. Mr. Pfahls still faces other charges, including tax evasion. A verdict is expected next week.

"My concerns will be to establish righteousness and justice." He also greeted a stream of community leaders and dignitaries, including Prince Charles and Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain and other European heads of state, who expressed their condolences on the death of his predecessor and half-brother, King Fahd, who was buried on Tuesday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RASHER, CHARLES
description: RASHER--Charles. It is with great sorrow that the Board of Trustees, medical staff and management of The Mount Vernon Hospital note with sadness the death of their Board Member, friend, community leader, and faithful supporter, Charles Rasher. Mr. Rasher has been a Mount Vernon resident for nearly eighty years, and service to his community was extremely important to him. Mr. Rasher was noted for his kindness, love and support for the hospital. He truly made a difference at the hospital and in the lives of many in the community. A former chairman of the Mount Vernon Housing Authority, and past director of the Westchester County United Way, Mr. Rasher served for 25 consecutive years as a trustee of the Mount Vernon Hospital and was currently treasurer. Charlie worked for more than forty years as a trader and member of the COMEX, and was elected to its board in 1993. He diligently served on the marketing and metals committees long before that. He was most proud of his service on the membership committee, and never once missed a meeting since 1963. He was also on the board of directors at Lehman College. Charlie was invaluable to us in many areas of the hospital and he will be greatly missed. Our sincere condolences to his family and friends. Vincent Bufano President, Board of Trustees John R. Spicer President & CEO Sound Shore Health System George Haskins Senior Vice President/COO The Mount Vernon Hospital Thomas J. Price, MD President, Medical Board

description: The top-selling album in the country for the second week in a row is the 19th installment of the pop compilation series "Now That's What I Call Music!" It sold 236,000 copies, according to Nielsen SoundScan. And Young Jeezy, a rapper from Atlanta who is part of the group Boyz N Da Hood, reached No. 2 with his new solo album, "Let's Get It: Thug Motivation 101" (Def Jam). But the biggest news on the chart this week is the No. 4 entry, Dane Cook's comedy disc "Retaliation" (Comedy Central). It sold 86,000 copies in its first week of release, and Billboard says it is the highest-charting comedy album since Steve Martin's "Wild and Crazy Guy" went to No. 2 in 1979. It has been a big year for comedy albums: in April Larry the Cable Guy reached No. 7 with "The Right to Bare Arms" (Warner Brothers); that album has sold nearly 500,000 copies. Elsewhere on the chart this week, Mariah Carey's "Emancipation of Mimi" (Island/Def Jam) is at No. 3 and Jason Mraz is at No. 5 with "Mr. A-Z" (Atlantic), which sold 81,000 units. BEN SISARIO

title: Arts, Briefly; Bruckheimer Buoys CBS
description: The top three programs in Nielsen's estimates for the week that ended on July 31 were all produced by Jerry Bruckheimer. Repeats of "CSI," "Without a Trace" and "CSI: Miami" led the weekly rankings, in that order. In the coming season CBS, NBC and WB plan to add four more shows by Mr. Bruckheimer to their schedules, hoping for exactly that kind of success. Because that current top three is on CBS, the network easily won the week in total viewers and tied with Fox among adults 18 to 49. It was the ninth week in a row that CBS was No. 1 in total viewers. On Tuesday the CBS lineup -- an "NCIS" rerun (9.14 million), "Big Brother" (8.82 million) and "Rock Star: INXS" (5.92 million) -- added up to a victory for the night in the major ratings demographics. The debut of NBC's "Meet Mr. Mom" fizzled, drawing only 4.55 million viewers. KATE AURTHUR

title: Design for Confusion
description: I'd like to nominate Irving Kristol, the neoconservative former editor of The Public Interest, as the father of "intelligent design." No, he didn't play any role in developing the doctrine. But he is the father of the political strategy that lies behind the intelligent design movement -- a strategy that has been used with great success by the economic right and has now been adopted by the religious right.

title: Art Listings
description: STANYA KAHN AND HARRIET (HARRY) DODGE Presented without fanfare on a small monitor as part of "Sugartown," an exhibition of 21 young and emerging artists from Los Angeles, the low-tech videos of Harriet (Harry) Dodge and Stanya Kahn might not seem like much at first. But stop and watch for a few minutes and you will be hooked by the funniest performance artist to appear in a New York art gallery since Alex Bag. In each of two 15-minute videos, Ms. Kahn, above, plays a hapless, badly dressed and coiffed character named Lois, who seems to be teetering on the brink of real insanity as a result of too much California-style hedonism and New Age philosophy. In "Let the Good Times Roll," she talks to an unseen cameraman named Dave (Ms. Dodge in reality) whom she met when they each mistakenly turned up at the same desolate and windy spot in the desert looking for an outdoor rock concert. Back indoors, she proceeds to tell Dave in extraordinarily vivid detail a long, convoluted and hilarious story about a night of kinky sex, drug consumption, abjection and mystical enlightenment she had shortly after she heard of the death of Kurt Cobain. She speaks with such goofy, deadpan earnestness and verbal inventiveness that you wish she would go on for another hour. Somebody, please, give these women money to make a feature-length movie! ("Sugartown" remains on view at Elizabeth Dee Gallery, 545 West 20th Street, Chelsea, (212) 924-7545, through Aug. 6; and at Participant Inc., 95 Rivington Street, Lower East Side, (212) 254-4334, through Aug. 7.) KEN JOHNSON

title: The Duplicate Dog
description: The cloning of a dog by South Korean scientists is notable mostly for the display of virtuosity and persistence by the research team. title: The Listings: Aug. 5 -- Aug. 11; PIANOS IN THE PARK
description: Brad Mehldau and Jason Moran, jazz pianists in their 30's, have both been upheld as auspices for the music's future. They are strikingly different musicians; Mr. Mehldau, above, has a fluid and expressively romantic style, while Mr. Moran favors jagged, delirious polyphony. But they have things in common, too: both emerged as sidemen in high-profile quartets; each came to prominence at the helm of a head-turning trio; and each has forayed fruitfully into nontraditional solo piano. They also have similarly broad-minded approaches to repertory. (Mr. Mehldau performs songs by Radiohead and Nick Drake; Mr. Moran has interpreted Afrika Bambaataa and Bjork.) Mr. Mehldau's most recent album, "Live in Tokyo" (Nonesuch), is a solo recital that blends judicious pop offerings with archaic songbook standards, employing a touch that runs from sprightly to somber; he'll play solo here, with his usual ambidextrous grace. At the opposite end of the stylistic spectrum is Mr. Moran's Bandwagon, which has lately been a quartet with electric guitar, but performs here in its original trio incarnation. "Same Mother" (Blue Note), the band's latest meteorite of an album, brings an avant-garde mutability to many shades of the blues. In performance, the group tends to walk a razor's edge; its rumbling crescendos should make for a rousing concert closer. The opener is a trio led by Eric Lewis, a percussive and probing young pianist who recently emerged from under the wing of Wynton Marsalis to pursue his own career. (Tonight at 7, Central Park SummerStage, Rumsey Playfield, midpark at 70th Street, (212)360-2777, free.) NATE CHINEN

title: Gasp, Where Quebec Jabs the Sea
description: AT the far northern end of the Appalachian chain, where the last ridges curve east to collide with the sea, Quebec's Route 132 hooks out onto the Gasp Peninsula, a curl of forests and farmland, cliffs and ancient harbors. Bordered on the north by the widening mouth of the St. Lawrence River and on the south by a narrow bay, the peninsula is called Gasp after the words for "land's end" in the language of the native Micmac people, and despite the occasional ptisserie or tamed botanical garden, the name still feels right. Following the highway's dips and braided turns along the St. Lawrence to the tip of the Gasp, you'll pass stunning scenery of woods, crags, rugged beaches and scattered towns, all sheltering an enduring French-speaking culture.

title: The Listings: Aug. 5 -- Aug. 11; THE HOLD STEADY
description: Imagine the best bar band you've ever seen. Now imagine it fronted by a guy with punk attitude, a def poet's way with words and some ripping yarns to tell. That frontman is Craig Finn of the Hold Steady. Since moving to Brooklyn a few years back, Mr. Finn, above center, has continued to draw inspiration from his adolescent antics in the Upper Midwest. But his Minneapolis of the mind is no artistic and agricultural idyll. Just like that city's other punk rock bard, Paul Westerberg of the Replacements, Mr. Finn fondly describes a cold and agitated milieu. It's a place where Catholic kids go bad, skip catechism class to sniff OxyContin in caves on the Mississippi Riverbanks, and race drunk down frontage roads. Mr. Finn's singular ranting bark combines Bruce Springsteen's passion with a kind of slacker stream of consciousness. Like the Boss, he's drawn to the darkness at the edge of town. On his band's 2004 album, "Almost Killed Me" (French Kiss), he observed militiamen cooking up a batch of crystal meth, and growled: "There's a war going down in the Middle Western states/The Kevlar vests against the crystal flakes." On this year's "Separation Sunday" (French Kiss), he follows characters with code names like Charlemagne and Casanova as their lives blur from kissing and coke to Born Again reminiscence. In the blush of youth, Mr. Finn's twisted but optimistic hood-rat chick tells him: "I ain't gonna do anything sexual with you/I'm kinda saving myself for the scene." But as Catholics like Mr. Finn might say, we start out with original sin -- and there's lots more where that came from. title: Measuring the Blogosphere

Some 900,000 new blog postings are added every day -- a steady increase marked by extraordinary spikes in new postings after incidents like the London bombing. Rock/Pop Listings
description: THE HOLD STEADY Imagine the best bar band you've ever seen. Now imagine it fronted by a guy with punk attitude, a def poet's way with words and some ripping yarns to tell. That frontman is Craig Finn of the Hold Steady. Since moving to Brooklyn a few years back, Mr. Finn, above center, has continued to draw inspiration from his adolescent antics in the Upper Midwest. But his Minneapolis of the mind is no artistic and agricultural idyll. Just like that city's other punk rock bard, Paul Westerberg of the Replacements, Mr. Finn fondly describes a cold and agitated milieu. It's a place where Catholic kids go bad, skip catechism class to sniff OxyContin in caves on the Mississippi Riverbanks, and race drunk down frontage roads. Mr. Finn's singular ranting bark combines Bruce Springsteen's passion with a kind of slacker stream of consciousness. Like the Boss, he's drawn to the darkness at the edge of town. On his band's 2004 album, "Almost Killed Me" (French Kiss), he observed militiamen cooking up a batch of crystal meth, and growled: "There's a war going down in the Middle Western states/The Kevlar vests against the crystal flakes." On this year's "Separation Sunday" (French Kiss), he follows characters with code names like Charlemagne and Casanova as their lives blur from kissing and coke to Born Again reminiscence. In the blush of youth, Mr. Finn's twisted but optimistic hood-rat chick tells him: "I ain't gonna do anything sexual with you/I'm kinda saving myself for the scene." But as Catholics like Mr. Finn might say, we start out with original sin - and there's lots more where that came from. (Tonight and tomorrow night at 9, Bowery Ballroom, 6 Delancey Street, near the Bowery, Lower East Side; (212) 533-2111; $15.) LAURA SINAGRA

title: The Listings: Aug. 5 -- Aug. 11; STANYA KAHN AND HARRIET (HARRY) DODGE
description: Presented without fanfare on a small monitor as part of "Sugartown," an exhibition of 21 young and emerging artists from Los Angeles, the low-tech videos of Harriet (Harry) Dodge and Stanya Kahn might not seem like much at first. But stop and watch for a few minutes and you will be hooked by the funniest performance artist to appear in a New York art gallery since Alex Bag. In each of two 15-minute videos, Ms. Kahn, above, plays a hapless, badly dressed and coiffed character named Lois, who seems to be teetering on the brink of real insanity as a result of too much California-style hedonism and New Age philosophy. In "Let the Good Times Roll," she talks to an unseen cameraman named Dave (Ms. Dodge in reality) whom she met when they each mistakenly turned up at the same desolate and windy spot in the desert looking for an outdoor rock concert. Back indoors, she proceeds to tell Dave in extraordinarily vivid detail a long, convoluted and hilarious story about a night of kinky sex, drug consumption, abjection and mystical enlightenment she had shortly after she heard of the death of Kurt Cobain. She speaks with such goofy, deadpan earnestness and verbal inventiveness that you wish she would go on for another hour. Somebody, please, give these women money to make a feature-length movie! ("Sugartown" remains on view at Elizabeth Dee Gallery, 545 West 20th Street, Chelsea, (212)924-7545, through Aug. 6; and at Participant Inc., 95 Rivington Street, Lower East Side, (212)254-4334, through Aug. 7.) KEN JOHNSON

title: Jazz Listings
description: PIANOS IN THE PARK Brad Mehldau and Jason Moran, jazz pianists in their 30's, have both been upheld as auspices for the music's future. They are strikingly different musicians; Mr. Mehldau, above, has a fluid and expressively romantic style, while Mr. Moran favors jagged, delirious polyphony. But they have things in common, too: both emerged as sidemen in high-profile quartets; each came to prominence at the helm of a head-turning trio; and each has forayed fruitfully into nontraditional solo piano. They also have similarly broad-minded approaches to repertory. (Mr. Mehldau performs songs by Radiohead and Nick Drake; Mr. Moran has interpreted Afrika Bambaataa and Bjork.) Mr. Mehldau's most recent album, "Live in Tokyo" (Nonesuch), is a solo recital that blends judicious pop offerings with archaic songbook standards, employing a touch that runs from sprightly to somber; he'll play solo here, with his usual ambidextrous grace. At the opposite end of the stylistic spectrum is Mr. Moran's Bandwagon, which has lately been a quartet with electric guitar, but performs here in its original trio incarnation. "Same Mother" (Blue Note), the band's latest meteorite of an album, brings an avant-garde mutability to many shades of the blues. In performance, the group tends to walk a razor's edge; its rumbling crescendos should make for a rousing concert closer. The opener is a trio led by Eric Lewis, a percussive and probing young pianist who recently emerged from under the wing of Wynton Marsalis to pursue his own career. (Tonight at 7, Central Park SummerStage, Rumsey Playfield, midpark at 70th Street, (212) 360-2777, free.) NATE CHINEN

title: Arts, Briefly; NBC's Twice-Told Tales
description: Because one of the facts of American life is that the general population loves "Law & Order" reruns, NBC was No. 1 among total viewers in Wednesday's Nielsen estimates. Its schedule of repeats -- "Most Outrageous Live TV Moments," followed by a double feature of "Law & Order" -- delivered an average audience of 8.06 million for the night. But 18-to-49-year-olds preferred dancing to crime. They made Fox's 90-minute "So You Think You Can Dance" (6.82 million) the most-watched show in that age group, giving Fox an overall victory in the demographic. At 9 p.m., ABC's "Brat Camp" drew 7.6 million viewers and was the night's No. 2 show among adults 18 to 49. It was sandwiched between low-rated shows, a repeat of last week's "Brat Camp" (5.1 million) and a "Lost" rerun (4.76 million); ABC's numbers were good enough for a third-place finish on Wednesday. description: A federal appeals court has ruled that citizens of Puerto Rico do not have the right to vote in presidential elections. Gregorio Igartua-De La Rosa, the lawyer who filed the case, asserted that Puerto Ricans, who are American citizens, were denied their constitutional right to vote for president. The Quebec and federal governments had asked for the delay in order to resolve the waiting-time problem. The June decision was considered a watershed for the beleaguered Canadian health care system, possibly opening the way to more private medicine and insurance across the country. The case covered only Quebec, but was expected to lead to suits in other provinces. Clifford Krauss (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Americas: Canada: Plane Landed 'Long'
description: The Air France jet that crashed on Tuesday at the Toronto international airport touched down on the runway farther than usual for an aircraft of its type, the Transportation Safety Board said. Investigators said the Airbus-340 landed at 140 knots and skidded off the runway at 80 knots, or about 90 miles an hour. "We have indications that he did land perhaps a bit long on the runway," Ral Levasseur, the lead investigator, said at a news conference. He also said that all four of the aircraft's thrust reversers were operating when it landed before skidding, erupting into flames and breaking into three pieces. Investigators said the cockpit and flight data recorders, sent to France, had been successfully downloaded despite damage. The co-pilot, who landed the plane, has been interviewed by investigators but what he said has not been released. Investigators said there was no indication that the aircraft was hit by lightning. All 309 passengers and crew members survived the crash, with just 43 injured. Clifford Krauss (NYT)

title: Arts, Briefly; Will War Be Hell for FX?
description: Thursday nights are good nights for CBS, and this week the network was No. 1 in every hour of Nielsen's estimates, as it nearly always is. The weekly "Big Brother" elimination episode, which featured the purging of Kaysar Ridha, a graphic designer who was the house manipulator, drew 7.76 million viewers. That was followed by reruns of "CSI" (13.5 million) and "Without a Trace" (11.88 million), both of which easily won their time slots in total viewers and in the significant demographic groups. Facing the "CSI" repeat at 9 p.m., the most-watched program of the night, new episodes of ABC's "Hooking Up" (4.01 million) and NBC's "Law Firm" (4.01 million) were limp. FX's new series, "Over There," about the Iraq war, did not fare as well in its second week as it did in its first. Wednesday's episode brought in 2.6 million viewers. description: A federal judge has ruled that Dan Brown's blockbuster novel "The Da Vinci Code" did not copy two earlier works by Lewis Perdue, who has loudly accused Mr. Brown, right, of copyright infringement for much of the last two years. Judge George B. Daniels of Federal District Court in Manhattan wrote in the decision, dated Thursday and released yesterday, that "there is no substantial similarity" between "The Da Vinci Code" and Mr. Perdue's books "Daughter of God" and "The Da Vinci Legacy." Both of those books "involve the unprotectable idea of a mystery thriller set against a religious backdrop," Judge Daniels said, but ideas and general literary themes are not protected by copyright. "Daughter of God" is more action-packed, "with several gunfights and violent deaths," the judge said, while "The Da Vinci Code" is "an intellectual, complex treasure hunt" that features clues and puzzles more than "any physical adventure." A spokeswoman for Doubleday, Mr. Brown's publisher, said the company was pleased with the decision. A lawyer representing Mr. Perdue did not immediately return a phone call yesterday seeking comment on the decision. EDWARD WYATT

Mr. Garza said he was encouraged by assurances from the Mexican authorities this week that they were committed to "taking back the border from the kingpins and capos." The men, Jim Monaghan, Niall Connolly and Martin McCauley, suspected of being members of the Irish Republican Army, were arrested in Bogot in 2001. Ireland has no extradition treaty with Colombia, but British authorities said the men would be extradited if they crossed into Northern Ireland. title: Post-Popism
description: Earlier this year, some American moviegoers rebelled -- not against the mediocrity of studio offerings or against their fellow patrons' refusal to shut off their cellphones -- but against the incursion of blatant commercialism into the hallowed moviegoing experience. Imagine that! In recent years, theater chains have adopted the practice, long common in other countries, of warming up the crowd with advertisements. Not advertisements for other movies -- those previews have been a cherished ritual of cinema for decades -- but spots pushing cars, cosmetics and soft drinks. Like television ads, these movie-theater offerings take advantage of the captivity of the audience: they typically run after the posted starting time for a given feature, when everyone has settled in with their Twizzlers and their Pepsis. It was this erosion of the temporal boundary between entertainment and hucksterism that infuriated the public: we pay to see the movie, not to be subjected to invitations to spend more money on something else. And in the face of protest, some exhibitors relented -- a little. In New York, the Loews chain announced that, while it would stop short of pulling the ads, it would institute a measure of truth-in-advertising when listing show times, informing ticket buyers of exactly when the movie itself would start.

description: "PRETTY PERSUASION" could be a comedy, or it could be a horror film, depending on your perspective. Either way it's an engaging piece of work. EVAN RACHEL WOOD ("Thirteen") plays a chillingly calculated teenage temptress at an exclusive Beverly Hills high school who -- well, we never quite know what she's up to. But she ends up framing a teacher (Ron Livingston) for sexual molestation, corrupting a young Muslim girl and betraying her own best friend. Ms. Wood might be channeling Nicole Kidman as Suzanne Stone in "To Die For," or any of the Heathers in "Heathers" (paging Shannen Doherty). She's toxic. JAMES WOODS does a hilarious and terrifying turn as her racist, egocentric father. The movie made its debut to enthusiastic audiences at the Sundance Film Festival in January, and opens in limited release on Friday.

In her view, travel was a privilege not to be squandered by booking stingily or mechanically. And to my lasting gratitude, she believed firmly in taking along the children.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   NAGIN, LEON P.
description: NAGIN--Leon P. Of Singer Island, FL, formerly of Neponsit, NY. Died peacefully at home in Manhasset August 6th, one week short of his 92nd birthday. Husband of Sylvia, father of Laurance (Francine), Joshua (Ronna), Kenneth (Laurie) and Suzy (Evan Klass). Grandfather of Matthew, Jason, Jonathan, Adam, Alexis Damonte (Jimmy), Meredith, Jessica, Perry, and Elliott, Nathan and Sarah Klass. Real estate executive since 1933 of Superior Management, was responsible for the first three FHA building rehabilitations in New York City. Served from 1942-46, First Lieutenant Signal Corps assigned to Army Security Agency in Arlington Hall Station, Virginia. Generous benefactor to many charities, enormously proud of the accomplishments of his children and grandchildren. Turned the sands of Rockaway beach into freezers full of vegetables. title: The Devil Is Still In
description: When Savanna Samson, above, watched the original "Devil in Miss Jones," she "fast forwarded a lot," she said. "They talk a lot. I thought: 'This is so dark. And there's so much hair everywhere."' Paul Thomas, who directed Ms. Samson in the remake of "Miss Jones," the 1973 hit that was part of pornography's first venture into the mainstream, agreed that the aesthetics of such films had changed over the last 30 years, and not entirely for the better. "If the original came out today, I think the sex would have been found lacking," said Mr. Thomas. (He is not Paul Thomas Anderson, director of the pornography-theme feature "Boogie Nights"). "Most porno put out today is simply a collection of the raunchiest, most extreme sex scenes possible, with no pretense of a story." Now Vivid Entertainment is betting that a story -- along with a famous title, a contemporary dosage of sex scenes and the presence of the pornography superstar Jenna Jameson as the Devil -- will sell DVD's of the first remake of "The Devil in Miss Jones," which it will release on Sept. 21. (Ms. Samson plays the new Miss Jones.) At $250,000, the production was Vivid's most expensive yet; marketing plans call for simultaneous release in the United States and Europe (in five languages) and a billboard in Times Square. Steven Hirsch, the company's co-chairman, said he expected to sell more than 100,000 copies of the new version domestically in the first year, or 10 times more than the average Vivid film. "It's a name that everybody knows," Mr. Hirsch said. "It's a compelling story. The story is updated, but it still pays homage to the original."

By now, the audience has spent enough time with Don (played by Bill Murray) to know that he is unattached by definition. If his name weren't enough of a giveaway, there is the fact that, in the movie's first scenes, his television is tuned to Alexander Korda's "Private Life of Don Juan," whose mythic protagonist is invoked by Don's latest lover (Julie Delpy) on her way out the door. title: DEALS & DISCOUNTS
description: SKIING ALREADY? -- Many skiers have already jumped on the Anywhere, Anytime Ski Pass that went on sale last month (and are offered each year) from Ski New Hampshire, an association of 38 alpine and cross-country resorts. The package of vouchers is good for lift tickets discounted 20 to 60 percent and valid any day -- including holidays and weekends. They can be shared by family, friends or anyone. A $400 pass includes 20 vouchers for lift tickets (at $20 each) for your choice of at least two of the 10 small-mountain ski areas. The $800 pass allows you to mix at least three small- or large-mountain areas (at $40 each ticket for large mountains). Some areas, like Bretton Woods and Wildcat, have sold out on this offer. For more details, call (800) 887-5464 or see www.skinh.com.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CARLSON, ARLEEN MARTIN
description: CARLSON -- Arleen Martin. March 10, 1912 - August 4, 2005. Long-time Minnesota philanthropist and Carlson Companies co-founder Arleen Martin Carlson died August 4 at her home in Minneapolis. She was 93. Arleen was preceded in death by her husband, Curtis L. Carlson. Together, in 1938 on a borrowed $55, they founded the Gold Bond Stamp Company which was the precursor of global travel, hospitality and marketing giant Carlson Companies. Carlson brands today include Radisson, Regent, T.G.I. Friday's, Carlson Wagonlit Travel, Carlson Marketing Group and others. Arleen Martin was born March 10, 1912, in Aberdeen, South Dakota, the only child of Charles and Nellie Martin, who later moved to Minneapolis. There, Arleen attended the University of Minnesota where she met Curtis Carlson. The two were married in 1938. A founding Carlson board member and civic leader, Arleen embodied the Carlson family spirit of faith, persistence, hard work and inclusiveness. In 1999, she donated $10 million to the University of Minnesota, continuing a long family tradition of giving to the institution. To date the family's gifts to the school exceed $46 million, and the University's Curtis L. Carlson School of Management is named in their honor. Continuing a long tradition of support for United Way, in 2000 Arleen made a personal gift of $1 million to the United Way's Century Legacy program. Survivors include two daughters: Carlson Foundation President Barbara Carlson Gage and husband Edwin "Skip" Gage, Carlson Companies Chair and CEO Marilyn Carlson Nelson and husband Dr. Glen Nelson; seven grandchildren: Christine Gage, Geoffrey Gage and wife Kelly, Richard Gage and wife Britt, Scott Gage and wife Gina, Curtis Nelson and wife Margie, Diana Nelson and husband John Atwater, Wendy Nelson and partner Daisy Mitchell; 14 great-grandchildren and three step-greatgrandchildren; brother-in-law Warren Carlson; sister-in-law Elaine Carlson, and numerous nieces and nephews. Husband Curt and granddaughter Juliet Nelson preceded Arleen in death. Funeral services will be held at 10 A.M., Wednesday, August 10, at Hennepin Avenue United Methodist Church in Minneapolis. Contributions in lieu of flowers may be made to the church, the Carlson School of Management at the University of Minnesota, or the World Childhood Foundation (www.childhood-usa.org), of which Arleen was a founding sponsor.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KIMBALL, BEATRIZ GABALDON
description: KIMBALL--Beatriz Gabaldon. Many will mourn the passing of Beatriz Gabaldon Kimball who died on July 29, 2005, at the age of 87. She died peacefully within 30 hours of suffering a massive stroke from which she did not regain consciousness. Beatriz was a resident of Cambridge, MA., where she had gone to live to be near her beloved niece, Julia Gabaldon. She was born in Clifton, Arizona, February 22, 1918, and spent her years before college in southeastern Arizona. She graduated from the University of California at Berkeley in l940, which served to launch her career as an international civil servant that took her to many parts of the world, beginning with 5 years in Paris for the newly formed United Nations Education, Scientific, and Cultural Organization (UNESCO). In the early 1950's she continued to expand her career with the United Nations Development Program (UNDP) in New York City. During the next 20 years, she was posted to assignments in Bolivia, Peru, Lebanon and the Middle East, Indonesia, Cyprus, and the Dominican Republic. She was married to Richard Kimball of Massachusetts during her stay in Bolivia and divorced a few years later. Her final U.N. post was that of Deputy Resident Representative to the Dominican Republic. She retired in l978 and spent the next 24 years as a happy resident of Meredith, New Hampshire. Beatriz Kimball was a beautiful, brave, and generous woman who could charm the proverbial birds from the trees. She helped many people, not only financially, but with her sunny, loving hospitality, and her understanding. She loved life, music (particularly opera) and her many friends from all over the world. She is survived by her brother, Robert Gabaldon, of Great Falls, VA., and his family, and her sister-in-law, Henrietta Gabaldon, of Pasadena, CA.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FRANCISCUS, SISTER MARY
description: FRANCISCUS--Sister Mary. The staff of Opportunities for a Better Tomorrow (OBT) deeply mourns the loss of Sister Mary Franciscus, our beloved founder, executive director and friend. Sister Mary was professed as a Sister of Mercy in 1958 and taught at various schools in Brooklyn. From 1970-1983 she was the principal of St. Agatha's School in Sunset Park and an active member of Community Board 7. In 1983 she founded OBT in a storefront on 53rd Street and 4th Avenue and turned it into one of the finest job-training programs for at-risk youth in the country, with professional sites in Sunset Park and Williamsburg. Sister Mary was a brilliant, courageous woman with a unique personality that endeared her to people from all walks of life. Government and private agencies honored her personally, yet she always remained humble and compassionate. Sister taught us that anything is possible, loved discussing politics, analyzing the stock market, eating peanut butter and jelly sandwiches, telling us "not to worry" when we came to her with a problem and, most of all, rooting and praying for her adored New York Yankees. She faced her final illness with the same fearlessness and dignity she displayed throughout her life. We will never forget this wonderful woman who always comforted us with her presence. Sister Mary will remain in our hearts forever and we will carry on her work. The staff of OBT extends their deepest condolences to her family and loved ones.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ROEMER, RUTH J. (NEE ROSENBAUM)
description: ROEMER -- Ruth J. (nee Rosenbaum). On August 1, 2005 after a short illness, at age 89. After receiving her law degree from Cornell in 1939, she represented the United Electrical Workers (UE) in Washington during the 1940s, later moving into the field of health law, and over the past 50 years did important work on hospital patients' rights and admissions laws, water fluoridation, abortion and reproductive rights legislation, and health manpower law. She initiated what later became the international Framework Convention on Tobacco Control, adopted by the WHO in 2003, served as president of the APHA and was professor emerita at the School of Public Health at UCLA. These accomplishments comprised but a small part of the person she was: a loving mother and grandmother, Ruth also mentored scores of students and friends, often redirecting their careers. Her dinner parties, co-hosted for many years with her husband and collaborator Milton, who died in 2001, were legendary, and continued until her death. She leaves a son, John, of New York City, a daughter, Beth, of Berkeley, a daughter-inlaw Natasha, six grandchildren, two great grandchildren, a sister Hilda Kahne, and a large extended family. Contributions in her memory may be made to the Ruth Roemer Scholarship Fund at the UCLA School of Public Health, Box 951772, Los Angeles, CA. 90095.

title: Paperback Row
description: SNOW, by Orhan Pamuk. Translated by Maureen Freely. (Vintage International, $14.95.) This seventh novel by the acclaimed Turkish writer is an eerily prescient tour of his country's divided soul. Ka, a poet, has been in exile for 12 years but returns to Istanbul for his mother's funeral. Posing as a journalist, Ka also makes his way to Kars, a decaying city, to investigate a wave of suicides among schoolgirls forbidden to wear their headscarves. Trapped by a snowstorm, Ka witnesses clashes between Kurdish separatists, political Islamists and secular government officials. The Book Review named "Snow" one of the 10 best books of 2004; our reviewer, Margaret Atwood, called it "an engrossing feat of tale-spinning" and "essential reading for our times."

title: Dark Debut
description: In the army of documentary filmmakers who scour the globe's hot zones for material, there is no less likely a recruit than the first-time director Pippa Scott: 70, not a hair out of place on her perfectly coiffed head, financially secure after a long career as an actress and producer. About 10 years ago, Ms. Scott -- who at 21 played one of the kidnapped girls John Wayne went looking for in "The Searchers," and would later be a founder of Lorimar Productions, which gave us "Dallas" and "Falcon Crest" -- decided that pioneering prime-time soap opera wasn't enough of a legacy. She began producing films about the human cost of war, including a recent "Frontline" documentary about the fugitive Serbian war-crimes suspect Radovan Karadzic. Now she has become perhaps the oldest debut director in her field with an adaptation of Adam Hochschild's book "King Leopold's Ghost." Screened recently at the TriBeCa Film Center and headed for the festival circuit in search of a distributor, the film is a two-hour journey into the real-life heart of darkness that was the Congo Free State, the huge personal fief that King Leopold II of Belgium carved out of Africa in the at the end of the 19th century.

title: Shuttle Makes Preparations For Risky Return to Earth
description: HOUSTON , Aug. 6 - The space shuttle Discovery separated from the International Space Station at 3:24 a.m. Eastern time on Saturday and conducted a victory lap around the station -- a fly-around that allowed Discovery's crew to photograph the orbiting outpost -- as the crew made final preparations to return to Earth on Monday. Even accepting for the sake of argument that the mission is, as the NASA administrator, Michael Griffin, put it on Friday, "magnificent," the shuttle returns to a realm of enormous uncertainty. NASA cannot yet say when shuttles will fly again, or how many missions can be flown before the 2010 retirement date that the Bush administration has set for the shuttle. Designs for follow-on vehicles are taking shape, but are still vague -- and the president's plan to use those new craft for missions to return to the moon and go beyond are even more so.

title: Angels Out East

Curtis Sliwa, the group's founder, has kept his organization busy opening chapters in cities and towns all over the country, where all kinds of people -- state representatives, mayors, city council members, even the governor of Hawaii -- have welcomed them with open arms, either forgetting or not caring about the Angels' reputation as vigilante goofballs.

title: These Little Toe Shoes Are Longing to Stray
description: ONCE upon a time in the 1960's, when dance jobs were scarce, Michael Smuin joined the circus. With seals on one side and lions on the other, he had to work hard to keep audiences watching him in the middle. Which may help explain why he is as much a showman as a choreographer. Speaking by telephone from Italy, where his San Francisco-based Smuin Ballet was on tour last month, he said he had learned from the three rings and his gigs in nightclubs and musicals that "the audience doesn't have much patience." So Mr. Smuin, a former dancer with American Ballet Theater and the San Francisco Ballet (where he was also a co-director), has never been afraid of using ballet to entertain.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ABELSON, PROFESSOR ROBERT P.
description: ABELSON--Professor Robert P., 76, died on July 13 of Parkinson's Disease. He was Eugene Higgins Professor of Psychology and Professor of Political Science at Yale University where he taught for 42 years. Professor Abelson received degrees from MIT and a Ph.D. from Princeton University in 1953. He was a Fellow of the American Statistical Assoc., American Academy of Arts and Sciences, the American Psychological Assoc., and a William James Fellow of the American Psychological Society. His professional writings included books and articles on social psychology, statistics, political science, and cognitive science. During his career, he received distinguished lifetime scientific contribution awards from the American Psychological Assoc., the Society for Experimental Social Psychology, and the International Assoc. of Political Psychology. He is survived by his wife of 50 years Willa Dinwoodie Abelson of Hamden, CT, his sons William Miles of Seattle, WA, John Robert, daughter-in-law Kendall Rafter and grandson Benjamin Abelson-Rafter of Urbana, IL. A memorial service will be held on Saturday, September 24 at 1 PM at the Unitarian Society of New Haven, 700 Hartford Tpk, Hamden, CT. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Unitarian Society of New Haven or the American Parkinson's Disease Assoc., 1250 Hylan Boulevard, Ste 4B, Staten Island, NY 10305.

title: Look, Ma, Two Hands (but No Camera)
description: The images in Micah Ganske's award-winning (more on that later) series of digital photographs, "Look Into My Eyes," have one common, improbable feature: Mr. Ganske's hands in the foreground, wielding not a camera but a coffee pot, a cigarette lighter or a video game. Some, like the final photo below, have the added how-did-he-do-that twist of Mr. Ganske's reflection in a window or mirror, still sans camera. By borrowing a "certain visual trope" from video games, Mr. Ganske said, he depicts everyday activities like shaving as they might be virtually experienced: as if we lived our real lives on small hand-held screens. How he does it is obvious if you know the award he won: an Adobe Design Achievement Award, for which the use of Adobe's Photoshop software is smiled upon, to say the least. But for Mr. Ganske, 25, who received a master's degree in painting from the Yale School of Art and bases his paintings on photo-collages, computer manipulation was just the last step in a long process of photographic gymnastics. Here are Mr. Ganske's descriptions of how he took the five images that went into this seemingly impossible photograph. ANDREW ADAM NEWMAN DIRECTIONS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MUDGE, DALE SPERRY
description: MUDGE--Dale Sperry, 1948-2005. Dale Sperry Mudge died July 13, 2005, in Boston, after a three-and-a-half year battle with colon cancer. Born in Danbury, Connecticut, in 1948, Dale is the daughter of the late Barbara Taylor Sperry and the late William Sperry. She graduated from Miss Hall's School, Pittsfield, Massachusetts, and attended the English Speaking Union on scholarship the next year. During the early years of her marriage, Dale and her husband, Taylor, moved from Boston to a farm in Lincolnville, Maine, where they restored the 19th century farmhouse, barn, and outbuildings and raised livestock. In 1983 the family moved to Chestnut Street in Camden. Following the birth and rearing of her four children, Dale resumed her formal education, earning a B.A. with honors in anthropology from the University of Maine in 1993. Dale's energetic zest for life, curiosity, and ability to connect with people of every stripe was legendary. Her work as an anthropologist, her love of of textiles, and her readiness for adventure fostered her world-wide travels. Dale was a memorable catalyst, and her life story speaks to her ability to attract people and make things happen. Dale's generosity and passion created opportunities for the countless people people that crossed her path. Professionally Dale independently produced the documentary for the MBPN series True North titled Acadian Yarns. Broadcast in 1999, the work examined a women's cooperative in the St. John valley in northern Maine. In 2002, after three years of research in New Mexico, Dale co-wrote with C. Stewart Dody and Herbert Benally the book Photographing Navajos. The publication featured original photographs taken on the Navajo Reservation in the early 1950's by John Collier Jr, and gave historical interviews with the original subjects and their descendants. This publication culminated in a traveling exhibition titled Photographing Navajos: On The Reservation, which pre viewed at the Albuquerque Museum in 2001-2002. Dale also wrote a chapter called Maine Yarns: Wool Textiles among Acadian Women in the Saint John River Valley that was published in 2005 in the edition Of Place and Gender: Women in Maine History. Recently, Dale initiated a project for the Carnegie Museum of Natural History in Pittsburgh to create a permanent exhibition showing the original photographs of the 1938 Belcher Islands Expedition with the Hudson Bay area and the local Inuit population as they currently exist today. A memorial in her name has been established at the Carnegie Museum of Natural History in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania. Perhaps the greatest testament to Dale lies in the facing of her own illness. Dale charged full steam ahead, anxious to experiment with the most aggressive treatment options available, and relishing each day with her signature optimism, courage and style. She exceeded every expectation of her medical team, and along the way garnered the love and awe of a vast network of devoted friends that includes the many Midcoast Maine families who shared child-raising years with the Mudges, members of the Navajo nation, knitters from a rural cooperative in the St. John Valley, anthropological colleagues, members of her extended family, childhood friends, and recent acquaintances. Dale is survived by her husband of 35 years, Taylor Mudge, and her four children: Webster of New York City; Matthew of Portland, Oregon; Samuel of Seattle, Washington; and Sarah of New York City. A service in her memory will be held on September 10th at 1 o'clock at the the Rockport, Maine Opera House. Contributions in her name may be made to the Tanglewood 4-H Learning Center in Lincolnville, Maine or to the Dale Mudge Fund, Carnegie Musuem of Natural History, Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania.

title: Clearing the Bar
description: My neighborhood bar flouts the city's smoking ban, making me, a nonsmoker, want to avoid the place. But I love this bar, and there aren't many others close by with low prices and a good jukebox. I've thought about making an anonymous complaint to the city, but I don't want to burden a local business with a heavy fine. Should I stop whining and just take my business elsewhere? Kathryn Klencheski, Brooklyn You should neither abandon the bar nor call the cops, at least not immediately. Instead, say something to the bartender -- calmly, tactfully, so you don't get yourself banned. You can pick up the phone later if that conversation proves ineffective. It is not your obligation to police the city's smoking ban, but you have the right to complain if the place ignores a law intended to safeguard its customers and employees.

title: Corrections
description: A review of the book "Crossworld," by Marc Romano, on July 10 misstated some crucial details of an anecdote about crossword puzzle experts based on an account presented in the book. It was David A. Rosen, not Stanley Newman, who beat Peter Gordon, a well-known puzzle maker, by finishing a puzzle, constructed by Gordon, faster than Gordon himself could finish it. Gordon had created the puzzle to be used in a crossword tournament, not in a personal challenge; and the "race" to finish arose unintentionally during normal testing and checking of puzzles for the tournament. At the testing and checking for a subsequent tournament, Gordon had memorized his own puzzle; this time, he beat Rosen.

title: A Hero in Every Aisle Seat
description: Pittsburgh - ONE survivor of the Air France crash in Toronto on Tuesday described the "panic" of his fellow passengers. Yet these people had just evacuated a burning plane in about two minutes. While they had had critical help from the plane's crew members, those trained professionals were busy assisting people with limited mobility, not providing psychotherapy. Thus what the passenger observed was clearly not "panic" in the sense of an unthinking crowd acting irrationally and abandoning the norms of civilized behavior. Indeed, it was the exact opposite.

title: Is There Room for a Gentleman in a Debate on Judge Roberts?

title: 'The First Emancipator'
description: There is only one known portrait of Robert Carter III. He posed for it in 1749 or 1750 in Thomas Hudson's London studio, and two hundred fifty years later, it is easy enough to imagine what the painter was thinking. Probably, Carter was just another colonial gentleman, raw but wealthy, and the portraitist knew his type, and knew their vanities. And so Carter was draped in a billowing gold suit and silver cape, brown hair neatly tied back and powdered gray, smirking, a mask dangling from the tapered fingers of his left hand. The suit is a century out of date, as if Carter were a courtier to Charles I, or masquerading as one. He looks like he is on his way to a ball, to a lifetime of balls, and has stopped just for a moment before donning the mask.

title: When a Heart Device Short-Circuits

But every so often one of these implanted devices fails to work when it is desperately needed. The story of how the Guidant Corporation, the nation's second-biggest maker of cardiac devices, handled a flawed defibrillator provides a troubling glimpse into the murky world of medical device regulation.

title: The Xbox Auteurs
description: Like many young hipsters in Austin, Tex., Michael Burns wanted to make it big in some creative field -- perhaps writing comedy scripts in Hollywood. Instead, he wound up in a dead-end job, managing a call center. To kill time, he made friends with a group of equally clever and bored young men at the company where he worked, and they'd sit around talking about their shared passion: video games. Their favorite title was Halo, a best-selling Xbox game in which players control armor-clad soldiers as they wander through gorgeous coastal forests and grim military bunkers and fight an army of lizardlike aliens. Burns and his gang especially loved the "team versus team" mode, which is like a digital version of paint ball: instead of fighting aliens, players hook their Xboxes to the Internet, then log on together in a single game, at which point they assemble into two teams -- red-armored soldiers versus blue-armored ones. Instead of shooting aliens, they try to slaughter one another, using grenades, machine guns and death rays. On evenings and weekends, Burns and his friends would cluster around their TV's until the wee hours of the morning, gleefully blowing one another to pieces.

Although it does little to alter the standard view of the artist's later output, dismissed by critics as mostly shallow and lightweight, it does provide an elegant, thoughtful coda to "Matisse: The Fabric of Dreams -- His Art and His Textiles," on exhibit at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.
