title: Editors' Choice
Paid Notice: Deaths   LAVINE, LEROY S.
description: LAVINE--Leroy S. A practicing orthopedic surgeon and researcher in NY for more than 30 years, died on July 25 in Chapel Hill, NC. He was 86. Born in Jersey City, NJ, he received his undergraduate and medical degrees from NYU. He was a Captain in the US Army in WW II. Dr. Lavine was Chief of Orthopedic Surgery at LIJ Hillside Medical Center (1956-81), Professor and Head of Orthopedic Surgery at SUNY Downstate Medical Center (1964-81), Associate Director of the Biophysics Research Lab at NYU (l967-81). After retiring as a surgeon, Dr. Lavine began a second career in Boston in 1983 that lasted nearly 20 years. He was Professor at the MGH Institute of Health Professions, Chief of Orthopedic Rehabilitation at Spaulding Hospital and Lecturer at Harvard Medical School. Dr. Lavine was active in many professional organizations. He was Chairman of the Orthopedic section of the NY Academy of Medicine, President of the Bioelectric Repair and Growth Society, advisor to the NIH, member of the Orthopedic Devices Panel of the FDA and Examiner for the American Board of Orthopedic Surgery. He was a member of Sigma Xi, the Cosmos Club, the American Orthopedic Association and a Fellow of the American Association for the Advancement of Science. A proponent of the arts, Dr. Lavine was a member of the MIT Council for the Arts and on the Advisory Board of MIT's List Visual Arts Center. Dr. Lavine's wit and humor won him many friendships. He kept his wry sense of humor to the end. He is survived by his wife of 59 years, the former Dorothy Kopp, his children, Shaughan of Tucson and Nancy Warwick of Chapel Hill, and his three grandchildren, Caila, Ryan and Zachary.

title: Nonfiction Chronicle
description: ALEC GUINNESS: The Authorised Biography. By Piers Paul Read. (Simon & Schuster, $35.) This ploddingly thorough account of Alec Guinness's professional life traces his enigmatic career to multiple, often competing ambitions. Regarded as one of the greatest stage actors of the 20th century, Sir Alec (1914-2000) spent prime years playing "demeaning if lucrative bit parts" in Hollywood, and is popularly best remembered as Obi-Wan Kenobi in "Star Wars." When he did appear in West End theater, critics were not always sympathetic: his 1951 Hamlet was a "monumental" failure; his 1966 Macbeth was "totally colorless." Still, he remained the gentleman thespian whose sheer presence could elevate the most meager script.

title: El Tovar in Grand Canyon, Ariz.
description: THE BASICS -- As we approached the Holiday Inn Express, about six miles south of the Grand Canyon, in early June, we decided to make one final phone call to El Tovar. Of the half-dozen lodges on the rim of the Canyon, El Tovar is the most famous. But despite several attempts, we hadn't been able to get a reservation. (Rooms are booked more than a year in advance.) We crossed our fingers while an employee -- who admitted she was new -- kept us on the phone interminably. Eventually, she came up with a room, with two queen beds, for the affordable price of $155. We would have paid that much for a pup tent, given the location. And El Tovar is hardly a tent. Built in 1905 to accommodate tourists arriving by railroad, it reopened in April for its 100th anniversary, after an extensive renovation.

title: Supreme Modesty
description: Jeffrey Rosen (July 24) misses the point when he says the Supreme Court confirmation battle is "largely symbolic." If Roe is overturned -- or eviscerated -- by the new court, we will return to the days of local control of women's health. That's fine if you're a wealthy woman in an antichoice state, who can fly to New York or Los Angeles or Chicago for an abortion. If you're not, you face the nonchoice of a dangerous, illegal procedure or a forced pregnancy. Simply put, abortion would be criminalized, except for the privileged, educated and mobile.

By now, everyone knows that Jamie Foxx (right) gave the performance of the year in Taylor Hackford's film portrait of Ray Charles, who died last year. Mr. Foxx won the best-actor Oscar for his portrayal of Charles, from his beginnings as a small-time nightclub piano player to his glory days as a world-famous performer, with hits like "I Got a Woman," "Hit the Road, Jack" and "Georgia on My Mind." title: Inside the List
description: McCARTHY HEARING: "I sent one boy to the gas chamber at Huntsville." That's the plain-spoken first sentence of Cormac McCarthy's new novel, "No Country for Old Men." But if the postings on McCarthy-obsessed Web sites are any indication, not all his fans are happy with it. "No Country for Old Men" is set in Texas, and the bummer about McCarthy's opening line is that, as Web critics have pointed out -- and as the director of the Texas Prison Museum, Jim Willett, confirms -- Texas has never executed anyone in a gas chamber. "That's a hell of an error," one fan wrote. "I mean, the very first sentence of the book." (When asked about the line, McCarthy said through his publicist at Knopf, "I put it in there to see if readers were on their toes.") McCarthy, whose propulsive novel enters the hardcover fiction list this week at No. 8, is no stranger to this page. While none of his first five novels sold more than 3,000 copies in hardcover, his sixth, "All the Pretty Horses" (1992), was his breakthrough -- it stayed on the hardcover list for more than five months. The next two books in his Border Trilogy -- "The Crossing" (1994) and "Cities of the Plain" (1998) -- made the list for 12 and 7 weeks, respectively. Critics seem to agree that if "No Country for Old Men" probably isn't McCarthy's best book, it's his most accessible. As one fan wrote on cormacmccarthy.com, "It's obvious to me that McCarthy has an account at Blockbuster, he's seen 'Pulp Fiction,' 'One False Move,' 'Natural Born Killers.' " Another wrote, "I think the book deserves the Pulitzer Prize."

title: It Was a Dark and Stormy Galaxy
description: THE future, as a literary device, was invented in the 19th century. Works of fiction purporting to describe the shape of things to come proliferated in the late 1800's, more or less keeping pace with the advance of evolutionary science. Many of these works took the form of utopias or dystopias -- anti-utopias, often depicted ironically. Earlier, such stories would have been set in obscure corners of the world, like the imaginary land where Lemuel Gulliver encountered the Lilliputians. But with most of the real world already mapped by European explorers, the future inevitably became the location of choice for writers who wanted to illustrate alternative ways of organizing society.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WALLACE, HENRY BROWNE, H.B.
description: WALLACE--Henry Browne, H.B., as he preferred to be known, was born September 18th, 1915 in Des Moines, IA. He was the son of Ilo Browne Wallace and Henry Agard Wallace, the latter a former Secretary of Agriculture and Vice President of the United States. H.B. received a BS from Iowa State College in 1938 where he studied genetics. In the manner of many extraordinary Americans, H.B. carried on his family's tradition of philanthropy, scientific research and community service. His revolutionary breakthroughs in the science of poultry breeding have greatly boosted the international effort to feed the earth's burgeoning human population. Putting together a staff of geneticists, immunologists, nutritionists and management specialists, he directed their pursuit of both basic and applied research. Upon retiring to Scottsdale, AZ in 1985, H.B. developed a passion for arid lands and in particular the Sonoran Desert. Combined with his support of the McDowell Sonoran Land Trust and the Desert Foothills Land Trust, he placed a conservation easement on 80 acres of his undeveloped property to ensure its lasting protection. He has created a unique botanical center housing one of the world's largest non-commercial collection of cacti and succulents. The Wallace Desert Gardens has served as a free research facility for scientists, ecologists, educators and students from universities, non-profit organizations and agencies. H.B.'s passion for scientific research was undiminished from his college days. He has granted millions of dollars to numerous universities and foundations for research in the fields of mercury-related illnesses, cancer, heart disease and amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS). H.B. was a strong believer that the future of America rested with its young people. His interest in the youth of America was evidenced in generous support of the Belin-Blank International Center for Gifted Education and Talent Development, an innovative program which uses sophisticated assessment tools and technology to provide scholarships and coursework. He initiated the Rural Schools Program for Gifted Students at the Belin-Blank Center. He felt children from rural schools should have the opportunity to have their talents developed without limits because of school size and geography. Gifted students from rural areas should be provided with scholarships to attend Belin-Blank Center. His support led to the formation of the H.B. Wallace Research Symposium, this Symposium has been internationally acclaimed as the research conference in gifted education. He gave support to many other national and international schools, including Russia and the Cayman Islands. Henry had been honored to receive a Doctorate of Science from Cumberland College in Williamsburg, KY. He was also in the Veterans Hall of Fame and received the ALS Campaign Medal for "service before self" in the fight against Lou Gehrig's disease. Henry leaves his wife, Jocelyn, his sister, Jean Wallace Douglas, his children, Henry (wife Cindy and children Jenelle and Kristin), Joan Myers (husband Bernard Lopez and children Raymond Buetens and Julian Buetens), Linda Wallace Gray (husband John), Diane (husband Jeff Yusem and daughter Heather), and his stepchildren, Juliet, Eric, Thomas, Clarice, Marshall, Angus and Alex (wife Robin) Gilchrist. Henry was a visionary, an eccentric, irascible and gentle man who was able to "chop" immediately an unworkable plan. He was able to adhere like the strongest glue to an idea whose time had not yet been recognized by the rest of us. Reclusive but enjoying individuals, agnostic but honoring goodness, he always maintained his integrity of heart, brain and soul. Memorial donations may be made to the Wallace Desert Gardens.

title: The Humblest of Victims

By studying the differences between male and female brains, we can generate significant insights into the mystery of autism.

title: Arts, Briefly; Springsteen and Hendrix
description: What is the impact of the music of Bruce Springsteen, below, on Roman Catholicism? On the Vietnam veterans' movement? What are his storytelling techniques? Questions like these will be explored in a three-day academic symposium beginning on Sept. 9 at Monmouth University in West Long Branch, N.J., The Associated Press reported. The organizer, Mark Bernhard, a Pennsylvania State University conference planner and a self-described Springsteen nut, said he expected the event to be attended by more than 270 educators, music historians and Springsteen fans. After days of rain, mud and music, on Monday, Aug. 18, 1969, the 30,000 fans remaining from the 400,000 who had swarmed to Bethel, N.Y., heard Jimi Hendrix, backed by the Gypsy Sun and Rainbows Band, close the Woodstock Festival. Now that historic moment in rock, never available commercially in its entirety, according to Billboard, is to be issued on a double-disc DVD. The set, "Jimi Hendrix Live at Woodstock," is to be released by Universal Music and Experience Hendrix on Sept. 12 in Britain and Sept. 13 in the United States. The DVD includes a documentary, "The Road to Woodstock"; a contemporary news conference; and other material. LAWRENCE VAN GELDER

title: The State of the Estate Tax
description: Senate Republican leaders declared their monthlong summer break without making time to vote on repeal of the estate tax. The majority leader, Bill Frist, knew that if he brought the measure to a vote, it would be defeated. A critical mass of senators has apparently realized, to their credit, that abolishing the estate tax would be unforgivably reckless, in large part because it would cost an estimated $745 billion during the first 10 years of repeal -- revenue that would have to be made up by borrowing, slashing government services or raising taxes elsewhere. And who would benefit? At most, the richest 2 percent of American families.

title: Arts, Briefly; Bookstore Rides Again
description: No, it's not the end of the trail for Booked Up, Larry McMurtry's storied 17-year-old antiquarian bookstore in Archer City, Tex. On Feb. 1, Mr. McMurtry, the author of "Lonesome Dove" and other best sellers about the West, announced on the company's Web site that after 35 years of trading in old books, he and Marcia Carter, his partner, planned to close the store -- with its 200,000 volumes in four buildings -- on Dec. 31, "for a term" while he took a sabbatical to travel. But now, he says, staff cuts and improved business have changed his mind, The Associated Press reported. "I think it will be able to stay solvent and stay open," Mr. McMurtry said. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CARLSON, ARLEEN MARTIN
description: CARLSON -- Arleen Martin. March 10, 1912 - August 4, 2005. Long-time Minnesota philanthropist and Carlson Companies co-founder Arleen Martin Carlson died August 4 at her home in Minneapolis. She was 93. Arleen was preceded in death by her husband, Curtis L. Carlson. Together, in 1938 on a borrowed $55, they founded the Gold Bond Stamp Company which was the precursor of global travel, hospitality and marketing giant Carlson Companies. Carlson brands today include Radisson, Regent, T.G.I. Friday's, Carlson Wagonlit Travel, Carlson Marketing Group and others. Arleen Martin was born March 10, 1912, in Aberdeen, South Dakota, the only child of Charles and Nellie Martin, who later moved to Minneapolis. There, Arleen attended the University of Minnesota where she met Curtis Carlson. The two were married in 1938. A founding Carlson board member and civic leader, Arleen embodied the Carlson family spirit of faith, persistence, hard work and inclusiveness. In 1999, she donated $10 million to the University of Minnesota, continuing a long family tradition of giving to the institution. To date the family's gifts to the school exceed $46 million, and the University's Curtis L. Carlson School of Management is named in their honor. Continuing a long tradition of support for United Way, in 2000 Arleen made a personal gift of $1 million to the United Way's Century Legacy program. Survivors include two daughters: Carlson Foundation President Barbara Carlson Gage and husband Edwin "Skip" Gage, Carlson Companies Chair and CEO Marilyn Carlson Nelson and husband Dr. Glen Nelson; seven grandchildren: Christine Gage, Geoffrey Gage and wife Kelly, Richard Gage and wife Britt, Scott Gage and wife Gina, Curtis Nelson and wife Margie, Diana Nelson and husband John Atwater, Wendy Nelson and partner Daisy Mitchell; 14 great-grandchildren and three step-greatgrandchildren; brother-in-law Warren Carlson; sister-in-law Elaine Carlson, and numerous nieces and nephews. Husband Curt and granddaughter Juliet Nelson preceded Arleen in death. Funeral services will be held at 10 A.M., Wednesday, August 10, at Hennepin Avenue United Methodist Church in Minneapolis. Contributions in lieu of flowers may be made to the church, the Carlson School of Management at the University of Minnesota, or the World Childhood Foundation (www.childhood-usa.org), of which Arleen was a founding sponsor.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FONER, LIZA
description: FONER--Liza. Died July 11, 2005, two days before her 96th birthday. A woman of independent spirit, artistic creativity and social commitment, she graduated from Hunter College in 1929 and taught art in New York City high schools from 1936 to 1955. She worked closely with Joseph Solman in his New York studio. Her paintings included still lifes, portraits, figure studies, and cityscapes. Her work was seen in group shows and in solo exhibitions at City Center and other galleries. She won several awards from the National Association of Women Artists and Audubon Artists. Her husband, Jack Foner, died in 1999. She is survived by a sister, Rose Apteker, of Florida, a son, Eric Foner, his wife Lynn Garafola, and a granddaughter, Daria Rose Foner, all of New York City.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RIPP, DR. RAYMOND M.
description: RIPP--Dr. Raymond M., of Garden City, NY, died August 5, 2005. He was born in Brooklyn on September 2, 1924, son of John A. Ripp and Genevieve O'Mahoney Ripp. He graduated from Garden City High School in 1942 and University of Pittsburgh Dental School in 1948. Upon graduation, Dr. Ripp served as Lieutenant J.G. in the United States Navy. Subsequently, he openeed a dental office in Garden City, where he practiced for over 40 years. Dr. Ripp was a long-standing member and President of the Nassau County Dental Society, where he recently received the Herbert L. Taub Award for Distinguished Service. He was President of the Long Island Academy of Odontology and Psi Omega Dental Fraternity. He served as President of the Catholic Dentists Guild of the Diocese of Rockville Centre and the Men's Guild of St. Joseph's R.C. Church. He is survived by his wife Joan Haskins Ripp, four sons, Thomas, William, Kerry and Stephen, two daughters, Dr. Nancy Ripp Clark and Patricia Ripp Janicke, and 17 grandchildren. He was preceded in death by his two brothers, Dr. John Ripp and Dr. Gerard Ripp. Friends may call at Fairchild Funeral Home in Garden City on Monday and Tuesday from 2-4 and 7-9 pm. A Funeral Mass will be conducted Wednesday at 10 am at St. Joseph's R.C. Church, Garden City. Donations in lieu of flowers may be made to Little Flower Children's Services, Wading River, NY.

title: Arts, Briefly; 'Dukes' of Honor
description: The only new wide release this weekend easily captured the No. 1 spot at the box office. "The Dukes of Hazzard" (Warner Brothers), the big-screen version of the CBS television series featuring a 1969 orange Dodge Charger named the General Lee and the pop singer Jessica Simpson, right, opened in 3,785 theaters. It was the widest opening ever for a feature film that is not animated or effects-driven, and the studio estimated that ticket sales amounted to $30.6 million. Last week's No. 1 film, "Wedding Crashers" (New Line), the sex comedy with Vince Vaughn and Owen Wilson, dropped back to No. 2 with $16.5 million in box office receipts, bringing its cumulative sales to $144 million. Three holdovers rounded out the top five, including two from Warner Brothers: "Charlie and the Chocolate Factory," at No. 3 with $10.5 million, and the romantic comedy "Must Love Dogs," with Diane Lane and John Cusack, at the No. 5 spot with $7.4 million; Buena Vista's "Sky High," with Kurt Russell and Kelly Preston, was at No. 4 with $9 million. description: JENNINGS--Peter. The Board of Trustees and staff of Carnegie Hall mourn the loss of our dear friend and colleague Peter Jennings. Peter joined the Carnegie Hall Board of Trustees in 1992 and was a committed and faithful friend throughout the years. Peter also served as a gracious and erudite ambassador for Carnegie Hall as anchor of our Opening Night broadcasts on PBS, sharing with viewers across the country the magic and thrill of these gala performances. All of us at Carnegie Hall will miss his warm and welcoming presence. We express our heartfelt condolences to his wife, Kayce; to his children Elizabeth and Christopher; and to his entire extended family, including his colleagues at ABC News. Sanford I. description: A man trying to run from the police yesterday got into a struggle with an officer and bit off one part of one of his fingertips, the police said. Just after 6 p.m., two officers from the 73rd Precinct stopped a car near Pitkin Avenue and Amboy Street in East New York. A man identified by the police as David O'Brien, 33, of Jersey City, tried to flee and began struggling with the officers. He bit the finger of one officer, severing the tip of his left ring finger, the police said. Mr. O'Brien was arrested and the officer was taken to Bellevue Hospital Center, where doctors operated to try to reattach the finger, the police said. The officer was reported in stable condition, but there was no report on whether the operation was successful. Corey Kilgannon (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Study Finds No Spread Of Altered Corn
description: A broad sampling of maize in Oaxaca State, where genetically modified corn was detected five years ago, has failed to find any transgenic seeds, leading researchers from Mexico and the United States to conclude that the bioengineered seeds had not spread widely. Their report, being published online this week in the Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences (www.pnas.org) is the largest study yet of the presence of transgenic corn in Oaxaca. "Despite the fact that Mexico imports transgenic maize grain for food, feed and processing, and despite the expectation that some of this grain may be planted in farmers' fields, the introgression of transgenes in the sampled area appeared to be negligible in 2003 and 2004," the researchers said. Mexico banned planting of genetically modified corn in 1998. Elisabeth Malkin (NYT)

Brown. The teenager, Vijai Dube, was charged with second-degree murder and attempted murder, among other crimes, and was ordered held without bail until his next court appearance on Aug. 22. He faces up to 25 years in prison if convicted. According to investigators, Mr. Dube confronted and then opened fire on Harrichad Singh, 15, and his friend, Shastra Sagar, 14, as the two were heading to a party about 8 p.m. on Saturday. Mr. Singh, who was struck twice, was found dead on the corner of 117th Street and 109th Avenue when paramedics arrived a short time later. Paid Notice: Deaths   KRAUT, ALICE F.
description: KRAUT--Alice F. 83. On Sunday, August 7, 2005. Survived by sons, Curtis and Glen. Predeceased by her husband Oscar. Raised in Stelton, New Jersey, Alice later moved to Manhattan, where she raised her family while attaining her Bachelor's and Master's degrees in education, from Brooklyn College and Fordham University respectively. Alice's teaching career spanned 35 years initially at the Henry Street Settlement, and later in the New York Public Schools, where she taught second grade and a variety of music classes. Alice pursued her love of music early in her career, as a member of Phil Spitainy's AllGirl Orchestra. While touring the U.S with the orchestra, she met Oscar, who was a member of the U.S. Army band. Alice later shared her talents in the saxophone, clarinet, recorder, and piano with a number of local orchestras. She also enjoyed ensemble music in their home, where she and Oscar, an accomplished violinist, were joined by other musicians. Services are Wednesday, 12:30 PM at Robert Schoem's Menorah Chapel W-150 Route 4 East Paramus, New Jersey. In lieu of flowers memorial contributions may be made to the American Cancer Society.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: School Meal Program Faces Cut
description: The city's public advocate, Betsy Gotbaum, left, criticized the Department of Education yesterday for planning to close dozens of schools next week where children can receive free, federally financed meals during the summer. In a letter to Schools Chancellor Joel I. Klein, Ms. Gotbaum said the department "should expand the summer meals program and make it as easy as possible to participate," instead of closing the sites when summer school is over. School officials, however, said they were keeping enough schools open, in addition to staffing other sites at parks and pools, to meet demand across the city for the rest of the summer. Further, a spokeswoman for the Department of Education, Margie Feinberg, said that officials would open more sites if they were needed. Susan Saulny (NYT)

Ms. Sheehan, the mother of a soldier killed in Iraq last year, is camping out near President Bush's ranch in Crawford, Tex., and says she won't leave until Mr. Bush agrees to meet with her to discuss the war. There are many reasons for the flood of media attention she is attracting: she has a poignant personal story and she is articulate -- and, let's face it, August is a slow news month. But most of all, she is tapping into a growing popular feeling that the Bush administration is out of touch with the realities, and the costs, of the Iraq war.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Newark: Violations At Building Where Boy Fell
description: More than half of the apartments inspected yesterday in a building where a 5-year-old boy fell last week did not have safety mechanisms to limit how far windows can be raised. On Friday, Gov. Paid Notice: Deaths   VOGELMAN, CLAIRE
description: VOGELMAN--Claire. who was known in the fashion world as Claire Newman, passed away at Lenox Hill Hospital on August 7th, 2005. Born in Stamford, CT on October 19th, 1911. She grew up in Westchester County as a child of the Great Depression, she launched her career as a fasion designer in the 1930's by designing bridal and evening gowns. Her fashions appeared in most major department stores nationwide and in Hollywood movies. An avid skier and horsewoman, her many interests took her around the world. After she left the world of fashion she devoted herself to philanthropies with her husband Phillip Vogelman including Federation-UJA where she served in many leadership roles, Shenkar College of Engineering & Design in Israel which she cofounded, The Brookdale Center on Aging and Rockefeller University where she served on the Advisory Council. For ten years she served as President of the Daughters of Jacob Geriatric Center, a 1,000 bed skilled nursing facility in New York. She is survived by one son Dr. Steven Sholem of Phoenix, Arizona and two devoted grandchildren, Scott and Julie Sholem. Her love of life and passion were gifts she left behind. We are saddened by her loss, but celebrate the beautiful memories she gave us. Services will be held at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st St on Thursday, August 11th, 2005 at 11:30AM. In lieu of flowers contributions could be made to Federation JDC, Shenkar College of Engineering & Design or Rockefeller University.

title: National Briefing | West : California: Prisoners Brawl

Eric Messick said. About 50 officers with batons and pepper spray put down the fighting in "a matter of minutes," Sergeant Messick said, adding, "They had some time to do some fighting, but staff kept anyone from getting seriously hurt." Stuck in Second
description: As Washington shuts down for August, President Bush's report card from the public for the first halfyear of his second term is not a good one compared with how the public graded Presidents Reagan and Clinton at a similar point in time. Only President Nixon, who had by then begun to tumble into the abyss of Watergate, had a lower presidential approval rating. Unlike Nixon's precipitous decline over one mega-problem, Mr. Bush's fall in public esteem reflects discontent in a number of areas: Americans are unhappy about economic conditions, the war in Iraq, Washington's intervention in the case of Terri Schiavo and general partisan bickering. In that regard, it is noteworthy that favorable ratings for Congress are lower than in the past, too.

Personal belongings of some victims were found in his home, the police said. The crimes of the serial killer had been horrific enough that Ukrainians had pleaded for help from Moscow during the late Soviet period. title: Arts, Briefly; CBS Wrests Victory From Impending Disaster

CBS was also No. 1 in total viewers and households, as it usually is on Sundays. Repeats of its "60 Minutes" (8.1 million) and "Cold Case" (8.61 million) delivered strong performances, as they generally do, but it was the appeal of "Deep Impact" (8.69 million) to the 18-to-49 audience from 9 to 11 p.m. that helped CBS edge out Fox in that demographic. NBC came in second for the night in total viewers. Its "Law & Order: Criminal Intent" rerun was the night's most-watched program, with an audience of 9.02 million. The criminal procedural was battered during the regular season by ABC's "Desperate Housewives," but it has regularly beaten that phenomenally successful serialized drama during the summer. On Sunday, a "Housewives" repeat drew 5.89 million viewers. KATE AURTHUR

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MCCORMICK, JACK
description: McCORMICK--Jack. 69, died August 8th at his residence in Ponte Vedra Beach. He was born August 17, 1935 in Binghamton, NY, the only child of the late James Leo McCormick and Esther Crimmins. Jack graduated from Cornell University in 1957 where he belonged to the SAE fraternity and played varsity golf. He served as a Lieutenant JG in the U.S. Navy and later earned his MBA from Columbia University in 1961. He served as president and CEO of Swisher Cigar Company from 1976 until 1986. After the company was sold to American Maize Company, he served as president and COO until his retirement. He was a member of the Ponte Vedra Inn and Club, the Cornell Continuous Reunion Club, Metedeconk, GC, and the Cornell Club of Jacksonville. He maintained homes in New York City, Bay Head, NJ and Ponte Vedra Beach, FL. Funeral Services will be held in Ponte Vedra Beach, FL. For more information contact Quinn-Shalz, A Family Funeral Home, 904-249-1100.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HIRSCHFELD, ABRAHAM
description: HIRSCHFELD--Abraham Made history and will be remembered dearly by family and friends. Born in Poland in 1919. Moved to Israel in 1933. Later joined Haganah to fight for Israeli independence. Emigrated to United States in 1950. Builder of parking facilities throughout Metro area and became affectionately known as the "garage king" of New York. Then formed partnership with son Elie Hirschfeld in 1976 to develop important residential, commercial, hotel and sport projects throughout New York area, including Hotel Pennsylvania, West Side Rail Yards, Sports Clubs-61 Street, 404 East 55th St, Apt. Towers, 25 Broad St. Tower, Crowne Plaza Hotel, Park Avenue Court, Grand Sutton and many more. Great civic leader. Publisher of NY Post in 1993. Treasurer of NYS Democratic Party. Member of Tristate Regional Planning Commission. Ran for U.S. Senator, NYS Lieutenant Governor and Manhattan Borough President. Elected City Commissioner of Miami Beach in 1989. Devoted husband to Zipora for 63 years. Survived by son Elie Hirschfeld and wife Dr. Susan Hirschfeld; daughter Rachel Hirschfeld; brother Menashe and wife Judith Hirschfeld; eight grandchildren and three great grandchildren. Gigante, the owner of Mulino's, an Italian restaurant in White Plains, was arrested yesterday by federal authorities on charges of tax evasion and bankruptcy fraud, accused of concealing assets to avoid paying more than $1 million in taxes. Ms. Lambert wraps fat little cylinders of fresh goat cheese in hoja santa (pronounced oh-ha santa) leaves, prized in Mexican cooking for their aromatic spiciness. The plant is also called Mexican pepperleaf or root beer plant, and the moist green leaves impart an alluring hint of sassafras, pepper and anise to the cheese. description: Demanding action against members of the governing Congress Party implicated in the anti-Sikh riots that followed the assassination of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi by her Sikh bodyguards in 1984, opposition lawmakers disrupted both houses of Parliament and forced it to adjourn. Family members of victims of the riots staged angry protests outside Parliament. In a report on Monday, a government commission said that Congress Party politicians, including a current government minister, had incited the mobs that attacked the Sikhs, leaving more than 3,000 dead. The leader of the Hindu nationalist Bhartiya Janata Party, Atal Bihari Vajpayee, who appointed the inquiry commission in 2000, when he was prime minister, also demanded action. The current Congress government, headed by Prime Minister Manmohan Singh, himself a Sikh, is of the opinion that not enough evidence is available to take action against the Congress Party minister, Jagdish Tytler. Hari Kumar (NYT)

An Unwelcome Fish
description: To read the United States Geological Survey's report on snakehead fish is to encounter a creature of extraordinary versatility and widespread distribution. Make that two such creatures. The first is humans, who are responsible for the near-ubiquity of snakeheads, some species of which are valued as food. The native range of the northern snakehead -- Channa argus -- includes Manchuria, parts of Russia and the Korean peninsula, and much of southeastern Asia and China. But this fish has also been introduced, intentionally or otherwise, into much of western Asia and Eastern Europe, not to mention the San Bernardino Mountains in California, southern Florida, the Potomac Basin, Michigan and Massachusetts, and now Meadow Lake in Queens, where several northern snakeheads were found last month.

In it we learn that Gov. Francis Cherry liked garlic grits; Dale Bumpers, pork chops and snickerdoodles; and the former president, presumably during periods of suppressed appetite, a Jell-O salad formulated from 7-Up.

The child was killed instantly, the police said, and Ms. Gibbs suffered a fractured skull and other injuries. title: World Briefing | Asia: Tajikistan: Major Arms Cache Found
description: A large cache of weapons and munitions was discovered in the mountains of eastern Tajikistan, in an area formerly used by both opposition groups in the Tajik civil war and by guerrillas with connections to Al Qaeda. The cache, which includes anti-tank weapons, rocket launchers and other weapons, was discovered by the Interior Ministry in the Tavildara district, Interfax reported. Tajikistan, impoverished and corrupt, has been generally stable in recent years, but is a main route for drug smuggling from Afghanistan. The Islamic Movement of Uzbekistan, a regional terrorist group that fought alongside the Taliban against the United States in 2001, used to be based in the area. C.J. Chivers (NYT)

The two men then made threatening comments involving a gun without displaying any weapon, and ran away, the police said. Kareem Fahim (NYT)

Originally from Levittown, PA, Ileen was an actress and will be remembered for her many roles in television, stage and film. Ileen's greatest joys were her family, friends and her work. Net income rose to 1.39 billion euros ($1.72 billion), from 846 million euros a year earlier, the insurer said in a statement to the Frankfurt exchange. The company, which is based in Munich, released results three days earlier than scheduled and will publish more detailed figures Friday. Revenue at the life insurance unit rose by a double-digit percentage in the quarter, the company said, benefiting from German tax changes that spurred sales at the end of last year. "Temporary weakness" in trading results at the banking business was offset by cost cuts, Allianz said. The company has struggled to increase revenue at Dresdner Bank, which it bought for $21 billion in 2001.

title: The Shuttle Returns, Safely
description: Yesterday's smooth landing of the shuttle Discovery ended a flight that was successful in almost every respect but one: the dislodging of a big chunk of foam, like the one that doomed the Columbia. This flight was supposed to vault the shuttle fleet back into space after a prolonged grounding for repairs. But given the repeat of the very problem that two years of retooling was supposed to resolve, the verdict is necessarily mixed. Once again, the space agency has been forced to suspend further flights until it can find a fix for the foam-shedding, and no one seems willing to guess how long that may take.

title: Arts, Briefly; Football Shoulders Into the Ratings
description: On Monday, the all-repeat CBS lineup managed to bring in more viewers than ABC's pre-season football broadcast, in which the Chicago Bears beat the Miami Dolphins. But in Nielsen's estimates, the first football game of the season in Monday's primetime won the 18-to-49 demographic for ABC. CBS's numbers benefited from the absence of the low-rated Monday edition of "Rock Star: INXS," which was broadcast on VH1, its Viacom sibling. A "Two and a Half Men" repeat took its place at 9:30 and drew 9.95 million viewers, far more people than have watched "Rock Star" on recent Mondays. For the week that ended on Sunday, CBS was No. 1 in total viewers for the 10th week in a row and also edged out Fox among adults 18 to 49. On Aug. 2 "Real World: Austin" was the most-watched broadcast in the show's 13-year history, attracting an audience of 5.6 million. title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Bridgewater: Ice Cream Vendor Accused Of Drug Sales
description: A month-long undercover investigation called "Operation Double-Dip" led to the arrest of a 41-year-old ice cream truck driver who was accused of selling crack and cocaine, sometimes even from the truck itself, prosecutors said yesterday. The vendor, Ozcan Demirbulaki, also known as John, drove the truck for the Bridgeville Ice Cream Company, which is based in Bridgewater, the police said. They said that a detective bought cocaine from him that he delivered through the side window used to sell ice cream, near the Old York Elementary School in Branchburg last week. Mr. Demirbulaki, who lives in Bridgewater, was charged with conspiracy to distribute drugs and with distribution of cocaine within 1,000 feet of school property. Jennifer 8. Lee

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: Investment Bank Sold
description: J.C. Flowers & Company, a private equity firm, led a group of investors who agreed to buy the Dutch investment bank NIB Capital for 2.1 billion euros ($2.6 billion) to expand in the Netherlands and Germany. NIB, which is based in The Hague, said it was among the top five banks in mergers and acquisitions in the Benelux region and was expanding into leveraged buyouts, real estate and public-private financing in Germany. Profit at NIB, which had 28.7 billion euros in assets at the end of June, more than doubled last year. NIB has a "strong brand name and market position" and is "quite a profitable business in the Netherlands, which is a good place to invest," J. Christopher Flowers, head of the private equity firm, said at a news conference in Amsterdam. Mr. Flowers reaped profits from his investment in Shinsei Bank, whose predecessor, the Long-Term Credit Bank of Japan, collapsed in 1998 under $26.7 billion of bad debt.

Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Snakehead Problem Is Being Investigated
description: Speaking of the recent discovery of snakehead fish in Meadow Lake in Flushing Meadows-Corona Park, Liam Kavanagh, the first deputy commissioner of the Department of Parks and Recreation, said at a news conference yesterday that it would probably take a month before the fish were eliminated. Snakehead fish, which are native to Asia, are large, uncommonly ferocious predators that are known to wipe out other species of fish. In the last month, five have been discovered in the brackish water of Meadow Lake. Mr. Kavanagh said that no decision had been made on how to deal with them, but that poisoning the pond was an option. Thomas J. Lueck (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Cost of Oil Sands Plan Rises
description: Shell Canada, Canada's fourth-largest oil and gas company, said the cost to expand output from its oil-sands project in Alberta would almost double, to 7.3 billion Canadian dollars, or $6 billion. Higher prices for steel, cement and equipment, along with design changes, are raising the cost, a Shell Canada spokeswoman, Janet Annesley, said in a telephone interview. The company, based in Calgary, and project partners said in April the expansion would add 100,000 barrels a day of mining and refining capacity by 2009 at a cost of at least 4 billion Canadian dollars. Rising oil prices are encouraging oil producers to expand in Alberta's tar sands, the largest oil deposit outside Saudi Arabia.

These three constituencies are all committed tipping -- as they quickly made clear on Web sites. To oppose tipping, it seems, is to be anticapitalist, and maybe even a little French.

Directed by Daniel Gordon, a British sports journalist whose first film, "The Game of Their Lives," documented the performance of the North Korean soccer team in the 1966 World Cup competition, "A State of Mind" follows two North Korean schoolgirls, 13-year-old Pak Hyon Sun and 11-year-old Kim Song Yun, as they train for a gymnastics performance in the 2003 Mass Games.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HERSH, LEONARD (LENNY)
description: HERSH--Leonard (Lenny). September 18, 1918--August 8, 2005. Of Brooklyn and New Rochelle, N.Y., Stamford, CT. Son of the late Benjamin and Sara (nee Gemson) Hersh. Devoted husband of the late Claire (nee Darmstadtler), father of Lin of Bearsville, N.Y. and Ron of Purchase, N.Y. Bemused uncle of ten, always with a special twinkle in his eyes for Bill and Myra, Bob and Jane, B.J. and Bob, as well as their children. Younger brother of the late Morty and Tippy Hersh, who together, building upon their mother's original New Rochelle store, made the Paris Shops into a household name through mail order and retail shops for over 50 years. Graduate of New Rochelle High School and Hobart College. Served as Captain in the U.S. Army Air Force in the South Pacific Theatre and also taught navigation. Received the Distinguished Flying Cross, Air Medal and Presidential Unit Citation, amongst others. Lover of many fine things from classical music to tomato plants, but first and foremost, of his family and friends. Fly low Pop, and call us when you get there. A memorial gathering will be Thursday 1-4PM. Service at 3PM. George T. Davis Funeral Home, 914-632-0324.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   JENNINGS, PETER
description: JENNINGS--Peter. The Board of Trustees and International Advisory Council of the American University of Beirut deeply mourn the death of Peter Jennings. Peter was a long-standing and valuable member of the AUB International Advisory Council, providing exceptional support and wise counsel to the University over the years. In 2004, the University was honored to bestow upon him an Honorary Doctorate of Humane Letters, which he so eminently deserved. He was a frequent visitor to the AUB campus, and he knew the entire Middle East region intimately. As an outstanding and esteemed journalist, he made a profound contribution to promoting a better understanding of the Middle East and its peoples to his global audiences. description: The police released the identity of a suspect last night in the muggings of five Asian-Americans at two Brooklyn subway stations over the past four months: four at the 59th Street stop on the N and R lines in Sunset Park, and one at the Prospect Avenue stop in Park Slope. The suspect was identified as William Reyes, 39, who they said is 5 feet 9 inches tall and weighs about 210 pounds. They said he has used a knife or silver gun in four of the muggings but injured only one victim, a woman, in April. The police said the victims identified the suspect from police photographs. Anyone with information is asked to call Crimestoppers at 1-800-577-TIPS (8477). A $2,000 reward is offered. Jennifer 8. Lee (NYT)

description: Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky, the former oil tycoon sentenced in May to nine years in prison, was transferred to a larger, more crowded cell and deprived of privileges, including watching television and reading newspapers, his lawyers said. One lawyer, Yuri M. Schmidt, said in a statement that the changes came in retaliation for critical comments Mr. Khodorkovsky has made in recent articles and interviews from prison. Mr. Khodorkovsky told the newspaper Vedomosti last week that Russia's weakened opposition parties needed to unite to challenge the Kremlin's political dominance. "It did not take long for revenge to come," Mr. Schmidt said. Steven Lee Myers (NYT)

description: VOGELMAN--Claire. who was known in the fashion world as Claire Newman, passed away at Lenox Hill Hospital on August 7th, 2005. Born in Stamford, CT on October 19th, 1911. She grew up in Westchester County as a child of the Great Depression, she launched her career as a fasion designer in the 1930's by designing bridal and evening gowns. Her fashions appeared in most major department stores nationwide and in Hollywood movies. An avid skier and horsewoman, her many interests took her around the world. After she left the world of fashion she devoted herself to philanthropies with her husband Phillip Vogelman including Federation-UJA where she served in many leadership roles, Shenkar College of Engineering & Design in Israel which she cofounded, The Brookdale Center on Aging and Rockefeller University where she served on the Advisory Council. For ten years she served as President of the Daughters of Jacob Geriatric Center, a 1,000 bed skilled nursing facility in New York. She is survived by one son Dr. Steven Sholem of Phoenix, Arizona and two devoted grandchildren, Scott and Julie Sholem. Her love of life and passion were gifts she left behind. We are saddened by her loss, but celebrate the beautiful memories she gave us. Services will be held at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st St on Thursday, August 11th, 2005 at 11:30AM. In lieu of flowers contributions could be made to Federation JDC, Shenkar College of Engineering & Design or Rockefeller University.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HIRSCHFELD, ABRAHAM
description: HIRSCHFELD--Abraham Made history and will be remembered dearly by family and friends. Born in Poland in 1919. Moved to Israel in 1933. Later joined Haganah to fight for Israeli independence. Emigrated to United States in 1950. Builder of parking facilities throughout Metro area and became affectionately known as the "garage king" of New York. Then formed partnership with son Elie Hirschfeld in 1976 to develop important residential, commercial, hotel and sport projects throughout New York area, including Hotel Pennsylvania, West Side Rail Yards, Sports Clubs-61 Street, 404 East 55th St, Apt. Towers, 25 Broad St. Tower, Crowne Plaza Hotel, Park Avenue Court, Grand Sutton and many more. Great civic leader. Publisher of NY Post in 1993. Treasurer of NYS Democratic Party. Member of Tristate Regional Planning Commission. Ran for U.S. Senator, NYS Lieutenant Governor and Manhattan Borough President. Elected City Commissioner of Miami Beach in 1989. Devoted husband to Zipora for 63 years. Survived by son Elie Hirschfeld and wife Dr. Susan Hirschfeld; daughter Rachel Hirschfeld; brother Menashe and wife Judith Hirschfeld; eight grandchildren and three great grandchildren.

description: A 22-year-old man was arrested yesterday after the police said he attacked a 73-year-old woman practicing tai chi in Kissena Park and tried to sexually assault her. Officers responding to a 911 call saw him attacking the woman about 9:15 a.m. near Kissena Boulevard and Peck Avenue, the police said. "Too many hard-working, middle-class New York families who used to see public schools as a pathway to success now see them as a fundamentally unsafe place for their children," he said outside the Tweed Building on Chambers Street, which houses the city's Education Department. Mr. Weiner said that principals should have the right to transfer students suspected of engaging in gang activity, which he called a "divide and conquer" approach to gang violence. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CIARDI, ALEXANDRA MORGAN
description: CIARDI--Alexandra Morgan. 48, died suddenly August 10 in a boating accident in Sardinia, Italy. She was a resident of London, Porto Ercole and NY. Born in NYC she graduated from The Brearley School, Tufts University and Columbia Business School. She was a path breaking business woman on Wall Street, beginning at Goldman Sachs in NY and then London; she then became a founding member of GLG Partners, one of London's largest hedge fund groups. Alexandra served as a Tufts University Overseer and on numerous boards of charitable organizations in London and NY. Beloved wife of Giuseppe. Adoring mother of Olivia, Francesco and Federico. Loving daughter of Alice Gerard and the late David E. Morgan. Dear sister of Leslie Solmonson, Fern Lindsay, Nicholas Morgan and Christopher Gerard. Devoted daughter-in-law of Francesco Ciardi and the late Natalia; sister-in-law of Olimpia, Francesca, Nicolo, Tito and Vittoria. Her nieces and nephews adored her and will miss her terribly. Her friends the world over will feel the loss of her boundless energy and love for life. Funeral services Monday 1PM at West London Synagogue.

description: The country-pop star Faith Hill's "Fireflies" (Warner Brothers Nashville) is the new No. 1 album on the Billboard charts. Featuring the hit song "Mississippi Girl," it had sales of 329,000 copies in its first week of release, according to Nielsen SoundScan. That's no shock, given Ms. Hill's platinum sales record, but two other new albums on the chart reached surprisingly high. Teairra Mar, a 17-year-old R&B singer, is at No. 5 with her debut album, "Roc-A-Fella Presents Teairra Mar" (Roc-A-Fella); that album, which includes the hit "Make Her Feel Good," sold 69,000 copies in its first week. And "Kidz Bop 8" (Razor & Tie), a compilation of toddler-friendly versions of pop hits, sold 67,000 copies to reach No. 6. Last week's No. 1, the 19th volume in the "Now That's What I Call Music!" pop anthology series, fell to No. 2, and Mariah Carey's "Emancipation of Mimi" (Island/Def Jam), an enduring summer hit, holds at No. 3. title: Arts, Briefly; The Rolling Stones Enter Political Fray
description: Mick Jagger is giving the White House a bit of lip. Treading political terrain covered already by artists including Eminem, Green Day and Bruce Springsteen, the Rolling Stones' new album includes a song railing against well-connected contractors and the war on terrorism. In the song, "Sweet Neo Con," Mr. Jagger sings, "How come you're so wrong / My sweet neo con? / Where's the money gone / In the Pentagon?" according to lyrics provided by a band representative. The rock band, still one of the most successful touring attractions in the business, has touched on political themes before, in such classics as "Street Fighting Man." But the new song, which also references Halliburton, the energy-services company that employed Dick Cheney before he became vice president, comes at a time when the nation's sharp political divisions have left the recording industry uncertain about how to handle sensitive topics. The Rolling Stones may not find out how fans respond to "Sweet Neo Con," from their forthcoming "A Bigger Bang" album, unless they perform it on tour. Virgin Records, the Stones' label, is not promoting the song to radio stations. The N.F.L. plans to broadcast some of a taped Stones' concert in the pregame show before the New England Patriots take on the Oakland Raiders on Sept. 8, but it will not be selecting "Sweet Neo Con," said to Brian McCarthy of the N.F.L. "We're not asking them to throw passes or discuss politics," Mr. McCarthy said. "We can draw from an extensive list of songs." Fran Curtis, a spokeswoman for the band, said, "People can disagree and still be friends." JEFF LEEDS

It also enables prosecutors to seek felony convictions against those accused of owning or stealing anhydrous ammonia, a main ingredient in producing the drug.

For Susan Habermann of Chappaqua, N.Y., a mother of three college-age children, the most important supply is an extra-long twin-size mattress cover that zips closed. description: A Polish diplomat was beaten by four men not far from Poland's embassy in Moscow. It was the second time this week that an embassy employee was attacked. The incidents followed a highly publicized attack on the teenage children of Russian diplomats in Warsaw on July 31, which President Vladimir V. Putin himself denounced as an "unfriendly act." None of the injuries have been grave, but the attacks have resulted in a flurry of diplomatic dmarches and summonses, reducing already tense relations to a new low. Officials in each country blamed the other for stoking deeply engrained political and ethnic tensions. Steven Lee Myers (NYT)

Paid Notice: Deaths   O'BRIEN, JOSEPH A.
description: O'BRIEN--Joseph A. 90, beloved father of Robert, Joel, and Geoffrey, adored grandfather of Heather, died in a car accident in Lenox, MA on July 24, 2005. Joe was born on July 16, 1915, in Yonkers. In 1935 he was hired as a radio announcer by WMCA, beginning an association of three decades. In the army, 1945-46, he served in Germany where he wrote and starred in "The Joe O'Brien Show" on AFN. For WMCA he hosted the popular "Gallegher and O'Brien Show," 1949-58. Joe's theater work included directing and acting for the Great Neck Community Theatre and the Hampton Playhouse, NH; in 1957 he co-founded the Cricket Theatre in New York, where he directed plays including Bernard Kops' The Hamlet of Stepney Green and Jean Anouilh's Ardele. As one of the WMCA Good Guys he was a major presence in Top 40 radio of the 1960s, and (with his imaginary sidekick "Benny") maintained wide popularity in his morning time slot. He left WMCA in 1968 for WNBC, and later moved to WHUD in Peekskill, where he had a daily show from 1972 to 1986; he made his final broadcast in 2000. Joe married the actress Margaret Owens in 1940. Joe and Maggie lived in Red Hook, NY, from the late 1960s until Maggie's death in 1997. In his final years he resided in Rhinebeck, NY. He was a man of wide-ranging intellectual curiosity, with an abiding interest in politics, literature, music, and the performing arts, and an enduring love of travel. His high spirits, energetic conversation, and unfailing humor brought joy to family and friends. He is survived by sons Robert and Geoffrey; Geoffrey's wife Kaalii and their daughter Heather; Joel's wife Harriet Katz; his beloved sister-in-law LaVerne Owens; Yasoko Owens; brother Paul O'Brien and sister Anita Sutor; his dear friend Ruth Meyer, and by friends, admirers, and fans who will miss his electrifying presence.

title: What Makes a Surprise Best Seller?

While online sellers are warning of shipping delays of one to two weeks, Carrie Thornton, the book's editor, said copies could begin to arrive in stores beginning tomorrow. Yesterday afternoon the book ranked No. 3 on the best-sellers list on the Barnes & Noble Web site and No. 2 on Amazon.com. Written by the humorist Mark Leyner and Dr. Billy Goldberg, a New York physician, the book was initially published in a $12.95 paperback edition, rather than in hardcover. In addition to the title question (the answer to which will not be revealed here), the book tackles puzzlers like why asparagus makes urine smell (and why you're more likely to smell that smell in France than in Britain), what causes an ice cream headache and why old people grow hair on their ears. EDWARD WYATT

Investigators discovered a small hole at the bottom of the helicopter's windshield and recovered from the cockpit metal shards consistent with those of a fragmented bullet, corroborating the pilot's belief that the aircraft had come under fire, Sheriff White said. The helicopter was responding to a robbery report when it crashed, injuring the pilot, Chris Holland, a civilian, and Ward Pfefferle, a sheriff's deputy. Steve Barnes (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: School Supervisors Endorse Ferrer
description: Fernando Ferrer, left, a Democratic candidate for mayor, received the endorsement of the Council of School Supervisors and Administrators yesterday at City Hall. "Freddy has proven his determination to fix what is wrong with our schools, not just focusing on test scores but by focusing on the real health of our school system," the union's president, Jill Levy, said. The union represents more than 10,000 school and day care administrators, including Mr. Ferrer's wife, Aramina, a Bronx school principal.

description: Dell Inc. said today that its second-quarter earnings jumped 28 percent, matching Wall Street's expectations, but investors were disappointed that revenue grew more slowly than anticipated.

World Briefing | Europe: Estonia: 14 Feared Dead In Baltic Sea Copter Crash
description: Fourteen people were feared to have died when a commercial helicopter traveling from Estonia to Finland crashed into the Gulf of Finland. The helicopter was lost from radar just three minutes after taking off from Tallin, the Estonian capital, the Estonian Interior Ministry said. The Estonian border guard was searching the area but could not immediately find either the downed helicopter or any survivors. By nightfall the search had had no apparent success. The copter carried four Estonians, six Finns and two Americans, as well as a crew of two, the ministry said. C.J. Chivers (NYT)

title: ESPN Executive Pursued
description: Mark Shapiro, the outspoken executive who has transformed the programming and production of ESPN, is considering a job offer from Daniel Snyder, the owner of the Washington Redskins, according to three television executives who did not want to be identified because the deal had not been completed. Little is known about what Shapiro's role would be if he takes Snyder's offer. In 2000, Snyder sold his marketing company, Snyder Communications, to a French company, Havas, for $2 billion. Through his company, Red Zone L.L.C., he owns 10.2 million shares of Six Flags, the theme park owner and operator, and has been rebuffed in his attempts to influence its management.

title: When a Night Out Is Dinner and a (TV) Show
description: PITTSFIELD, Mass., Aug. 8 - Ever since Rich Cohen and Cheryl Sachs decided to get rid of their satellite dish six years ago, their home has been virtually television-free. So when their two sons get a special treat (or, let's be honest, Ms. Sachs needs a bit of a TV fix), they all take a quick hop down Route 7.

description: WEIL--Stephen, an internationally recognized leader and mentor in the field of museum management, died on Tuesday, August 9, 2005, at the Washington Home Hospice. Steve also leaves four grandchildren: Ariel, Yoni, Tamar, and Benjamin. A memorial service will be scheduled in September. Contributions may be made in Steve's name to one of the following: Washington Home Hospice, Inpatient Unit, 3720 Upton St, NW, Washington, DC 20016; or American Association of Museums, 1575 Eye St, NW, Suite 400, Washington, DC 20005; or Fund for Johns Hopkins Medicine, 100 N. Charles Street, Suite 440, Baltimore, MD. 21201.

On a site subject to high winds and storms, Jaffe placed thick cedar shingles on the roof and walls over a base of granite slabs.

title: Games That Keep Bringing Back Summer
description: MORE than two-thirds of Americans had plans to visit the beach this summer, according to the nonprofit Travel Industry Association of America. With a few weeks still to go in the season, which unofficially ends on Labor Day weekend, there's plenty of time left to play on the sand. And it's not too late to try some of the new beach games that could help work off a little beer and barbecue. All of these games are fresh twists on classic beach diversions, and all promise to keep kids and parents alike busy for an afternoon. YISHANE LEE

description: At least 66 people have died of infectious diseases in Mumbai and nearby areas since the heavy monsoon rains two weeks ago and more than 3,000 have been treated at hospitals, officials said.

title: Just Before the Appetizers, Drizzle a Little Vinyl on the Table
description: Spun vinyl is the newest material from Chilewich, the company that put woven vinyl on the tabletop and the floor. The new material looks like a finely woven web. It is made by dripping liquid vinyl through tiny holes to create an abstract, random pattern. Table runners, above, in chocolate brown, beige, white, black or moss green, will be available this month through the company, (212)679-9204. description: In the shadow of the major carriers, more than two dozen mobile ventures are focusing on the one in three Americans who lack traditional wireless service, including the credit-challenged, teenagers and those who want a cellphone for limited use.

title: Corrections
description: An article on July 22 about efforts by the White House to shore up support for Judge John G. Roberts Jr. among social-issue conservatives, a full year before he was nominated for the Supreme Court, referred incorrectly to his dissent in a case before the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit, involving the arroyo toad. (The error was repeated in articles on July 23 and on Tuesday.) Judge Roberts said the court should rehear the case and consider whether the Interior Department had properly invoked the Endangered Species Act in this circumstance. He did not say the federal government lacked the power to block a California real estate development because it endangered the toad.

title: Hilfiger Investigation Stops With Agreement to Pay More Tax
description: The Tommy Hilfiger Corporation, whose commissions to its overseas subsidiaries have been under federal investigation for nearly a year, said yesterday that it had signed a nonprosecution agreement with the United States attorney's office and would not face criminal tax charges.

title: ON THE STREET: THEN
description: IN the summer of 1991 the sheath dress asserted itself as an uptown badge of chic. Like its near relations, the more forgiving A-line and the shift, the sheath captured the popular imagination in the Camelot era, when Jacqueline Kennedy made it a keystone of her White House wardrobe. Classically accessorized with pilgrim pumps and pearls, this fashion perennial has been interpreted by designers as diverse as Oleg Cassini, Yves Saint Laurent and Andr Courrges. The latest to place his stamp on the style is Alexander McQueen, whose tight-bodice, bracelet-sleeve version for fall is a homage to Alfred Hitchcock's primly sultry heroines.

title: Goldman Sachs Decides to Stay at Ground Zero
description: Goldman Sachs has agreed to build a $2 billion new headquarters across the street from the former World Trade Center site, reversing its decision this spring to abandon its building plans, according to city, state and company officials who have been briefed on the investment firm's plans.

title: Exploring One Man's Fate in the Alaskan Wilderness
description: One rainy afternoon in the Alaskan wilderness two years ago, a self-made man named Timothy Treadwell was mauled and eaten by a grizzly bear. It may be that the animal, a scrawny male about 28 years old and 1,000 pounds, was trying to fatten up in preparation for its winter's sleep. As it happens, Treadwell, who achieved minor celebrity as an expert on grizzlies, publishing a book on the bears and jousting with David Letterman on late-night television, had pitched his tent in a feeding ground. The call of the wild was as irresistible to Treadwell as his flesh proved to be to that bear.

A verdant California landscape of rolling hills cooled by coastal winds, the valley is famous today as the setting for the movie "Sideways," but what few people know is that it has long been an equestrian paradise.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Siegel Wins Union Endorsement
description: District Council 37, the city's largest municipal workers union, endorsed Norman Siegel yesterday for public advocate. It was one of the most significant endorsements Mr. Siegel, left, has received in his effort to defeat the incumbent, Betsy Gotbaum. The union's 121,000 members range from social workers and architects to clerical workers and school cafeteria personnel. Jonathan P. Hicks (NYT)

title: Officials Warn of Possibility of Attack Around Sept. 11
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 - A group of F.B.I. counterterrorism analysts warned this week of possible terrorist attacks in New York, Los Angeles and Chicago around Sept. 11, but officials cautioned on Thursday that they were skeptical about the seriousness of the threat.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Bail Denied For Suspect In Beating
description: Nicholas Minucci, the white Howard Beach man charged with using a baseball bat to attack a black man on June 29, cursed loudly in Queens Supreme Court yesterday after being denied bail by Justice Pauline Mullings. Mr. Minucci's lawyer, Lori Zeno, said she would file another bail request. On Wednesday, a judge set bail at $500,000 on the assault charge -- a hate crime -- but Mr. Minucci was held yesterday on a probation violation from an earlier case. Mr. Minucci's mother, Maria Minucci, said she planned to hold a fund-raiser to raise bail money, with well-known rappers performing and "anyone who cares about injustice" attending. Corey Kilgannon (NYT)

title: Johnson Will Pitch Soon; It's a Question of How Soon
description: Randy Johnson was supposed to pitch yesterday, but all he did was play catch in the outfield before batting practice. That was considered progress for Johnson, the left-hander whose bad back may keep him out of another start.

Qubcois Treasures at Shelburne Museum
description: Americans tend to love French provincial antiques -- witness the success of the Pierre Deux franchise -- and the Shelburne Museum in Shelburne, Vt., has come up with a reason: they are not so different in style from the handsome if simpler country pieces made just north of the border. Works from Quebec have the charm of France but also an authentic patina that reflects the hard lives of the settlers who arrived in North America in the early 17th century.

description: Whirlpool is being advised by Greenhill & Company, the Boston Consulting Group and the law firm of Weil, Gotshal & Manges on its bid for Maytag. Lazard and the law firm of Wachtell, Lipton, Rosen & Katz are advising Maytag, which had earlier agreed to an offer by an investor group led by Ripplewood Holdings. description: A federal judge sentenced Scott D. Sullivan, the former chief financial officer who acknowledged his leading role in WorldCom's $11 billion accounting fraud, to five years in prison yesterday -- a fifth of what sentencing guidelines suggested and a striking example of the benefit of working with government prosecutors.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on June 30 about efforts by powerful Shiite leaders in Iraq to create an autonomous area in the oil-rich south, which is heavily populated by Shiites, misidentified the home region of Ahmad Chalabi, a Shiite deputy prime minister and former exile who supports those efforts. His family is from Baghdad, not the southern city of Nasiriya. A Chalabi aide alerted The Times in early July to the possibility of an error, but this correction awaited verification from the Iraqi reporter who had provided the information and who was out of the country when it appeared. (Go to Article)

title: Adventures Outside The Classical Canon
description: IT is hard to know, anymore, exactly how to define contemporary Western classical music. How recent does a work have to be? For that matter, how Western does it have to be, with, for example, the stimulating incursions Chinese composers have made in the United States? And does the term "classical" even retain any significance as the music returns to its roots, in a sense, becoming ever more saturated with pop gestures and idioms?

title: Officials Defend Actions to Keep Goldman Sachs Downtown
description: Just six months ago, Goldman Sachs, the big investment bank, appeared to be in a bind. It had committed to building its headquarters across the street from ground zero, but it did not like the city and state plans for traffic and security around the site.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Guns Found In Station Wagon
description: A California man was arrested yesterday and charged with criminal possession of a weapon after he tried to enter a parking garage at United Nations Plaza with two guns and a large knife in his station wagon, the police said. The man, Vernon Welker, 59, of Salton City, drove to the garage of the Millenium Hotel at 44th Street and First Avenue, which holds United Nations satellite offices, around 10:30 a.m., and it is believed that security guards saw guns inside the car. The man protested a search, but the guards found a .22-caliber revolver, a .22-caliber Winchester rifle, and a large knife, the police said. They said that Mr. Welker was not coherent when he was brought in for questioning. Jennifer 8. Lee (NYT)

Sons of a Law-Abiding Mother Become Outlaws to Avenge Her Murder
description: The director John Singleton knows about desolation. In his atmospheric, propulsive and ultimately preposterous melodrama, "Four Brothers," the pictures of snow drifting over a decrepit Detroit neighborhood in the post-Thanksgiving gloom can put a lump in your throat, especially because these images are associated with the murder of a saintly mother figure. Add some faded holiday decorations along with the plaintive cry of Marvin Gaye's "Trouble Man," and you have a mood of cosmic sadness laced with fear and loathing.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Court Blocks Codey's Budget Plan
description: A Superior Court judge ruled in favor of two Republican legislators yesterday who sought to block the Codey administration's plans for a $2.1 billion bond refinancing deal that would have injected $150 million into this year's state budget. Judge Linda Feinberg agreed with arguments made by State Senator Leonard Lance and Assemblyman Alex DeCroce that such a refinancing deal would violate a State Supreme Court ruling last year that concluded that using money from bonds to pay for the state's operating expenses was unconstitutional. Administration officials said they were not sure whether they would appeal. David W. Chen (NYT)

title: In Oregon, the Lure of a Cold and Blustery Beach
description: Cannon Beach, Ore. - SOMEWHERE in the vicinity of what is now a hiking trail leading from a wide cliff to the sea, filled with salmonberry plants and Sitka spruce, Capt. William Clark spied Cannon Beach. In pursuit of a beached whale and eager for its oil and blubber, he was bushwhacking along a punishing Indian trail, through the lush rainforest in what is now Ecola State Park, when he saw the Oregon coast in stark view.

description: The most surprising thing about the public's dissatisfaction with President Bush's handling of the economy, as expressed in recent polls, is the administration's apparent astonishment at Mr. Bush's low marks. His advisers have offered various explanations. Treasury Secretary John Snow says that strong consumer spending indicates that people don't feel as bad about the economy as they tell pollsters. He also suggests that part of the problem is that "less educated people have seen their incomes and wages grow more slowly." Before a meeting with top economic advisers in Crawford this week, the president cited the high cost of energy and health care as weighing on "the future of economic growth."

title: In Defense of Common Sense
description: Garrison, N.Y. - AS anyone remotely interested in science knows by now, 100 years ago Einstein wrote six papers that laid the groundwork for quantum mechanics and relativity, arguably the two most successful theories in history. To commemorate Einstein's "annus mirabilis," a coalition of physics groups has designated 2005 the World Year of Physics. The coalition's Web site lists more than 400 celebratory events, including conferences, museum exhibits, concerts, Webcasts, plays, poetry readings, a circus, a pie-eating contest and an Einstein look-alike competition.

title: Barre, Vt.
description: WHAT better foundation for a city than granite? Barre, where tourists gawk at the world's largest active granite quarry and stone carvers helped shape the National World War II Memorial, has built a lively city on a rocky base. And seven miles down the road in Montpelier, most of the Vermont State house is constructed, naturally, of the favorite local material. The two cities, often mentioned in the same breath, share a Green Mountains landscape, a single newspaper and space on the same free tourist map. But they also maintain an ingrained individuality. Moneyed Montpelier (population 8,035), the smallest state capital in the nation (population 8,035), has wide streets, Greek Revival and Federal-style buildings, abundant bookstores and evidence of Ben-and-Jerrification -- tie-dye sightings are common. Blue-collar Barre (population 9,291) is a union stronghold with a radical past, where immigrants from Scotland, Sweden, Spain, France, Italy, Quebec and elsewhere came to excavate, sculpt and ship the granite. Together, Barre (rhymes with Larry) and Montpelier are vintage Vermont: tidy and hardworking, with a feast of music, artisanship and farm-fresh good cooking just behind a reserved facade.

title: Regulating Fantasyland
description: "It ain't no trick to get rich quick," the Seven Dwarfs sing in their "Heigh-Ho" song, "if you dig dig dig with a shovel or a pick." Michael Ovitz made a fortune at Disney, not by mining diamonds but by walking away with a $140 million severance package after just 14 months as president. A Delaware court ruled this week that Disney's board did not violate its duties by giving Mr. Ovitz such a generous sendoff. The decision may look like a victory for board members. But it makes it clear that corporate governance rules are changing -- and that the next board sued for being so profligate with shareholders' money may not get off as easily.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Italy: ABN Amro May Increase Bank Stake
description: ABN Amro Holding, the largest Dutch lender, may buy Banca Popolare Italiana's stake in Banca Antonveneta, a court-appointed custodian for the stake, which was confiscated in July, said. Last month, Milan magistrates impounded the 40 percent of Antonveneta held by Popolare Italiana, formerly known as Popolare di Lodi, and its partners. Popolare Italiana's chief executive, Gianpiero Fiorani, was suspended from his job last week amid an inquiry into whether the bank breached securities regulations in amassing the stake.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Report On Children's Deaths
description: Nearly half of the estimated 300 children who die each year under suspicious circumstances could have been saved had some basic preventive steps been taken, according to Dr. Anthony D'Urso, the chairman of a state panel on child fatalities. The panel released a report yesterday that detailed 87 fatalities and 5 near-fatalities, and found that 45 percent of those were attributable to "preventable causes" like drowning, suicide and parents rolling onto their children while sleeping. Thirty-one cases involved children who were under the supervision of the Division of Youth and Family Services, the state's much-criticized child welfare agency. David W. Chen (NYT)

title: JUELZ SANTANA & KANO
description: Juelz Santana, a wildly charming Harlem rapper, is to be the headliner at a trans-Atlantic hip-hop concert that could be one of this summer's most exciting musical afternoons, with a few big ifs: if the weather cooperates, if the crowd cooperates, if the performers cooperate. A protg of Cam'ron, Mr. Santana, above, raps almost without rapping: instead of a conventional stanza, you get a series of barked-out phrases. He loves to issue outlandish statements, sometimes repeating himself just to make clear his disdain for the rules of the genre. The latest in a long line of his great mixtape hits is "There It Go (the Whistle Song)," in which he is accompanied by a mechanical rhythm and wolf whistle; expect a riotous performance, as long as he shows up. (Somewhere a bookie is working out the odds.) He is to be joined by Kano, one of the brightest lights of the London hip-hop offshoot known as grime. Where other stars of the genre spit frantically (and thrillingly) to stay atop the jagged beats, Kano barely seems to break a sweat; his smooth but tricky delivery creates the seductive impression that the music is bending to match the rhythms he makes with his mouth. (With DJ Cameo and others, tomorrow at 2 p.m., East River Amphitheater, East River Park, Grand Street at the East River, Lower East Side, www.goldspotmusic.com; free.) As it happens, this is only one of three concerts celebrating grime this weekend. Kano is to be the headliner at what looks like a great party tomorrow night at the Knitting Factory, along with a DJ set from Diplo. (At 10, 74 Leonard Street, TriBeCa, (212)219-3006; $12.) And tonight at the Knitting Factory, the grime kingpin Wiley is the headliner at a concert featuring his crew, Roll Deep, alongside DJ A-Trak, DJ Ayres and others. (At 11:30 ; $12.) KELEFA SANNEH THE LISTINGS: AUG. 12 TO AUG. 18

title: Adventures Outside the Classical Canon: Pathfinding Composers
description: It is hard to know, anymore, exactly how to define contemporary Western classical music. How recent does a work have to be? For that matter, how Western does it have to be, with, for example, the stimulating incursions Chinese composers have made in the United States? And does the term "classical" even retain any significance as the music returns to its roots, in a sense, becoming ever more saturated with pop gestures and idioms? However you choose to define it, "serious" music seems livelier and more variegated today than it has in many a decade, a trend the classical music critics of The New York Times are eager not only to acknowledge but also to encourage. And so, with rough justice, we present for your consideration and listening pleasure critics' selections of CD's by a handful of composers who we think deserve broader recognition, however disparate the starting points. They are Olivier Messiaen, Luciano Berio, Alfred Schnittke, John Corigliano and Stephen Hartke. Some are alive, some dead, and there is little to unite them in terms of age or nationality. But you have to start somewhere, and all at least helped set the table for 21st-century music; some are still partaking of the feast. JAMES R. OESTREICH

Then formed partnership with son Elie Hirschfeld in 1976 to develop important residential, commercial, hotel and sport projects throughout New York area, including Hotel Pennsylvania, West Side Rail Yards, Sports Clubs-61 Street, 404 East 55th St, Apt. Towers, 25 Broad St. Tower, Crowne Plaza Hotel, Park Avenue Court, Grand Sutton and many more. Great civic leader. Publisher of NY Post in 1993. Treasurer of NYS Democratic Party. Member of Tristate Regional Planning Commission. Ran for U.S. Senator, NYS Lieutenant Governor and Manhattan Borough President. Elected City Commissioner of Miami Beach in 1989. Devoted husband to Zipora for 63 years.
