description: Play the Chubby Checker classic "The Twist," and most people, whether toddlers or grandparents, can shake their hips through some version of that dance. The rapidly executed, high-flying steps involved in the Lindy Hop, many perfected in the Savoy Ballroom in Harlem, take a bit more skill to master. Whatever your dance ambitions, the Battery Park City Parks Conservancy's "Dancing Through the Decades" program tomorrow evening should satisfy. Felix and All the Cats, a 10-member swing band led by Felix Endico, above, will perform a mix of standards and original compositions from the group's newest album, "At the Rainbow Room," as Bill Kline and Katrine Bangsgaard demonstrate basic steps and call the Charleston, the Lindy Hop, the Twist and the Hustle. All told, it's more than a hundred years' worth of American social dancing and centuries of cumulative musical experience, including the 83-year-old trombonist Eddie Bert, a Benny Goodman alumnus, and the 84-year-old bassist Leonard Gaskin, a Brooklyn native who played with a Who's Who of musical legends on West 52nd Street in Manhattan in its jazz heyday. Mr. Kline and Ms. Bangsgaard, both 92nd Street Y Harkness Dance Center instructors, are also husband and wife, but neither a partner nor experience is needed for interested participants. The conservancy encourages all ages and a communal atmosphere, and large portions of the evening will consist of free-style dancing. So hustle up a few neighbors, dig out those dancing shoes and swing till the sun sets. (Tomorrow from 6:30 to 8 p.m., Esplanade Plaza, at Liberty Street and the Hudson River, Battery Park City, Lower Manhattan, (212)267-9700 or www.bpcparks.org. Free.) title: 'THE ANONYMOUS ARTIST PROJECT II'
description: What's in a name? Where success is measured by name recognition in the right circles, plenty. Name tags also help us to evaluate and interpret work we have not seen before. So to withhold the name of the artist deliberately, as Triple Candie is doing in its current show -- and as it did with a different artist last summer -- is a provocative gesture. Like last year's, this year's artist is well known, said the gallery co-directors, Shelly Bancroft and Peter Nesbett, but for the occasion has done something much different from what he or she is best recognized for. In a style you might call urban arte povera, the artist has evoked a gritty metropolitan ambience. Sneakers wrapped in colored tape and plastic hang from ropes overhead, and low, faux-iron plastic garden fences enclose patches of dirt and litter around existent columns roughly painted brown and tan to resemble trees. Nailed to one long brick wall, large letters cut from carpet, Astroturf and foam spell, "Wouldn't you have thought by now things would be different between us," echoing Rodney King's famous cri de coeur, "Can't we all just get along?" It seems a safe guess that the installation is meant as a poetic comment on race relations, but without knowing the artist's identity, it is hard to be certain. Maybe that uncertainty is a good thing; maybe the absence of a name allows the work to operate on our imaginations less predictably. It is a question worth pondering. (Triple Candie, 461 West 126th Street, Harlem, (212)865-0783, through Sunday.) KEN JOHNSON THE LISTINGS: AUG. 12 TO AUG. 18

description: The ecstasy of creation flows from joy to melancholy in the work of the avant-garde filmmaker Jonas Mekas. For more than half a century, this Lithuanian-born artist has been making intensely personal films (now videos) that testify to the creative durability of Romanticism even as they furnish a richly textured portrait of his adopted home, New York City. Among Mr. Mekas's many achievements, one of the finest remains "Lost, Lost, Lost" (1976), a beautifully constructed diary film consisting of material from three decades, beginning in 1949 and ending in 1963. At once rough-hewn and delicate, marked by jagged edits and held together by the lyrical voice-over of Mr. Mekas, above, this portrait of the artist initially presents him as a young, displaced person trying to carve out room for himself within Brooklyn's immigrant community. It wasn't until Mr. Mekas moved to downtown Manhattan and joined a wilder, woollier tribe, whose members included Allen Ginsberg, Ken Jacobs and LeRoi Jones (before he became Amiri Baraka), that the filmmaker breathed more sympathetic air. Mr. Mekas might never have found a paradise to match the one he lost when he fled Lithuania during World War II. But to watch "Lost, Lost, Lost" is to think that for a time, downtown New York, with its cheap rents and band of bohemians, was as close to heaven as a young artist could get. "Lost, Lost, Lost" will play at Anthology Film Archives, which Mr. Mekas helped found and continues to assist in running, in a newly preserved print. (The film will be shown today through Aug. 18 at Anthology, 32 Second Avenue, at Second Street, East Village, (212)505-5181.) MANOHLA DARGIS THE LISTINGS: AUG. 12 TO AUG. 18

title: Arts, Briefly; Bad Toe Stops Maazel

"It is not a major thing," said Eric Latzky, the spokesman for the New York Philharmonic, where Mr. Maazel, above, is music director. "It involves his toe. I honestly don't know more than that." Mr. Latzky said that the conductor showed no signs of discomfort late last month during the orchestra's residency in Vail, Colo., and that he was expected to join the Philharmonic on Sept. 1 in Frankfurt for the start of a European tour. He was to have conducted the Sydney Symphony on Thursday, next Friday and Aug. 20, 24, 26 and 27. description: A North Brunswick man pleaded guilty to stealing more than $2.1 million from a Linden company where he worked as the comptroller, the Union County prosecutor's office said yesterday. Joseph Antonello, 53, could face up to 10 years in prison when he is sentenced in January for writing checks to himself from a company account. After Mr. Antonello suffered a heart attack this year, officials at the company received calls from creditors about unpaid bills. The company contacted the authorities, who uncovered the theft, including paperwork that indicated Mr. Antonello was paying himself a salary for a 65-week work year. Mr. Antonello was convicted in 1992 for stealing $33,000 from another company. John Holl (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Subway Station To Close
description: The Cortlandt Street station on the R and W lines will close for six months, starting on Aug. 20, to allow construction of a 150-foot underpass as part of the $750 million Fulton Street Transit Center. Trains in both directions will bypass the station until February. The underpass will link the new transit center with PATH trains and with a future development at the World Trade Center. New York City Transit, which announced the closing, advised riders to use four nearby stations: Rector Street and City Hall on the R and W lines, World Trade Center on the E, and the Fulton Street/Broadway-Nassau complex on the A, C, J, M, Z and the 2, 3, 4 and 5 lines. title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Hartford: State Cracks Down On Casino
description: State officials yesterday declared that an online game offered by the Foxwoods Resort Casino was illegal, rejecting the casino's claims that the game was simply a marketing tool, not a form of Internet gambling. The game, PlayAway, started on July 18 and allowed gamblers to buy keno-like tickets at the casino, which is owned by the Mashantucket Pequot Tribal Nation, and then play a game online to find out whether they had winning numbers. Winners could collect prize money only at the casino. Officials with the state's division of special revenue, which regulates gambling, initially shut down the game on July 22, saying it violated federal and state laws against online gambling. title: Arts, Briefly; Aging Smithsonian Gets Its Money From Congress
description: The Smithsonian Institution in Washington is to receive more money from Congress next year, but perhaps not enough to address its greatest need: repairs. Budget appropriations over all will increase to $621.3 million for fiscal year 2006, up from $615.2 million this year, according to the institution's federal budget, released this week. But money for revitalization, planning and construction of facilities will drop to $99.5 million from $126.1 million. Officials said much of the drop is due to the completion of costly renovations of the Patent Office building, built into last year's budget, and that they actually received $9 million more for facilities upkeep than they had requested. Still, the budget announcement comes on the heels of a report by the Government Accountability Office that detailed a "broad decline in the Smithsonian's aging facilities," including water leaks, asbestos problems and other maintenance concerns that threaten collections. The Smithsonian estimates that it will need $2.3 billion over the next nine years to address the problems. Next year's budget may leave the museum complex running behind. LYNETTE CLEMETSON

description: KAPLAN--Hon. Harry V. Died in his Florida home on August 12, 2005. A long-time resident of Sea Gate, Brooklyn, N.Y. He leaves his wife Yetta, daughter Linda Weis, son Gerald and wife Jerilyn, seven grandchildren and four great grandchildren. A graduate of Saint John's Law School, he was admitted to the Supreme Court, Second Department in June 1933. An Administrative Court Judge, Trustee of the Brooklyn Bar Association, and Chairman of its Judiciary Committee, he was Master and District Deputy Grand Master of the Masons' State of New York and Second District of Kings. His generosity of spirit is reflected in his involvements in numerous charities and civic activities including President of the American Jewish Congress, Chairman of the Israel Bond Drive, Chairman of the Interfaith Association of Kings County, member and President of the Local School Board and Eagle Scout. He was an outdoorsman, an amateur artist and extraordinarily devoted to his family. Funeral services private.

title: Arts, Briefly; CBS Takes Thursday
description: Another Thursday, another victory for CBS in Nielsen's estimates. The network was No. 1 in every half-hour in the ratings in both total viewers and adults 18 to 49. On CBS's "Big Brother" (7.6 million), Kaysar Ridha, the schemer booted by his housemates last week, was voted back into the game by the public. Repeats of "CSI," the night's top draw with an audience of 13.54 million, and "Without a Trace" (11.77 million) rounded out the CBS schedule. Elsewhere on the networks, ABC's "Hooking Up" ended its limited run with as little ratings success as its subjects found in the world of online dating. It brought in 4.31 million viewers and placed fourth in the 18-to-49 demographic at 9 p.m. Earlier this week, NBC announced it was shipping its Thursday reality-show flop, "The Law Firm," to Bravo, one of the NBC Universal cable units. In its stead, the network ran repeats of "Will & Grace" (5.2 million) and "Scrubs" (3.89 million). But "CSI" killed those shows, too. KATE AURTHUR

Corrections: For the Record
description: A front page article last Saturday about resistance to the early start of the school year in some areas referred imprecisely to the policies of eight states that regulate starting dates. Seven states -- Iowa, Minnesota, North Carolina, Texas, Virginia, West Virginia and Wisconsin -- set a date for the earliest permissible start, but let districts select a specific day. And four of those states -- Iowa, North Carolina, Texas and Virginia -- grant waivers for earlier starts. Missouri, which used to set a statewide starting date, returned the decision to districts last year.

title: BUSINESS BRIEFS
description: Liability Lawsuit Against Stun Gun Maker Is Dismissed by Court in Arizona Taser International said yesterday that an Arizona court dismissed a wrongful death and product liability lawsuit against the company. The ruling, in the third wrongful death suit against Taser to be dismissed in the last month, sent the company's shares up about 11 percent. In the latest legal action, Taser, which makes stun guns, said the court in Maricopa County ordered a suit against it to be dismissed with prejudice, meaning that the plaintiff would not be able to refile the suit. The suit cited Taser for wrongful death, negligent infliction of emotional distress and product liability. Shares of Taser rose 91 cents, to $9.35. (Reuters)

title: India's Industrial Output Jumped 11.7% in June

Manufacturing, which makes up more than three quarters of industrial production, rose 12.5 percent in June compared with 8.1 percent in the month a year ago. Production of consumer goods like televisions and washing machines soared 23.7 percent. Saritha Rai (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Newark: Guard Accused Of Smuggling Drugs
description: For the third time in two months, Essex County authorities have charged a guard with smuggling drugs into the county jail and selling them to inmates. Authorities said on Friday that the latest culprit was Jay Griggs, 35, a correction officer who worked at the jail for 10 years. According to the police, Officer Griggs was arrested on Wednesday night lugging trash bags full of marijuana, heroin, cocaine, cigarettes, rolling papers and other contraband into the jail. The scheme, prosecutors said, involved a jailed drug dealer, Jibreel Williams, who placed orders over the telephone to his girlfriend, Janie K. Singletary, in suburban Orange. Officer Griggs then picked up the drugs and contraband at Ms. Singletary's home and smuggled them into the jail, prosecutors said. Officer Griggs has been charged with official misconduct and drug possession and conspiracy. Mr. Williams, 25, and Ms. Singletary, 31, face similar charges. All three remain in jail. Jeffrey Gettleman (NYT)

description: Vernon Welker, a 59-year-old from Salton City, Calif., who was arrested Thursday night near the United Nations for having loaded guns and a knife in his car, will be held without bail for a month, a Manhattan Criminal Court judge ordered yesterday. Mr. Welker spoke out several times in court, at one point asking who owned the United Nations building, prompting the judge, Donna Recant, to order a psychological evaluation. Mr. Welker was charged with three counts of illegal weapons possession, after authorities spotted a pistol and a rifle, both loaded, in his car near 2 United Nations Plaza. He told the authorities that he had the right to protect himself from terrorists, prosecutors said. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HIRSCHFELD, ABRAHAM
description: HIRSCHFELD--Abraham Made history and will be remembered dearly by family and friends. Born in Poland in 1919. Moved to Israel in 1933. Later joined Haganah to fight for Israeli independence. Emigrated to United States in 1950. Builder of parking facilities throughout Metro area and became affectionately known as the "garage king" of New York. Then formed partnership with son Elie Hirschfeld in 1976 to develop important residential, commercial, hotel and sport projects throughout New York area, including Hotel Pennsylvania, West Side Rail Yards, Sports Clubs-61 Street, 404 East 55th St, Apt. Towers, 25 Broad St. Tower, Crowne Plaza Hotel, Park Avenue Court, Grand Sutton and many more. Great civic leader. Publisher of NY Post in 1993. Treasurer of NYS Democratic Party. Member of Tristate Regional Planning Commission. Ran for U.S. Senator, NYS Lieutenant Governor and Manhattan Borough President. Elected City Commissioner of Miami Beach in 1989. Devoted husband to Zipora for 63 years. Survived by son Elie Hirschfeld and wife Dr. Susan Hirschfeld; daughter Rachel Hirschfeld; brother Menashe and wife Judith Hirschfeld; eight grandchildren and three great grandchildren.

title: 'Migration': The Solemn Art

Like most ascetics, Merwin is a seducer: his poems invite submission to a pared-down, essences-only view of the world, suggesting that any other way would be square, or, given Merwin's disdain for the human ''species-ego,'' bad for the planet. Merwin has long lived on a pineapple farm in Hawaii, meticulously restoring his acres to their ancient beauty and, one imagines, opening his mail: from his distant vista he's watched nearly every honor of the poetry world flutter his way.

They had reunited for this lone gig as a tribute, benefit and possible farewell to CBGB, the club that could face eviction in September after nearly 32 years on the Bowery. Some are straight-out commands, like "First, Break All the Rules" and "Now, Discover Your Strengths." Others pose quirky metaphorical questions: "How Full Is Your Bucket?" or "Who Moved My Cheese?" Several of them trumpet forth a kind of numerological majesty: "The 8th Habit," "The Five Dysfunctions of a Team." All lay claim to the almost infinite territory of "work and life," as in the "Cheese" subtitle, "An A-Mazing Way to Deal With Change in Your Work and in Your Life." Clearly you are not in the literature section, or even ordinary diet and mood-boosting self-help; this is the bustling genre of business success books, descended from Dale Carnegie's mid-20th-century oeuvre and ready to transform you into a C.E.O. now.

description: SIMON--Helen K. (Flowers), of Manhattan, died peacefully on August 12, 2005, at the age of 94. Wife of the late H. Theodore Simon of New York, and secondly of the late James P. Flowers. She is survived by her only child, her daughter Elaine Simon Ward (Mrs. Ralph E. Ward) of Darien, CT, and London. Born in Quogue, LI, she was a former Trustee of the Mannes College of Music in New York. From 1948 until the early 1960's she and her husband Theodore Simon designed and created handwrought sterling silver objects in a workshop in their townhouse. Their work is represented in the permanent collections of The Museum of the City of New York and the CooperHewitt Museum. Funeral Mass at the Church of St. Thomas More, 65 E. 89th St, NYC, on Saturday, August 20th, at 10 AM. Burial will be private. title: PHOTO-OP
An Islamic Alienation
description: Even if they produced no other positive result, the attacks on the London Underground have compelled Europeans of all faiths to think with new urgency about the Continent's Muslim minority. Such a reckoning was long overdue. Some left-wing politicians, like London's mayor, Ken Livingstone, have chosen to emphasize the proximate causes of Muslim anger, focusing on the outrage widely felt in Islamic immigrant communities over the war in Iraq and the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. But the harsh reality is that the crisis in relations between the European mainstream and the Islamic diaspora has far deeper roots, consoling as it might be to pretend otherwise.

Rather than navigating temperature-controlled aisles under hazy skylights, shoppers meander along a tree-lined street where it is possible to see the setting sun. Rather than a Starbucks, there is Coffee Talk. And instead of uniform signs for the Gap and Wal-Mart there are one-of-a-kind ones above the henna tattoo parlor, Neptune Gifts and the Free Shop boutique.

The chimpanzees retired under the Chimp Act, with federal funds, are still owned by the National Institutes of Health and might therefore be returned to research. At Save the Chimps, we believe retirement should be permanent -- the chimps we care for will never be allowed to go back to research labs.

Coming Home
description: Tallahassee, Fla. - IT was raining when I stepped off the plane and into a chilly Georgia morning. The line of soldiers, heads down, struggled underneath the weight of their gear across the tarmac and into a long, low building full of Red Cross coffee and doughnuts. Along the way a general stood shaking hands and exchanging salutes with the returning soldiers. Next to him, a young lieutenant shivered as he held an umbrella out at arm's length over the general. Neither had combat patches on their uniforms, and I splashed by without saluting or shaking hands. It gave little satisfaction.

description: SCHWARTZ--Joel. Professor of History at Montclair State University, died Wednesday, August 10, 2005, of complications of leukemia. He was 62. Professor Schwartz received his BA, MA and PhD from the University of Chicago. He taught at Roosevelt University and the University of Illinois, Chicago Circle, as well as Brooklyn College, before teaching for over 30 years at Montclair State. He wrote "The New York Approach" and a major part of "The Empire State" and compiled "An Illustrated Guide to Public Housing" for the LaGuardia and Wagner Archives Photo Exhibit, which appears on the Internet. He is survived by his wife of 35 years, Bonnie Fox Schwartz, two children, Marjorie Schwartz Poulos of Chicago and David J. Schwartz of NY, and a brother, Robert Schwartz also of NY. The funeral will be private. A memorial service is being planned for after Labor Day. Always receptive, supportive, wise and deeply affectionate father of Andrea, Robert and James. Adored grandfather of Simon, Lily and Rosalie and father-in-law of David, Susan, and Audrey. title: WHY WE TRAVEL: METROPOLIS, ILL.
description: AT THE 27th ANNUAL SUPERMAN CELEBRATION, JUNE 11, 2005 -- Ryan Beyer, 26, a graphic designer from Paducah, Ky. "No phone booths around, what do you do? As a kid I used to take pajamas, and mix and match them to try to come up with a super costume. This was the first time I dressed up as Superman as an adult. I was taking pictures with young and old alike, people coming up and saying 'Hey, Superman, can I have your picture? Hey, Superman, can I have your autograph.' There were little kids there saying 'Can you fly? Can you run real fast? Can you do tricks of strength?' It was sort of intoxicating: you're just wearing spandex for the most part, and people still had that respect. There's a lot of reverence for Superman in Metropolis." As told to Seth Kugel

title: The Belle Curve
description: At Christian Dior, where the house is celebrating what would have been the venerable matre's 100th birthday, the designer John Galliano let it all hang out. With a wink to Dior's New Look, he based his entire fall haute couture collection upon a trompe l'oeil corset. This strange nude undergarment -- part girdle, part armor -- reshaped his cast of runway models into an army of walking dress forms upon which Galliano pinned a lesson in fashion history. Galliano's strategy was to draw attention to what goes on behind the seams (even punctuating the statement with wrist corsages made from pincushions). And indeed, his collection ultimately served as a reminder that the real beauty of haute couture is on the inside. The same could be said at Chanel, where Karl Lagerfeld hid all the pyrotechnics in the linings of his coats only to turn them inside out.

title: New York on the Never, Never
description: New York's Constitution makes it clear that in all but a few cases, the state needs taxpayer approval to go into debt. But the rules are not working. New York's debt has risen to $49 billion in 2005, and voters have approved only about 10 percent of it. Albany's politicians have become very adept at borrowing behind our backs. The state's long-term financial security depends on our making them stop.

title: Awash in Information, Patients Face a Lonely, Uncertain Road
description: Nothing Meg Gaines endured had prepared her for this moment. Not the six rounds of chemotherapy for ovarian cancer that had metastasized to her liver. Not the doctor who told her, after Ms. Gaines was prepped for surgery, that he could not operate: a last-minute scan revealed too many tumors. "Go home and think about the quality, not the quantity, of your days," he said.

description: Heidi Theresa Wasson, a daughter of Betsy Pal of Surry, Me., and Steve Wasson of Ellsworth, Me., was married yesterday to William Joshua Wailand, a son of Adele and George Wailand of New York. Judge Dennis Jacobs of the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit in New York officiated at the tannery building at the Mount Lebanon Shaker Village, a museum in New Lebanon, N.Y. The bride and bridegroom graduated from Harvard, she cum laude and he magna cum laude. They met on a weeklong field trip to a biological research station in central Florida as part of a course in ecology and land-use planning.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KAPLAN, HON. HARRY V.
description: KAPLAN--Hon. Harry V. Died in his Florida home on August 12, 2005. A long-time resident of Sea Gate, Brooklyn, N.Y. He leaves his wife Yetta, daughter Linda Weis, son Gerald and wife Jerilyn, seven grandchildren and four great grandchildren. A graduate of Saint John's Law School, he was admitted to the Supreme Court, Second Department in June 1933. An Administrative Court Judge, Trustee of the Brooklyn Bar Association, and Chairman of its Judiciary Committee, he was Master and District Deputy Grand Master of the Masons' State of New York and Second District of Kings. His generosity of spirit is reflected in his involvements in numerous charities and civic activities including President of the American Jewish Congress, Chairman of the Israel Bond Drive, Chairman of the Interfaith Association of Kings County, member and President of the Local School Board and Eagle Scout. He was an outdoorsman, an amateur artist and extraordinarily devoted to his family. Funeral services private.

title: THE WEEK AHEAD: Aug. 14-Aug. 20; FILM
description: The mainstreaming of pornography is such a modern clich that even a mention of the phenomenon seems so last millennium. Much of the porning of our culture is ornamental, as empty of threat as a suburban teenager in a "Porn Star" T-shirt. Less debatable is the idea that commercial success domesticated pornography, as evidenced by one of the genre's earlier and tawdrier specimens, "DEEP THROAT." Bankrolled by mob associates, this 1972 crime against celluloid starred the hapless LINDA LOVELACE (ne Boreman) as a good-time gal with a bizarre anatomical anomaly. Unspeakably, hilariously, tediously bad, the flick hit the zeitgeist like a hydrogen bomb, clearing the way for porno chic. The Pioneer Theater is showing "Deep Throat" Saturday at midnight. Two Boots Pioneer Theater, 155 East Third Street, East Village, (212)591-0434.

title: Australia: Muslims Rein in a Cleric
description: With its largely homogeneous population -- 92 percent Caucasian; 65 percent Christian; fewer Muslims than Buddhists -- Australia would seem an unlikely place for Islamic extremists. But after the London bombings, Australia's prime minister, John Howard, has joined Britain in suggesting that new laws might be needed to deal with Islamic extremists, including deportation of clerics who preach violence.

title: The Keyboard Trade

More revealing, perhaps, was that 8 of the 35 competitors in the Cliburn were from China, the most of any country.

title: Italy: Deport, Then Deport More

And in November 2003, the imam, Abdel Kader Fadlallah Mamour, was deported to his native Senegal from his home near Turin -- the first time Italy used a law allowing the expulsion of radical imams. An additional seven Muslims termed as extremists were also expelled then, following a crackdown in Italy after an attack in Iraq killed 19 Italian soldiers.

title: The Sound and the Fury
description: SALZBURG, Austria - CULTURAL festivals do not get much more glamorous than the one that takes place every summer in this immaculately preserved Baroque city. At the opera here two weeks ago, the audience included men in sleek tuxedos and women in gowns that evoked the splendor of imperial ages past. You might have imagined that they were streaming in for some music by Mozart, the local hero, but this summer Salzburg opened its festival on a different, more complex note. Austria's elite was turning out for a dark opera called "The Branded," by Franz Schreker.

title: A Montreal Troupe Kicks Off Its Dusty Toe Shoes

True, it produced the popular rock ballet "Tommy" in 1970, and its repertory contained work by internationally recognized ballet choreographers. But for the most part the company, founded in 1957 and based in Montreal, seemed more worthy than exciting.

From school-prayer advocates to creationists, there is no shortage of those who see religion and government as two inseparable sides of the same coin.

title: Iraqi Game Plan
description: If you're unhappy about the way things are going in Iraq or Afghanistan, you can grumble, you can protest, you can even vote. But Kuma Reality Games, a Manhattan-based maker of downloadable computer games, has lately offered another option: you can refight the battles yourself, from the comfort of your couch. In the last 18 months the company has churned out more then 50 games set on the ground in such war zones (as well as a popular re-creation of a Vietnam War Swift boat mission involving John Kerry; it was released before the election last fall). Kuma manages this -- in an industry where games typically take millions of dollars and several years to produce -- by working the way studios produce television shows. The eight-person staff uses a rotating cast of outside programmers and production companies, usually creating a new game in three days to three weeks.

Meanwhile, another group of singers, who might claim to answer a slightly higher calling, will be in Dallas this week for "Gospel Dream 2005," a reality competition show that begins this fall on the Gospel Music Channel. As on "American Idol" contestants on "Gospel Dream," like Malinda Gholson, below, will compete for a recording contract before audiences and a panel of judges. But the similarities end there. description: Art and life cross paths unexpectedly in the excellent Sundance Channel series "Slings & Arrows," a satire of the backstage shenanigans and conspiracies at a Canadian Shakespeare festival that should be reason enough for theater fans to pay for cable. In next Sunday's episode, Holly Day (Jennifer Irwin), the villainous face of the American corporate sponsor (shudder!), reveals her plan to sell more tickets. Forget boring old Shakespeare: she is working on acquiring the rights to a musical about the life of John Lennon. "I've already talked to Yoko," she says, giddily. In real life, her dream has come true, of course: "LENNON," written and directed by Don Scardino -- who really did talk to Yoko Ono -- opens at the Broadhurst Theater today. The musical received less-than-enthusiastic reviews during its out-of-town run in San Francisco, but it has been retooled for the Broadway opening, which was recently postponed 10 days to allow more time to work out the kinks. Fans can expect familiar hits along with unreleased songs like "India, India" and "I Don't Want to Lose You." Holly Day would be pleased. Broadhurst Theater, 235 West 44th Street, (212)239-6200. ("Slings & Arrows" runs Sundays at 8 p.m.)

title: Nonfiction Chronicle
description: CINDERELLA MAN: James J. Braddock, Max Baer, and the Greatest Upset in Boxing History. By Jeremy Schaap. (Houghton Mifflin, $24.) One of several recent books about the Depression-era boxer James J. Braddock, including another with the same title, Schaap's biography serves as a helpful corrective to the mawkish biopic from Ron Howard. Schaap, an anchor and reporter for ESPN, at first can't get the TV hyperbole out of his voice ("the decline in his personal fortunes mirrored the national collapse, perhaps more than that of any other American"). But eventually, he settles down and spins out the story of the man who went from the dole to boxing's biggest crown. Richer, however, is the tale of Max Baer, the conflicted champion whom Braddock defeated for the title. A playboy haunted by the death of at least one opponent, Baer fought for money and fame more than pride and family. His Jewishness, glanced at in Howard's film, became a rallying point (and a marketing tool), especially in his bout with the Nazis' hero, the German fighter Max Schmeling. Baer deserves at least one book and film of his own.

A trim man with the oddly pale suntan of someone who spends every day in the sun lathered up with industrial-grade sunblock, he wore a rumpled cream shirt, disintegrating khaki slacks and bizarre yellow plastic clogs -- cartoon shoes -- that are now the cutting edge of gung-go fishing footwear.

title: Knockoff Originals
description: Wegmans Basting Oil Every shopper knows the drill: you're at the supermarket or the drugstore or the big-box discount center, and on the shelves, right next to the brand-name cereal or pain reliever or detergent, you notice an alternative product that looks pretty similar. Only it lacks the familiar name and happens to be quite a bit cheaper. This is the "generic" version -- or the "store brand," or the "private-label product," depending on who is describing it. The increased popularity of private-label products has been cited as evidence that consumer loyalty to "real" brands is on the wane. But there is a substantial subcategory of the private-label universe that doesn't exactly support that thesis: goods that retailers create not as de facto knockoffs but as original inventions.

title: Needed Up the Road: Guardians
description: MARGE ELIKER has been taking care of her daughter for 49 years. Debbie Eliker, who has Down syndrome, still needs help with things like bathing and brushing her teeth. She can't manage her money on her own, and when she wants to head out to a social occasion, she needs a ride.

title: 'I Didn't Do It for You'
description: Whenever I land in Asmara, a novel read in adolescence comes to mind. It tells the story of a small plane whose pilot turns hijacker. Crash-landing in a remote part of the Himalayas, he dies of his injuries before he can explain his bizarre actions to the dazed passengers. They emerge from the wreckage to be greeted by a wizened old monk, who leads them to a citadel hidden above the peaks, a secret city whose existence has never been recorded on any map. They are welcomed to Shangri-La, where, breathing the chill air that wafts from the glaciers and surveying the world from a tremendous height, they begin reassessing their lives with the same calm detachment and cosmic clarity as the monks. But as time goes by, they learn they must make a terrible choice. They can stay in Shangri-La and live forever, for their hosts have discovered something approaching the secret of eternal youth. Or they can plunge back into the hurly-burly of the life they knew and eventually die as ordinary mortals, grubbing around down on the plains.

title: Mets Sweat the Small Stuff, and the Result Is a Big Victory
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 13 - Starting pitcher Jae Seo called for the ball. So did first baseman Marlon Anderson. They met between the mound and the first-base line, Anderson's left leg and Seo's right leg a frightening tangle of limbs.

title: The Single That Wouldn't Stay in the Closet
description: Instead of writing a single to promote his new album, R. Kelly did something grandiose even by pop music standards: he wrote five. "Trapped in the Closet," Parts 1-5 -- a slow-jam soap opera in which a love triangle expands into a love hexagon over five lurid songs, or chapters -- is a mini-epic, and it forced the marketing minds at Jive Records to think as creatively as Mr. Kelly. "It was a very interesting idea," said Roberta Magrini, one of his publicists. "But we didn't know how we were going to work it." Jive decided to release only three of the five chapters to radio. The third would arrive when the album, "TP.3: Reloaded," reached stores, encouraging fans to buy the album to find out what finally happened.

title: Living in Poverty Never Looked So Good
description: NOTHING warms the heart like two beautiful, rich young people pretending to be poor. Especially if they're beautifully dressed, as they are in the Goodspeed's new production of "The Boy Friend," directed by Julie Andrews. The first musical number, "Perfect Young Ladies," is sung by four actresses in matching flapper dresses and hats -- one pink, one blue, one yellow and one apricot. When the show's would-be lovers meet on the beach, he is in a blue-striped jacket, her dress is light blue, and their giant beach umbrella is an aqua-and-white stripe.

title: Two Steps Toward a Sensible Immigration Policy
description: San Antonio - What do you say to the working-class guy from the south side of San Antonio? He feels his wages are stagnating because he has to compete against illegal immigrants. He watches thousands of people streaming across the border, bankrupting his schools and health care system, while he plays by the rules.

title: Correction

It was the Clean Air Act, not the Clean Water Act.

"We will stay the course," he insistently tells us from his Texas ranch. What do you mean we, white man?

title: DEALS & DISCOUNTS
description: OFF-SEASON NANTUCKET -- After Labor Day, being 50 or older will mean steep discounts for guests at the Jared Coffin House -- actually a complex of five historic buildings -- on the Massachusetts island of Nantucket. Its 50/50 program offers a 50 percent savings when at least one guest is 50 or older. This means from Sept. 5 to Oct. 9, 50/50 rooms will start at $112 a night for a room with a full-size bed (though all types of rooms are eligible for the discount). After Oct. 10, rooms start at $60. Taxes of 9.7 percent are extra. All rates are for Sunday through Thursday nights, although there are some blackout dates. Guests must show proof of age. Reservations can be made only by phone; call (800) 248-2405. Details are available on the Web at www.jaredcoffinhouse.com.

title: Other Great Artists of the Samurai Epic
description: THE Film Forum's bracingly sanguinary "Summer Samurai" series is, among other things, a useful reminder that before Chinese martial artists became iconic figures for Western action-movie aficionados, stern, unsmiling Japanese swordsmen were pretty much all we knew about Eastern styles of violence and the rigorous codes that governed them. We learned much of this, of course, from the peerless Akira Kurosawa, five of whose pictures (including the greatest of them all, the 1954 "Seven Samurai") are in this 15-film series. But for many of Film Forum's patrons, I suspect, the revelation of the four-week extravaganza, which starts Friday, will be the fiercely beautiful work of Masaki Kobayashi. His two movies here, "Harakiri" (1962) and "Samurai Rebellion" (1967), are amazing: stirring, subversive and, beneath their dauntingly severe surfaces, sneakily lyrical.

title: UP FRONT
description: Francine Prose, the author of 13 books of fiction -- and the review of a biography of Eudora Welty on Page 21 -- says she thinks of herself as "a novelist who happens to do other things." Along with plenty of book reviewing, those things include journalism and critical essays, travel writing, translating and editing, and, in the past few years, art criticism. In a recent conversation, she explained that she has always followed her own curiosity when deciding what to tackle next, whether it's a novel about religious devotion ("Household Saints") or a fictional dissection of academic politics ("Blue Angel"). She hasn't steered away from difficult subjects -- her novel "A Changed Man" features a sympathetic skinhead and a self-absorbed Holocaust survivor -- and she seems to thrive on the pressure of deadlines: her biography of Caravaggio is coming this fall; "Reading Like a Writer" ("about learning to write by reading great literature instead of attending another writing workshop") is scheduled for next year; and she's deep into another novel. Although she never met Welty and their lives are vastly different, Prose (a married New Yorker, the mother of two sons) understands how frustrating it was for Welty to have been pigeonholed as a kind of mythic Southern maiden aunt: "You get stuck with a label -- social satirist is mine -- and it's hard to be seen in a different way. I was surprised to learn that the supposedly reclusive Eudora Welty traveled more widely and had a better social life than I do." The Editors

title: THE WEEK AHEAD: Aug.14-Aug. 20; POP/JAZZ
description: Of all the stars created in the glorious period of country music excess from the late 1960's to the late 80's, DOLLY PARTON, has probably been the best at reading the winds, for good and ill. When bluegrass audiences became more catholic in taste in the 90's, she threw down a few excellent albums of old-timey sounding repertory with Celtic leanings. More recently, in honor of our troops abroad, she issued a cornpone explosion titled "For God and Country." On Thursday, she appears at Radio City Music Hall, where she'll introduce some material from a coming album, "Those Were the Days." The CD is built around a hippieish set of 60's and 70's folk and pop standards, and it is reported to include Norah Jones, Yusuf Islam (the former Cat Stevens), Kris Kristofferson, Keith Urban, Judy Collins, Roger McGuinn and Sean Lennon. At Radio City, she'll play her own songs of the past, too, from a catalog that includes classics like "Jolene" and "Traveling Man." Thursday at 8 p.m., Radio City Music Hall, 1260 Avenue of the Americas, at 50th Street, $39.50-$74.50.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GROEL, CAMPBELL CLARK JR.
description: GROEL--Campbell Clark Jr. Of Vero Beach and Martha's Vineyard, died on August 11, 2005, in Royal Palm Convalescent Center, Vero Beach, FL, after a brief illness. He was born February 16, 1914, in Orange, NJ. Campbell was a graduate of Lawrenceville Academy and Princeton University class of 1936. Shortly after graduation from college he joined the Army and obtained the rank of Captain while piloting transport planes over "The Hump" to China. After his military service he joined his father in the family business, "Port Warehouse," based in the Tribeca section of New York City. This led to a long and successful career in real estate investments until his retirement in 1986. He never lost his love of flying and piloted private planes until he was 82. Surviving are his wife of 22 years, Eleanor Groel of Vero Beach and Martha's Vineyard; stepsons, Don Reese, Hunter Corbin and Peter Corbin; stepdaughter, Sally R. Anderson; seven grandchildren and five great-grandchildren. He was preceded in death by his first wife Elizabeth M. Corbin in 1981. In lieu of flowers the family would appreciate donations to your favorite charity in Campbell's memory. For information, contact Strunk Funeral Home, Vero Beach.

title: Comings and Goings
description: CONTINENTAL AIRLINES has changed its checked-bags policy for international travel. Passengers can check two pieces of baggage, each with a maximum weight of 50 pounds, for no charge, the same as for domestic flights. Starting Sept. 7, passengers to most destinations will be charged $25 for each bag weighing more than 50 pounds, but less than 70. The charge for a bag between 70 and 100 pounds to most destinations is $75. Information: (800)523-3273 or www.continental.com. SWEDEN has become the latest European country to ban smoking in its cafes, restaurants and nightclubs, joining Ireland, Italy, Malta, Montenegro, and Norway. Now, 21-year-olds can rent a car from AVIS or BUDGET, although they must pay an additional $25 a day. The new policy from Avis and Budget lowers the minimum age to rent a car from 25 to 21 in most locations. In Washington, D.C.; Connecticut; Idaho; Iowa; and northwestern New Jersey (including Newark Airport), renters still must be at least 25. And in New York, the old rules still apply: drivers between 18 and 24 are charged an additional $110 each day at Avis and an additional $115 at Budget. MARJORIE CONNELLY

title: The Ethicist and The Rabbi
description: The Ethicist's advice (July 17) to the interfaith couple who were not completely forthright in expressing an intention to create a Jewish home and the Reform rabbi's response (Letters, July 31) prompted me to write. The rabbi writes that a rabbi's role is "to make sacred those unions that strengthen the hope for our collective Jewish future." To this I would add that the future can be difficult to discern. Interfaith (Protestant-Catholic) marriages have been common in my family. Often priests have declined to officiate unless certain concessions were made or have refused to permit Protestant clergy members to have a role in the service. This is their right. However, it may be shortsighted to turn people away from the religion they grew up with at a joyous milestone of their lives. It causes lingering bitterness and erects one more barrier against the return to religious practice.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DETMOLD, GEORGE ERNST
description: DETMOLD--George Ernst. 88 died August 12, 2005 at home in St. Augustine, FL. Born February 18, 1917, in New York City, he was the son of George Justus and Mabel Porter Detmold. A 1938 graduate of Cornell University, where he captained the fencing team and coached its saber men, he earned the AB, AM, and PhD degrees there before joining the Army during World War II. Commissioned in Ordnance, he was sent to the Chinese Language School at Yale University before overseas assignment to the X Force of the Chinese Training and Combat Command, serving in Ramgarh, India, along the Ledo Road into Burma, and in China's Yunan Province. At war's end, Lieutenant Detmold returned to Cornell as Instructor in English and Assistant Dean of the College of Arts and Sciences, before moving up Cayuga Lake to teach English at Wells College in Aurora, NY. After completing a course in higher educational administration at Columbia University's Teachers College, he became Dean of Gallaudet College in Washington, DC, which awarded him an honorary LittD degree in 1996. Meanwhile, he carried on an avocational career in non-commercial theatre, directing more than 200 productions with college students and amateur actors in community theatres. He also designed Gallaudet's first theatre building. Realizing the dramatic power of sign language, he directed a series of classical dramas in sign language, including Hamlet, Othello, Macbeth, Oedipus the King, The Trojan Women, Iphigenia in Aulis, and Medea. The student actors in these critically acclaimed productions, with the support of the Eugene O'Neill Memorial Foundation, went on to form the world-renowned National Theatre of the Deaf. After retiring, Mr. Detmold moved to St. Augustine in 1976. He leaves his wife, Louise, a son and daughter-in-law, Christopher and Dorrit, of St. Augustine; two stepsons, Eugene Y. Willis III and Dr. Amos Johns Willis of Fredericksburg, VA; a granddaughter, Maya, and great-granddaughter, Zoe, of Newport News, VA; a brother, John, of Leeds, MA; six nephews and five nieces. Burial will be in Arlington National Cemetery on a date to be determined. Memorial gifts may be made to the Drama Department at Gallaudet University.

A poet and a philosopher as well as a painter, Chi's object was to bring the whole of his personality into his paintings, reflecting not only his visual interpretation but the entire range of his emotions, spirit and intellect. His works are included in such museums as The Metropolitan Museum of Art, NYC, The Butler Museum of American Art, Youngstown, Ohio, Chen Chi Museum, Jiao Tong University, Shanghai, Chen Chi Museum in Wuxi. There is currently an exhibition at the National Art Museum of China in Beijing. The only artist chosen to exhibit at the First World Cultural Summit in Versailles; recipient of many awards, medals & honors; member of numerous prestigious clubs and organizations in the US & China. title: THE WEEK AHEAD: Aug.14-Aug. 20; DANCE
description: The last chances to see some lively dance events are coming up. HUBBARD STREET DANCE CHICAGO, an unusually lively contemporary company, is in its final week at the Joyce Theater. Purists may sniff a bit at the way the troupe blurs the conventional boundaries between ballet, modern and jazz dance. But anyone interested in the ways dance can expand its horizons may be curious to see what Hubbard Street is up to. And audiences of all aesthetic persuasions will surely find the dancers remarkably versatile, capable of bounding with the utmost ease between a variety of styles. The Joyce season offers works by Jim Vincent, Lucas Crandall, Daniel Ezralow, Lar Lubovitch, Nacho Duato, Ohad Naharin and Christopher Bruce. And the accompaniments range from Baroque music by Vivaldi and contemporary scores by Leonard Bernstein and Arvo Prt to pop standards like "Smoke Gets in Your Eyes" and "Nature Boy" and songs by the Rolling Stones. Tomorrow through Friday at 8 p.m., Saturday at 2 and 8 p.m., Joyce Theater, 175 Eighth Avenue, at 19th Street, Chelsea, (212)242-0800 or www.joyce.org, $42.

description: Those who think that the hip, publicity-obsessed hedonist is a new figure in New York architecture should take a stroll through the current show on NORMAN JAFFE at the Parrish Art Museum in Southampton through Sept. 18. Jaffe, whose model good looks can be seen on the catalog's cover, where he lounges in a tweed jacket and turtleneck, helped define the cool neo-Modernist style of a certain late-1960's Long Island milieu. But his houses were more than fashionable settings for cocktail parties, creepy bachelors and dysfunctional postwar families. Stripped down and decorated with wood shingles, sunken living rooms and stone fireplaces, they blend vanity and romance in a way that was particular to that era, and they even exhibit occasional signs of a modest architectural talent. 25 Job's Lane, Southampton, N.Y., (631)283-2118.

title: Inside the List
description: HE SAID, SHE SAID: This week, we witness a rare phenomenon on the list: a couple with his-and-hers best sellers. Bill Maher's "New Rules: Polite Musings From a Timid Observer" makes its debut at No. 10 on the nonfiction list, where it joins "Confessions of a Video Vixen," a memoir written by his significant other, Karrine Steffans, which is at No. 6 after five weeks on the list. "Confessions of a Video Vixen" charts Steffans's life from her troubled girlhood in St. Thomas to her stint as an exotic dancer and a dancer in music videos. Her account of her sexcapades with music industry personalities and professional athletes has caused quite a stir in some circles. "We've had to listen to rappers brag about their conquests for ages in their music," Jawn Murray, a columnist for America Online's "Black Voices," told The Times. "Karrine is the first female to flip the script and brag about her conquests with actual names, and that's making a lot -- and I do mean a lot -- of people uncomfortable." Steffans bares all about her liaisons with many men, including Ja Rule, of the hip-hop collective Murder Inc., and Shaquille O'Neal. But this prodigal daughter's story seems to have a happy ending. "I still enjoy an exciting lifestyle with celebrity colleagues, friends and lovers," she writes. "The difference is that now I am my own woman and look for no one to complete me." Not even, it would seem, Bill Maher.

title: Finding the Sleeper Cells
description: The British experience this summer has lessons for us about finding terrorist sleeper cells. The British bombers were of diverse origins: Pakistani, Jamaican, Somali, Eritrean. Most were raised in England. At least two of the terrorists were married and had small children. The bombs were literally made in a bathtub with store-bought components. Although radicalized in British mosques, the bombers appeared to lead normal lives, one as a special-education teacher. At least three had traveled to Pakistan, where they were instructed by radical jihadists. These trips did not, apparently, come to the attention of the British government. Indeed, the bombers were essentially unknown to British antiterrorism authorities. One was known only as an associate of someone on the periphery of a previous, foiled plot.

title: Fair Affair?
description: I always find The Ethicist (July 31) interesting. However, the response to the woman who wondered if it was O.K. to cheat on her husband, who had been unable to have sex for the previous 10 years, was deeply saddening. The endorsement of her affair with a married man was not only unethical but also hurtful to all concerned. What about the married man's family? What about the bond between the woman and her husband, whatever the circumstances? Has sex become something so lacking in real intimacy and yet so important as a biological urge that it can replace trust, commitment, honor and love? I was grateful the woman heeded her own sense of ethics and ended the affair.

title: Fiction Chronicle
description: MAN CAMP. By Adrienne Brodeur. (Random House, $21.95.) This first novel by the founding editor of Zoetrope: All-Story is fantasy fiction for wealthy, young, soulless Manhattan-dwelling women with Lady Chatterley tendencies. Brodeur's two heroines, sporting red lipstick, blas anti-intellectualism and a yen for slumming, click their heels and return -- gratefully -- to a time preceding the women's movement. Before whisking her rapidly regressing girlfriends off to the country, Brodeur takes a few potshots at city types; for example, "hipsters from the art world" who have "unwashed hair, scuffed shoes and untucked shirttails." Couldn't we be a tad more specific? Hooked up to an iPod playing the Arcade Fire? Dutifully on their way to the Film Forum? Chortling over Vice magazine? We're supposed to side with the smug, well-heeled heroines against artsy types, as well as against all modern urban men who can't put up shelves or chop wood. Convinced that feminism ruined dating, the women wish all men were like their farmer friend, Cooper: "He holds doors and carries things, and it never feels patronizing. It feels natural." To convert sushi-nibbling sissies into bacon-scarfing alpha males, the women start a retreat on Cooper's farm. There the gentlemen repair fences and the ladies play damsels in distress (literally, in a game where they pretend to get lost). Predictably, the men develop great tans, the women are enveloped in strong arms, and readers learn why 1960's-era feminists are appalled by the "Sex and the City" generation.

title: THE WEEK AHEAD: Aug. 14-Aug. 20; FILM
description: The mainstreaming of pornography is such a modern clich that even a mention of the phenomenon seems so last millennium. Much of the porning of our culture is ornamental, as empty of threat as a suburban teenager in a "Porn Star" T-shirt. Less debatable is the idea that commercial success domesticated pornography, as evidenced by one of the genre's earlier and tawdrier specimens, "DEEP THROAT." Bankrolled by mob associates, this 1972 crime against celluloid starred the hapless LINDA LOVELACE (ne Boreman) as a good-time gal with a bizarre anatomical anomaly. Unspeakably, hilariously, tediously bad, the flick hit the zeitgeist like a hydrogen bomb, clearing the way for porno chic. The Pioneer Theater is showing "Deep Throat" Saturday at midnight. Two Boots Pioneer Theater, 155 East Third Street, East Village, (212)591-0434.

title: A Second Womb
description: Even before Heidelise Als escorted me into the intensive-care unit for newborns at Children's Hospital in Boston, she began to whisper. Als understands, as much as anyone, that premature infants are fragile creatures and that even the smallest noise or disruption can overload their still-developing plum-size brains. Stepping gently, she led me to a tiny boy lying on his back in a plastic bed no bigger than a briefcase. He was surrounded by a tangled nest of wires, tubes and hoses, a respirator and other lifesaving devices. As we watched, a nurse arrived and fumbled with an IV needle; she grabbed one of the baby's tiny, almost translucent heels and stretched his leg in the air to give herself room to work. The baby tried to retract his leg. He started to cry.

title: Meanwhile, People Starve
description: Were it not for Hilary Andersson, a BBC television journalist, Niger's starving people would very likely be getting as little attention as the starving citizens of nearby Mali, Burkina Faso and Mauritania. Her wrenching report from Niger, where more than three million people are now in danger of starving to death, set off a worldwide aid effort that a year of United Nations warnings could not. Had attention been paid sooner, lives could have been saved, at one-eightieth -- that's right, one-eightieth -- what it will cost today. And easy, affordable steps that could prevent such scenes elsewhere, like a proposed United Nations $500 million emergency response fund, haven't been taken.

Paid Notice: Deaths   SAGER, DR. CLIFFORD JULIUS
description: SAGER--Dr. Clifford Julius. Died on August 13th at the age of 88 at Southampton Hospital, Southampton, NY from cardiac arrest. He leaves his wife, Anne; four children from previous marriages, Barbara Sager, Dr. Philip Sager, Rebecca Sager Riviere and Anthony Sager; two grandchildren, Elissa and Sabine Riviere; and four stepchildren, Lisa Bussey, John Schnall, Nina Montezinos and Anthony Schnall. He was an internationally renowned psychiatrist, university professor, educator, and author, who received many honors. He was a Professor of Psychiatry at Cornell Medical Center in New York and is a past president of the American Group Psychiatry Association. He pioneered modern approaches to couples and family therapy by developing key concepts around making conscious the implicit individual contracts that couples utilize in relationships. These ideas were fully developed in his ground-breaking book Marriage Contracts & Couple Therapy. He wrote or coauthored four other books. He was an avid swimmer, sailor and up until a few years ago was actively windsurfing. A private memorial service will be announced at a later date. Contributions in Clifford Sager's honor may be directed to the Southampton Hospital (240 Meeting House Lane, Southampton, NY 11968).

description: STEINER -- Lenard DeNeil, M.D., age 88, died on August 13, 2005. Longtime resident of Cedarhurst, Lawrence, and Manhattan, NY. Loving and much beloved husband of Elaine for 54 years. Receptive, supportive, wise and affectionate father of Andrea, Robert and James. Adored grandfather of Simon, Lily and Rosalie and father-in-law of David, Susan, and Audrey. Dear brother of Alfred. Respected Family Practitioner in the Five Towns for nearly 50 years. Educated at Brown University and Buffalo Medical School. Served 41/2 years in US Army Medical Corps, Pacific Theater, WWII. A quiet, deep thinking man with a huge heart, a great sense of humor and a strong character. We will miss him so much. Service Monday, 11:30 am, at "The Riverside," 76th St and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Arts, Briefly; An R-Rated Box Office
description: Two of the four films that opened in wide release this weekend were at the top of the box office chart, playing moderately well among audiences seeking revenge or horror. The R-rated "Four Brothers" (Paramount), directed by John Singleton and starring Mark Wahlberg as one of four adopted siblings who seek revenge for their mother's murder, opened at No. 1 with $20.7 million. "The Skeleton Key" (Universal), a horror film starring Kate Hudson, Gena Rowlands and John Hurt, opened at No. 2 with an estimated $15.8 million. Two R-rated holdovers dropped to No. 3 and 4 after leading last weekend's returns: "The Dukes of Hazzard" (Warner Bros.) took in $13 million in estimated ticket sales, and "Wedding Crashers" (New Line), in the top five for its fifth week, collected $12 million in receipts. The R-rated comedy "Deuce Bigalow: European Gigolo" (Sony), directed by Mike Bigelow and starring Rob Schneider, above, and Eddie Griffin, opened at No. 5 with $9.4 million, according to studio estimates. CATHERINE BILLEY

Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: Officer Shoots Man In Struggle
description: An off-duty officer shot and wounded a man during a struggle on the Bruckner Expressway yesterday after the man, who the police said was drunk, struck the officer's vehicle twice. Neither the officer's name nor the wounded man's were released. The officer, who has been with the department for less than one year, had just finished work and was entering the expressway at Country Club Road about 2:30 a.m. when the man, backing his car off the ramp, hit the officer's car, the police said. The man drove off, and the officer followed, eventually pulling in front of him in an effort to force him to stop, the police said. The man again struck the officer's car, and then pulled over, and the two men began to struggle, the police said. At one point, the police said, the officer asked a passer-by to call 911. The fight ended after the officer fired five rounds with his service pistol, striking the man in the left hip and buttocks, the police said. The man was in serious condition at Jacobi Medical Center, the police said. The officer had a broken arm and finger. The police said the man would be charged with assault and driving while intoxicated. Michael Wilson (NYT)

description: LARSON--Jack Everett. 88, of NYC, formerly of Union, CT, and Ware, MA, died Friday, August 12, 2005. The son of the late Frank O. and Beulah E. Larson of Tulsa, OK, he was a graduate of the Principia Upper School, the University of Paris and George Washington University. A First Lieutenant in the U.S. Army Air Corps during WW II, he served primarily in the Pacific Theater from 1941-45. Employed by Travelers Insurance, Hartford, CT, for several years, he helped create the homeowner's policy and at the time of his retirement, was a Vice President of the company. A Francophile, an historian, a refined and humorous gentleman with boundless curiosity, he is survived by his wife of 61 years, Esther M. Larson of NYC, a special canine companion, Melvin, also of NYC, and a son, Jack E. Larson Jr. of Eastford, CT.

description: A 15-year-old boy was critically injured when he fell four stories from the roof of an apartment building down an air shaft, the police said yesterday. The boy, whose identity was not released by the authorities, tumbled from the roof of 2029 Ryer Avenue in Tremont about 9:15 p.m. Saturday, the police said. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LANDMAN, AMOS
description: LANDMAN--Amos, of New York and West Cornwall, CT, died Sunday morning of cancer at age 90. A journalist, public relations executive and World War II veteran, he was a reporter for the Daily Mirror and PM and a radio and newspaper correspondent in China from 1948 to '50. He retired in 1985 as Senior Vice President of Ruder & Finn. Born in Philadelphia and educated at Townsend Harris High School and Brown University. He will be remembered for decency, integrity and loyalty, having chosen to endure the blacklist in the 1950s rather than betray his friends. He is survived by his wife of nearly 60 years, Lynn, his children, Jonathan (Bonnie) and Margot, his grandchildren, Rachel and Aaron, and his sister Louise, all of whom will cherish his memory forever. He made us all laugh. Service 4:30 pm, today, Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th St. In lieu of flowers, please make a contribution to Doctors Without Borders or the Central Park Conservancy.

title: The New, Exciting and Soon Forgotten
description: Last week, as the Festival of Contemporary Music at Tanglewood was gliding to a close, the large student orchestra of the Tanglewood Music Center lit into Steven Stucky's Second Concerto for Orchestra. It is an electrifying piece: three movements that explore an orchestra's potential in much the way Bartok's and Lutoslawski's concertos for orchestra do, but in ways that sound fresh and exciting. It alludes to works by other composers without losing its own focus, and like many of the festival works it stands apart from academic disputes about style and language, and strives for direct communication.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about Cindy Sheehan, the antiwar protester whose son died in Iraq and who is camped out near President Bush's ranch in Crawford, Tex., quoted incorrectly from remarks about her by Bill O'Reilly, the Fox News television host. Mr. O'Reilly did not call Ms. Sheehan treasonous. His comment, during his program on Tuesday, referring to applause for her cause on an antiwar Web site, was, "I think Ms. Sheehan bears some responsibility for this, and also for the responsibility of other American families who have lost sons and daughters in Iraq, who feel that this kind of behavior borders on treasonous." And on Wednesday he added, "I said some families who also lost loved ones in Iraq believe what she's doing borders on treason."

title: New CD's
description: Thug love is a lot more complicated than old-fashioned romance. A man is supposed to be a street warrior first, a superstud second, a partner as a distant third. Even when he's making promises, his fidelity is reserved for his posse, not his lover. A woman is supposed to be ultra-sexy and ready to give her all for her man, but also practical, selective and psychologically bulletproof. Both men and women profess their ghetto authenticity while they flaunt as much conspicuous consumption as a rhyme scheme can hold. And both try to be good to their mamas, true to their crews and ruthless to nearly everyone else. Above all, passion is never to interfere with toughness -- anything less could be dangerous. The new albums reviewed here all revolve around fashionable fantasies of thug love, pro and con.

title: LOOKING AHEAD
description: FIRST HEATHROW, NOW THIS -- It lacks the color of the 24-hour strike at Heathrow Airport in London that stranded 70,000 travelers last week, but Delta Air Lines faces an extended deadline today for filing its second-quarter financial data with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Delta delayed the filing last week amid negotiations with a credit card processing company, heightening expectations that it could seek bankruptcy protection soon. If that doesn't grab your attention, how about this: a cooling-off period between Northwest Airlines and its mechanics expires at 12:01 a.m. on Saturday, opening the way for a strike if a labor accord isn't reached by then.

title: Adding Glass-Box Minimalism to Midwestern Downtown
description: DAVENPORT, Iowa - Whatever you think of Minimalist architecture -- sleek and sexy or cold and impersonal -- it's hard to deny its remarkable durability in the art world. For decades it has been the preferred style of art dealers and curators, as conservative in its way as the 19th-century salon tradition. Its familiarity only adds to its main virtue: the ability to instantly imbue an art institution with a gloss of cultural sophistication.

Paid Notice: Deaths   SIMON, HELEN K. (FLOWERS)
description: SIMON--Helen K. (Flowers), of Manhattan, died peacefully on August 12, 2005, at the age of 94. Wife of the late H. Theodore Simon of New York, and secondly of the late James P. Flowers. She is survived by her only child, her daughter Elaine Simon Ward (Mrs. Ralph E. Ward) of Darien, CT, and London. Born in Quogue, LI, she was a former Trustee of the Mannes College of Music in New York. From 1948 until the early 1960's she and her husband Theodore Simon designed and created handwrought sterling silver objects in a workshop in their townhouse. Their work is represented in the permanent collections of The Museum of the City of New York and the CooperHewitt Museum. Funeral Mass at the Church of St. Thomas More, 65 E. 89th St, NYC, on Saturday, August 20th, at 10 AM. Burial will be private. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to Lenox Hill Hospital, attn: Dr. Stuart Orsher, in her memory.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Justice Report Finds No Complaints
description: The Justice Department's inspector general did not receive any complaints in the first six months of the year related to misconduct by department employees in their use of the antiterrorism law known as the USA Patriot Act, the inspector general reported. The inspector general is required by Congress to review such complaints and report back twice a year, but the office has yet to find any confirmed abuses since the law was passed in October 2001. However, the office said in its report that it is continuing to investigate accusations of misconduct related to last year's mistaken arrest of Brandon Mayfield, a lawyer in Portland, Ore., suspected of being connected to the Madrid train bombings, as well as reports by F.B.I. agents of prisoner abuse at Guantnamo Bay, Cuba. A "60 Minutes" repeat brought in an audience of 10.8 million, which buoyed the network to the No. 1 position. But among 18-to-49-year-olds, CBS placed third. ABC won that demographic with ease, as it broadcast a new episode of "Extreme Makeover: Home Edition" for the first time since May. The heart-wrenching home show was the most-watched program of the night, with 11.39 million viewers and dominant ratings among 18-to-49-year-old viewers. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SAGER, DR. CLIFFORD JULIUS
description: SAGER--Dr. Clifford Julius. Died on August 13th at the age of 88 at Southampton Hospital, Southampton, NY from cardiac arrest. He leaves his wife, Anne; four children from previous marriages, Barbara Sager, Dr. Philip Sager, Rebecca Sager Riviere and Anthony Sager; two grandchildren, Elissa and Sabine Riviere; and four stepchildren, Lisa Bussey, John Schnall, Nina Montezinos and Anthony Schnall. He was an internationally renowned psychiatrist, university professor, educator, and author, who received many honors. He was a Professor of Psychiatry at Cornell Medical Center in New York and is a past president of the American Group Psychiatry Association. He pioneered modern approaches to couples and family therapy by developing key concepts around making conscious the implicit individual contracts that couples utilize in relationships. These ideas were fully developed in his ground-breaking book Marriage Contracts & Couple Therapy. He wrote or coauthored four other books. He was an avid swimmer, sailor and up until a few years ago was actively windsurfing. A private memorial service will be announced at a later date. Contributions in Clifford Sager's honor may be directed to the Southampton Hospital (240 Meeting House Lane, Southampton, NY 11968).

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Bank Chief Under Investigation
description: The chief executive of Commerzbank, Klaus-Peter Mller, is being investigated by German and Swiss prosecutors as part of an investigation into laundering of money from Russia, the bank said. The investigation, which prompted a board member, Andreas de Maizire, to resign last month, has been expanded to include Mr. Mller a few days ago, the bank said in a statement. Commerzbank said that it expected that Mr. Mller would be fully exonerated. Investigators are examining whether employees of Commerzbank may have helped to divert money from state businesses in Russia through a division of First National Holding of Luxembourg, a company that the bank used to control.

title: Car Bomb in Chechnya Kills One; Premier Possible Target
description: A car bomb exploded in Chechnya's capital, Grozny, killing at least one and wounding 11 others, 3 gravely. The attack might have been an attempt to kill the republic's prime minister, Sergei Abramov, who was scheduled to preside at the opening of a cultural center nearby, Interfax reported, citing one of his aides. The bombing came a day after a Russian colonel and four soldiers died when a blast destroyed their vehicle. Separately, a senior Chechen official, Taus Dzhabrailov, said that 150,000 to 160,000 people, including soldiers, had died in Chechnya's two wars from 1994 to 1996 and from 1999 to now. That estimate exceeded even the worst estimates compiled by human rights organizations. Steven Lee Myers (NYT)

description: THE debate over education reform has tended to divide children's learning along two axes, the emotional and the academic. That means that promoting students' social and emotional skills plays a critical role in improving their academic performance.

Paid Notice: Deaths   OSTERMAN, MELVIN H.
description: OSTERMAN--Melvin H., 70, of Delmar, New York died suddenly on Sunday, August 14, 2005. He was born in NYC on September 26, 1934, son of the late Melvin H. Osterman Sr. & Selma Lenz Osterman. Melvin was a graduate of Cornell University and the Cornell Law School. He was a founding partner of Whiteman Osterman & Hanna LLP, Albany, NY and practiced law there from 1975 through the present. Prior to starting the firm he was an Assistant Counsel to Governor Nelson Rockefeller and Director of Employee Relations of the State of New York. He was Legal Secretary to Mr. Justice Charles D. Breitel. He was counsel to the Taylor Committee in drafting the public sector labor law in New York State. He published numerous articles and was Editor of the New York State Bar Association's Public Sector Labor and Employment Law book. He taught as an adjunct professor at various times as the Graduate School of Public Affairs at SUNYA; the Cornell University NYS School of Industrial Relations Extension Division; and Siena College. His passions included: travel, theatre and music, photography and gardening. He is survived by his wife, Norma Meacham; and five children: Lawrence (Valorie) of Woodinville, WA; Edith of Albany; Jeffrey of Scarsdale, NY; Laura of Washington D.C. and Andrew of Colorado Springs, CO; and two grandchildren: Daniel and Sharron Osterman of Woodinville, WA. His first wife, Elaine Pevar Osterman of NYC, also survives him. Calling hours Wednesday, August 17, 4-8 PM and Thursday, August 18 from 10:30 AM-12 noon at the Applebee Funeral Home, 403 Kenwood Avenue, Delmar. A funeral service will be held 12 noon Thursday at the funeral home. Memorial contributions may be made to Albany Pro Musica, 50 Colvin Avenue, Albany, NY 12206 or the Mohawk Hudson Land Conservancy, PO Box 567, Slingerlands, NY 12159, or the charity of your choice.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Government Seeks New Judge In Case
description: The Justice Department has asked that a different judge be assigned to a long-running lawsuit filed by a group of American Indians seeking billions of dollars from the federal government for oil, gas, timber and other leases on Indian land. The judge who has presided over the case for nearly a decade, Royce C. Lamberth of Federal District Court in Washington, has consistently sided with the Indians, saying in a ruling last month, "Our government still treats Native American Indians as if they were somehow less than deserving of the respect that should be afforded to everyone in a society where all people are supposed to be equal." The government contends that Judge Lamberth has been an obstacle in concluding the matter. The conflict dates back to the Dawes Act of 1887. John Files (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: China: Industrial Production Rises 16%
description: China's industrial production rose 16.1 percent in July as companies including General Motors and Huaneng Power International increased output. Production increased to 581 billion yuan ($71.8 billion), the highest ever after June's record 619 billion yuan, the National Bureau of Statistics said on its Web site. Car output jumped 55 percent from a year earlier. The report adds to evidence that China' is sustaining a rapid pace of expansion as the Chinese premier, Wen Jiabao, restricts property development to help ease power shortages and keep inflation in check.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Wrongfully Convicted Man Is Deported After Release
description: David Wong, an illegal Chinese immigrant whose 1986 murder conviction was overturned by a state appellate court last year, was deported last week to Hong Kong. Mr. Wong, 42, had been a cause clbre for Asian-American activists who were convinced that he had not killed a fellow inmate in an upstate prison, where he had been serving time on an armed robbery conviction. After fresh evidence emerged casting doubt on his guilt, an appellate court overturned the conviction in October, and a Clinton County judge dismissed the charges in December. Mr. Wong arrived in Hong Kong last Wednesday, and has been trying to adjust to life as a free man for the first time in two decades, said one of his lawyers, Jaykumar Menon. David W. Chen (NYT)

World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Bidding Up Leica Geosystems
description: Hexagon of Sweden offered to purchase Leica Geosystems of Switzerland for 1.44 billion Swiss francs ($1.15 billion) in a deal that would create the world's biggest maker of surveying and measuring technology. The offer trumps a bid made by the Danaher Corporation, which is based in Washington, D.C. Hexagon said that it would pay 573 Swiss francs a share in cash and stock, 73 francs more than Danaher offered on July 26 and 137 francs more than its own initial bid. Leica, which sells the only surveying system that uses satellites to improve the accuracy of ground-based equipment, said it would review the bid in coming days. Shares of Leica rose 51 francs, or 9.9 percent, to 565 francs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WEI, WALING CHUNG
description: WEI--Waling Chung. Died on August 12, 2005, in Princeton, New Jersey. Born in China on May 10, 1909, Waling grew up in Shanghai, where she met her husband, the late Tseh Heen Wei. She moved to this country with her family in 1941. She lived in Bronxville, NY, until 1971, and resided in Manhattan from 1975 to 2003. Waling was the daughter of Chung Mun Yew, who held various diplomatic posts representing the Chinese Government in Washington, and elsewhere, and later was Managing Director and Chairman of The ShanghaiNanking Railroad. He was a member of The Yale College Class of 1883. Waling is survived by her children and their spouses, Jacqueline Wei Mintz and Sidney Mintz, of Baltimore, MD, Madeleine Wei, of Far Rockaway, NY, Dr. Fong Wei and Theodora Z. Wei, of Princeton, NJ, and Robert C. Wei and Susan Wetchler Wei, of Upper Saddle River, New Jersey. She is also survived by her grandchildren, Christopher, Alexander, Samantha, and Thomas, a granddaughter-inlaw, Michelle Christman, and her sisters, Lucille Chan, of Vancouver, BC, and Lulu Bau, of Hong Kong. An enthusiastic and indefatigable traveller, Waling often accompanied her husband on his world-wide trips, and, after his death, frequently traveled on her own to Europe, the Far East, and the Near East. She was also a devotee of The Metropolitan Opera. Delighting all her life in new learning and experiences, Waling took courses well into her ninth decade, and even learned to check her stocks on the Internet. Her children, grandchildren, and the rest of the family will sorely miss her, her vitality and spirit. Memorial services will be held at Marble Collegiate Church, Fifth Avenue and West Twenty-Ninth St., NYC, Thursday, August 18 at 12 noon. In lieu of flowers, contributions in her memory may be directed to: Mun Yew Chung Memorial Fund, Yale University, POB 2038, New Haven, CT. 06521-2038.
