description: Talks broke down between the airline meal company Gate Gourmet and its British union, pushing the company's British operations a step closer to bankruptcy. The money-losing Gate Gourmet, which is owned by the Texas Pacific Group, has been trying to cut jobs and costs at its Heathrow operations. A heavily negotiated pay and benefits plan was agreed to by union representatives in June but has not been approved by the union's members. Gate Gourmet employees staged a wildcat strike Aug. 10 that spread to British Airways, temporarily grounding all its flights. Gate Gourmet has fired 560 employees over the strike. Tony Woodley, left, the union's general secretary, said the breakdown was a "consequence of Gate Gourmet wanting to selectively re-employ those who had been sacked even though there is enough work for everyone." But by exercising its right to extend the deadline in the face of Washington's undisguised and unhelpful impatience, Iraq's parliament took the most responsible and constructive course available: to grant quarreling Sunni Arab, Shiite and Kurdish delegates another week to seek compromises that all can live with.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BRANCHE, DR. MATTHEW DAVIDSON
description: BRANCHE--Dr. Matthew Davidson. A longtime resident of Westchester, passed away at his home in Hartsdale, NY on Saturday, August 13, 2005. He was born on October 30th, 1927 in Tuskegee, AL and was one of three children born to Dr. George Clayton Branche and Lillian Vester Davidson. He was a graduate of the Boston Latin School and earned his BA degree from Bowdoin College. He earned his MD from Boston University School of Medicine, and completed his residency at Boston City Hospital. As an avid athelete, he developed a passion for tennis, golf, and boating. Matthew Branche, MD, was a practicing physician and surgeon for over 40 years. He was on the faculty of Columbia University and served as attending surgeon at Harlem Hospital Center. He was a Diplomate of the American Board of Surgery. He had admitting privileges at Sound Shore Medical Center in New Rochelle and Mount Vernon Hospital. He was an active participant in several societies, associations, clubs and organizations including; the Guardsmens, the Westchester Clubmen, the Rainbow Yacht Club and Sigma Pi Phi Fraternity. He is survived by his brother George C. Branche, Jr., MD of White Plains, NY; his former wife of many years Alma Craft Branche of Sarasota, FL; and their two children son Matthew Branche, Jr. of Carmel, NY; and daughter Daryl Roberta Flowers of Burlington, VT; five granchildren; and his dear friend and companion Jacqueline L. Dunbar, MD of Scarsdale. He will be profoundly missed. Visiting hours Wednesday 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Memorial Service to be announced. Information: McMahon, Lyon & Harnett Funeral Home, White Plains, NY 914-949-7777.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Court Overturns Ban On Radical Party
description: The Supreme Court overturned a ban on a fringe political party that has gained notoriety for needling the Kremlin with publicity-grabbing protests. A lower court banned the party, the National Bolsheviks, in June, citing irregularities in its registration and accusing it of extremism. The higher court did not explain its ruling; a spokesman said a written decision would be published in 10 days. The organization's leader, the writer Eduard Limonov, called the reversal a surprise. "The ban could have set up a precedent and given a free hand to those who want to see a one-party system and authoritarian rule in Russia," he told Ekho Moskvy radio. Prosecutors said they would appeal the ruling to the Supreme Court's Appellate Division. Steven Lee Myers (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Workers To Receive Compensation

The company pleaded guilty in Brooklyn Criminal Court to a felony charge of lying on a government form and admitted submitting false payroll reports. The workers were paid $130 to $218 a day, with no benefits, far less than the prevailing wage-and-benefit rate of $52 an hour. The office of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority's inspector general discovered the fraud. Sewell Chan (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: Morning-After Pill Ruling
description: A panel of state lawmakers made permanent an April emergency order by Gov. Rod R. Blagojevich that requires pharmacies to dispense all contraceptives approved by the Food and Drug Administration without delay, including the morning-after pill. The order was issued after two women reported that a Chicago pharmacy would not fill their prescriptions for morning-after pills. If the drug is not in stock, pharmacies must provide an alternative, order it, transfer the prescription to a different pharmacy or return the prescription. Eight pharmacists have sued, arguing that the order requires them to violate their religious and ethical beliefs. Gretchen Ruethling (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LINKER, MIRIAM
description: LINKER--Miriam. Of Rehovot, Israel formerly of Scarsdale, NY passed away quietly in her sleep at age 87 on Thursday, August 11 after visiting the Jewish Quarter of Prague, where she was travelling with her daughter, Naomi Yanis. Miriam also leaves a brother, Seymour Wolf; a son Prof. Charles Linker, M.D. and his wife Helene; and a daughter Laurie Tako and her husband Reuben. She is survived by eight grandchildren and five great grandchildren: Lynn Yanis, her husband John Maher and daughter Yelena; Lloyd Yanis, his wife Caren and their children Lia and Sam; Lauri Yanis and her children Zachary and Aliza; Sarah and Alex Linker; Eitan, Ayelet and Daphna Tako; and numerous adoring nieces and nephews, neighbors and friends in Israel and the United States. Miriam was pre-deceased by her husband of 57 years, Jacques Linker, former CEO of Dellwood Dairy. Their home was always open to generations of caring and cared-for individuals. Miriam touched the lives of people around the world, sharing opinions, wisdom, and strength of spirit, and lived life to the fullest. She was dearly loved and will be sorely missed. A memorial service will be held at Congregation Kol Ami in White Plains, NY on Friday August 19 at 1PM. The family welcomes guests while they sit Shiva at the home of Jennifer and Alon Markowitz, 9 East 10 St in Manhattan all day Saturday and Sunday morning. A memorial service was held in Israel on Tuesday.

World Business Briefing | Asia: China: 7,000 Coal Mines Closed for Safety
description: The Chinese government ordered production suspended at more than 7,000 coal mines in 26 provinces because they have not met work safety requirements. Operators of 5,290 coal mines failed to present work safety licenses by a July 13 deadline set by the State Administration of Work Safety, the agency said in a statement on its Web site. Another 2,000 mines were not issued licenses because they had not complied with standards, the administration quoted its director, Li Yizhong, as saying. China, the world's biggest coal producer, has one of the worst mining safety records. The number of workers killed in major mining accidents in the first seven months of 2005 more than doubled to 879, from 385 a year earlier.

description: LA TRINIT-SUR-MER, France - BRITTANY, the rocky finger that France points across the Atlantic toward America, affords no greater pleasure than a plateau de fruits de mer -- a metal platter piled high with bracingly fresh, ravishingly sweet iced seafood -- to be devoured in the summer sunshine, preferably accompanied by a chilled bottle of first-rate muscadet enticingly beaded with condensation.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Subway Station Mugging
description: A 26-year-old man was arrested yesterday in a mugging in a subway station last month in which the victim was stabbed 13 times, the police said. The man, Charles Maxwell, of Manhattan, was charged with robbery, assault and criminal possession of a weapon, the police said. On July 23, at about 1:45 p.m., as a 53-year-old woman waited for the J train at the Bowery station, Mr. Maxwell approached her, covered her mouth and eyes with his hands, and then took her purse, the police said. Michelle O'Donnell (NYT)

title: Protester Vows to Continue Her Vigil Near Bush Ranch
description: CRAWFORD, Tex., Aug. 16 - Cindy Sheehan, the mother of a soldier killed in Iraq who has set up a vigil near President Bush's ranch, said Tuesday that she was "very disturbed" that a local resident had mowed down hundreds of small crosses bearing the names of other dead American soldiers, and that her now 10-day protest was "only the beginning" of what she described as a growing national movement to bring all American men and women home from the war.

title: Senate Democrats Increase Resistance to Roberts
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 - Senate Democrats on Tuesday night sharply escalated their resistance to the president's Supreme Court nominee, Judge John G. Roberts Jr., with Senator Patrick J. Leahy saying that as a young lawyer he worked aggressively for "policies that are deeply tinged with the ideology of the far right wing of his party."

title: From Asia and South America, New Takes on the Familiar Puff
description: The first surprise at Puff & Pao is that unlike other cream puff emporiums that have opened in New York in the past few years, it is not Japanese. The second surprise is that the shop, at 105 Christopher Street (Hudson Street), also sells paolitos, South American cheese puffs.

description: O'SHEA--John Nelligan. On August 15, 2005, retired Lt. FDNY (35 years of service). title: A Glimpse of Forces Confronting Saudi Rule
description: Western reporting on Saudi Arabia has been in attack mode ever since Sept. 11. Not since the Borgias has a ruling family received such bad press as the House of Saud, and the United States-Saudi connection is probably the one that Americans would most like to sever, if it could be done without raising gasoline prices.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Warning On Deed Backlog
description: Millions of dollars in real estate fees that were supposed to help county clerks improve their services have instead been diverted to general state and county budgets in the last four years, leaving the counties ill-equipped to handle an increase in real estate transactions, according to a report released yesterday. In the report, the State Commission of Investigation said that seven of the state's 21 counties have experienced delays in recording deeds, mortgages and other paperwork of up to two months -- a gap that the commission warned has made these transactions vulnerable to fraud. David W. Chen (NYT)

description: GOLDSCHMIDT--Minna. 95, formerly of Eastchester, NY died peacefully at home on August 15, 2005 in Tucson, AZ. Beloved wife of the late Bernard Goldschmidt. title: National Briefing | Plains: South Dakota: Limits On Cage Fighting
description: The Sioux Falls City Council has passed an ordinance banning cage fighting in parks and city-owned facilities and requiring organizers to get a permit and have security officers and a paramedic present at fights. Under the ordinance, passed Monday, organizers are not allowed to make more than 25 percent of their income from alcohol sales, and they must have at least $1 million in liability insurance and cover medical expenses of fighters who are injured and do not have health insurance. Cage fighting involves two people who fight in a chain-link cage using any combination of boxing, kickboxing, martial arts or wrestling. Gretchen Ruethling (NYT)

title: How to Spin a Potato Chip
description: BARCELONA, Spain - FOR Ferran Adri, a chef who wakes up each workday asking what he can do that has never been done before, potato chips may not seem like the most fertile terrain. But Mr. Adri has begun helping Lay's develop new recipes that he says contain a touch of the free-spirited philosophy behind his celebrated cuisine.

Paid Notice: Deaths   HILDT, JOHN
description: HILDT--John, 88. of Gates Mills, Ohio, died of complications from emphysema Saturday, August 13, 2005. Beloved husband of Dorothy (nee Tremaine); devoted father of Anne H. Geddes (Robert), J. Bradley Hildt (Elizabeth), David T. Hildt (Kate), Daniel T. Hildt, Cary H. Mathews (James) and stepfather to K. Bryant Wick (Emily) and Dorothy C. Wick. He is also survived by eight grandchildren, one greatgrandchild and five stepgrandchildren. His wife of 36 years, Patricia Hildt (nee Delehanty), predeceased him, succumbing to cancer in 1977. Mr. Hildt grew up in Baltimore, class of '35 at The Taft School, and attended John Hopkins University. In 1941, he served as an officer in the Signal Corps attached to the Army Security Agency. In 1946 he lived in Locust Valley, New York, and was an officer at the Bank of New York. In 1952, Mr. Hildt moved to Hunting Valley, Ohio, and joined The National City Bank of Cleveland, until his retirement in 1981 as Senior Vice President. While a resident of Hunting Valley from 1955 to 1974, he was a member of the Council, the Finance Director and Treasurer. Mr. Hildt was a member of the Chagrin Valley Hunt Club, The Kirtland Country Club, The Union Club, the Everglades Club and the Bath and Tennis Club of Palm Beach. A memorial service will be held on Wednesday, August 31st, at 4 PM, at St. Christopher's By The River in Gates Mills, Ohio. In lieu of flowers, the family asks that contributions be made to the VNA Hospice and Palliative Partners of Ohio, 2500 East 22nd Street, Cleveland, Ohio 44115.

title: A Tale of Drug Use, and Reformation
description: In a one-man show, "Confessions of a Dope Dealer," Sheldon Norberg is surprisingly unapologetic about his life choices. He says a drug dealer is "a pioneer to whom we entrust our consciousness," and notes, " 'Dealer' is 'leader' misspelled." He also argues for the legalization of illicit drugs, maintaining they have value as both medicine and guides to spiritual clarity. (Indeed, with his shaved head, piercing eyes, all-black outfit and dynamic delivery, Mr. Norberg could be mistaken for a rogue preacher.) The blunder that he and his customers made, Mr. Norberg says, was in using drugs "as toys rather than tools."

World Business Briefing | Europe: Russia: Norilsk Seeks Approval for Spinoff
description: Norilsk Nickel, the world's biggest nickel and palladium miner, will seek shareholders' approval on Sept. 30 for a plan to spin off its gold assets. Norilsk wants to spin off its Polyus unit to shareholders, creating a company analysts say would be worth up to $4 billion. The spinoff would combine Polyus; a 20 percent stake in Gold Fields, the world's No.4 gold producer; and 10 billion rubles ($352 million) in cash, Norilsk said in an e-mailed statement. Norilsk produces more than half the world's palladium, a fifth of its nickel and 14 percent of its platinum. Last year, Polyus produced 1.1 million ounces of gold. It wants to triple output by 2010.

description: UNLIKE good cookbooks, which can become old family favorites, diet books come and go. Mostly they go, as one diet fad is supplanted by another.

title: Sparing the Least of Those at the Table
description: Congress must soon decide on the details of a $3 billion cut in agricultural spending across the next five years. In the kind of selflessness that normally characterizes special-interest lobbying, powerful farm-commodity lobbyists are urging that farmers be protected and that the brunt of the pain be born by the neediest citizens, who struggle to get by on food stamps.

title: Many Going to College AreNot Ready, Report Says
description: Only about half of this year's high school graduates have the reading skills they need to succeed in college, and even fewer are prepared for college-level science and math courses, according to a yearly report from ACT, which produces one of the nation's leading college admissions tests.

title: Ted Croner, 82, Dies; Photos Captured New York Energy

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Economy Grows 3.1% in Second Quarter
description: Mexico's economy grew less than expected in the second quarter as farming slumped 3.3 percent from a year ago and demand fell in the United States for Mexican-made cars. Gross domestic product expanded 3.1 percent from a year ago after growing 2.4 percent in the first quarter, the government said. "The most obvious thing that happened to Mexico in the first half of the year is that U.S. industrial production and the car sector in particular took a big hit," said Michael Hood, an economist with Barclays Capital in a telephone interview. The United States buys about 85 percent of Mexico's exports.

description: A Kabul court sentenced seven members of a criminal gang to death for the kidnapping of three United Nations election workers last October and for armed robbery, the official Bakhtar news agency reported. The United Nations workers were held hostage for more than three weeks. Two other men received 16-year prison sentences for the same crimes. Carlotta Gall (NYT)

title: People: Michael Brand, Michael Chabon, Tom Hanks
In the Lonesome West, Together
description: You could drive a herd of cattle through the dead spaces in Gabriel McKinley's sere, Old West-set two-hander "Love Sick." The talk is as empty as the pauses here. When a querulous young prostitute, Jinx (Stefanie Frame), tries to befriend a cranky, boozing outlaw named Tax (Mr. McKinley), these two inarticulate souls neither spark to each other nor clash with much fire. Instead they gingerly circle the obvious, then state and restate it, until finally one of them has the sense to shoot the other.

title: Israeli Troops Persuade, and Force, Settlers to Quit Gaza
description: NEVE DEKALIM, Gaza Strip, Wednesday, Aug. 17 - Israeli soldiers moved into this Jewish settlement in larger numbers Wednesday morning in an effort to persuade reluctant residents to leave their homes voluntarily before being forced out.

title: Observance
description: An hour before the start of the Sabbath, nine disrobed men stand by a secluded stream in upstate New York. Singing a niggun, a song without words, they immerse themselves in flowing water, one by one, performing a Jewish purification ritual in a mikvah. Obligatory for Orthodox women, many men also use a mikvah, before Yom Kippur, for example, or the Sabbath. In the United States, the ritual is almost always performed indoors. But at Elat Chayyim, a Jewish spiritual retreat in Ulster County, men use a mikvah in a setting much like that of their ancestors in the Pale of Eastern Europe. "We connect to the primordial waters and prepare ourselves for Shabbat," Rabbi David Ingber said. "Our great hope is that religion and spirituality can become what it is intended to be: the great reservoir of compassion, hope and inspiration pointing us to a more ethical world, a more peaceful world." LENS

description: ROME, Aug. 17 - An Italian court today approved the extradition of a British man suspected of taking part in the failed bombings of London's subway system on July 21. Hamdi Issac, 27, could be transferred to Great Britain after a period of 35 days, said his lawyer, Antonietta Sonnessa. During this time, Italian authorities will have a chance to conclude their investigation.

Labor support is considered crucial for the bond measure, which would provide $1.45 billion for state highway and bridge projects and $1.45 billion for the Metropolitan Transportation Authority. The panel's chairwoman, Carolyn Merritt, said its findings pointed to "systemic lapses" that "could lead to additional serious accidents." title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Jobless Claims Keep Rising
description: Jobless claims rose for a sixth month in July, extending the longest string of gains in more than 12 years as slower consumer spending deterred hiring. The number of people claiming unemployment benefits climbed by 2,800 from June, to 866,000, the highest since April 2004, the Office for National Statistics said. The jobless rate remained at 2.8 percent, the highest since May 2004. Economic growth slumped to 1.7 percent in the second quarter, the slowest annual pace in 12 years, and this month the Bank of England cut its benchmark interest rate for the first time in two years.

title: Shelter for the Homeless, With Rooms Built From a Kit
description: Prefab structures, championed as a way to produce everything from modernist homes to emergency shelters, will soon be making an appearance on the Bowery. The Andrews House, a residence for homeless men at 197 Bowery (Spring Street), is being renovated using more than 100 living units prefabricated by ACC Construction of Brooklyn. The units, which will allow more light and air into the building than traditional rooms would, come in two versions. One, by Rafi Elbaz, left, is called the Kit of Parts. It has a door cutout to encourage socializing, walls with elastic straps to hold magazines, and adjustable shelves, center, made of wood and steel pipe.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LAVITT, PAULINE K.
description: LAVITT--Pauline K. The loving wife of Paul P. Lavitt has passed away after a long illness. She is also survived by: son Howard and his wife Jodi, their children Brett, Jacqueline and Austin of Ryebrook, NY; son Arthur and his wife Julie, their children Jake and Brandon of Charlotte, NC; her brother Barry J. Jacobson of NYC and his children Ari, Adam, Brette, Spyro and Stefano. In loving memory of a woman of valor and great dignity who for 35 years of her life fought a severe lung disease. We remember a woman who never complained, a person who always thought of other people first with her sense of caring, always overshadowing any devastating illness that she suffered in life. Pauline had a most special relationship with her father Archie, and her mother Martha, both deceased, and had a special bond with her brother Barry that could never be broken. They shared a love that will be everlasting. May G-d bless her, keep her, her husband and all of her children, grandchildren, nephews, niece and friends who loved her so much. Barry J. Jacobson

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Men Charged With Hate Crime
description: Four Brooklyn men accused of beating a black man, Alex Moore, 29, with pipes and bats earlier this month, pleaded not guilty yesterday at their arraignments in Brooklyn Criminal Court on charges of assault as a hate crime, possessing a weapon, aggravated harassment and menacing. A fifth man, Anthony Capone, who investigators said also participated in the attack, had not yet been arraigned last night, but law enforcement officials said they expected him to face similar charges as the four, Anthony David, Robert Lombardi, Stephen Cucarese and Nicolas Morse. Investigators have said Mr. Morse was the leader of a group of white men who chased Mr. Moore and five other black men on Avenue N in Flatlands on Aug. 7. The five other men escaped, but Mr. Moore was beaten and seriously injured. Prosecutors said some of the attackers shouted racial epithets during the beating. Kareem Fahim (NYT)

description: A flower kiosk stocked with delicate myrtle topiaries, potted azaleas and mixed bouquets has opened in Bryant Park, the manicured patch of grass and foliage behind the Public Library on Fifth Avenue (42nd Street). Painted in shades of pea and evergreen, the kiosk has a crisp awning, oversize windows and a flared cornice. The goal is to allow vines to enshroud it like an Alpine hut, said Daniel Biederman, president of the Bryant Park Restoration Corporation. (When it comes to a garden kiosk, he said, one should "drape it with the kinds of things it will be selling.") Jennifer Pfeiffer, an owner of Magnolia Flowers & Events, which runs the kiosk and contributed to its design, calls it "very Parisian" -- as are the trained ivies and twined bouquets (from $20) neatly displayed on an tagre. The kiosk is on the south side of the park, next to the Parisian-style carousel. DEBORAH BALDWIN

Devoted daughter of the late Benjamin and Regina Harris and sister of the late George Harris, all of New York. Employed 25 years by NY Schools at PS 94 and Bayside HS in Queens, she retired in 1980 to Deerfield Beach, FL, where she married Benjamin Miller in 1988 (deceased 1994). Of the 202 people killed in the attacks, 88 were Australians. Mr. Bashir's 30-month sentence was cut by four and a half months; he could now be released as early as April. Many Western governments had been critical of the 30-month sentence as too lenient. Evelyn Rusli (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Pirro Receives Two Endorsements

The endorsement was unusual, coming 15 months before Election Day and as other Republicans seek to be the party's nominee against Mrs. Clinton. But one committee member, Alexander Treadwell, a former chairman of the state Republican Party, is a longtime friend of Ms. Pirro, the Westchester district attorney. The other, Jennifer Saul Yaffa, said in a statement that Ms. Pirro was "the right candidate to defeat Hillary Clinton." Patrick D. Healy (NYT)

description: Recovery teams located the bodies of almost all of the 160 people on board a West Caribbean Airways plane that crashed in a mountainous region of Venezuela on Tuesday. It was still not known what caused the twin-engine failure of the Colombian MD-82 charter airliner. Aviation experts have suggested that fuel contamination may have been the cause. The plane was traveling from Panama to Martinique. Most of the 152 passengers were from Martinique. Brian Ellsworth (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Australia/New Zealand: New Zealand: Billionaire Bids for Carter Holt
description: Graeme Hart, New Zealand's third-richest man, bid $2.3 billion for Carter Holt Harvey, prompting speculation he would split up and sell the group's forestry assets. The Rank Group, Mr. Hart's investment company, said it agreed to pay 2.50 New Zealand dollars ($1.76) a share for the International Paper Company's 50.5 percent stake in Carter Holt. Rank agreed to extend the offer to all shareholders in four to six weeks. Carter Holt rose 4 percent, to 2.56 New Zealand dollars ($1.80) a share. Mr. Hart, a onetime tow-truck driver, built a $1.4 billion fortune buying and selling undervalued assets. A successful bid would give him control of 543,000 acres of plantation forest, 26 sawmills and board plants, 4 pulp and paper mills and 13 packaging plants, employing 10,000 workers in New Zealand, Australia and Asia.

title: Arts, Briefly; News of the News
description: Last week, the week after Peter Jennings died of lung cancer, ABC's "World News Tonight" was No. 1 in Nielsen's estimates for the first time since June 2004. The broadcast on Aug. 8, the day after Jennings died, drew 10.5 million viewers. Over all, "World News Tonight" brought in an average of 8.9 million viewers for the week. NBC's "Nightly News" placed second (8.2 million); "CBS Evening News" was third (6.3 million). ESPN2's new nightly show, "Quite Frankly," with the brash host Stephen A. Smith, delivered an average of 232,000 viewers in its first two weeks. The show made its debut on Aug. 1 and has posted lower viewer totals than ESPN2's July average in the time slot, but higher ratings in the male demographics the channel seeks. CBS won Tuesday night in both viewers and adults 18 to 49. The Bush administration has been encouraging this constant push for more drilling, almost entirely without regard to other values. A case in point is the growing pressure to open Valle Vidal, a part of the Carson National Forest in northern New Mexico, to coal-bed methane development.

title: Relics of Czech Modernism From Between the World Wars

Both were collecting pieces from what they saw as a pivotal moment in design: the period in Czech history and culture that fell between the two world wars. title: Metro Briefing | New York: The Bronx: Health Inspector Attacked
description: A health department inspector was attacked by a man yesterday during a visit to a day camp in the Longwood section, the police said. The inspector, a 26-year-old woman who was not identified by the authorities, arrived at the New Apple Family and Community Service Day Camp, a licensed camp, at 726 Prospect Avenue, about 8:30 a.m. She was admitted by Donald McKinnon, 54, who began punching, choking and biting her, the police said. The inspector fought him off, and he fled. The inspector was taken to a hospital and treated, the police said. Officers used bloodhounds to track Mr. McKinnon, who was arrested a few hours later at a nearby building. Last night, charges against him were pending, the police said. Sid Dinsay, a spokesman for the health department, said he did not know if the inspection was routine or the result of a complaint. He said day camps are inspected once a year. title: 36 Hours in Halifax, Nova Scotia
description: HALIFAX is a harbor city steeped in maritime history. Founded in 1749 as a British naval and military base, it originally served as a strategic counter to French bases elsewhere in Atlantic Canada - and many years later as an assembly point for shipping convoys during World Wars I and II. Today, Halifax is better known for its lobster, which you can fill up on from morning (lobster eggs Benedict anyone?) till night and still have enough cash left for a sail around the harbor on a tall ship. A vibrant student population - six universities with more than 30,000 students - gives the city of 115,000 a youthful, bohemian feel, too. As a result, it's often compared to that other hilly town on the ocean, San Francisco, but you'll find that Halifax's blend of fair-trade coffee bars, wharfside lobster shacks and public gardens is special.

title: How to Poison a River
description: New York is increasingly a state of mega-dairies, and when things go wrong with such operations, they go wrong in a mega-way. The Marks Farm near Lowville, N.Y., has a herd of some 3,000 dairy cows. Their milk is trucked away regularly, but their liquefied manure is stored in a reservoir with earthen walls. How much manure? Before Aug. 11, the reservoir at the Marks Farm contained some three million gallons. Sometime in the next day, one of the walls blew out and released most of that waste into the Black River, a popular fishing stream and a water source for towns downstream. In case you have trouble visualizing it, three million gallons of liquid manure is roughly equivalent to the water in six Olympic-size swimming pools.

The most glorious red sunset fitting to a passionate fisherman followed. Paul was born in Chestnut Hill, PA on December 28, 1930. He attended St. Georges School in Newport, RI and the University of Miami. He is survived by his three children, Susan Bell Latham of Coto de Caza, CA and her husband, Glenn and two sons, Alex and Collin; Paul Lewis Bell, Jr. of Miami, FL., his wife Pam and two daughters, Morgan and Paula; and daughter Roberta Laural Bell of Rancho Santa Margarita, CA; his loving companion, Barbara Gellner of Delray Beach and his brother Samuel Bell, Jr. of Queenstown, MD. His wives, Arlene W. Bell and Jeanne W. Bell, the mother of his children, predecease him. Paul had a long career in the travel industry working for National Airlines and Pan American Airlines and then starting Ocean Ridge Travel with wife Arlene. Paul was a Bon Vivant who loved life and his friends, who made his life full. He traveled extensively and took many groups to exotic places around the world. He was a Founding and International member of Skal, and member of Rotary, The Little Club, St. Andrews, West Palm Beach Fishing Club, Manalapan Yacht Club, Delray Beach Yacht Club and founding member of Ocean Ridge Croquet Club. Paul's memory lives on in his family and friends whose lives he has touched. A celebration of his life will be forthcoming. title: The Listings: Aug. 19 -- Aug. 25; 'PRECIOUS MOMENTS'
description: Mall culture, with its peculiar poignancies, is the theme of "Precious Moments," a smart, sad five-person group show organized by the artist Josh Kline. Liz Rywelski, a member of the Space 1026 collective in Philadelphia, sets the tone with two large series of photographic portraits, of which she is the subject. She had the pictures taken in photo studios of Kmarts and Wal-Marts across the country. At each store, she told the staff a story, real or invented, about her life, then let them style the image they felt was most "her." In some, she looks like a schoolgirl, in others like a matron, in still others like a country-western star. And in all of them, she is a passive screen on which other people can project tastes, expectations and fantasies. Brian Belott deals in found-fantasy, too, but in a more hands-on way. He collects packets of lost or abandoned snapshots from junk shops and trash bins, chooses those that interest him, and arranges them in cheap albums by theme: dozens of pictures of televisions, say, or middle-American dining rooms decorated for holidays. Although there's an occasional hint of a narrative, people rarely appear; he lets their snapshots of the things they value, and an illusion of individuality common to us all, speak for them. Shana Moulton raises illusion to the spiritual plane in a video titled "Whispering Pines No. 5" (above), in which she plays a New Ager named Cynthia, who performs rituals of regeneration while wearing an American Indian blanket. Or rather an electric blanket -- mall-bought, no doubt -- printed with American Indian motifs. But for true mall realness, you must turn to two other artists. From Walead Beshty comes a picture of a boarded-up "dead mall," only a few years old and already killed by the competition. And from Michael Smith, the show's senior artist, there is an unnerving document of a mall of yesteryear. In his photographic cartoon strip, "The Biggest Building in the World," dated 1982-2005, the artist appears wandering through an indoor plaza, in a self-contained and inviting commercial ecosystem, that turns out to be the main concourse of the World Trade Center. (Joymore, 236 Grand. Street, Williamsburg, Brooklyn, (646)270-0376, through Sept. 10.) HOLLAND COTTER

title: 36 Hours in Halifax, Nova Scotia
description: HALIFAX is a harbor city steeped in maritime history. Founded in 1749 as a British naval and military base, it originally served as a strategic counter to French bases elsewhere in Atlantic Canada -- and many years later as an assembly point for shipping convoys during World Wars I and II. Today, Halifax is better known for its lobster, which you can fill up on from morning (lobster eggs Benedict anyone?) till night and still have enough cash left for a sail around the harbor on a tall ship. A vibrant student population -- six universities with more than 30,000 students -- gives the city of 115,000 a youthful, bohemian feel, too. As a result, it's often compared to that other hilly town on the ocean, San Francisco, but you'll find that Halifax's blend of fair-trade coffee bars, wharfside lobster shacks and public gardens is special. title: The Listings: Aug. 19 -- Aug. 25; JALEEL SHAW
description: A decade ago, a young musician like Jaleel Shaw would probably be touting a major-label recording debut. But the market for new jazz artists has roughly followed the same trajectory as the Internet bubble, and so Mr. Shaw, above, has instead been compelled to announce his arrival with "Perspective," a CD on the Barcelona-based label Fresh Sound New Talent. Musically, this may not be a bad thing; the album is a showcase for Mr. Shaw's stout, self-assured alto saxophone playing and his smartly conceived original compositions, without the taint of commercial pressure. "Perspective" also introduces a strikingly cohesive ensemble of Mr. Shaw's peers, including the drummer Johnathan Blake, a childhood friend from Philadelphia; the guitarist Lage Lund and the bassist Vicente Archer, fellow graduates of the Berklee College of Music; and the pianist Robert Glasper, who released his own Fresh Sound album before signing with Blue Note Records this year. Altogether, these musicians are stewards of a next-generation jazz mainstream that's inspired, not constrained, by timeworn traditions. Mr. Shaw's sound on alto saxophone can variously suggest Cannonball Adderley, Jackie McLean or his mentor, Bobby Watson -- it's brawny and full-bodied, but capable of quicksilver actions -- and his improvisational method is surefooted and exploratory. His songs range in tone from "The Heavyweight Champ," an intricately boppish charger, to "Miss Myriam," a melancholy ode in waltz time. On these originals and a few choice covers (like "Grand Central," a barnburner memorably recorded by Adderley and John Coltrane), Mr. Shaw's crew provides evidence of jazz's vigorous health -- and the upside of independence. (Tonight at 9 and 10:30, Jazz Gallery, 290 Hudson Street, South Village, (212)242-1063; cover, $15; members, $10.) NATE CHINEN

title: The Listings: Aug. 19 -- Aug. 25; KATE BURTON
description: When it comes to dishing out brittle dialogue in a drawing room, Kate Burton talks the talk better than any American actress of her generation. Whether playing a grandiloquent Victorian actress in "The Elephant Man" or a quip-dispensing Sapphist in David Mamet's "Boston Marriage," Ms. Burton has never been less than fluent in the ornate language of epigrams. What sets her apart, though, is her gift for finding psychological grit in linguistic sparkle, a trait most happily in evidence in Mark Brokaw's production of W. Somerset Maugham's "Constant Wife" for the Roundabout Theater Company, which closes Sunday. As the title character in this 1926 tale of marital infidelity, Ms. Burton (above with John Dossett) turns the manners in comedy of manners into potent, all-conquering weapons. Like her Hedda Gabler (on Broadway in 2001), Ms. Burton's Constance Middleton comes across as the brightest, most forward-thinking person in a roomful of dim relics. Intelligence and a wicked sense of humor were what finally destroyed Hedda, in Ms. Burton's rendering of her. They are what allow her Constance to triumph, while illuminating unexpected Shavian ironies in Maugham's droll charting of the intersection of economic and sexual power in the early 20th century. description: ELDER--R. Duncan. 88, of Cold Spring Harbor, after a long illness, on August 14, 2005. Beloved husband for over 64 years of Frances (nee) Noyes. Loving father of Robert D. (Betsy), Sarah M, and Alexander N. (Jacki). Adoring grandfather of Rebecca, Duncan S, Molly, Henry and Angus. Housing visionary. Hotchkiss 1935, Yale 1939, Columbia Law School 1946, Captain USNR, World War II, destroyer USS Hobson, and commanded USS Jeffers. Under his stewardship Phipps Houses developed over 2300 units of housing including Bellevue South and Bronx Park South and managed housing in Sunnyside, Manhattan westside, New York Hospital, Rockefeller University, and Sloan Kettering. Also director of the National Housing Conference and president and director of the Citizens Housing and Planning Council of NY; vice chairman for the NY Foundation for Senior Citizens and past co-chair NY Housing Conference. Founder and president of Huntington Senior Citizens Housing Committee Inc. from 1971-2003 creating Paumanack Village with over 500 units of affordable senior citizen housing on LI. Duncan Elder was a socially committed man of exemplary int egrity and vision. Little known to the thousands of families who he enabled to live comfortably, he worked tirelessly for the public good. He was a gentle, deeply loving husband and father. Funeral Service to be held at St. John's Church in Cold Spring Harbor on Saturday at 11AM. In lieu of flowers, please make donations to The Duncan Elder Fund, C/O Huntington Senior Citizens Housing Committee Inc, 36 North New York Ave, Huntington, NY 11743, 631-421-5353.

title: The Listings: Aug. 19 -- Aug. 25; SUFJAN STEVENS
description: You could say that the indie folk singer-songwriter and banjoist Sufjan Stevens believes in state's rights. That is, this Detroit native and questing Christian, now living in Brooklyn, believes in every state's right to be the subject of a gentle, exhaustive album. His second offering in this monumental project, "Illinois" (Asthmatic Kitty), is a 22-song swing through Prairie State history. Of course, historical tidbits like the 1893 Chicago World's Fair, homesteader hardship and the relative debating talents of Lincoln and Douglas mostly provide a jump-off for self-reflection. A man of his times, the 30-year-old Mr. Stevens, above, is both a legitimate history buff and a Google tourist. He is imbued with an outward-looking, Copland-esque musical vision and a narcissistic idea of the surveyable self reminiscent of Walt Whitman, though his lyrics can have an emo overreach and his compositions tend to forge into the folksily baroque. But his quiet, assured voice and pained personal revelations keep things intimate. At his best, Mr. Stevens has our pleasure in mind, as when the humorously titled "Come on, Feel the Illinoise" slides out of its complex meter into a simpler rhythm. When Mr. Stevens's lyrical approach succeeds, as in his account of a friend's death from bone cancer, falling on Casimir Pulaski Day, it can be breathtaking. When it doesn't, it can be a trifle maddening, especially when the melody is indelible. An antifolk aria about John Wayne Gacy disingenuously turns a falsetto lament for the killer's victims into an inward-looking recrimination. But such indulgences are forgivable for an emotional cartographer who promises so much. (Tonight through Tuesday at 8 p.m., Bowery Ballroom, 6 Delancey Street, Lower East Side, (212)533-2111; $15, sold out.) LAURA SINAGRA

Most of the victims are from poor village families, with parents complaining of a shortage of medicines, doctors and hospital beds. title: United States of Emergency
description: Anyone who has been to the border areas in Arizona and New Mexico knows about some of the horrible things that are happening at America's edge. The news is so alarming and the hope for relief from Washington is so dim that the governors of New Mexico and Arizona have finally declared states of emergency in those areas. It is as if those counties bordering on Mexico had been hit by floods or hurricanes or any other natural disaster, except that this is not a natural disaster. The scenes of death, drug smuggling, kidnapping and more are manmade, a security emergency that should be fixed, soon, by politicians in Washington and Mexico City.

In June, a fisherman, Antonino Randazzo, spotted Mr. Lubeck's credit cards, still in a plastic sheath, in a net 15 miles off Gloucester, nearly 30 miles from where it was lost. title: Italy Plans Security for the Colosseum

The movable barriers are to go up within several days, but there was no word on how long they would be in place. In the wake of the terrorist attacks in London last month, Italy has been revamping its security measures and taking strides to protect its most treasured historic monuments. Metal detectors and X-ray machines were installed at the Colosseum's entrances this month. Brian Wingfield (NYT)

title: Arts, Briefly; 'Big Brother' Big for CBS
description: Though a public vote among viewers put Kaysar Ridha, below, back in the "Big Brother" house a week after he was evicted, Thursday's private vote among contestants resulted in his ouster again. In Nielsen's overnight estimates, "Big Brother" brought in an audience of 8.34 million, once again anchoring a Thursday win for CBS. Repeats of "CSI" (12.52 million) and "Without a Trace" (12.82 million) followed "Big Brother," and CBS was No. 1 both in total viewers and among adults 18 to 49 in every half-hour of prime time. Fox, usually in the ratings basement on Thursdays this summer, finished second for the night on the strength of its preseason football broadcast of the New Orleans Saints' victory over the New England Patriots. NBC finished fifth in total viewers with repeats of shows it has renewed for next season: "Joey," "Will & Grace," two episodes of "Scrubs" and "ER" drew an average of just 4.7 million viewers. Arts, Briefly; Rehab for Eminem
description: Eminem is undergoing treatment for a dependence on sleep medication, his publicist said. The announcement, made late Thursday, came two days after the Grammy-winning rapper canceled the 12-date European leg of his Anger Management tour, citing exhaustion and unspecified medical issues. The tour was scheduled to end with a Sept. 17 performance at Slane Castle in Ireland. Since releasing his first album in 1999, Eminem has kept a demanding schedule. He has since produced three other solo studio albums (including the best-seller of 2002, "The Eminem Show," which has sold 9.4 million copies), two albums with his rap crew D12, and a soundtrack to his semi-autobiographical film, "8 Mile." Last month, the rapper, whose real name is Marshall Mathers, denied reports that he planned to retire from recording and touring. Paul Rosenberg, his manager, said at the time that Eminem's current album, "Encore," was "the close of the first chapter of Eminem the recording artist." He added, "To speculate beyond that is just a guess." Eminem's current tour, with 50 Cent, had suffered from lackluster box-office sales, compounded by what analysts regarded as high ticket prices and the historically weak track record of live rap concerts. Before the news of his medication dependency, Interscope Records, the label that distributes his albums, was in the early stages of planning an Eminem greatest-hits package, intending to release it the next few months; it is now unclear when the project will be completed. JEFF LEEDS

title: Presidential Vote Set in Kazakhstan
description: The Constitutional Council ruled that the next presidential election should take place in December, setting the stage for another electoral confrontation between an authoritarian government and its opponents in one of the former Soviet republics. The decision thwarted initial efforts by President Nursultan Nazarbayev to hold the vote a year later, citing a constitutional provision calling for elections seven years after the president takes office. Since Mr. Nazarbayev began his second term in January 1999, that would have meant pushing the election back until December 2006. Mr. Nazarbayev, who has ruled throughout the country's independence from the Soviet Union in 1991, has already said he will seek a third term. Opposition parties have vowed to unite behind a single challenger. Steven Lee Myers (NYT)

title: Intelligent Design and the Smithsonian
description: The Smithsonian Institution can't seem to disentangle itself from the clutches of the anti-evolution crowd. Earlier this year, the Smithsonian's natural history museum discovered to its dismay that it had agreed to be the host and co-sponsor of a movie intended to undercut the theory of evolution and make the case for "intelligent design," the idea that an intelligent agent had a hand in designing the universe. Only after intelligent-design proponents started chortling on the Internet about their stunning coup in co-opting the Smithsonian did museum officials reverse course and withdraw their sponsorship, while allowing the film to be shown.

title: BUSINESS BRIEFS
description: Takeover Bid for Nursing Home Chain The nursing home operator Beverly Enterprises said that it had received an unsolicited $1.64 billion takeover offer from a group of investors that topped its existing $1.63 billion acquisition pact with North American Senior Care. An investor group led by Formation Capital had raised its offer for Beverly Enterprises to $12.90 a share in cash, which was higher than overtures it previously made and exceeded the $12.80-a-share deal the nursing home company sealed on Wednesday with North American Senior Care. Traders said that the two offers were so close in value that North American Senior Care could return with a higher bid, creating a bidding war for Beverly, which operates 345 nursing homes, and assisted-living and hospice centers. (Reuters)

If you threw in resemblances to the mature Gregory Peck and Charlton Heston, the air of patriarchal gravitas Mr. Diamond oozed seemed almost ready for enshrinement on Mount Rushmore, or if not that monument, at a Las Vegas imitation that replaces the faces of presidents with the mugs of entertainers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HELTON, MARY (GOODELL)
description: HELTON -- Mary (Goodell), Director Emeritus of the Hoff - Barthelson Music School in Scarsdale, NY, died on August 13, after a long illness, at the age of 78. She was recognized throughout the country as an extraordinary leader in the field of music education. Mrs. Helton joined the faculty of Hoff-Barthelson in 1952. In the course of her twenty-seven year tenure as the Music School's Director, which ended with her retirement in 1999, the school became a respected cultural institution for arts education and performance in the county, as well as one of the largest and most renowned community music schools in the country. Mrs. Helton's Let's Play the Piano, Books 13 was last published in a 1998 revision. Her professional affiliations included the Advisory Boards of New York's Education through Music, Inc., and the Suburban Community Music Center of Madison, New Jersey. She was a past secretary of the New York State Music Teachers' Association and the Music Educators' League of Westchester, and a member of the New York Federation of Music Clubs Program Committee and the National Guild of Community Schools of the Arts. She received the Woman of the Year Award in 1997 from the Zonta Club of the Mount Vernon Area and was recognized by the Westchester Arts Council in 1999 for her artistic vision and leadership. Sigma Alpha Iota, an international music fraternity, named her a National Arts Associate. She was a member of Phi Kappa Phi. Her husband, Charles Helton, and her sister, Margaret Ebersole of Lansing, Michigan, preceded her in death. She is survived by her sister, Muriel Benedict, of San Pedro, California; eight nieces and nephews; and her many dear friends whom she considered her family. A Memorial Concert will be held in her honor at the Hoff-Barthelson Music School on a date to be announced this fall. Donations in her name may be sent to the Mary Helton Scholarship Fund at the HoffBarthelson Music School, 25 School Lane, Scarsdale, New York, 10583.

description: TOMASHEFSKY--Philip, 81, of Somers, NY, died of respiratory failure, August 15. Beloved to wife Rhoda (37 years), sons Steven and Michael and sister Sondra. Phil attended Erasmus Hall and City College and earned a Ph.D. in biochemistry from NYU. During his career as a research biochemist at the Funk Foundation and on the Columbia Medical School faculty, he published many important scientific papers. During WWII, Phil served with the Timberwolf Division, earning a Purple Heart after being seriously wounded in Germany. Phil's interest in travel, the arts, food and wine and model railroading enriched the lives of all who knew him. He once observed that he had family that were like friends and friends that were like family. The "Rigor Mortis Society", which he co-founded, is a group of the latter who have gathered for over 60 years. A celebration of Phil's life will be held on September 21. Contributions in Phil's name can be made to the Parkinson's Foundation, 710 W. 168 St, NY, NY 10032.

title: File Share and Share Alike
description: For most in the culture industry, the chance of the file-sharing program BitTorrent serving a positive function is as likely as Darth Vader joining Habitat for Humanity. The popular program is a well-known tool for downloading pirated versions of films and television series. It has been especially popular among fans of Japanese animation, or anime -- especially "fansubbers," anime lovers who swap their own subtitled versions of programs, and frequently get them into circulation before the original series is on the market. Fansubbers tend to think of themselves as enthusiasts sharing material they love, rather than pirates who buy, sell or horde it. Nonetheless, lawyers are not amused: in December, a Tokyo law firm representing one Japanese anime distributor e-mailed four major Web sites, asking them to stop encouraging the theft of the distributors' series.

title: The Breaking Point
description: The largest oil terminal in the world, Ras Tanura, is located on the eastern coast of Saudi Arabia, along the Persian Gulf. From Ras Tanura's control tower, you can see the classic totems of oil's dominion -- supertankers coming and going, row upon row of storage tanks and miles and miles of pipes. Ras Tanura, which I visited in June, is the funnel through which nearly 10 percent of the world's daily supply of petroleum flows. Standing in the control tower, you are surrounded by more than 50 million barrels of oil, yet not a drop can be seen. 'The world has never faced a problem like this,' a report for the U.S. Energy Department concludes. 'Previous energy transitions (wood to coal and coal to oil) were gradual and evolutionary; oil peaking will be abrupt and revolutionary.

Cross into the lava desert or the geothermic badlands and you'll understand why the island's people -- descendants of Vikings, most of them -- talk freely of elves and the "invisible people."

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BEITER, JOHN F. II,
description: BEITER--John F. II, son of Laraine and Jack Beiter, died suddenly of heart failure, August 10, on the island of Mykonos, Greece. John was Managing Director of Resolution Partners LLC., in New York City. John was born in Wilkes Barre, Pennsylvania. His schooling started in King of Prussia, PA., and was furthered in Edison, N.J., and Mayfield, Ohio. At Mayfield, he became only their 2nd State Wrestling Champion in school history. John graduated summa cum laude from Hofstra University, New York, where he wrestled Varsity for 4 years, as well as participating on the Debate Team. John received his Law Degree from George Washington University in Washington, D.C., and after practicing Law for a period, moved into the Investment Business, where he traveled throughout the Middle East. He furthered his career by studying abroad and then received his MBA from New York University in New York City. Gaining experience at several Investment Companies, he then formed a partnership with Niklas Lamotte and their own company, Resolution Partners, L.L.C., New York City. John is survived by his wife, Johanna, and two daughters, Katie and Andrea; mother, Laraine, and father, Jack; twin brothers, Justin and Jeffrey; Justin's son, Kyle; Jeffrey's wife, Sheryl, and daughters, Haley and Carly. Friends may offer condolences from 9:30AM to 11AM, Monday, August 22, at St. Katharine's Catholic Church, corner of Aberdeen and Lancaster Avenues, Wayne, PA., followed by a mass at 11AM to be said in his honor. Burial will be private for family only. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to Bridges to Community, 95 Croton Avenue, Ossining, N.Y. 10562.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DIAMOND, EVA
description: DIAMOND--Eva. Died peacefully at home, August 10, 2005, after a long illness. She was 82 years old. She was born in Hanover, Germany. Her father, Edmund Lillienstern, died when she was nine, and she came to the United States at age 13, with her mother, a U.S. citizen by birth. Eva spoke no English when she arrived, but became fluent in the language by the time she finished high school and went on to Barnard College. During WWII, she completed the program at Columbia-Presbyterian School of Nursing, worked for a year at the Hospital and then began a long association as a public health nurse with the Visiting Nurse Service of New York. She took graduate courses at Teachers College, and in 1952, to pursue her abiding passion for constitutional law, she entered the Columbia University Law School. After her first year, she took a leave of absence to accompany her husband for a year in Boston. She returned to New York with a five-week-old baby, the first of her four sons, and decided then to be a full-time homemaker. She lived with her young family for a time in London, St. Louis, and New York City before moving to Garden City where she resided for the past 38 years. As a proud homemaker, she was a devoted wife and a loving mother to her sons. She was admired for her sharp wit and her directness; and her significant contributions to school, church and community, coupled with a strong sense of loyalty and fairness, endeared her to all who knew her. In 1973, she returned to work with the VNS. She became a respected grievance representative for her fellow nurses, and served as a member of the executive committee of their Union in the UFT. These were roles she relished, both for the pursuit of causes she judged to be just, and to express more fully the camaraderie she felt with her colleagues. After retirement, she resumed all those activities which her declining health allowed. She was a prodigious reader, a prolific writer and a devoted gardener. She was also a talented cook who was wellknown for the Stollen and an endless variety of cookies she baked and distributed every Christmas. She was greatly loved, and will be held fast in memory by her many friends & her extended family; by Sidney, her husband of 52 years; by her sons, Michael (Reina), Andrew (Elizabeth), Robert and Christopher (Dione); and by her grandchildren, Laura, Amy, Julie, Lilly and Meredith. A memorial service will be held on October 1, at 1 P.M., at the Unitarian-Universalist Church in Garden City, New York.

title: Will We Ever Arrive at the Good Death?
description: When my siblings and I found out that our mother's cancer had spread and that she had weeks, at the most, we grappled with whether or not we should discuss this with her. My sister and brother loved the frank way that my mother had initially discussed the diagnosis with us and wanted to continue being honest with her. I, on the other hand, was afraid that she would be unable to handle the news. That night, my brother sat at her bedside while she recounted an earlier conversation with a doctor who was apparently trying to be straightforward with her about her treatment. "I don't like her," my mother said. "She takes away my hope. You can't take away my hope." He realized then that she needed her hope more than she needed the truth.

title: Nonfiction Chronicle
description: THE EDWARDIANS. By Roy Hattersley. (St. Martin's, $35.) The Edwardian period has long been dismissed as a mere interlude between the Victorian era and World War I. Hattersley, a former deputy leader of the Labor Party and cabinet minister, will have none of this. Displaying an A. J. P. Taylor-like zest for turning orthodoxy on its head, Hattersley argues that the Edwardians blazed the path to modernity. He traces the emergence of the Labor Party and the consequences of David Lloyd George's famous 1909 "People's Budget," which levied punitive taxes on the aristocracy. His forays into social history, including the rise of the populist Fleet Street "New Journalism," are never less than riveting. Looming over Hattersley's account is the shadow of Queen Victoria's insolent grandson, Kaiser Wilhelm, whose fecklessness triggered the Big Bang of August 1914, which toppled the Russian and Austro-Hungarian dynasties, not to mention his own. For all the ferment chronicled by Hattersley, it was the British monarchy that proved the ultimate survivor.

description: Q. In a summer surprise, everyone in your department received a salary increase. Upon chatting with colleagues, however, you learn that your raise was significantly more modest than the rest. What do you do?

title: Walking the Wrong Way
description: The Bush administration has announced plans for a Freedom Walk on Sept. 11, which will start at the Pentagon and end at the National Mall, and include a country music concert. The event is an ill-considered attempt to link the Iraq war to the terrorist attacks of 2001, and misguided in almost every conceivable way. It also badly misreads the public's mood. The American people are becoming increasingly skeptical about the war. They want answers to hard questions, not pageantry.

title: A STROLL IN GALWAY
description: To the Editor: J.P. Slavin's great overview of the sites to see in "Going to Galway" (July 10) correctly concludes that it is always best to walk the city and its environs.

description: On the morning of Jim Denevan's outdoor dinner party, finding a skiff topped a long list of problems.

title: La-La Land: The Origins
description: California legislators are worried about the decline in film production in Los Angeles, and are considering a bill to encourage more of it. But how did the American movie business, which was born in New York City in the 1890's, wind up on the other side of the continent in the first place?

title: DOT-COM PLAY PAYS OFF
description: As a hedge fund manager, Robert L. Chapman Jr. is supposed to find savvy investments overlooked by others. But one of his best picks is neither stock nor bond. Nine years ago, he acquired the rights to the domain name hedgefunds.com, and he says that a prospective buyer recently offered $500,000 for it.

title: Editors' Choice
THE WEEK AHEAD: Aug. 21 -- Aug. 27; POP/JAZZ
description: "Sleeper hit" may seem like an odd way to describe a teen-pop smash. But the term seems to fit "LET ME HOLD YOU," a collaboration between the singer OMARION and the rapper BOW WOW, formerly known as Lil' Bow Wow. (After a few years, the adjective seemed to refer less to his age than to his stature; perhaps that's why it was retired.) The song sneaked up the pop charts and stuck around near the top; in a less competitive season -- one without MARIAH CAREY, say -- it could have been a candidate for song of the summer. As it is, it's just another delectable also-ran. Bow Wow delivers shockingly polite pick-up lines, rapping, "When you cry, I wanna feel your pain/ No secrets, no games." Even better is the lithe chorus from Omarion, a former member of the black boy-band B2K, who began a solo career with a CD called "O" (Sony/BMG).

title: Matched Sets: The Pen and the Voice
description: A playwright's best fortune is to share the profession with actors whose mouths seem shaped to fit his words. Jason Robards deftly personified the written worlds of Eugene O'Neill (even if the playwright didn't live long enough to see any of the actor's definitive performances). During the past two decades, Edward Albee's exacting syntax has been very nicely voiced by Marian Seldes and Rosemary Harris. And recently, the moody, ruminative Ron Rifkin completed his latest stint as mouthpiece of choice for the moody, ruminative playwright Jon Robin Baitz, in "The Paris Letter."

title: Girls Just Want to Belong
description: Club Libby Lu Whether we want to admit it or not, Mary Drolet argues, there was a time in our lives when we all pretended to be rock stars or princesses. That time was childhood, the years before the line between fantasy and reality becomes more tangible. This belief, in part, is what guided Drolet in founding, with two partners, a business called Club Libby Lu, which offers 5- to 13-year-old girls the chance to live out one of several (overtly girlish) fantasies, at least for the duration of an hour-and-a-half-long party in a shopping mall.

title: How's That? You Want to Be in Politics?

title: IN THE ''BACK YARD'' OF WALL DRUG, OFF INTERSTATE 90, July 22, 2005
description: Pat Caldwell, owner of a construction company in Sobieski, Wis. "We were on our way back home from Yellowstone and the Tetons. And we had hoped to take a trip like this for several years with our children because my wife and I hadn't been out there in 28 years. I think that places like this are just a way for us to attempt to participate in what actually did take place, even though it is so artificial." But what about that wildly bucking bronco? "Well, it looked like a real horse," Mr. Caldwell said. "It still had the hair on it and everything. The reason I got on was just to act like a kid and to have fun with my family -- a little bit of escapism, you know? I relish the real stuff more than the artificial stuff, and this place is just such a tourist trap but you have to stop, you know?" As told to Austin Considine WHY WE TRAVEL: WALL, S.D.

I'd be sitting there having a beer and watching the wrestling on TV when suddenly the guy sitting next to me would say to the guy on his other side: "The dummy drew a gun. The black dude who's always got to count the money first. There's no need of that stuff if you do business right. I don't need it with him anymore."

Blowing in straight off the South China Sea, the wind molds and remolds the white and pink-gold sand dunes that surround Mui Ne and frustrates the fishermen, who eke out a living catching squid and tuna on the horizon.

He still lives in his boyhood home on Willis Creek, which feeds into the Forge, but Mr. Lupski has not been able to take advantage of his waterfront property in years.

title: Up Front
description: Marilyn Stasio is a woman of mystery in more ways than one. Google her name and you'll find thousands of entries, but most of them will steer you away from her and directly to her work -- as a theater critic and as one of the country's most respected reviewers of mystery and crime fiction. She lectures frequently and doesn't actually swear off interviews, but when we recently asked her to talk about herself, her first reaction was typical: "Couldn't I wriggle out of this?" Stasio is smart, funny and, even after 17 years of writing the Book Review's crime column, "kind of passionate" about what she does. "I've always been analytical," she says. "I loved algebra in school." So it's natural that she's less interested in writing "thumbs up, thumbs down" reviews than in figuring out why a book works -- or doesn't. She started out as a fan of classical puzzle mysteries, then fell for hard-boiled writers like Chandler and Hammett. These days, she's a particular champion of small-press mysteries, which are often foreign imports or reprints of classic novels from earlier eras. The mystery field continues to unfold new riches: "There are so many moving parts, so many subgenres and categories, with new ones turning up all the time." In a special essay this week, she turns her attention to one of the newest -- what's come to be known as the chick-lit mystery.

title: It's Cool When the Sun Comes Out. Really.
description: ON a blazing hot afternoon earlier this month, Gene Feeney stood outside his home in West Harrison and studied his electric meter. The wheel turned slowly to the right, measuring the electricity it was pulling from the power lines. Mr. Feeney stepped inside and shut off the air-conditioner. The wheel stopped ever so briefly, then started turning the other way.

title: A WALKING TOUR
description: To the Editor: Regarding "Hikes in Europe, With Your Boots on the Ground and Your Bed Above It" (June 19), by Christopher Solomon: We have been considering the Hadrian's Wall Path in Britain for a couple of years. The article convinced us that now is the time. We sent an e-mail message to the tour operator, Lomond Walking Holidays, but received no reply. We called the telephone number and left a message but received no reply. I believe The New York Times should check out tour operators to make certain they are reliable before recommending them.

title: Orelia Merchant and Karim Camara
description: Orelia Eleta Merchant, the daughter of Audrey and Roland S. Merchant Sr. of Agoura Hills, Calif., was married last evening to the Rev. Karim Camara, a son of Ora Abdur-Razzaq and Abdullah Abdur-Razzaq, both of Brooklyn. The Rev. Ross M. Johnson Jr., a Baptist minister, performed the ceremony at Tulane Memorial Baptist Church in New Orleans.

title: Summertime, and the Parking Is Easy
description: WHITE PLAINS, Aug. 18 - The rising mercury and occasional thunderstorms are enough to know it is August. But a better barometer of summer may well be the lunchtime concert in the middle of the business district here.

title: In Two-Player Comeback, It's the Battle of Belgium
description: TORONTO, Aug. 20 - Neither Justine Henin-Hardenne nor Kim Clijsters, rivals from different parts of Belgium, could have known when they last met, in the 2004 Australian Open final, that they would soon tumble into the abyss of injury and illness.

title: New Overtures at the Symphony
description: YOU do not have to know anything about classical music, a St. Louis Symphony-linked Web site says. You do not have to dress up "like a fancy-pants." Then there is this ringing recommendation for a musical experience: "Yes, it will be possible to get your Brahms on and enjoy yourself at the same time."

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about the popularity of nonfiction books at at airport stores misspelled the surname of one of the authors of "Freakonomics," a best seller. He is Steven D. Levitt, not Leavitt.

title: Katherine Worden and John Shepherd
description: Katherine Hill Worden, a daughter of Virginia Hill Worden and Geoffrey F. Worden of Summit, N.J., was married at her parents' house in Highlands, N.C., last evening to John Redpath Shepherd, the son of Anne L. Shepherd and Thomas A. Shepherd of Fort Collins, Colo. The bride's father, an interfaith minister, officiated.

title: A Girl's Guide to Killing
description: HERE'S something I pulled up from the memory bank the other day, after cruising the mystery aisles of my neighborhood bookstore and discovering that many of the new titles had a distinctly chick-lit ring. The memory that still burns bright is of an editor at a major publishing house addressing a packed auditorium of would-be authors, advising them to retool their unsold novels as mysteries. "That's what I've been telling my romance authors to do," she said, "because the mystery has a built-in structure. This solves your plot problems by giving you a simple formula to follow, but it still allows you to develop your heroine and get your romance into the story." I nearly crawled under my seat, dreading the invasion of crime fiction by all those undisciplined romantics.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: The Weekend With the Kids column on Aug. 7, about Chicago, misstated the nickname for a stretch of Michigan Avenue known for its upscale shopping. It is the Magnificent Mile, not the Miracle Mile. (There is a Miracle Mile in Manhasset, on Long Island.)

title: In the Woods, Monuments of Steel
description: AN old rusty farm rake was the inspiration for placing outdoor sculpture at Ward Pound Ridge Reservation in Cross River, N.Y., the nature preserve on the Fairfield-Westchester County border.

title: A Crescendoing Choir From the Graveyards of History
description: ATLANTA - AFTER a Mississippi grand jury indicted the 80-year-old Edgar Ray Killen in January for the killings of three civil rights workers in 1964, his trial was described as the last in a series of reckonings over the unpunished wrongs of the era.

title: Kitchen Voyeur: Sunny Side Up
description: It's getting harder and harder to save the world, particularly in the meteorogicially challenged Northeast. Intrigued by my friend the writer Patricia Bosworth's fervor for solar cooking -- using the sun alone for fuel -- I contacted one of its best-known and most passionate proponents, the figurative painter and sculptor Mary Frank. She enthusiastically invited me to lunch.

title: Will We Ever Arrive at the Good Death?
description: I read Henig's article with more than a casual interest. I was diagnosed with A.L.S. 16 months ago, and in May sat by my father's bed as he died, so I have given the subject of death a lot of thought. While taking care of practical matters (including paying for my own cremation), I can attest that it is almost impossible to grasp the fact of your own impending death. Part of me is still certain that it is all one colossal error. After all, I am incredibly healthy, except for the fatal disease.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A report in the Advisory column on June 19 about the Hilton Vancouver Washington referred incorrectly to its expected certification by the United States Green Building Council. Although the Hilton said it expected to become the first hotel in the United States to receive the Leadership in Energy and Environmental Design certification, another establishment -- the University of Maryland University College Inn and Conference Center in Adelphi -- was certified by the council on June 9 and thus became the first. A letter dated July 22 from OPX, the architecture firm for the Maryland center, reported the error. It was addressed to a freelance writer and did not reach the editors until Aug. 8. The Hilton hotel is still awaiting certification.

title: Other Voices: Advice for The Times About Using Freelancers
description: Hooray for your column on the use of freelance writers. Being one, I would like to suggest a return to an apparently abandoned policy of briefly stating the credentials of any writer who is not on staff.

title: Mlle. Non Tries a Few New Moves
description: LONDON - SYLVIE GUILLEM has never lacked character. So it was that in 1988, already the star dancer of her generation at 23, she walked out of the Paris Opera Ballet rather than bend to the will of its director, Rudolf Nureyev. At her next stop -- the Royal Ballet in London, where she remains a principal guest artist, "guest" being the operative word -- she was soon nicknamed Mademoiselle Non for being less than malleable.

title: Bad Yoga Pose
description: I am a yoga teacher seeking certification from a national yoga association, a rigorous process that includes demonstrating poses and teaching them to students. I am also pregnant. Until recently, pregnant women could be tested, performing modified poses, but now there is a new policy: "You must not be pregnant at the time of the assessment, out of consideration for your own health and that of your unborn child." Doesn't this unethically penalize women? Anonymous

title: Mama's Gone, Along With the Peach Cobbler
description: The fried chicken, collard greens and peach cobbler that had been churned out by Mama Duke Southern Cuisine from an unassuming Brooklyn storefront suddenly came to a halt one day this summer. The soul-food takeout restaurant, at Flatbush Avenue and Bergen Street in Prospect Heights, covered its windows, locked its doors and abruptly went out of business after nearly four years.

title: Vancouver
description: WHY GO NOW -- With clear days, August and September are two of Vancouver's months to shine. Much of the year, the city's rainfall rivals Seattle's, but in the sunny season, the number of outdoor cafes is the standard of comparison between the two coffee capitals. In September, whale-watching season is still good as orcas and humpbacks continue to appear along the mainland coast. There's always been a healthy energy to this outdoorsy, athletic city, but the buzz (construction and otherwise) increases ever more as Vancouver prepares to play host to the Winter Olympic Games in five years' time.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MCALEER, FRANCIS (FRANK)
description: McALEER--Francis (Frank). Died peacefully at his home on August 18, 2005. Beloved husband of Ann (nee Herlihy) for 48 years. Devoted father of Karen Conti of Sherman, CT., Ann Marie of Roslindale, MA. and Eileen McAleerGorman of New York City, and the late Francis McAleer, Jr. Brother to Thomas, Michael John, Patrick Joseph, Mary Ellen, Charles, Peter and Ann. Proud and loving grandfather to Laura, Stephen and Andrew. The family will receive friends at the Barrett Funeral Home, 148 Dean Dr., Tenafly, N.J. Sunday 2-4 and 7-9PM. Champions of ill-fitting clothes, itinerants who don't dwell on price-to-rent ratios, clowns are enemies of impulse control, averse to agenda setting. They thrive on humiliation and find truth in navet. Clowns, it can be said, are that species of performer ontologically most at odds with all that is New York.

title: Live From Gaza: A New View of Israel
description: RAMALLAH, WEST BANK - SOMETHING strange happened last week: Israeli settlers and Jewish extremists appeared human on Arab TV. This is not to say that Arabs have suddenly become soft on their historical enemies. But hours and hours of watching -- on all stations, including Al Jazeera -- close-ups of mothers and babies, of young women and older men, visibly in anguish as they were forced out of their homes, had an emotional effect.

title: How India Reconciles Hindu Values and Biotech
description: LONDON - IN 2001, President Bush restricted federal financing for stem cell research. The decision, which was shaped at least partly by the Republican Party's evangelical Christian base, and which disappointed many American scientists and businessmen, provoked joy in India. The weekly newsmagazine India Today, read mostly by the country's ambitious middle class, spoke of a "new pot of gold" for Indian science and businesses. "If Indians are smart," the magazine said, American qualms about stem cell research "can open an opportunity to march ahead."

title: Inside the List
description: TAXING AND SPENDING: There's a new No. 1 title on the hardcover nonfiction list this week -- "The FairTax Book," by Neal Boortz, a talk radio host, and John Linder, a Republican congressman from Georgia. Their jeremiad against the income tax and the I.R.S. knocks off David McCullough's "1776," which spent 10 weeks in the top spot. Boortz and Linder's plan is to nix the current income tax system (and the filing of tax returns) and install in its place a 23 percent retail sales tax on new goods and services. It's a big idea, and a pretty small book. ("Yes, we know," the authors write in their preface. "This book seems rather short. It's not 300 pages long. Well, that's exactly as it should be. So take it to the cash register and buy it anyway.") When Boortz and Linder appeared on Neil Cavuto's Fox News program, Cavuto didn't think their tax plan had much of a chance in the real world: "You work," he said to Linder, "in a body that I don't think will do diddly on it." By the end, though, Cavuto and the authors were trading jokes about who was richer, and whom the proposed tax plan would hurt most. "It's going to nail you, Neil," Boortz said to Cavuto. "It is going to nail you," Cavuto shot back. Then Cavuto added: "Talk about the congressman. . . . He's doomed no matter what."
