title: Fiction Chronicle
description: HERE IS WHERE WE MEET: By John Berger. (Pantheon, $24.) Berger's new book is referred to on its cover as "a fiction," but it feels more like a mishmash of semi-autobiographical musings. "Here Is Where We Meet" starts out promisingly. The narrator, John, is joined in Lisbon by his dead mother, who warns that "the dead don't stay where they are buried." As they wander the city, Berger, who is also an art critic, shows off his keen eye: the city's tiles, he writes, "draw attention to the visible" even while they "insist upon the fact that they are covering something up." But once John leaves Lisbon for Geneva, Krakow and other cities and other ghosts, Berger the critic gives way to Berger the sentimentalist, and the narrative descends into tedium. As he hangs out with former lovers, a teacher, a sculptor friend and even Rosa Luxemburg, it becomes impossible to tell who's alive and who's dead or why they've returned, and more difficult to care. The brief flashes of Berger's established brilliance will only make you itch to revisit his seminal book of criticism, "Ways of Seeing."

title: Neo-Creo
description: The word creationism, coined in 1868 in opposition to what was then called Darwinism or evolutionism, had fallen on hard times. As a result, the noun creationism (like its predecessor, teleology, the study of purposeful design in nature) gained a musty connotation while evolutionism modishly lost its -ism.

Her dread persists even after she remarries and raises a family with a crusading lawyer. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BELL, PAUL LEWIS
description: BELL--Paul Lewis.A lover of life and laughter, Paul Lewis Bell, 74, of Ocean Ridge, FL. passed away on August 10, 2005. The most glorious red sunset fitting to a passionate fisherman followed. Paul was born in Chestnut Hill, PA on December 28, 1930. He attended St. Georges School in Newport, RI and the University of Miami. He is survived by his three children, Susan Bell Latham of Coto de Caza, CA and her husband, Glenn and two sons, Alex and Collin; Paul Lewis Bell, Jr. of Miami, FL., his wife Pam and two daughters, Morgan and Paula; and daughter Roberta Laural Bell of Rancho Santa Margarita, CA; his loving companion, Barbara Gellner of Delray Beach and his brother Samuel Bell, Jr. of Queenstown, MD. His wives, Arlene W. Bell and Jeanne W. Bell, the mother of his children, predecease him. Paul had a long career in the travel industry working for National Airlines and Pan American Airlines and then starting Ocean Ridge Travel with wife Arlene. Paul was a Bon Vivant who loved life and his friends, who made his life full. He traveled extensively and took many groups to exotic places around the world. He was a Founding and International member of Skal, and member of Rotary, The Little Club, St. Andrews, West Palm Beach Fishing Club, Manalapan Yacht Club, Delray Beach Yacht Club and founding member of Ocean Ridge Croquet Club. Paul's memory lives on in his family and friends whose lives he has touched. A celebration of his life will be forthcoming. In lieu of flowers, the family requests contributions in memory of Paul Bell to The Cleveland Clinic Foundation, P.O. Box 931517, Cleveland, OH 44193-1655.

title: Pool Table
description: One of the splashier debuts at this year's Milan furniture fair was that of the London company Established & Sons. Contrary to what its name implies, it is run by young upstarts who want to showcase the best of British design and manufacturing talent. The show stopper of its first collection was easily the Aqua table by Zaha Hadid, the architect famous for her dynamic, fluid forms and compositions. While Hadid is no stranger to furniture design -- her chandelier for the Italian firm Sawaya & Moroni was another of the fair's most-talked-about items -- she has outdone herself here. The polyurethane-resin table's arches and asymmetrical curves imply a liquid quality that is rendered even more vivid by its swimming-pool-blue silicone-gel top. "It's like flying over water," Hadid says. And from a less metaphorical point of view, the table's structure allows the top to cantilever well out over the base, so people can sit at the corners without bumping their knees.

description: Sometimes being No.1 is not such a good thing. Take the latest report from the Center for Public Integrity in Washington. New York ranks first nationally as the state with the most lobbyists per legislator. Most states have about five lobbyists per lawmaker, which already seems like a lot. But New York clocks in at 18. That makes it more overloaded with lobbyists than Texas, more than Alaska. As anyone in the state lawmaking business can attest, being worse than Texas and Alaska is never a terribly good sign.

Under his leadership, the company grew from one store to ten branches, stretching along the Maine coast from Calais to Rockland. He was predeceased by his first wife, Louisa Robins Goodyear. He is survived by his wife, Sara Sulari Goodyear, two daughters, Grace Roosevelt and Cullen Goodyear, and one son, Tom Goodyear.

From my window, on the 10th floor of the ndra, the Westin (a pair of round skyscrapers) dominates the skyline. For those who want to avoid large convention hotels, boutique-style offerings include a handsome W and the Monaco (part of the Kimpton chain of quirky small hotels). The ndra, which opened in April 2004, is less chic than the W, less offbeat than the Monaco and less expensive than either.

title: Will We Ever Arrive at the Good Death?
description: Your article touched me deeply because of my husband's yearlong battle with cancer. May I suggest that those who are terminally ill may cling to life because they realize how precious every moment is, while those of us who experience good health generally take living for granted.

title: Better Than Google
description: Garrison, N.Y. - RECENTLY, with the still heat of summer pressing firmly across the Hudson River Valley, I contracted my first case of poison ivy -- an ugly, ripe mess that spread up my legs awaking me around midnight in a fit of fierce clawing at my flesh. A relative newcomer to the region by way of Manhattan, I was clueless about cures and so spent the long minutes between 12 a.m. and 1 a.m. hunched over a laptop Googling for help.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ALTFEST, BETH
description: ALTFEST--Beth, 59, died peacefully on August 19, 2005 surrounded by family and friends. She was a mother, wife, daughter, sister, and friend who deeply touched the lives of all who knew her. Her wit, candor, selflessness, generosity and most of all, the bravery with which she fought her illness, will forever serve as a source of inspiration to us. She is survived by her husband Robert, daughter Rachel, parents Frances and Seymour, brother Harvey and his wife Connie. Services will be held at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 331 Amsterdam Avenue on Sunday, August 21, 2005 at 12:45 PM. In lieu of flowers, please send contributions to: Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center, Ovarian Cancer Research, www.mskcc.org.

title: Some Notes on Reality
description: It's not that female supermodels are not real. They are flesh -- a little flesh -- and blood like anyone else. But the phrase "real women" automatically excludes them, if "real" means something like well within the range of normal body types. The new ad campaign from Dove featuring amateur models, with amateur bodies, in their underwear has turned the reality of real women into at least a temporary advertising asset. These women -- brightly lit, smiling broadly and unmodishly from the sides of buses -- are not likely to put the tall, thin tribe of beauties out of work anytime soon. But they give heart to real women everywhere. And they remind us how strange the human species looks through the lens of advertising.

title: Machine Dreams
description: If you needed any more proof that Democratic politics were in a profound state of upheaval, consider this: on the eve of the 2004 election, there were three especially powerful groups, aside from the Kerry campaign itself, working to turn out votes for the party in critical states, and those were the Democratic National Committee, the A.F.L.-C.I.O. and a lavishly endowed start-up known as America Coming Together. Nine months later, not one of these institutions has emerged entirely intact. First, Howard Dean staged a hostile takeover of the D.N.C. Then big labor unraveled on its 50th birthday. And finally, earlier this month, ACT announced that it was suspending most of its operations and closing down its state offices, effectively shuttering the largest independently financed turnout drive in history after a single outing.

title: Where the Play Dates Are Fun, but Itchy

She attended the Brearley School in New York City, Swarthmore College, and was a graduate of the Columbia-Presbyterian Hospital School of Nursing in New York. title: Movies
description: VANITY FAIR (2004) Tuesday at 7:30 a.m. on Cinemax. Who could be better than Reese Witherspoon, who played tough in "Legally Blonde" and "Election," to portray Becky Sharp, Thackeray's young, determined, almost ruthless heroine? Unfortunately, Ms. Witherspoon is not at her best here. Maybe she or the director, Mira Nair, saw Becky differently. But Ms. Nair does bring some welcome (and authentically 19th-century) Indian touches to the story. (Thackeray was born in Calcutta, after all.) Ms. Witherspoon is still an appealing presence on screen, as she traces Becky's climb out of poverty and up the social ladder. The many men in her life are played by, among others, Gabriel Byrne, Jonathan Rhys-Meyers, James Purefoy (above, with Ms. Witherspoon), Rhys Ifans, Jim Broadbent and Bob Hoskins.

title: Still Rocking, Still Swaggering, Still the Stones
description: BOSTON, Aug. 21 - Four decades ago, the Rolling Stones made their name by defying propriety. Now they are defying age. They opened their latest tour tonight at Fenway Park, with an audience of 36,000 filling the stands, the outfield and balconies overhanging the stage for the first of two shows here. Mick Jagger is 62, Keith Richards 61, Charlie Watts 64 and Ronnie Wood a spry 58. Age can be cruel to musicians, eroding voices and stamina. But yes, the Stones can still do it.

description: The University of Connecticut recently announced plans to build a new main entrance to its campus in Storrs, to be completed in 2007.

It's the Simple Things, but Some Hospitals Don't Do Them
description: AMERICANS' consolation for the vast and escalating cost of health care has always been the assurance that their money was buying a first-class system capable of extending their lives.

title: One of the Finest Exits In All of America
description: New Jerseyans generally avoid classification by exit. Nobody likes to be defined by an off-ramp -- unless it starts to make good business sense. In a marketing move inspired more by an if-you-can't-beat-'em line of thinking than by a wish to perpetuate the "what exit" stereotype, the Greater Elizabeth Chamber of Commerce has put forth its cartoony "Shop, Play and Stay at Exit 13A" campaign for a second summer season.

title: White Sox Reduced To a One-Man Show
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 20 - The Orlando Hernndez Show started early on Saturday and was, as always, entertaining. Statistically, El Duque, as Hernndez is known, ended up being the worst player on the field as the Yankees silenced the slip-sliding-away Chicago White Sox, 5-0, but he still forced almost every pair of eyes to follow him.

title: Will We Ever Arrive at the Good Death?
description: Never before has an article hit so close to home. Was it the timing, having lost my mother to lung cancer three months ago? Was it the opening paragraph about the death rattle and painfully remembering those last days of listening to it, feeling my mother was in distress? Was it the denial by both the patient and loved ones that death was imminent? After thinking long and hard, I realized that, if not for the hospice program, my mother never would have arrived at a good death, if there is one. She died at home with her five children present. Hospice and the home-health aide were saviors to my siblings and me.

title: Tennis's Other 'Battle of the Sexes,' Before King-Riggs
description: Margaret Court followed the money down a desolate two-lane highway. About 40 miles northeast of San Diego, the road known as Wildcat Canyon slithered past orange groves, a dusty Indian reservation and through the shadows of the Cuyamaca Mountains. It was an uncomfortable stretch, so isolated that Mexican drug smugglers favored the route for their midnight drops.

title: Empty House
description: IN May, about 30 cops stormed the downtown Manhattan club on West 14th Street where I am a member. They poured up the stairs, pushing through the twin security doors, and herded the 100 or so club members into a back room, where the police officers interrogated and photographed them. The last members were released at 2 a.m., but the staff on duty spent the night in jail. The doors were locked, and the club was closed. Permanently.

title: Will We Ever Arrive at the Good Death?
description: As a hospice social worker, I feel that "open access" is a trend that belongs in the realm of palliative care rather than hospice; we in the hospice movement must be wary of blurring our goals of enabling more natural, comfortable well-supported deaths. It is true that many are anxious about giving up medical interventions; it is our job to help them define what measures increase comfort rather than cure, and to offer only those measures.

That's by far the most popular month."

To date, the program has raised more than $1.5 billion for the organization. More than three million Americans participate in these local events each year, as do people in 21 other countries around the world.

title: Exile From Wall Street

It's a glorious summer day in Salt Lake City, where the deposed Morgan Stanley chief executive has come to lick his wounds, seeking the solace of hometown friends and family -- as far removed as a man can get from the serpentine intrigues of Wall Street.

title: The Secret Jardin
description: HOW will it feel to meander through a park 30 feet above the streets of Chelsea? Thanks to a recent decision by a federal agency giving the city an important green light to create just such a park along the High Line, the long-unused elevated railroad bed that snakes through the lower West Side, New Yorkers may well find out. People will not be able to stroll along that viaduct until 2007, when the first segment of the refurbished High Line is scheduled to open. For a quicker taste of what the future may hold, here is the story of another such midair park -- the only other one, in fact. It is called the Promenade Plante, and it is in Paris.

title: Strong Demand for Midrange Rentals
description: LIKE Gladys and Brian Ferrara, who have lived in the same garden apartment complex in New Rochelle for 25 years, many working families in Westchester continue to be priced out of home ownership. With the median cost of a single-family home soaring to a record $700,000 at the end of June, and the prices of condominiums and co-ops also reaching new highs, many middle-income earners have had to defer the dream of home ownership.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DUFFY, JOHN FRANCIS VINCENT ''JACK''
description: DUFFY--John Francis Vincent "Jack". Born May 8, 1915 in Brooklyn, NY, died July 10, 2005 in Pasadena, CA, following a brief illness. He was named for Uncle John Vincent Duffy. He was educated by the Sisters of Mercy at St. Catherine's Grammar School, the Jesuits at Fordham Prep, and the Christian Brothers at Manhattan College (BBA in Accounting, 1937). He became a CPA in New York and New Jersey, was associated with major accounting firms in New York, and worked for the legendary J.K. Lasser. He graduated from Brooklyn Law School in the top 5 percent of his class, was admitted to the State Bar of New York, and was a graduate of the Harvard Business School Advanced Management Program. In the 50's, he went to work for Charles Pfizer & Co. (Pfizer Inc.) at Bartlett St. in Brooklyn, where he started the Tax Department. During his tenure, he was instrumental in the development of the Pfizer Pension Plan, served as President of the Pfizer Foundation, and was Treasurer of the Company when he retired. He was predeceased by spouse Sophia Schaker Duffy in 1997, sister Eleanor Duffy Egan in 2000, and brother-in-law John F. Egan in May, 2005. He is survived by nieces Gae Brunner of Ridgewood, NJ, Bonnie Busenberg of Claremont, CA, Eleanor Egan-Bogart of Nanuet, NY, Marybeth Egan of New Paltz, NY and nephews Dr. John Kutch of Grapevine, TX and Edward Kutch of Pasadena, CA. A generous and kind man of great character, intellect and charm, Uncle Jack will be missed and fondly remembered by all who had the pleasure of knowing him. Memorial contributions may be made to the Sisters of Mercy, 150 Ridge Road, Hartsdale, NY 10530.

title: Charles Grodin's Back in (a New) Business
description: Having perfecting the deadpan delivery that made him one of Hollywood's leading character players (and a headliner in films like "The Heartbreak Kid" and "Midnight Run"), Charles Grodin, right, walked away from acting in 1994. He started a new role as host of a cable talk show. But when that ended, a few years later, he retreated into near obscurity. Now Mr. Grodin, at 70, is coming out of hiding. He has written a play, "The Right Kind of People," that opens Off Broadway in January, and he recently wrapped his first movie role in 12 years, in the forthcoming "Fast Track," where he plays a businessman forced to hire his slacker son-in-law (Zach Braff). To find out where Mr. Grodin went, Spencer Morgan turned the tables on the professional interviewer.

Let's Surf!" It was accompanied by stories assuring readers that visiting Biarritz and Capri is still fashionable. title: DEALS & DISCOUNTS
description: CRUISE TO COSTA RICA -- Windjammer Barefoot Cruises offers a seven-day cruise along the Pacific Coast, between the Panama Canal and Costa Rica, for $999 including all meals and round-trip air fare from Kennedy or Newark Airport. A transfer fee of $75 a person is extra. The price varies by flight departure city; from Miami, it is $899. This cruise is on the Amazing Grace, a freighter/passenger ship that has a capacity of 92 passengers. There is some live entertainment but no casino. Twelve cabins have shared baths. Available sailing dates are Sept. 10, 17, 24 and Oct. 1 and 8. For reservations: (800) 327-2600; www.windjammer.com.

title: As Oil Prices Soar, Is It Time to Bail Out?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SILVERMAN, SOL
description: SILVERMAN--Sol. Died August 16, 2005 in West Palm Beach, FL. Longtime labor leader and political activist with AFSCME and the United Furniture Workers Union in New York and in Florida for many years after retirement. An inspirational orator, a truly funny man, a gifted storyteller, he remained a strong and principled advocate for working people until the day he died. He leaves behind to carry on his legacy his wife Jill, son and daughter-in-law Bill and Bonita, grandson Will, in-laws, nieces and nephews, and many, many friends. We all miss him terribly. title: Will We Ever Arrive at the Good Death?

title: George Weah's New Game
description: One morning in May, George Weah, arguably the world's most famous Liberian, sat in the back seat of a black Toyota Land Cruiser as it barreled by the burned-out skyscrapers of the ruined city of Monrovia. It was the start of the rainy season, and fat tropical raindrops splattered across the windshield. Weah, dressed in a dark blue suit, a Liberian-flag pin stuck in his lapel, was concealed behind tinted windows. But he did not travel unnoticed. In a city of rickety jalopies, his gleaming ride is known to all, in part because, until recently, his car bore a vanity license plate reading "2 Phat." Since announcing last November that he's running for the presidency of Liberia, Weah has switched to something less conspicuous -- assassination is always a worry -- but on this morning no one was fooled. Along the cracked sidewalks, the grimy kids selling bootleg gas from glass jars shouted: "Weah! Weah!" as the Land Cruiser blew past.

title: The Swift Boating of Cindy Sheehan

Bush responded to an intelligence briefing titled "Bin Laden Determined to Attack Inside the United States" by going fishing. On this Aug. 6 the president was no less determined to shrug off bad news. Though 14 marine reservists had been killed days earlier by a roadside bomb in Haditha, his national radio address that morning made no mention of Iraq. Once again Mr. Bush was in his bubble, ensuring that he wouldn't see Ms. Sheehan coming. So it goes with a president who hasn't foreseen any of the setbacks in the war he fabricated against an enemy who did not attack inside the United States in 2001.

Porter Goss, the former spy and congressman who was awarded the intelligence directorship last year, generously summoned his predecessors and two of their widows on Tuesday to a cafeteria celebration to bid adieu to the agency's tattered primacy. The agency director, once the morning briefer of presidents, is now a secondary player under the umbrella of the new director of national intelligence, John Negroponte. In the wake of 9/11, the agency that once swaggered romantically as "the Company" has been subsumed like the loser in a corporate takeover.

description: Colombia has chosen Telfonos de Mxico, or Telmex, to take over operations and administration at Colombia Telecomunicaciones, the official press agency in Colombia said. "The government will reveal over the course of the week the accord it has reached with Telmex," the agency said. The deal could be worth $3 billion, Colombia's most widely circulated magazine, Semana, reported this week. Telmex will secure a management fee based on the company's operating revenues. Carlos Slim Hel, above, the billionaire owner of Telmex, is expected to meet President lvaro Uribe on Thursday, according to local media reports. Telefnica of Spain was also bidding to take over the management of Colombia Telecomunicaciones, a fixed-line company, and the deal is another step in the regional competition between Telefnica and Mr. Slim, who also controls the wireless giant Amrica Mvil. Amrica Mvil owns Colombia's largest mobile phone company, Comunicacin Celular, or Comcel, which had 9.17 million users at the end of June.

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Hostile Bid for Cargo Handler
description: Toll Holdings, the largest road and rail freight company in Australia, made a hostile $3.7 billion bid for the Patrick Corporation, the nation's biggest port cargo handler, seeking to control the flow of goods from ship to delivery. Patrick rejected the cash-and-stock bid, which values it at 7.10 Australian dollars ($5.34) a share at yesterday's closing price. Patrick stock rose 14 percent to 7.38 Australian dollars. Shares in Toll, which outlined its bid in a statement, surged 8 percent. The chief executive of Toll, Paul Little, is seeking to dominate freight hauling in an economy in its 14th year of expansion and make Toll the world's fourth-largest company in its field. He plans to sell Patrick's control of the airline Virgin Blue Holdings back to the founder, Sir Richard Branson, removing a drag on profit that caused Patrick's shares to slump this year. Toll Holdings is based in Melbourne, and Patrick in Sydney.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Geneva: More Victims Of Water Infection
description: The number of people who have developed a gastrointestinal illness linked to a water attraction at Seneca Lake State Park has climbed to 2,200, state health officials said yesterday. The outbreak of the disease, cryptosporidiosis, was traced to the park last week after health investigators discovered contaminated water in two tanks that feed a popular play area called the Sprayground. As of last night, 24 counties around Seneca Lake had reported cases, up from eight last Thursday, but a spokesman for the state health department, Rob Kenny, said that most of the people infected had recovered. The Sprayground has been closed for the rest of the summer. A local assemblyman, Joseph D. Morelle, said he would open an investigation. Anahad O'Connor (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   NYHUS, PAUL LUTHER
description: NYHUS--Paul Luther. 70, former Bowdoin College Dean of Students and Dean of the College, and Frank Andrew Munsey Professor of History Emeritus, died at his home in Brunswick, Maine, on August 17, of brain cancer. After graduating from Augsburg College in Minneapolis, he studied for a year at the University of Heidelberg on a Fulbright Scholarship, and in 1961 received his bachelor of sacred theology degree from Harvard Divinity School and in 1967 his doctorate in history from Harvard. He was the author of scholarly reviews, articles, and books, including Reform and Revolution: Franciscans in South Germany 1450-1530, published by the American Philosophical Society. He is survived by his wife, Katharine Johnson Watson, and his three daughters, Katharine Ellen Nyhus, Karen Ida Nyhus, and Kristina Victoria Rotach. A memorial service will be held Saturday, September 17, 2005, at 10:30 A.M. in the Bowdoin College Chapel, Brunswick, Maine. In lieu of flowers, gifts in his memory may be made to The Paul L. Nyhus Travel Grants Fund, 4100 College Station, Bowdoin College, Brunswick, Maine 04011.

Paid Notice: Deaths   FAULKNER, STANLEY
description: FAULKNER--Stanley. Beloved father, grandfather, uncle and brother died quietly on August 22 at the age of 96. His three children, two daughters-in-law, six grandchildren and sister survive him. On February 1, 1947 the Amsterdam News, commenting on the admission of Black persons to the Grand Jury said "In Nassau county Stanley Faulkner lit the firecracker that made the Nassau County Grand Jury jump". During his long and illustrious career he represented CIO Unions, witnesses called before the House Un-American Activities Committee and the McCarthy Senate Committee, civil rights workers in Mississippi, Viet Nam war resisters, victims of the coup in Chile and other civil rights causes. Stanley and Sylvia Faulkner lived their lives committed to working to better the conditions of others. Throughout his life, Stanley used his considerable professional skills in support of human rights. The impact of that commitment will survive him in the causes and persons he assisted and in his children and grandchilren. Donations in his name may be sent to The 92nd Street Y 60+ Group.

Paid Notice: Deaths   DE BARY, PATRICIA
description: de BARY--Patricia, noted community leader and beloved wife of Marquette de Bary, died peacefully, at her home in New York, Sunday, August 21, of natural causes. She was born on June 19, 1919, in Atlanta, Georgia, to Elizabeth Sturgis Murrill and Hugh Ambrose Murrill. She had three siblings: Tracy, Kathleen and Hugh II. She moved to Greenwich, Connecticut, when she was 13 years old, and was head of the Chapel Committee and Head Marshall of The Rosemary Hall School, from which she graduated. She attended Sweet Briar College and in 1958, married David DuVivier, an attorney. Jerome Sturgis DuVivier, was born on October 22, 1947, and her daughter, Eleanor Tracy DuVivier, was born on April 11, 1951. In the early fifties, she became one of the first New York Stock Exchange registered stockbrokers. In 1956, she was divorced and in 1958, married Theodore Sauvinet Gary, an electronics entrepreneur. Ted's daughter, Laura Gary, became her daughter. The Gary's lived in New York, Miami Beach, Madeline Island, Wisconsin, and in Wayzata, Minnesota. In 1972 they were divorced. In 1977, she married Marquette de Bary, President of Marquette de Bary Co., an investment banking firm. Since then, they have lived in New York, Southampton and Paris. All her life, she was a dedicated leader and benefactor of charitable and community organizations. She founded the Madeline Island Public Library in Wisconsin and was an outstanding leader in Florida with the American Cancer Society. In New York, she was on the Women's Advisory Board of the Boys Club of New York for over 50 years, and devoted herself to boards and events for The Central Park Conservancy, The Southampton Hospital and the New York Botanical Gardens. She remained a stockbroker until 2002, and was a gracious hostess, as well as a social and community force. She will long be remembered for her elegance, her taste, her love of family, her loyalty to friends, her commitment to excellence, and her generosity to the nonprofit community in every place she found herself. She is survived by her devoted husband, Marquette deBary; her son, Jerome Gary; her daughters, Laura Gary Thorne and Tracy Gary; her sister, Kathleen Murrill Lee; and her grandsons, Jordan Lambert Gary, Edwin Thorne III and Hunter Gary Thorne, and her granddaughter, Melanie Thorne Wagner. Memorial contributions should be sent to the Boys Club of New York, The Central Park Conservancy, the New York Botanical Gardens, or the Madeline Island Public Library. A memorial service will be held, at 11 AM, at Saint Bartholomew's Episcopal Church, Park Avenue at 51st Street, Thursday, September 15th.

Arts, Briefly
description: Singer Never Missing, Manager Says The manager of the American jazz singer Madeleine Peyroux said today that Ms. Peyroux was in New York, exhausted from a recent tour, and not missing. The manager said reports from Britain that Ms. Peyroux had vanished were a hoax. "She was never missing," said the manager, Cynthia B. Herbst. "She's fine and looking forward to going back on the road." The BBC reported over the weekend that Ms. Peyroux's distributor in Europe, Universal Classics, said she had not appeared for promotional work for her album "Careless Love" and was concerned that she might be missing. The label said it had hired a private detective, the BBC reported. Ms. Herbst said Ms. Peyroux was resting after a grueling tour, from May through mid-August. In a statement, her American label, Rounder Records, said, "Recent news reports regarding Madeleine Peyroux are the result of a hoax story planted in the U.K."

title: Punishment for Merck
description: Merck deserves some sympathy, but not a lot, for the staggering loss it suffered last week in a case involving its painkiller Vioxx, which was withdrawn from the market because it raises the risk of heart attacks and strokes in a small percentage of patients. A Texas jury hit Merck with a symbolically staggering $253.5 million judgment (it will be reduced to $26.1 million under a Texas law capping punitive damages) even though the evidence that Vioxx actually caused the victim's death was extremely thin. The verdict may reflect the fact that Merck was facing an extremely capable lawyer, while its own lawyers committed blunders that alienated the jury. But before heaping too much sympathy on the beleaguered drugmaker, it is important to note that Merck brought a lot of this problem on itself -- by failing to react quickly to evidence that Vioxx can be harmful in some patients and by promoting the drug beyond any rational use.

ABC broadcast repeats of "Extreme Makeover: Home Edition" (5.37 million viewers, then 7.56 million), a new episode of the reality-variety show "My Kind of Town" (5.79 million) and a "Desperate Housewives" rerun (5.68 million). But CBS had the most-watched program of the night: its repeat of "60 Minutes" drew 10.18 million viewers. The second part of CBS's mini-series "Living With the Dead" drew 7.68 million viewers from 9 to 11 p.m., but was in fourth place among the 18-to-49-year-olds. The mini-series, originally broadcast in 2002, is based on the life and work of the medium James Van Praagh, played by Ted Danson. Mr. Van Praagh's otherworldly profession is also the basis of one of CBS's fall series, "Ghost Whisperer," but in that series the character based on him is played by a woman, Jennifer Love Hewitt, above. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SETON, CHARLES B.
description: SETON--Charles B. Prominent New York attorney for over 50 years in the arts and publishing fields, died at 94 of respiratory and cardiac failure on August 20, 2005 in Greenwich, CT. He left his loving wife Suzanne Maimin Seton, daughter Pam Seton Lorenzo, son Charles B. Seton Jr., son-in-law Dr. Joseph A. Lorenzo, grandsons Alexander Seton Lorenzo and Gregory Maimin Lorenzo, sisters Lucile S. Bendick, Myra S. Meyer, brothers Theodore R. Seton, and the late Fenmore R. Seton. His clients in the music field included the promoters of the 1969 Woodstock Music Festival, Dick Clark, rock promoter Bill Graham (Fillmore East and West), Clark Gesner ("You're a Good Man, Charlie Brown"), Walter Donaldson ("Makin' Whoopie"), Beverly Sills, The Boston Symphony Orchestra and Kurt Weill. In the publishing field, he was General Counsel for Ziff Davis Publishing Company, and did special projects for Billboard Publications. Within the legal profession, he was a co-founder of Copyright Society of the U.S.A., and of the Copyright Luncheon Circle. In addition, he acted as an informal "clearing-house" for young copyright lawyers looking for jobs. During WWII, he served in the Solomon Islands as a Lt. Commander in the Naval Reserve. Wellknown for his integrity and resourcefullness, he represented not only the eminent, but also aided unknown composers and musicians who were being exploited by unscrupulous music publishers and management. In his personal life, he was an avid sheet music and antiquarian book collector and was known for his wry sense of humor. Contributions may be made to Literacy Volunteers or your favorite charity. There will be a private memorial service.

description: MAY--Harry, O.D. Passed away in his sleep on August 22, 2005. Born in Rock Hill, N.Y. on June 20, 1916, he received his undergraduate and optometry education at the University of California Berkeley. He served in the Army Air Corp. during WWII, rising to the rank of Major. He was married to Edith Nachamkin, an attorney, for 49 years, and together they raised their two beloved children, Lawrence May, M.D., and Margo May Shaw. He practiced optometry in Brooklyn, N.Y. for over 40 years, where he was admired and respected by his patients and colleagues. He was a resident of Boynton Beach, FL., and spent his summers in Monticello, N.Y., where he died. He is survived by his two children & his beloved son-in-law David, who will never forget him, & five grandchildren, Corey, Matthew, Seth, Lindsay and Julie, who will honor his memory with their continued achievement with the dedication and integrity he personified.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: General Electric to Seek Banking License
description: General Electric plans to seek its first Indian banking license this year and hopes to have more than $10 billion in consumer finance assets there by 2010. G.E. will apply for a license in the fourth quarter, said Vishal Pandit, who heads the Indian arm of GE Money, the company's consumer finance business. G.E., which owns banks in 19 nations, wants to tap growing demand for things like mortgages and credit cards in India. G.E., based in Fairfield, Conn., is looking for a ninefold expansion of consumer finance assets in India within five years. The company has the equivalent of $1.3 billion in Indian consumer finance assets, and will make acquisitions to raise growth after 2009, when India may ease foreign ownership rules, Mr. Pandit said.

description: de BARY--Patricia M. The Board, staff and friends of The New York Botanical Garden are deeply saddened by the loss of our dear friend and esteemed Board member Patricia de Bary. Pat was untiring in her devotion to The Botanical Garden, playing a leading role in The Garden's renaissance over the last 17 years. An elegant society hostess and an astute business woman, Pat was the visionary and creative enthusiast who first made The Conservatory Ball successful and glamorous, serving as Chairman or Honorary Chairman for more than a decade. Her counsel helped the Garden address many challenges, and her charisma brought many new friends into the Botanical Garden's world. The Garden has benefitted tremendously from her intelligence, energy, and stewardship. We shall miss her friendship, imagination, creativity, and joie de vivre. At a public hearing in the Tuxedo Elementary School on Monday, John Flynn, the administrator of New Jersey's Department of Environmental Protection, cited negative impacts on his state's water supply and contiguous woodlands in opposing Sterling Forge, a proposed development of 107 minimansions on a 575-acre tract of privately owned land within the 20,400-acre Sterling Forest. New York, New Jersey and private donors have spent $78.2 million to create the preserve. Louis Heimbach, the president of Sterling Forest L.L.C., the Tuxedo developer, was at the hearing, and said that Sterling Forge would conform to all state environmental requirements. description: For three years, Congress has been staring ostensible success in the face -- the 1996 reform of the old welfare system -- and dithering about what to do next. The tough-edged "workfare" plan, which cut welfare cases in half, has expired but has been temporarily extended 10 times as lawmakers have clashed over what kind of balance to strike between toughness and humaneness. A showdown moment for two million marginal families is approaching, with hard-line Republicans in the House insisting on a measly $1 billion increase over five years for child care support.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BROWN, FREDERICK ROBERT, M.D.
description: BROWN--Frederick Robert, M.D. Of West Palm Beach, FL., formerly of Manhasset, N.Y., on August 23, 2005 at age 94. Beloved husband of the late Cynthia Barnett Brown. Devoted father of Pamela Brown-Inz, Alice Brown and Melissa Brown, and father-inlaw of Steven Brown-Inz and David Siegel. Loving grandfather of Elizabeth, Amanda, Matthew, Phillip, Alison, Eric and Zachary. Adored brother of Rosalie (Mickey) Greenberg and the late Claire Joseph. An allergist in practice for over 50 years, he was revered by his many patients. He was a pioneer in the field of allergy and an active member of Phi Delta Epsilon medical fraternity, which was founded by his father Aaron Brown. Funeral services will be held at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76 St and Amsterdam Ave on Thursday, August 25th at 1PM. Memorial contributions to Hospice of Palm Beach County, 5300 East Ave, West Palm Beach, FL. 33407, or Cornell University, POB 2600, Ithaca, N.Y. 14851.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Port Chester: Man Dies In Fall From Bridge

The man, Oscar Reyes, 34, fell off the Highland Street bridge, where he had been walking on the train tracks around 9:15 p.m., said Marjorie S. Anders, a spokeswoman for Metro-North. It was not clear if the train hit Mr. Reyes, but he was pronounced dead at the scene. The death did not appear to be a suicide. Investigators are awaiting a toxicology report to determine whether Mr. Reyes was under the influence of drugs or alcohol, the authorities said. There were no passengers on the train, which was going from Stamford, Conn., to Grand Central Terminal. Jennifer Medina (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Corn Syrup Tariff Weighed
description: Mexico may impose an import tariff of up to 210 percent on corn sweetener from the United States after the World Trade Organization ruled a Mexican tax on high-fructose beverages violated trade agreements, a Mexican trade official said. Mexico is studying the option of a tariff to protect its sugar industry from United States corn sweetener imports because the United States blocks imports of Mexican sugar exports allowed under the North American Free Trade Agreement, said Hugo Perezcano, the legal director for international negotiations at the trade ministry. "We're considering resolving the tax issue and substituting it with an import tariff under the Nafta framework," Mr. Perezcano said in Mexico City. "The W.T.O., for example, allows us to adopt a maximum tariff of 210 percent on fructose imports."

title: Congregation Suspends Rabbi in Drug Arrest

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Judge Backs City On Bag Searches
description: A federal judge yesterday suspended an order that required New York City to hand over information about the frequency of random bag searches in the subways to the New York Civil Liberties Union, which has sued the city over the searches. On Aug. 18 a federal magistrate judge, Frank Maas, ordered the city to provide the group with information about a sample of the searches, to determine whether they were frequent enough to be effective. After reviewing sample data sent to him by the city, Judge Richard M. Berman of Federal District Court in Manhattan issued a stay on that order yesterday. City officials had argued that releasing the information would compromise security by tipping off potential terrorists to the patterns of the searches. Julia Preston (NYT)

description: The former mayor of West Long Branch, Paul R. Zambrano, pleaded guilty yesterday to one count of extortion for his role in accepting bribes and awarding public contracts, the United States attorney's office in Newark said. Mr. Zambrano, 49, was charged in February with accepting $15,000 from an undercover F.B.I. agent and an informant who posed as businessmen looking for contracts. The meetings took place between September 2003 and November 2004 while Mr. Zambrano was mayor, the authorities said. Ten other Monmouth County officials were arrested in the sting operation. Mr. Zambrano remains free on bail and faces up to 20 years in prison and a fine of $250,000 when he is sentenced on Nov. 29. John Holl (NYT)

description: A $2.4 billion Enron-related settlement led the Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce to report its largest quarterly loss. After accounting for payments to settle Enron shareholder claims, the bank said it lost 1.91 billion Canadian dollars ($1.6 billion) in the quarter ended July 31. In the period last year, the bank had a profit of 596 million Canadian dollars. The bank had a profit of 2.2 billion Canadian dollars for all of 2004. While other Canadian banks are expected to make settlements with Enron shareholders, none are likely to approach the level of C.I.B.C.'s payments. Revenue at the C.I.B.C. investment banking operation, which carried the Enron losses, were up 12 percent, to 981 million Canadian dollars. Revenue was up 16 percent at its consumer business. The bank is based in Toronto. Ian Austen (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Southwest: Texas: Child Health Care Lapses
description: The state has not only abridged a court order intended to improve health care for poor children but is providing medical services to fewer youths than before the consent decree was entered, a federal judge found. The judge, William W. Justice, said the Texas Medicaid program had consistently failed its obligations under a 10-year-old agreement in a class action lawsuit brought in behalf of indigent children. Judge Justice said that the 1.5 million Medicaid-eligible children who did not receive health examinations last year represented an increase of almost 50 percent above the figure for 1998, when the plaintiffs accused the state of failing to comply with the consent order. The state has argued that its outreach program meets federal guidelines. Steve Barnes (NYT)

description: Volkswagen, Europe's largest carmaker, expects losses in the United States at least through 2006 because of pricing pressures and a weak dollar. "We will be most unlikely to break even in the U.S. business next year as well." Volkswagen's vehicle sales in the United States in July fell 16 percent from a year earlier as customers turned to competitors like General Motors and Ford Motor, which offered larger incentives. description: Bombardier, the world's No.3 maker of commercial aircraft, said its second-quarter earnings surged fivefold on the sale of a financing unit and increased demand for business jets. Net income in the quarter ended July 31 rose to $117 million, or 6 cents a share, from $23 million, or 1 cent a share, a year earlier. Revenue, however, fell 4.4 percent, to $3.68 billion, Bombardier said in a statement. Deliveries of private jets, used by corporations and wealthy individuals, rose 41 percent. title: Arts, Briefly; CBS's 'NCIS' Stealth Attack
description: CBS won another Tuesday night in both total viewers and adults 18 to 49 years old. It has been a good summer for the network's under-the-radar "NCIS," which has outperformed its 2004 seasonal average by double-digit percentages. On Tuesday, the "NCIS" repeat at 8 p.m. delivered the night's largest audience in Nielsen's estimates, with 9.25 million viewers. "Big Brother" (8.05 million) followed the military crime show, and it attracted the highest ratings among 18-to-49-year-olds of the evening. As usual, "Rock Star: INXS" fell off from those lead-in numbers, but it did win the 10 p.m. hour in the 18-to-49 age group, and outdrew ABC's "Boston Legal" (6.28 million versus 5.06 million). World Briefing | United Nations: Drug Stockpile For A Potential Pandemic
description: The Swiss pharmaceutical company Roche agreed to donate millions of doses of an antiviral drug to help prevent or slow transmission of the avian influenza virus if it begins to spread among humans, the World Health Organization said. The United Nations agency is building a stockpile of the antiviral, Tamiflu (oseltamivir), so it can be flown quickly to areas where early outbreaks are detected, particularly in countries that cannot afford it. Thirty million capsules, enough for three million people, are to be ready in stages, starting in early 2006. The aim is to buy time until large amounts of a vaccine can be produced; use of the antiviral drug would be combined with other measures, like quarantine. Lawrence K. Altman (NYT)

title: Bubbles of Whimsy And the Sheen Of Genius, Frozen in Glass
description: Frederick Carder has been called the Mad Hatter of glass. As head of the Steuben Glass Works from 1903 to 1932, he concocted hundreds of colorful formulas with bubbles, layers, marbleizing and (as at above left) metallic sheens, as well as thousands of objects, including frilly lampshades and streamlined candlesticks. "Frederick Carder: Glass, Passion, Invention," an exhibition of 82 of his pieces, opens Sept. 6 at the Gallery at Steuben, 667 Madison Avenue (61st Street). The show, running through Feb. 18, "will express Carder's excess and his variety, his maximalism with some moments of minimalism," said the curator, Donald Albrecht. Wallpaper by Flavor Paper (below left), silk-screened by hand, will also be on display, a homage to Carder with swirled motifs, gold powders and forest green ink on pewter-tinted Mylar ($200 a roll from flavorpaper.com). EVE M. KAHN CURRENTS: EXHIBITION

title: 36 Hours in Healdsburg, Calif.
description: HEALDSBURG, in the heart of Sonoma County, dates to the mid-1800's, when it was a stopping point on a heavily traveled route from San Francisco to the gold mines of Northern California. Healdsburg was a farming community and in many ways still is, though prunes, which dominated the fruit crop until the 1970's, have now been supplanted by grapes. In fact, it is just a short drive from the center of town to three Sonoma County wine locales, the Alexander Valley, the Dry Creek Valley and the Russian River Valley, that are filled with wineries but lack the weekend crowds of neighboring Napa. Mid-September marks the start of crush, the grape harvest, so fall visitors will see bustling vineyards and undoubtedly smell fermenting grape juice. But these days Healdsburg is about more than wine. Over the last few years, new shops and high-end boutique hotels have made it a destination for all things culinary.

Located some eight miles east of the Mediterranean, this barrier runs more or less -- how much more and how much less is a matter of intense dispute -- along the 1949 armistice line (or Green Line) that divides Israel from the West Bank. That this more than 400-mile proposed stretch of asphalt, wire, trenches and concrete summons up the Berlin Wall is just one of its many wrenching paradoxes. More wrenching still is that it effectively drives yet another wedge between Israelis and Palestinians.

title: The Line Between Species Shifts, and a Show Explores the Move

Her wrinkly pinkish skin seems downright human, even to its vestigial hairs. So do her hands and feet. It's her face -- except for brooding humanoid eyes with brows -- that really marks her as, well, different. There are fleshy ears that start at the top of her nearly bald head and flop down like long tongues, a flattened ape-ish nose and a cowlike muzzle with a wide moo-ey mouth.

The state said that the county must cover the 14-inch gap between two underwater conveyor belts with a grate or guard, move the height-requirement sign closer to the ride operators, and ensure that there are at least four operators on duty at all times, as the county's guidelines require. At the time of the accident at the ride, Ye Old Mill, only two operators were present, the agency said. Susan Tolchin, the chief adviser to the Westchester County executive, Andrew J. title: The Listings: Aug. 26 -- Sept. 1; 'GLENGARRY GLEN ROSS'
description: When the seven actors in "Glengarry Glen Ross" take their final curtain call on Sunday afternoon, Broadway will be losing a big bright light. David Mamet's hilariously obscene autopsy on business, American style, has one of the best ensemble performances you can find anywhere (the play won the Tony Award for best revival this year). As these furious, trapped real estate salesmen compete to sell worthless land to suckers, the exhilaration on the part of the audience becomes palpable. The characters' desperation, scarily evident behind the comic turns in Joe Mantello's knife-sharp production, seems so familiar. This must be America, right? The three opening arias of what is really a tragic farce begin with Alan Alda's Shelly Levene literally pleading for his life before the impassive office manager (Frederick Weller), who is privy to a list of potential buyers the salesmen aim to delude. Mr. Alda is all supplicating hands and bared teeth as he tries to conceal his anxiety behind a wall of jokes and a skull's grin. He and Mr. Weller are followed by Gordon Clapp, as an insidious spider who ensnares Jeffrey Tambor in a plot to steal the list. As the shocked prey, Mr. Tambor is compulsively watchable and soon neatly tied in. The crescendo of the first act is a bitingly funny, surreal sermon by Liev Schreiber (Tony Award No. 2), who gets into the skin of the snakelike supersalesman Richard Roma. The forlorn patsy is Tom Wopat, his studly Broadway musical past nowhere evident here as Roma hypnotizes him in a hell-red parody of a Chinese restaurant designed by Santo Loquasto and filled with (symbolically?) empty fish tanks. Because of these shrewd introductions by the playwright -- who dedicated the 1983 "Glengarry" to Harold Pinter -- the audience is primed for the knockout second act set in the real estate office, which Mr. Loquasto has transformed into a foreboding sea of gunmetal desks. A cop, Jordan Lage, is interviewing each salesman behind a closed door. It's like a mad tennis match, with the dialogue volleying among seven players, some leaving and then re-entering the game. As the cast lobs its lines, watch Mr. Lage and Mr. Schreiber joust for power; Mr. Clapp turn on Mr. Schreiber; Mr. Alda instantly impersonate a satisfied buyer as the quaking Mr. Wopat tries to wriggle out of a contract. In this darkness, Ricky Roma speaks. "I swear it's not a world of men," he says, "there's no adventure to it." But there is great theatrical adventure in this "Glengarry Glen Ross," and it's not to be missed. (From left, above, Mr. Tambor, Mr. Lage, Mr. Wopat, Mr. Alda, Mr. Weller, Mr. Schreiber and Mr. Clapp. Bernard B. Jacobs Theater, 242 West 45th Street, (212)239-6200.) ANDREA STEVENS

Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Mayor Vetoes Sunday Parking Bill
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg vetoed a bill yesterday that would eliminate Sunday parking meter fees across the city, provoking a promise from Gifford Miller, the City Council speaker and a Democratic candidate for mayor, that the veto would be overridden. Advocates of the bill, which was adopted in a 41-to-3 Council vote on July 27, say it is intended to eliminate fees for people attending church. Another Democratic mayoral candidate, Fernando Ferrer, has chided Mr. Bloomberg on the issue, saying people should not be forced to "pay to pray." But the mayor said yesterday that Sunday parking fees were needed to turn over parking spaces in commercial areas, giving more people access to the spaces and cutting down on double parking. title: Fresh Blood and Kinkiness on the Menu
description: Lush, lurid and completely besotted with itself, "Eternal" is one of those movies normally found slinking around the ether of late-night cable television. title: Snowmobile Deceit
description: It's hard to think of another subject in the history of the national park system that has been as thoroughly studied as the use of snowmobiles in Yellowstone National Park. Since 1996, there have been three major official assessments of snowmobiles' impact on the park in winter. Two of those were done during the Bush administration. Now a fourth major study has been authorized; it is to be completed by 2007, when the current three-year plan for winter use comes to an end. This new study will cost $2 million to $3 million -- for a park that is annually underfinanced by nearly $23 million. There is only one conceivable reason for this study. It's part of the tried and true methodology of the Bush administration: if you don't like the results the first time, do it again and change the definitions so you do get the results you like.

Two Guys Shouting and Magical Trees
description: A maximalist who loves cramming the screen with noise and raucous nonsense, Terry Gilliam has a history of navigating past treacherous obstacles, including those of his own design. When his films work, these excesses have a liberating, exhilarating effect, allowing you to hitch a ride on the director's ingenious flights of fancy. But Mr. Gilliam's strengths as a filmmaker -- an out-of-bounds visual imagination, a tendency to spiral wildly off topic, a fractious wit -- can also be his gravest liabilities. Almost invariably there comes the moment in his films when it feels as if you have entered one of those bewildering junk shops stuffed to the rafters with mildew and treasure.

title: The Listings: Aug. 26 -- Sept. 1; 'GIRLS ON FILM'
description: If someone had predicted 25 years ago that paintings by Mel Ramos would be found in seriously hip New York art galleries one day, they would have been laughed out of town. Yet here he is serving along with Francis Picabia as one of the godfathers of an enduring trend that finds inspiration in popular erotica and pornography. Mr. Ramos's sweetly lubricious "Camilla Queen of the Jungle Empire," above, from 1963 is one of the highlights of an entertaining exhibition that ranges from the kitschy portraits of women that Picabia copied from men's magazines in the 1940's to recent, lovingly made watercolors based on pornographic sources by the young German painter Martin Eder. Along the way, the show zigzags all over the map, including a fine Elizabeth Taylor portrait by Andy Warhol; a collage about beauty and commerce by the feminist Martha Rosler; poignant faux film stills by Cindy Sherman; and a large photograph of a naked young woman on a motorcycle appropriated from a biker magazine by Richard Prince. There are raw collages by the professional provocateurs Franz West and Paul McCarthy; sensuously painted fantasy women by Lisa Yuskavage and John Currin; and a pixilated nude lifted from a pornographic Web site by Thomas Ruff. And don't miss the videos upstairs in which Candice Breitz cannily imitates the emotive styles of the screen goddesses Julia Roberts, Cameron Diaz and Jennifer Lopez. (Zwirner & Wirth, 32 East 69th Street, Manhattan, (212)517-8677, through Sept. 2.) KEN JOHNSON

title: The Listings: Aug. 26 -- Sept. 1; CHARLIE PARKER JAZZ FESTIVAL
description: The death of Charlie Parker, above, a half-century ago closed the book on an outsized jazz talent. But in the months and years that followed, new footnotes kept cropping up, as a generation of musicians strove to emulate both his dazzling saxophone heroics and his gargantuan narcotic habit. Fifty years of hindsight have reaffirmed the singularity of Parker's genius; this summer, Uptown Records released a newly discovered live recording, "Town Hall, New York City, June 22, 1945," that added luster to an already luminous discography. Musicians have long been aware of the futility of the task; today's jazz mainstream is bebop-tinged but rarely Parker-shaped, so that even the 13th annual Charlie Parker Jazz Festival shows no trace of simulacra. The lineup tomorrow at Marcus Garvey Park includes two alto saxophonists who have each absorbed Parker's style into his own: Bobby Watson, a commanding soloist schooled in hard bop; and Soweto Kinch, a bracing young player who also draws on myriad contemporary sources. The concert Sunday in the East Village features an excellent post-bop piano trio fronted by Geri Allen; a probing quartet led by the powerhouse drummer Cindy Blackman; and a group led by the pianist John Hicks and featuring the tenor saxophonist David (Fathead) Newman, who studied with Parker's mentor but mainly eschews bebop for rhythm and blues. Both concerts will feature Odean Pope's Saxophone Choir, an audacious assemblage of nine saxophones plus a rhythm section. The group's aesthetic connection to Parker is circuitous but deeply inscribed. (Tomorrow at 3 p.m. at Marcus Garvey Park, between Mount Morris Park West and Madison Avenue, from 120th to 124th Streets, Harlem, free. Sunday at 3 p.m. at Tompkins Square Park, between Avenues A and B, from Seventh to 10th Streets, East Village, free.) NATE CHINEN

title: Arts, Briefly; Fox Dances to Another Win
description: Perhaps because of the fickle audience voting on "American Idol," Fox's dance competition "So You Think You Can Dance" is leaving little to chance: the judges choose their least favorite six performers, and then the public is allowed to vote on whom to save in that group. The system appears to be appealing to the audience, as a two-hour episode of "Dance" put Fox in first place among total viewers and 18-to-49-year-olds, as well as in a tie for first in households with NBC. The second hour of "Dance" outpaced its first in Nielsen's estimates: 7.07 million viewers watched the 8 p.m. hour, but 8.71 million tuned in at 9 p.m., bringing up its average. NBC had the most-watched program of the night, however: the 10 p.m. "Law & Order" repeat (9.17 million). Over its run, the ratings for ABC's "Brat Camp" have decreased significantly since its premiere in mid-July. Wednesday's finale drew 6.27 million viewers, 4 million fewer than the debut drew. 36 Hours in Healdsburg, Calif.
description: HEALDSBURG, in the heart of Sonoma County, dates to the mid-1800's, when it was a stopping point on a heavily traveled route from San Francisco to the gold mines of Northern California. Healdsburg was a farming community and in many ways still is, though prunes, which dominated the fruit crop until the 1970's, have now been supplanted by grapes. In fact, it is just a short drive from the center of town to three Sonoma County wine locales, the Alexander Valley, the Dry Creek Valley and the Russian River Valley, that are filled with wineries but lack the weekend crowds of neighboring Napa. Mid-September marks the start of crush, the grape harvest, so fall visitors will see bustling vineyards and undoubtedly smell fermenting grape juice. But these days Healdsburg is about more than wine. Over the last few years, new shops and high-end boutique hotels have made it a destination for all things culinary. AMY GUNDERSON

The Listings: Aug. 26 -- Sept. 1; BUTOH MEETS EAST VILLAGE
description: When one thinks of the East Village one thinks of Butoh, which of course brings to mind the Rockettes, right? No? Skeptics should head to the Howl! Festival on Sunday, when a range of performers, including the Butoh Rockettes, above, will bring Japan's expressionistic post-World War II dance form to the Manhattan streets. Just don't expect strict adherence to tradition. The artist Matthew Flower and the dancer and choreographer Shizu Homma will present a Butoh fashion show, which Ms. Homma describes as "not quite fashion show and not quite Butoh." Bo Akiko Nishijima will perform a "Butoh-cat piece that speculates on the future." And the Butoh Rockettes will present satirical chorus work, which nonetheless maintains ties to the form's traditional existential quality. The troupe's director, Celeste Hastings, has studied with a host of Butoh masters and will dance the more traditional "In Runes," a layered, political solo inspired by her film of the same title, which ruminates on the earth. Another soloist, Catherine Hourihan, will perform her Butoh-influenced "Neverness," incorporating images projected onto her body and trying to explore the world's interconnectedness. These solos will kick off the "Dance of Darkness," which the curators Bradley Eros and M.M. Serra describe as a showing of Artaud- and Butoh-inspired films. The evening is part of Howl!'s Avant-Garde(n), a series of public programs in East Village community gardens. "The avant-garde is not finished," said Paul Bartlett, one of the event's producers. "Surrealism, Dada, Butoh -- these are experimental forms that try to figure out who we are as a people." Sociopolitical concerns aside, they are also fabulously theatrical art forms. The Vangeline Theater's French sci-fi-inspired Butoh offerings, Rockettes in white body paint: what's not to love? (Street performances Sunday, 1 to 6 p.m., Avenue A and Tompkins Square Park. "Dance of Darkness," dusk to 8 p.m., La Petit Versailles Garden on East Second Street, between Avenues B and C, (212)505-2225 or www.howlfestival.com.) CLAUDIA LAROCCO

title: Call of the Wild, or, Rather, the Grim Reaper?
description: WERNER HERZOG'S current documentary, "Grizzly Man," about Timothy Treadwell, who lived among bears during 13 seasons in southwestern Alaska, details the killing of four creatures. Two are human: Mr. Treadwell and his girlfriend, who were mauled and eaten in October 2003. And two are bears: the animals that may have done the couple in, and were shot when they charged investigators at the scene.

title: A Baseline Recovery
description: On May 6 of last year, James Blake was standing beneath an awning beside a clay tennis court in Rome, waiting out a sudden downpour. Two days earlier, Blake, a professional player then ranked No. 43 in the world, lost a close first-round match to Jiri Novak at the Italian Open. Ordinarily, Blake will practice the day after an early-round loss, but taking advantage of the perks available to him, he attended Mass at the Vatican instead, met the pope and then, that evening, dropped by a private party given for Giorgio Armani. (The Association of Tennis Professionals, for obvious publicity reasons, had arranged for his access.) Now, following his privileged glimpse of Rome, Blake, who was ranked as high as No. 22 in May 2003, had the remainder of the European clay-court season on his mind. One of the hardest workers on the tour, he was eager to practice.

title: Detroit
description: WHY GO NOW The four wheels of Detroit culture - sports, music, machines and beer - are all on a roll. The city will be host to this season's Super Bowl, after having mounted the baseball All-Star game last month, and the high-profile events have fueled much sprucing up of downtown. Detroit's music revival, led by Eminem, Kid Rock and the White Stripes, is being extended by acts like Brendan Benson, the Dirtbombs and the Detroit Cobras. Car culture is always intense, and this January sees the opening of the North American International Auto Show; last year it drew over 780,000 people. As for beer - well, there's never an off-season there.

title: The Cult of the Cycads
description: A man who calls himself Marty Sterns is taking care of business in the faux French Provincial dining room of a top-floor suite in the Las Vegas Mirage. Sterns is a small, trim man in his late 40's with a close-cropped graying beard, sandy hair and the quick, carefully controlled moves of a man on the make who doesn't want to look like one. "This is everything that came in the March shipment," he says to the two men sitting at the table. Rolf Bauer is beefy, a Bob Hoskins look-alike, wearing a plaid short-sleeved shirt that's tight against his gut. Jan Van Vuuren, jowly, with a receding hairline and reading glasses, has the look of an Omaha insurance salesman circa 1965. Sterns is standing between them, pointing to an itemized list he has placed on the table.

description: After a sloppy victory over the Jets, Giants Coach Tom Coughlin said yesterday that he was concerned about the team's inconsistency on defense and its propensity for turnovers. But he also said the offense would be upgraded for the season opener.

title: Summer In the Bag
description: As summer vegetable gardens reach their peak, summer houses close down, and summer vacations give way to the start of school, the end-of-season load to tote grows a little heavier. Enter Garnet Hill's collapsible canvas basket, a sturdy well-designed carryall with a lightweight aluminum frame and a rubber-padded handle that holds up to 55 pounds of precious cargo, be it corn and tomatoes or dorm room supplies. The basket ($38 at www.garnethill.com), which collapses flat for easy storage, was introduced by Garnet Hill this year in black and khaki and became a surprise sellout; to meet demand, the company has just added a roster of bright colors -- green, red, orange and periwinkle -- to satisfy customers who want to carry home their harvest in more stylish hues.

title: Movies
description: SHARK TALE (2004) Saturday at 8 p.m. on HBO. It's one of those freakish accidents. A tough guy decides to mug a mild-mannered Everyman but accidentally kills himself in the process. When everybody assumes Oscar (the Everyman) saved himself, he decides just to go along and enjoy the hero worship, which includes being pursued by a femme fatale named Lola. That breaks the heart of the pretty receptionist who secretly loves him. And it all takes place deep in the ocean. This animated fantasy from DreamWorks stars the voices of Will Smith, Angelina Jolie and Rene Zellweger as the fish in that romantic triangle; Robert De Niro as the local mob boss; and Jack Black as Lenny (above), his sensitive, vegetarian son. The film doesn't have the charm of "Finding Nemo," but it's fun and there are plenty of jokes for the grown-ups.

title: The Past Lingers in Changing Vietnam
description: BREAKFAST at the Morin Hotel in Hue was a game of Russian roulette. As my husband, Tad, and I sat sipping Vietnamese coffee in the courtyard, nuts from the bang trees above us dropped like bombs onto the stone patio. I asked our waiter, Dinh, a slender young man, if they ever hit people. "Yes," he said, pointing to his forearm and shoulder with a shrug. "One broke a table."

And thus, unavoidably, jeans promptly became "just as much a uniform as the dark suit." Since then, fashion types have tried to liberate denim from bourgeois casual-Friday uniformity; a current attempt comes from the growing swarm of "premium" and "superpremium" jeans.

description: UNTIL this year, filling a natural gas car was a hit-or-miss proposition. Pumps were hard to find, and many were available only to fleets operated by municipalities, utilities and other companies. title: Bankruptcy Not Expected to Close Delta
description: The financial problems of Delta Air Lines are prompting customers to wonder what to expect if it seeks bankruptcy protection this fall. Based on what has happened at other airlines, they should be prepared for some changes, but they should not expect it to shut down -- Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection is intended to give companies the opportunity to keep operating while they reorganize. Nor do consumers have to worry about their frequent-flier miles, although airlines always can revise the rules of their programs without notice.

title: Confounding Machines: How the Future Looked
description: SMALL children and prescientific peoples, it is said, employ magical thinking to deal with a world they can't understand or control. In an age of technology, which produces a constant flood of incomprehensible phenomena, such forms of thinking may be an occasional necessity for everyone.

Hours later, however, the Israeli cabinet voted overwhelmingly to allow Egypt to patrol the international border with Gaza with 750 armed men, which would allow Israel to pull all its soldiers out of Gaza in the next month.

Some towns, however, may have taken atonement for hair misdeeds too far.

title: Language Born of Colonialism Thrives Again in Amazon
description: SO GABRIEL DA CACHOEIRA, Brazil, Aug. 23 - When the Portuguese arrived in Brazil five centuries ago, they encountered a fundamental problem: the indigenous peoples they conquered spoke more than 700 languages. Rising to the challenge, the Jesuit priests accompanying them concocted a mixture of Indian, Portuguese and African words they called "lngua geral," or the "general language," and imposed it on their colonial subjects.

There is also something about the store's open design that keeps you engaged, moving from one insight to the next, as the visual narrative of a magazine layout does.

title: The Other Army
description: People may not be wary of private security companies only because we have negative associations with the old term "mercenaries." They may remember the events of Abu Ghraib and how many soldiers involved in torturing the prisoners said they were directed by independent "outside contractors." There are many people in Iraq working in tandem with our military who cannot be court-martialed or held accountable by our military courts and who can freely ignore the Geneva Conventions and all standard practices of warfare without having to answer to anyone (except perhaps the private company that hired them, which is primarily out to make money). The military may delegate to these people acts it does not wish to undertake itself because of possible legal consequences and P.R. risks. These men's deaths are rarely reported when they are killed in battle, not listed among American casualties -- and neither are their acts discussed the way the acts of United States soldiers might be. They operate in a gray area with troubling implications for our national honor and for our understanding at home of what this war is all about.

description: 1912: Wilson, Roosevelt, Taft & Debs -- the Election That Changed the Country, by James Chace. (Simon & Schuster, $14.) Chace (1931-2004), the author of many books on foreign policy, captures the campaigns, primaries, conventions and personalities: President William Howard Taft (Republican), former President Theodore Roosevelt (Republican turned Progressive), future President Woodrow Wilson (Democrat) and Eugene V. Debs (Socialist).

description: THE BASICS -- Launched by the company behind the no-frills airline easyJet, easyCruise has been offering cut-rate summer cruises along the French and Italian Rivieras on an ostentatious orange and white ship recalling a Creamsicle. From November to April the circuit will shift to the Caribbean. It's the antithesis of traditional cruising: amenities are scaled back; food and drinks aren't included in the price; and the boat (easyCruiseOne) spends nearly all day and night in port -- with a curfew that's never earlier than 4 a.m. The philosophy is apparently that its youngish clientele -- easyCruise concentrates on people between the ages of 20 and 40 -- is more interested in dining and partying in exotic destinations than playing shuffleboard at sea.

title: The Saunterer Tries the Bronx
description: Walking the clamorous traffic bridge from Manhattan to the Bronx, the pilgrim was fortunate not to attract Homeland Security with his incessant muttering. "The last of the Queen Anne's lace is around here somewhere," Cy Adler announced, strutting forth as if his search were for Rosebud. The determined walker took a turn away from the cacophonous strangle of rush hour and soon was rather magically on a quiet back path overlooking the Harlem River. Giant sunflowers loomed, hanging their heads as if in awe of the concrete city on the horizon. But no Queen Anne's wildflowers in sight. Cy Adler walked on. He exchanged suspicious glances with a feral albino cat in the deep weeds of the Bronx. He walked the wilds far below serpentine traffic overpasses while the river glistened by a hobo camp.

title: The Industry: Killer Tomatoes
description: Douglas Heath, Ph.D., says he is on the verge of perfecting what he hopes will be the defining fruit of his career, one with a trifecta of rare and attractive qualities. It is a seedless tomato; it delivers the robust, sweet-and-tart flavor most supermarket tomatoes lack; and it has all the disease resistance the commercial industry demands. He has, in fact, created it -- the patent on the technique has been filed and approved -- but just a few minor kinks remain. Although seedless grapes have been around for more than 100 years, seedless tomatoes aren't yet commercially available.

title: 'On the Ridge Between Life and Death'
description: The trouble began on the fifth pitch. I handed Gabe our hardware - half a dozen soft-iron pitons and eight or nine carabiners dangling from a nylon sling - and said, "On belay." Once again, I had been unable to drive a single piton for my anchor: instead, I had found a bucket-shaped hollow in the ruddy sandstone and sat in it with my back against the right wall, my feet braced against an opposing bulge.

description: When it comes to fashion, women are going organic. We're not talking about the pesticide-free cottons and sustainable, sweatshop-free business models that are getting so much press. We're talking about women who are jumping off the luxury hamster wheel to support local designers. The result is personalized style with personalized service, maybe even a personal relationship -- perhaps the truest luxury of all. Consider fashion's current hero, Alber Elbaz of Lanvin, an impishly charming, unmediagenic man who can often be found at his Paris flagship store, doing the windows or popping downstairs from his atelier to offer suggestions, fittings and cookies. (It happened to me, and suddenly the price was no longer such a deterrent.) The garments even look touched by him, not designed by committee, mass-produced and sold based on a carefully constructed media mythology. Tom, we hardly knew ye.

title: Where Tea Doesn't Mix With Political Sympathies
description: At El Khaiam cafe on Steinway Street in the middle of what is known as Little Egypt in Astoria, Queens, Arab immigrants sit around imitation marble tables and chat animatedly as they play backgammon or cards. They sip ink-black Egyptian tea or tart lemonade and smoke fruit-flavored tobacco from stained-glass water pipes.

title: Got Milk? Crestwood Farms Makes Sure Its Customers Do, Right at the Doorstep
description: WHEN Sharon Felder moved to Stony Brook from California eight years ago, one of the first things she noticed was a metal milk box beside the front door of a neighbor's house.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HOWARD, BARR
description: HOWARD--Barr, of Cos Cob, CT, died on August 17, 2005, at Northern Manor Nursing Home in Nanuet, NY. He was 81. Mr. Howard for many years worked in sales. Mr. Howard was born January 17, 1924, in Elizabeth, NJ, to Frank A. and Almeda Barr Howard. He was educated at the Taft School and earned a Bachelor's degree in Liberal Arts from Princeton University in New Jersey. Mr. Howard served in the United States Army during World War II. On September 11, 1949, he married Virginia F. Chase. Mr. Howard lived in Cos Cob for the past 20 years. Before that he lived in Rye, NY, from 1950 to 1985. Locally he was a member of Christ's Church, Addelpate Ski Club and Manursing Island Club. He is survived by his wife, Virginia C. Howard of Cos Cob, CT; his daughter, Barbara C. Howard of North Salem, NY; and his two sons, Christopher B. Howard of Milford, CT, and Peter C. Howard of Cos Cob, CT. His son, William C. Howard predeceased him in 2003. A memorial service will be held 2:00 PM, on Tuesday, August 30, 2005, at Christ's Church, Rye, NY.

title: Williams Feels Ready for Another Open Title
description: Serena Williams stepped into the interview room at the National Tennis Center yesterday in Flushing Meadows-Corona Park with a companion, and it was not her sister Venus or her father, Richard.

title: The Remix; The Good, the Bad and the Glossy
description: Finally, scent strips you'll want to inhale. Martin Parr, the art photographer known for immortalizing beautiful doughnuts, is taking on the fashion magazine. In the ersatz publication Fashion Magazine, he subverts the form with his hypercolored imagery that straddles the appealing and the grotesque (a cozy match for the subject matter). Every photo is either taken by or features Parr -- who also plays the cover model -- including the advertisements, some of which are photographs of existing ads, like one for Christian Dior handbags snapped on a bed of hay. It even has a food feature: a photo spread of wet baked beans on toast, a far cry from Irving Penn. "It's a mischievous poke at a world of which I'm not really a part," concedes Parr, who does shoot fashion from time to time, so he says he's both respectful and ambivalent. Fashion Magazine is available at www.magnumphotostore.com and at exhibitions opening in January at Rose Gallery in Santa Monica and Daiter Contemporary in Chicago. MARK JACOBS

title: Mussels on Prince Edward Island
description: On an island that produces 80 percent of North America's cultured mussels and a third of Canada's potatoes, the classic Belgian dish of moules frites (mussels and French fries) seemed like a no-brainer to Garner Quain.

title: The Get; Shoppin' Safari
description: Style Map/Venice Beach: For decades, shopping in Venice Beach, Calif., was ideal if you were in the market for incense or a surfboard. But for the past few years, as ber-agents and A-list actors have stormed the bohemian beach town in search of New York-style lofts and Arts and Crafts bungalows, the neighborhood has made over its funky-town image. Along the once-wonky strip of Abbot Kinney Boulevard, the skate shops and tie-dye emporiums have been replaced by high-design boutiques and botes du jour. Maura Egan
