title: Healing in Southampton
description: It might have been possible to dismiss a news conference in Southampton last week as a routine event on a humdrum topic: a new program using state and federal money to combat drug addiction. But because the people who called it were leaders of the Shinnecock Indian Nation, which had never publicly acknowledged its long battle with drugs and alcohol, and because they were joined by state and local officials who have waged a vigorous, sometimes bitter battle with the tribe over plans for a casino on the East End, it was a compelling moment, remarkable for its openness and candor.

description: Plenty of good reasons can always be found for keeping open military bases the Pentagon no longer needs. Well-paying, federally financed jobs will be lost. Local economies will be devastated. New strategic threats may develop someday that might make that unwanted base useful again. And so on.

description: One Hogan Place does not look much like the White House. Home to the Manhattan district attorney's office, the dark and rather grim building near Foley Square scarcely has a lobby, much less a rose garden suitable for official photos.

title: Neglected Poor in Africa Make Their Own Safety Nets
description: DAKAR, Senegal, Aug. 27 - Nogaye Sow is a humble street vendor in a rough patch of urban Africa, but hidden in her flowing robe is a weathered piece of cardboard that helps put her on equal footing with those who work in air-conditioned offices instead of at the curb.

title: The Remix; Now Showing/Black Roses
description: Unlike the garden variety, the black rose tends to bloom on winter runways, where it is rhinestoned and sequined (at Sonia Rykiel), twisted into fabric (Rochas), layered (Kenzo), printed on silk (Prada) and given a goth makeover (Dries van Noten, shown here). The latter designer, a confessed gardening addict, found traditional corsages too sweet, "so I literally just took a can of spray paint and sprayed them black," he says. "It gave them a dark edge. I love that you can see a hint of color coming through." Like the first sign of spring. IAIN R. WEBB

title: Constitution Sent to Parliament in Iraq Despite Sunni Objections
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Aug. 28 - Iraqi leaders today presented a disputed constitution to the country's Parliament, overriding the objections of Sunni negotiators and setting the stage here for a protracted period of political conflict.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   JACKSON, JAY
description: JACKSON--Jay. Of Jupiter, FL, formerly of Manhasset, NY. Died August 16 at 86. He moved to NY when television was in its infancy and hosted many of TV's early drama and quiz shows including Philco Television Playhouse, Lux Video Theater, Twenty Questions and Tic Tac Dough. He narrated newsreels, documentaries and feature films. "Crashing the Water Barrier", a 1956 documentary won the Oscar for Best Short Subject. In the mid-1950's he started "Christmas for Kids" a non-profit organization. In 1961 The Association for the Help of Retarded Children gave Jackson its Humanitarian Award. A guest appearance on "The Honeymooners" in 1956 brought him repeated visibility, and a clip from that show was part of a 2003 "Sopranos" episode. Jay Jackson is survived by his son, Jay Stephen and his wife Molly Wigand and four grandsons Steve, John, Joey, and Danny, and by his daughter Sally and her husband Paul F. Nace. He is also survived by his brother Dr. William T. Jackson and his sisters Opal Brown and Grace Knoder. He was predeceased by his wife of 54 years, Ann (Rodgers) in 1995. Donations in his memory can be made to the Louis Armstrong House Museum, 34-56 107th Street, Corona, NY 11368.

title: The Remix; Back to Collage
description: During his 30-plus years in fashion, The New Yorker's fashion director, Michael Roberts, has worn more hats than a Philip Treacy model. He began as a tart-tongued writer and critic at The London Sunday Times, where he was never afraid to say that something was hideous, leading to all sorts of litigation. He went on to art-direct memorable magazine covers, like one featuring Brooke Shields wearing a live turkey on her head for Vanity Fair and another with Vivienne Westwood looking like the spitting image of Margaret Thatcher for Tatler.

title: An Islamic Alienation
description: David Rieff (Aug. 14) seems to imply that the Muslims coming to France in the 1950's, and their children, were supposed to accept the values of their new country but didn't. In fact, until about five years ago, the great majority of Muslim women in France did not wear religious gear at all; I have seen people go from wearing miniskirts one day to burkas the next. In my neighborhood, where most people are Muslim, it is now rare to see a woman without at least a scarf on. Sometimes girls wear pants and skirts at the same time for modesty's sake.

title: Case Is Appealed Over Lack of West Indians on the Jury
description: In an unusual reflection of New York City's growing diversity, lawyers for a West Indian man are arguing that he was denied justice because the Bronx jury that convicted him of rape, sodomy and burglary included only American-born blacks while all five potential jurors who were West Indian were improperly excluded by the prosecution.

That will leave a shortage of 10 million workers and a huge gap in skills and knowledge, Mr. Green argues. Here are excerpts from a conversation:

title: Label Conscience
description: Some things just don't look right on a label. An Herms canvas-and-leather beach bag made in France works. An H&M $15 V-neck sweater made in Romania works. A Richard James suit made in England works. A Comme des Garons leather change purse made in Spain does not. Perhaps I still reside in another era, but I like there to be a logical connection between a brand's provenance and price.

title: Connect the Dots
description: Like the universe, Comme des Garcons is expanding. (But unlike the universe, Alvy Singer, there is no need for alarm.) The label, founded by Rei Kawakubo in 1969, now spans 13 separate collections and collaborations ranging from Repetto to Speedo. In addition to its retail spaces all over the world, Comme has sponsored a spate of temporary ''guerrilla'' stores, as well as the Dover Street Market in London and partnerships like the 10 Corso Como store in Tokyo. Moreover, Junya Watanabe is no longer the only emerging star in the Comme cosmos. Kawakubo recently tapped Tao Kurihara, a seven-year veteran of the house, to create Tao Comme des Garcons, which made its debut with a fall collection of cable-knit corsets and crocheted camisoles that were frothy enough to top with a cherry.

title: Witness to the Wee Hours
description: THERE may come a time when you are lonesome or restless or simply in the mood for a walk. This sometimes happens on those warm summer mornings when the air is good and, aside from the garbagemen, the only thing up is the sun.

title: White Mischief
description: One of Tilda Swinton's ancestors on her very posh, very military Scottish family tree was painted by John Singer Sargent, and it is easy to imagine Swinton, with her alabaster skin, otherworldly green eyes and regal 5-foot-11 bearing, captured in oils. "I do look like all those old paintings," Swinton joked over a midsummer lunch of raw oysters at the Mercer hotel. "But I'm afraid my temperament does not conform. At all."

title: The Great Divide
description: There's something mesmerizingly suggestive about great cleavage, the way the whole ingeniously configured architecture of the thing divides and conquers, drawing the eye onward and inward, toward the valley between two swelling orbs, indicating more supple delights just around the curve. Men, women and even children recognize it when they see it, which may be why I've always thought of it as one of the female body's triumphs: the physical embodiment of a come-on, a wink of flesh.

description: To the Editor: Regarding "An End to a Dolphin Program," (July 31): Responsible swim-with-the-dolphin and other interactive programs provide a personal connection for travelers with the wonders of ocean life.

description: Melvin Howard Osterman, a founding partner of the Albany law firm Whiteman Osterman & Hanna and an architect of important state labor legislation, died on Aug. 14 at his home in Delmar, N.Y. He was 70.

description: IN his uniform of blue slacks, black shoes and a white shirt with epaulets that sag a bit over narrow shoulders, Joey Quinn, 19 years old, radiates an air of authority as he darts across the marble lobby and under the expansive awning of 1088 Park Avenue to hail a cab for a resident. He opens the door for a trim, middle-aged woman in sunglasses and a flowered Lilly Pulitzer skirt who barely acknowledges his presence, then returns to his desk, which has seen a steady traffic of bags and visitors in the midmorning heat.

description: Nicole Lisa Karagheuzoff and Marc Darrin Denker are to be married today at the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx. Rabbi Marcia Rappaport is to officiate, and the Rev. Thomas Joyce, a Roman Catholic priest, to participate in the ceremony.

title: The Remix; Shock Troupe
description: Who says style can't have substance? The Citizens Band, a sexy take on Weimar-era cabaret, may count some scantily clad supermodels and trapeze artists among its performers, but it's not all titillation. In elaborately staged shows, with themes that explore love and loss, religion and politics, the band walks a tightrope between the serious and the surreal. The model and singer Karen Elson, the composer Paul Cantelon, the recording artist Angela McCluskey and the aerialist Chelsea Bacon are among the band's 30 members. The roster keeps growing as like-minded friends pile on, according to the filmmaker Sarah Sophie Flicker, who founded the troupe with the singer Jorjee Douglass and the director Adam Dugas. The collective's latest production, "The Trepanning Opera," which satirizes the American health care system, will have its debut next month at Deitch Projects' Wooster Street space. The gallery's owner, Jeffrey Deitch, who represents Citizens, has also enlisted the group to make a float for the Art Parade, which marches down Grand Street on Sept. 10 -- a fine day to jump on the bandwagon. SANDRA BALLENTINE

title: 911 Response Time Helped by Computer

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FIELDSTEEL, IRA
description: FIELDSTEEL--Ira of Rockport, MA, formerly of Closter, NJ, died on August 26, 2005 at the age of 91. He was the beloved husband of Nina and loving father of Joshua (and Esther) Fieldsteel of Jerusalem, Israel, Adam Fieldsteel (and Irene) Mulvey of Middletown, CT, and the "adopted" father of Emmanuel Noggoh of Trenton, NJ. His cherished grandchildren are Chiam Zvi, Meir, and Menachem Fieldsteel of Jerusalem, Eli, Nathan, and Zoe of Middletown, and Jason and Matthew of Trenton. A graduate of CCNY and Columbia University Law School (1937), he served in the OSS in World War II and worked as an Immigration Judge for the last 26 years of his professional career, serving as the Judge in several high profile cases. He was also a gifted photographer and had had a one man show at the Rockport Art Association in March, 2004. A scholar with a broad range of interests, he was a true example of a Renaisance man. He will be missed by his loving family and friends. A Funeral Service will be held at the Mt. Jacob Cemetery, West Gloucester, Massachusetts on Tuesday, August 30 at 1 PM. Donations in his memory may be made to the Earthjustice, the legal arm of the Sierra Club, 426 Seventeenth Street, 6th Flr, Oakland, CA 94612 or to the charity of your choice. For information contact Stanetsky Hymanson Memorial Chapel, Salem, MA.

title: How Photos Became Icon of Civil Rights Movement
description: Mutilated is the word most often used to describe the face of Emmett Till after his body was hauled out of the Tallahatchie River in Mississippi. Inhuman is more like it: melted, bloated, missing an eye, swollen so large that its patch of wiry hair looks like that of a balding old man, not a handsome, brazen 14-year-old boy.

description: THE high school lunch tray piled high with pizza, French fries, a soda and a brownie may soon be a thing of the past.

title: Does Lighter Equal Deadlier?
description: THE last time the government decided to make cars go farther on a gallon of gas, during the energy shocks of the 1970's, the strategy worked. Or at least it did for about a decade, as new regulations forced automakers to make more efficient vehicles. Soaring gas prices and shortages were also a powerful motivator for consumers to trade in their Oldsmobile Toronados for little Datsuns and Ford Escorts. Gas mileage for the average new vehicle went from 13.1 miles per gallon in 1975 models to 22.1 miles per gallon in 1987 models, according to the Environmental Protection Agency.

title: The Other Army
description: Nothing I have read illustrates the twilight of the American empire more clearly than Daniel Bergner's article (Aug. 14). In hindsight it is apparent that by the time Rome had begun to rely upon the hiring of Germanic tribes to protect its borders and fight its wars, the dissolution of its empire was inevitable. You can call Bergner's subjects "mercenaries," "private armies" or "private security companies," but what they are in reality are echoes of the past and glimpses of the future.

title: The Talk; Scissor Sisters
description: Kate and Laura Mulleavy are excited to be excited. A conversation with the Mulleavys -- the sisters behind Rodarte, the year-old California label that's set to show in New York next month -- is an exercise in connecting the dots between Kate Moss, James Joyce, the Temple of Dendur and Clover the orphaned rhino. Their first collection was championed by Cameron Silver, who allowed the girls to use his store, Decades, in Los Angeles, to show Anna Wintour their old-Hollywood-style dresses. They scored a Women's Wear Daily cover, and orders came in from the likes of Kirna Zabte in New York. But Kate and Laura remain charmingly free of pretension. Quite the opposite: how many fashion players do you know who get caught running in museums? Which all goes back to their exotic provenance. To call the sisters and their family the Royal Tenenbaums of Fashion is not an overstatement.

title: 'The First Poets'
description: "What would a man not give," declares Plato in the Apology, "to engage in conversation with Orpheus and Musaeus and Hesiod and Homer?" Can we do something of the sort? If not to engage in conversation, then at least to glimpse them as they go about their holy and unholy business?

title: The Remix; Fashion Credits
description: Editors who turn a new page to become designers are nothing new. Vera Wang began at Vogue, and Kate Spade at Mademoiselle. But these days, editors turned designers are as common as subscription cards littering nail-salon floors. Lucy Sykes, late of Allure and Marie Claire, has a kiddie-couture collection, Lucy Sykes Baby; Thakoon Panichgul, formerly at Harper's Bazaar, founded Thakoon; Stacey Lapidus followed Vanity Fair with a line of bags. But the real world has its limitations. "At Vanity Fair," Lapidus says, "I could send 100 messengers a day." This must be why some of her contemporaries have kept their day jobs. Irini Arakas, of Vogue, moonlights designing Prova's jewelry (left). AKA New York was created by three editors -- Abigale Levinson, Karen Reinitz and Ana Maria Pimentel -- who met at Elle (two still work there). Most of the designers who remain editors say their jobs keep them in the know. Knowing how to edit helps, too. Says the bag-lady Lapidus, "My radar, my decisions, are really quick." If only home offices came with a fashion closet. Alexandra Zissu

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MCCABE, MARGARET ELLEN ''NINI''
description: McCABE--Margaret Ellen "Nini", age 53, died August 24, 2005 in Fairfield, CT. after a long illness. She was born October 29, 1951, Cuernavaca, Mexico to Charles Raymond McCabe, a former columnist for the San Francisco Chronicle, and Margaret Ellen "Peg" Scripps Buzzelli. Nini was a great-granddaughter and heiress of Edward Willis Scripps, founder of the Scripps newspapers and United Press International. Educated at Cobham Hall, Kent, England, Simon's Rock, Great Barrington, MA, and a graduate of Bennington College in Bennington, Vermont, she was a recipient of The Mark Van Doren Prize for Poetry. She first worked for publisher, Al Goldstein in New York, for Grabhorn-Hoyem Press in San Francisco, and afterwards as a freelance writer. A 30 year denizen of North Beach, Nini was an integral part of the tapestry of San Francisco, well known at her father's favorite watering hole, Gino and Carlo's, and beloved to many San Franciscans. She was preceded in death by her parents. Survived by her brothers, Peter (Debbie) of Portland, OR, Charles (Gail) of San Francisco, CA and Bob Buzzelli of Sarasota, FL; sisters, Mary (David) Peirce and Liz (Sam) Logan of Sarasota, FL. Also survived by four nieces and and three nephews, many dear friends in San Francisco, CA and Connecticut and her faithful companion and guardian, Olive. A celebration of Nini's life will be held at Gino & Carlo's, 548 Green Street in San Francisco, CA on October 29 at 5:00PM. All friends and relatives are welcome. Private memorial services will be held in Connecticut and Florida. Donations may be made in her memory to: The Connecticut Chapter of National Multiple Sclerosis Society, One Selleck Street, Suite 500, Norwalk, CT 06855, Delta Society National Service Dog Center, 875 124th Avenue, NE, Suite 101, Bellevue, WA 98005, The Nature Conservancy, 4245 N. Fairfax Drive, Suite 100, Arlington, VA 22203 or the Mechanics Institute Library, 57 Post Street, San Francisco, CA 94104. To send an online condolence please visit www.shaughnesseyfuneralhome.com

title: Pops and Locks Set to Bach

Hip-hop, pure and simple. But that sound, could it be Stravinsky?

title: The Remix; Dark Horse
description: A fashion education in London and a childhood in Southern Italy with a widowed mother and eight older sisters might explain Riccardo Tisci's fascination with sisterhood, both the pious and the profane. His hooded capes and gauzy dresses suggest prayers, hysterics and a touch of poverty. At his second show in Milan last spring, editors not used to Lenten parades grew impatient at the progression led by his model muse, Maria Carla Boscono. At the time, no one thought to compare the happening to Vittorio De Sica's film "Miracle in Milan," about an orphan discovered in a cabbage patch. But two weeks later, Tisci became the latest cabbage-patch discovery -- hired by Givenchy. Tisci, 30, is the fourth designer to take over since its namesake retired in 1995, but he seems to be the first to recognize that its legacy goes beyond Audrey Hepburn. At his fall couture debut last month, Tisci showed delicate dresses in cobweb lace, patent leather skirts and a white shirt with a pleated cuff that caused Carine Roitfeld, the editor in chief of French Vogue, to coo, "It's so modern." CATHY HORYN

title: Getting Out the Vote, Not to Mention the Dictionary

Judge Sussman is survived by her husband David, daughters Jane and Rebecca, parents Howard and Barbara Levine, and brothers Neil and Jim Levine. The family will celebrate Ruth's life with a ceremony at the Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave. on Sunday, August 28, at 1:15 pm. Senior Rabbi Nancy Solomon, President $(6$)SUSSMAN -- Ruth. Through her vitality, Ruth taught us so much of life. She will continue to enliven our memories. Love especially to Becky, Jane and David. Bars and restaurants were filled with "Sex and the City" clones, the bag of the moment in one hand and its cocktail counterpart in the other. But then, even before the movie "Sideways" showed that it was sexy to talk about terroir, the same women who collected Marni and McQueen began turning their attention to a different sort of label altogether: the one on a bottle of wine.

title: Passion and the Prisoner
description: I once wanted to write a novel called "Bad Taste," about a female character who has incomprehensibly rotten instincts when it comes to making romantic choices. While I was toying with this idea, I was also deeply enamored of a man whose upper-middle-class presentation (which included engraved stationery of the thickest stock, on which he penned the most proper of thank-you notes) couldn't fully mask some alarming tendencies, one of which required him to report in monthly to a law-enforcement agent as to his whereabouts. This relationship had followed upon a two-year involvement with another questionable sort who ended up serving a yearlong prison sentence after we stopped going out, convicted of some white-collar malfeasance he may or may not have committed. By that low point in his life he was married to another woman, but all the same, he sent me letters from the clink describing his daily routine (which seemed to consist of working out in the gym and taking computer courses courtesy of the federal government). I always felt a faint outlaw thrill when an envelope bearing a Pennyslvania postmark and an anonymous, "Stalag 17"-like return address (Bunk #, Unit #, Division #) arrived in the mail, as if I were implicated in the whole sordid drama, a Bonnie Parker by proxy.

title: The Talk; Flea Bitten
description: Rossella Tarabini is given to making pronouncements. This one is a pip. "Your closet," says the 37-year-old designer behind the Anna Molinari label, "is like a boyfriend. It starts to look the same after a while." She is speaking of a closet that is actually a room in her family home in Carpi, a pretty village just north of Modena, Italy, that is more palatial than most Manhattan studios. Two long racks hold hundreds of articles of vintage clothing, tidily arranged by color, while shoes are displayed on round tables like fine silver. The petite Tarabini doesn't have a count. "I'm not a rational person," says the designer, who with her hair bundled up in Princess Leia plaits suggests a Bjorkian nymph. "I like my clothes to tell a story." She points to a camisole she purchased in Paris that originally belonged to a former high-class mistress whose lover left her but who refused to sell any of her clothes. "So she died a poor woman with a great wardrobe." A kindred spirit, no doubt.

Wearers can position the belts high and snug at the waist, threaded through belt loops or slung low on the hip without any strain or adjustment. The selection of six styles includes a best-selling leather belt with beads and hidden elastic panels ($228), a stretchy metal circle-link belt ($418) and a fish-scale belt with bronze metallic and leather detail ($489, all at Searle stores).

The saucy platinum blonde is the Sade of fado, a hybrid of Brazilian music styles that comes from the word "fate" and is linked with saudade -- which roughly translates as longing and sadness tinged with joy. And you can feel the joy, especially as fado was in disrepute after the 1974 Carnation Revolution because the country's dictator Antnio de Oliveira Salazar had exploited it for propaganda. But now it is back. As Mariza describes it: "Fado is our hip-hop. It makes us feel like part of something." You can be part of it, too, at Carnegie Hall in October, when Mariza will attempt to influence your fate. Paul L. Underwood

title: Inside the List
description: WAR STORIES: In the aftermath of previous wars, it took years if not decades for books by soldiers to filter into bookstores. The current war is different. This fall will see the publication of at least five on-the-ground memoirs by recent combatants. The first to make an impact is "The Last True Story I'll Ever Tell: An Accidental Soldier's Account of the War in Iraq," by John Crawford, which enters the hardcover nonfiction list this week at No. 12. Crawford, who ended up in Iraq after joining the Florida National Guard to help pay his college tuition, turns out to be a bracing writer. ("My M-249 squad automatic weapon fired 850 rounds a minute, and if that didn't stop whatever was after me, then I had a problem that nothing would solve.") Crawford thinks the war in Iraq is a mistake. But as he put it, memorably, to Terry Gross recently on National Public Radio, he believes it's too late to stop now: "I liken it to getting in a bar fight. Occasionally, you know, you get drunk and you get in a fight because you think some guy's eyeballing you in the bar. And you wake up in the morning, and you say, 'Wow, that guy didn't deserve that at all.' But the morning is the time for regret. If you do it in the middle of the fight, then you still wake up feeling bad, but you got beat up, too."

title: For Manhattan Borough President
description: There was a time when politicians coveted the job of borough president because of the clout, which included a seat on the powerful Board of Estimate. Since that plum was taken away, the office's chief attractions are simply a staff, a budget and a potentially high profile. In Manhattan, nine Democrats aspire to replace the term-limited C. Virginia Fields. The sheer size of the field makes this race one of the most unpredictable in the Sept. 13 primary, since no runoff is required. The winner may need fewer than 20 percent of the ballots. The candidates should be judged on what they might do to make this weak office into a voice for borough residents.

title: The Ethicist
description: The Ethicist (Aug. 14) usually makes sense, but not this time. The suggestion that a person observed trapping and drowning squirrels in his backyard should be anonymously reported to the A.S.P.C.A. is ridiculous. Squirrels and their brothers, chipmunks, are one step up from rats. They are destructive pests. They multiply like flies and are not (unfortunately) in danger of extinction.

title: ROBBERY ON THE RIVIERA
description: To the Editor: Regarding "St.-Tropez  Go-Go" (July 31): We need to add another word to this litany of glamour, wealth, decadence and chic in this Cte d'Azur town. The word is thievery.

title: The Remix; The Mod Couple

The results show the unmistakable influence of two youthful stars: the drug-addled ingenue Edie Sedgwick and the model Jean Shrimpton. Which of these two 60's style icons are you? IAIN R. WEBB

title: Turn of Faith
description: I am uneasy about the parallels I sense between Joy Castro's upbringing as a fundamentalist Jehovah's Witness and Muslims who are educated in fundamentalist Islamic madrasas around the world (Lives, Aug. 14). Everything Castro describes, from the social isolation to the promise of eternal life in paradise to the desire for destruction of everyone who isn't a Witness, sounds chillingly like the formula we now know breeds young people willing to blow themselves up along with everyone around them.

title: Botox Babies
description: Did you hear about the 19-year-old girl who had botox injections to stop the crinkling around the eyes when she smiled? Or the 26-year-old beauty editor with a porcelain complexion who went for laser treatments to prevent sagging skin and sun spots from appearing in the future? Or the woman in her 20's who, alarmed at the incipient folds forming at the sides of her mouth, made the rounds of top Manhattan plastic surgeons until she found someone willing to give her a face-lift?

title: Show Me the Science
description: Blue Hill, Me. - PRESIDENT BUSH, announcing this month that he was in favor of teaching about "intelligent design" in the schools, said, "I think that part of education is to expose people to different schools of thought." A couple of weeks later, Senator Bill Frist of Tennessee, the Republican leader, made the same point. Teaching both intelligent design and evolution "doesn't force any particular theory on anyone," Mr. Frist said. "I think in a pluralistic society that is the fairest way to go about education and training people for the future."

title: The Get; Midwestern Modern
description: 1. Ikram Goldman isn't afraid to take chances. She lines the racks of her impossibly chic eponymous store in Chicago with fashion, as opposed to inventory. After four years in business for herself, she cherry-picks from the collections with conviction and has no qualms ordering a $62,000 alligator trench coat by Proenza Schouler or a faux-fur skirt from Undercover, the Tokyo label designed by Jun Takahashi. "If it's good, someone will buy it," she says. Here, she's wearing a top by Junya Watanabe and necklaces from Prova.

Its long red arm, leaning over a fresh construction site, is visible for blocks around -- visible even, as some residents have discovered, from the Lower East Side.

title: ART
description: There are few better places to make peace with the waning of summer evenings than at P.S. 1 in Long Island City, Queens, inside JAMES TURRELL's ethereal permanent exhibit called "MEETING." This Saturday is the last day for a while that you can count on visiting the work, a room with a retractable ceiling and subtly hidden lights, in which viewers can sit or lie down and watch -- weather permitting -- as the rectangle of sky above them shades from bright blue to purple to deep black; after Saturday, the room is only open when the sunset, the museum's hours and clement weather coincide. Mr. Turrell calls such works spyspaces and has said his intention is for people "to pay attention to the thingness and revelation of light." Visitors are allowed to enter about half an hour before sunset, which this Saturday will be about 7:30. 22-25 Jackson Avenue, at 46th Avenue, (718) 784-2084, $8.

title: Works That Suggest Kaleidoscopic Vision
description: Yonkers - SUSAN LEOPOLD'S photo-constructions play tricks on your eyes. But I imagine that is probably the point, for her wall assemblages at the Hudson River Museum here have been carefully fashioned in such a way that their appearance is changeable: the viewer's movement makes her art come alive, tripping up your vision.

title: The Remix; Witchy Woman
description: At a downtown dinner party one night, the artist Hope Atherton was seated next to Perry Moore, an executive producer of the film "The Chronicles of Narnia: The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe," based on the children's book by C.S. Lewis. "Just looking at what she was wearing, and sensing her inner style," he says, "I could tell she would be a fabulous addition to the project." So when Atherton was asked to collaborate with the film's costume designer, Isis Mussenden, and others to help bring Tilda Swinton's White Witch character to terrifying life, she felt she was in her own fairy tale: Lewis's book was one of her childhood favorites, and Swinton was already one of her inspirations.

description: SMALL children and prescientific peoples, it is said, employ magical thinking to deal with a world they can't understand or control. In an age of technology, which produces a constant flood of incomprehensible phenomena, such forms of thinking may be an occasional necessity for everyone.

Quickly the fashion photographer Steven Klein strode over and asked the riders, in their helmets and padded suits, if they would mind posing with the boys in the midday sun.

title: DEALS & DISCOUNTS
description: EASY STAY IN SWITZERLAND -- The easyGroup, which brought the world its low-cost, no-frills easyCruise and the easyHotel in London, expects to open an easyHotel franchise in Basel, Switzerland, by Sept. 20. Rates for the 24 double rooms in a town house start as low as $21 for the three rooms that have no window (but do have air-conditioning); prices increase based on availability. The rooms are 97 to 172 square feet. Beds consist of double mattresses on platforms. There are private bathrooms (showers only) as well as pay-as-you-watch televisions (about $8, at 80 cents to the Swiss franc, for 24 hours). Reservations at www.easyhotel.com only.

title: Unraveling A Complex Imagery
description: WHEN people ask what I do when I'm not looking at exhibitions, I always feel embarrassed. As an art critic, I know how I'm supposed to reply: I do anything other than visit museums, look at art and browse through exhibition catalogs. But the truth is that I actually spend leisure time deepening my interest in certain artists and art forms, like Japanese Jizo, standing wooden figures from the Kamakura period, and Tibetan thangkas.

title: The Family Patriarch As Movie Hero and Star
description: WESTHAMPTON - BUSTER ROBINSON was not the sort of cop who would talk about the gut-clenching horror that comes with being a homicide detective. It was his wife who compiled the family scrapbook, filling half of it with autopsy photos and other gruesome memorabilia from more than 30 years with the Nassau County Police Department and the other half with family photos and newspaper clippings of bake sales.

title: Today's Horoscope: Now Unsure
description: IN the not-too-distant future, maps of the solar system may be redrawn to add another planet -- or perhaps take one away. Last month, when scientists announced the discovery of a possible 10th planet, some nine billion miles from the Sun, they reignited a long-running debate about what a true planet is. They are grappling with whether the newly found celestial body, known for now as 2003 UB313, should be granted planetary status, and if it is not, whether Pluto, a like-size ice ball in a far orbit of the Sun, should be stripped of the title.

title: Lawton Arrives in Bronx And Starts in Right Field
description: The Yankees acquired outfielder Matt Lawton from the Chicago Cubs late Friday for the minor league pitcher Justin Berg. General Manager Brian Cashman said he hoped the move would add flexibility to the Yankees' roster.

title: A Tragedy's Aftermath
description: The deaths last month of two toddlers, scalded in their tub in Yonkers while adults slept nearby, have cast the county's Department of Social Services in an unforgiving light. The boys' mother and the father of the younger child face criminal charges, and a caseworker was fired after investigators discovered that she had skipped meetings with the family in the months before the boys died.

title: The Talk; New Bold Faces
description: These arrivals on the social circuit have yet to be overexposed. But the season is young.

title: The Remix; MODEL ON THE MOVE
description: Step aside, Lauren Hutton. The Hemingway Model Award now goes to Jodie Kidd. At 26, the British beauty is not only an accomplished polo player, she's also fast becoming a racing star. Two years ago, she appeared in a segment on the television show "Top Gear," which sends celebrities around a track in a cheap car. "I thrashed everyone," she says. Maserati soon tapped her to compete in its eight annual Trofeo races. And Pirelli, a cosponsor, is outfitting her in PZero Pirelli clothes and shoes that perform on and off the road. Her next goal? Earning the respect of the Italian drivers. "It's hard enough being a model woman track driver. Imagine being a blond model woman track driver. You've got to be pretty gutsy." C.M.

title: The Remix; Room and Board
description: The fashion designer Rick Owens has always had a thing for retro glamour, however tattered and faded. The pieces in his new furniture line -- massive chairs, ottoman, sofa and table -- look like half-completed prototypes for Norma Desmond's living room. He left the finishes raw, choosing rough wooden planks and translucent resin with the occasional snake skeleton embedded. The pillows are cashmere or beaver. Intentionally shabby but definitely chic. ALIX BROWNE

title: DANCE
description: You can stroll through several continents' worth of dance this week at the relaxed, free LINCOLN CENTER OUT OF DOORS festival. There will be Taiwanese dancing, drumming and acrobatics by the HUNG-SHENG LION DANCE THEATER, American hip-hop by the FLY DANCE COMPANY, and African dance by the KANKOURAN WEST AFRICAN DANCE COMPANY of Washington. Hung-Sheng and Fly will perform for children in daytime programs on the plaza and for the entire family in the evening at the DAMROSCH PARK BAND SHELL. CELEBRANDO MXICONOW brings the dance component to a close in the band shell on Thursday night. Information from www.lincolncenter.org or (212)875-5766.

title: Winning in Iraq
description: Andrew Krepinevich is a careful, scholarly man. A graduate of West Point and a retired lieutenant colonel, his book, "The Army and Vietnam," is a classic on how to fight counterinsurgency warfare.

title: Romeo Is Burning
description: The fashion plate of the season is not a model but a dish served at the Anaheim White House restaurant in California. The Romeo Gigli Salmon Chocolat is named for the recently revisited Italian designer who has inspired Marc Jacobs, among others, this fall. It's made of poached Norwegian salmon served with mashed potatoes whipped with melted white chocolate in a citrus beurre blanc and decorated with tortilla and pasta butterflies. "I saw white chocolate -- I don't know why," says Bruno Serato, the restaurant's owner and a fashion aficionado. "It's a little bit of everything. It's not easy to describe what it tastes like." The dish shares the menu with fashion-conscious fish entrees like the Fendi Prawns (served over handmade pasta with herbs and a touch of soy), the Ferr Halibut (prepared in a pinot grigio sauce with julienned vegetables) and the Cartier Calamari Ripieni (stuffed with Dungeness crab meat on a scarlet orange sauce). Burberry check, please. MARK JACOBS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GREEN, SIDNEY
description: GREEN--Sidney. Passed away June 1, 2005 in Ithaca, NY. Retired printer from New York Times composing room. Born 1912 in London, England. Predeceased by wife Kathleen E. Green. Survived by wife Bobbie K. Green, daughter Hilary Green Ford, grandchildren, family and friends. Actor and friend to all.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CIVIN, SYLVIA
description: CIVIN--Sylvia. 89 years old. Passed away peacefully on August 23, 2005 in Fresh Meadows, Queens. Beloved wife of the late Louis and mother of Margaret and the late Matthew. Adored grandmother of Jonathan, Joshua and wife Rachel. Devoted English teacher. Friend to all. Lover of books and words. Her generosity, letters, and love will be deeply missed.

title: Letters
description: The legal implications of outsourcing the war in Iraq were on the minds of many who responded to our report on soldiers for hire. Other readers said that all infants, not just fragile newborns, deserve sensitive surroundings. And is there something unsavory, some asked, about those gourmet meals in a bag?

title: Muffin-Top
description: The fashion world is a fecund, fruitful and fertile source of metaphoric phrases. (Funny, that all these synonyms for "productive" begin with f.) In 1999, an outbreak of bare midsections in the fashion world led this department to a midriff riff: I expressed my preference for the informal term bellybutton to be written as a single word, on the analogy of bellyache; this stand was opposed by a legion of navel-gazers who preferred a two-word usage, on the analogy of belly dancer. The dispute has never been resolved.

title: DISNEY'S MAGIC
description: To the Editor: Charles Passy vacationed at Disney World and was disappointed. We can understand disappointment.

title: Comings and Goings
description: The Dec. 31 target date to put in effect new travel rules for Americans visiting the Caribbean is still up in the air, according the STATE DEPARTMENT. The intelligence reform law passed last year by Congress requires that by Jan. 1, 2008, Americans returning from the Caribbean, Bermuda, Mexico and Canada have a passport, rather than just a driver's license and birth certificate. The State Department had proposed beginning to apply it on Dec. 31 with travelers coming back from the Caribbean, and extending it to Canada and Mexico in December 2006, but the State Department continues to evaluate public response to the plan. Current travel requirements to and from every country are available at travel.state.gov. SPIRIT AIRLINES is introducing several new flights from Orlando, Fla., on Nov. 10. There will be daily nonstop service to Fort Lauderdale, Fla., and flights to Montego Bay, Jamaica, on Thursday, Saturday and Sunday until Dec. 14, when the service becomes daily. Information and reservations: (800) 772-71172 or www.spiritair.com. MARJORIE CONNELLY

title: On Baseball; It's Not a Typo: Peralta and the Indians Are Rolling
description: THE Cleveland Indians have a player named Peralta who is different in at least two respects from other players of similar name or origin: he is a Dominican shortstop who was not born in San Pedro de Macoris, the cradle of Dominican shortstops, and he doesn't know how to spell his first name correctly.

description: A 39-year old Brooklyn man was shot to death early yesterday by a man who burst through the door of the victim's apartment and argued with him about money, investigators said.

title: Blissfully Up a Creek
description: FEW things are as transporting -- or as disorienting -- as plunging into nature on a summer weekend. You almost understand why city dwellers prefer the cosseted and connected world of the Hamptons, where only the setting changes, but the faces, pace and Internet service are all the same. When you jump into aqua incognita, it can feel so cold and foreign that you may need something more redolent of civilization -- a copy of Us Weekly and skim caffe latte, say -- to warm up.

title: Different Kind of Football and New Role as Jets Punter
description: Ben Graham played in the Australian Football League for 12 years before coming to New York in January to try to make his N.F.L. dreams come true. Now he is the last punter standing on the Jets after the six-year veteran Micah Knorr was waived yesterday.

title: Beijing's Quest for 2008: To Become Simply Livable
description: BEIJING, Aug. 27 - There is a placard beside Tiananmen Square that counts the days until the 2008 Summer Olympics, and every one of them would seem precious: Beijing must build or renovate 72 sports stadiums and training facilities, lay asphalt for 59 new roads and complete three new bridges by the opening ceremony.

title: Installing a Food Disposal Unit

And if my landlord agrees to install one at his expense, how would any rent increase be calculated? C. Brody, Manhattan.

This fall alone, 10 are to play off Broadway -- twice as many as are expected on the main stem itself. The first three contenders have just started previews.

Synge on the Irish stage has been a checkered one. Celebrations of Synge have filled the newspapers and the bookshops this summer, thanks to the enterprising efforts of Garry Hynes, the Tony-winning director best known abroad for her work with Martin McDonagh, himself an aesthetic heir of Synge, with whom he shares a gift for gritty lyricism as well as a taste for rollicking, sometimes violent physical comedy.

title: A Baseline Recovery
description: On May 6 of last year, James Blake was standing beneath an awning beside a clay tennis court in Rome, waiting out a sudden downpour. Two days earlier, Blake, a professional player then ranked No. 43 in the world, lost a close first-round match to Jiri Novak at the Italian Open. Ordinarily, Blake will practice the day after an early-round loss, but taking advantage of the perks available to him, he attended Mass at the Vatican instead, met the pope and then, that evening, dropped by a private party given for Giorgio Armani. (The Association of Tennis Professionals, for obvious publicity reasons, had arranged for his access.) Now, following his privileged glimpse of Rome, Blake, who was ranked as high as No. 22 in May 2003, had the remainder of the European clay-court season on his mind. One of the hardest workers on the tour, he was eager to practice.

title: Coming Soon to Brooklyn: Alabama
description: Perhaps it was only a matter of time until real estate and theater, two of New York's favorite obsessions, converged. On Sept. 18, lovers of classic plays and aficionados of transitional neighborhoods can meet in Ditmas Park, a Victorian section of Flatbush in Brooklyn, where the Brave New World Repertory Theater will perform "To Kill a Mockingbird" using the street, the sidewalk and the porches of six turn-of-the-century (the 20th, that is) homes on either side of Westminster Road as setting and stage. "I live in a large Victorian house on Westminster Road and a year ago I was standing on the porch with a friend and associate, Christine Siracusa, when we decided to do 'To Kill a Mockingbird,"' said Claire Beckman, 44, the producing artistic director of Brave New World, a Brooklyn-based company in its second season. "My fear about the play was that it is so much of an outdoor story, that involves trees, porches, porch swings, tree swings and kids running around. I couldn't imagine doing it inside."

title: QUICK BITE/North Wildwood; Where the Hot Dog Finds a New Partner
description: Six years ago, Michael D'Antuono returned from his long-term chef's job in Hawaii to settle in Wildwood, where he spent his summers as a young man. He had made all sorts of fancy things at the Hyatt Hotel in Maui, but he was aiming for something a bit more lowbrow for the Shore. "I would make hot dogs for special occasions, and my friends said, 'You've got to open up a place,' so I did," said Mr. D'Antuono, whose Maui's Doghouse is inspired by the nickname his Wildwood friends gave him: Maui. He makes three styles of hot dogs -- beef, white (a veal, pork and beef combo) and veggie -- and 29 dressings.

title: A Hedge Fund Falls Off the Face of the Earth
description: "HELLO, this is Dan Marino," says a weary, raspy voice on an answering machine. Mr. Marino, the chief financial officer of the Bayou Group, a $400 million hedge-fund and brokerage firm that is under investigation by state and federal authorities in Connecticut, sounds beleaguered. "Please leave me a message," he goes on. "I am receiving lots of phone calls. I am unable to pick up every call, so if you do call, leave a message and a number. I will get back to you."

title: In California Enclave, Cougars Keep the People at Bay
description: ATHERTON, Calif. - You would think that if you plunked down $10 million for a home, including millions to buy three adjoining properties, you could count on a little freedom to roam. But then the occasional mountain lion traipses across your land and, if you are Barbara Proulx, you feel trapped, afraid to let your two young sons out by themselves because of the dangers lurking outside.

title: How Do Their Gardens Grow? Perhaps Not the Way You'd Think
description: The city's greenmarkets have lately brimmed with August's familiar bounty. At 54 markets, tables are piled high with bulbous eggplant, luscious blackberries, and at least a dozen precious varieties of heirloom tomato. But behind the selling booths, a rumor persists at a low din among farmers that some in their ranks sell items they neither grew nor produced themselves, in violation of the strict "producer-only" rules put in place by the city Greenmarket program.

Pop Art was trendy at the time, and the Gottliebs hoped that Two Plus Three, the wholesale giftware company that they were running part time from their home, might defray the cost of sending their three sons to college.

title: The Hotel Detective (Age 12)
description: MARTHA GRIMES is three books into a series of dreamy, semiautobiographical mysteries, set in the post-World-War II South, about Emma Graham, a 12-year-old sleuth who is smarter, funnier and more devious than most licensed grown-ups in the trade. I dread the day this darling girl turns 13 -- and so, it seems, does she. "Thirteen was coming down the tracks right at me. And after 13 came, there'd be no stopping it," she says in BELLE RUIN (Viking, $25.95). "Even so," she adds, "it wasn't what was coming fast at me that was so upsetting, it was what was left behind."

The former tenant had proudly "personalized" the concrete floor with a lurid Jackson Pollock effect, but otherwise the commercial space, which rents for $1,375 a month, was a nearly empty 1,035-square-foot box with running water, a bathroom and a nice closet.

title: DARTH DID IT

He told investors and analysts that a "miscreants' ball" of market participants was somehow working together to push down his company's stock. Several PowerPoint slides mapped out a web of alleged connections involving certain hedge fund managers, market pundits, lawyers, even the S.E.C. Masterminding it all, he claimed, was a financial wizard identified only as Sith Lord, a reference to the "Star Wars" villain.

title: Finding Holes in the Housing Bubble
description: THE median value of single-family homes in Westchester skyrocketed 78 percent between 1990 and 2003 to $502,882 from $282,200, the fifth-highest among more than 200 counties nationwide, according to census data. The median value soared in Dutchess County too, up 60 percent to $238,258 from $149,200. Simultaneously, the population aged 20 to 34 in Westchester and Dutchess fell 18 percent and 20.5 percent, respectively, during the last decade -- that's nearly four times the national decline.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ANTON, PAUL
description: ANTON--Paul. On August 27, 2005. Beloved husband of Jung Suk. Devoted father of Sandra, Laura Madden (Fred), Anthony, Philip and James. Adored grandfather of Kimberly, Natti and Shannon Madden. He faced his illness with bravery, surrounded by his family. Paul was a master furrier and was the owner of Paul Anton Furs in NYC for many years and was a successful real estate entrepreneur. He had a life long love of the sea and was an avid fisherman. Paul loved to play cards, visit the casinos in Atlantic City and spend time at his home in Puerto Rico. He was a natural salesman and great storyteller. Paul was a proud Navy veteran of WWII and fought in the Pacific Theater. He will be missed by his family and friends, his dog Snowball, and the many people he helped and loved in his life. For information: Macagna Funeral Home, Cliffside Park, NJ. 201-945-7100.

title: Sniff, and Scratch Your Head
description: Start with the obvious: Diorella is a profoundly strange perfume. A Frenchman I said this to became very defensive and replied, "Diorella is a classic!" Which was not only irrelevant -- it also missed the point entirely. Can you describe Diorella? People say, "Intensely flowery"; they say, "Fresh yet weightless"; they say, "Notes of citrus and ripe fruit" and blah-blah-blah. O.K., fine. All of this is wrong: what is wonderful about Diorella is that it smells like a new fur coat that has been rubbed with a very creamy mint toothpaste. Not gel. Paste. It is a great, great fragrance. It was created for Dior by the legendary perfumer Edmond Roudnitska in 1972, and it feels like 1932 and 2022 at the same time. And that means that Diorella is -- there's just no other way to describe it -- strange. And that's good.

title: The Remix; ROCKER WEAR
description: The song remains the same, now with outfits to match. The vintage clothing store Cherry, a favorite of stylists, will have the distinction of presiding over the first mega-boutique of used threads when it opens an outpost in the Virgin Megastore in Times Square next month. The roughly 400-square-foot space will offer the greatest hits of antiestablishment style: biker gear, pirate jackets, death-metal ephemera. "Everything basically associated with rock," says Cesar Padilla, a Cherry owner. "The person who's shopping for CD's should be able to buy cowboy boots, cop shades, whatever they want." It's a savvy association on the part of Virgin, as Cherry has credibility to spare. Padilla assures that the new endeavor will also carry the premium wares -- a Victorian coat from the Barcelona Opera House or a Gang of Four T-shirt from 1979 -- for which his stores in New York and L.A. are known. He also believes there is enough worthwhile vintage in the world (let alone in his Long Island City warehouse) to meet the demands of such a heavily trafficked outlet: "I have so much good stuff, you have no idea," he says. A Hollywood Boulevard location is scheduled to roll out in October. MARK JACOBS

This seems slightly more credible than a remedy for cellulite, but Dr. Paul Jarrod Frank, a New York dermatologist, says if the jeans are worn very tight, "you might notice some improvement." title: AT THE SACSAYHUAMN RUINS, JUNE 30, 2005
description: Brian Flack, 29, a high school teacher and coach from Rockport, Tex., photographs his fiance, Damaris King (off camera). "I knew the stones the Incas used were big, but I didn't realize they were that big. I took out a credit card and I could not stick it in between. No mortar, nothing. Really intriguing. This was our first trip together, Damaris's first trip out of the country. She was nervous, didn't know what to expect. I'm trying to train her to be a good traveler. We tried a lot of different kinds of food. Ceviche? That was different. We had alpaca. She found out down in the jungle that she liked watching animals, so we'll end up going to Costa Rica, and then in two years to Africa on a safari. It worked; she loved it." As told to Seth Kugel WHY WE TRAVEL: CUZCO, PERU

title: Detroit
description: WHY GO NOW -- The four wheels of Detroit culture -- sports, music, machines and beer -- are all on a roll. The city will be host to this season's Super Bowl, after having mounted the baseball All-Star game last month, and the high-profile events have fueled much sprucing up of downtown. Detroit's music revival, led by Eminem, Kid Rock and the White Stripes, is being extended by acts like Brendan Benson, the Dirtbombs and the Detroit Cobras. Car culture is always intense, and this January sees the opening of the North American International Auto Show; last year it drew over 780,000 people. As for beer -- well, there's never an off-season there.

title: War Relief
description: There was a soldier playing a fly-fishing video game in a room in Building 109. Outside, there was a black flag whipping in the wind to warn that the heat was rising toward 115. Past that there were the other buildings that make up Camp As Sayliyah, then a ring of concrete bomb-blast barriers and armed guards; past that was Doha, Qatar, a little U.S.-friendly thumb of a country sticking up into the Persian Gulf from Saudi Arabia, and then the desert, Iraq a few hours northwest, Afghanistan a few hours northeast.

title: O.K., Freshmen, It's Time to Study the Real World
description: SUMMER is just about over -- boohoo -- and college students have been heading back to campus, to the books and the parties and to their first classes of the fall term. It all makes me think of my first few weeks at Columbia back in September 1962. I was a bewildered freshman, overwhelmed with the heady mixture of Contemporary Civilization, Humanities, Physics for Poets (really unbelievably difficult physics), wrestling and -- was it English Lit? Who knows. Anyway, a lot of time has passed since then. John F. Kennedy was president. The schools in the Deep South were still segregated. The Vietnam War had not started in deadly earnest. Nelson A. Rockefeller was a mighty force on the Republican scene.

title: Grim Fairy Tales
description: An over-the-top banquet is in full swing, but the heir to the kingdom, an ever-so-handsome prince, is not eating. "I was thinking how odd the world is," he confesses. A pal laments, "They say it will stop turning." No, says our prince, "the fairies will never let it happen." This deliciously hopeful moment is just one of many memorable passages in Jacques Demy's 1970 movie, "Donkey Skin," one of the kookiest, most vibrantly colorful pieces of celluloid to ever come out of France. The film has become such a cult favorite among artists -- it stars a singing, jaw-droppingly gorgeous Catherine Deneuve and was recently re-released with a restored print (overseen by the director Agns Varda) -- that I predict it's only a matter of time before it crops up as an inspiration in fashion. How can designers resist a plot in which the heroine asks for a dress the color of the weather -- and gets it? John Galliano, do I hear you taking out your scissors?

title: New Spice
description: My fellow ladies: perhaps it's time we divert those queer eyes from our straight guys and take over decorating and renovating the opposite sex ourselves. I have nothing against gay men; some of my best friends, etc. But it's time for us to rescue the clueless hetero man from being bossed around by anyone but us. And since we've gained the vote as well as the right to stand in crowded subways while alpha males spread their legs over a three-seat vista, we can certainly make a contribution toward furthering the cause of male vanity, which has suffered so extensively from apathy and neglect.

title: POP/JAZZ
description: There aren't enough opportunities to hear traditional country and folk music in New York, but for 22 years now, one of the best and most dependable has been LINCOLN CENTER'S ROOTS OF AMERICAN MUSIC FESTIVAL, part of its free Out of Doors series. This year's two-day festival features, on Saturday, an 80th-anniversary tribute to the Grand Ole Opry with, among others, the Georgia-born blues guitarist LARRY JOHNSON; the snazzy bluegrass group DAVE PETERSON & 1946; the NASHVILLE BLUEGRASS BAND; and, returning once again, the mountain-music patriarch DOC WATSON. Next Sunday brings a reunion of the 1960's folk group the HIGHWAYMEN, the stylish and eclectic singer SUZY BOGGUSS and the master picker RICKY SKAGGS. Beginning at 2 p.m. each day, North Plaza and Damrosch Park, Lincoln Center, (212)875-5766 or www.lincolncenter.org. American folk is at the heart of SONS AND DAUGHTERS, a young band from Glasgow. But they've inherited it through the indie tradition, from the nervy exuberance of the Violent Femmes to the exquisite gloom of Cat Power. The band has a chilling new album, "THE REPULSION BOX" (Domino), and plays at the Mercury Lounge on Friday night. 217 East Houston Street, at Ludlow Street, Lower East Side; 10:45 p.m, (212)260-4700, $12, $10 in advance.

title: Blues for Fatty: A Silent Comic Gets a Jazzy Soundtrack
description: The silent-film comedian Roscoe (Fatty) Arbuckle may seem like an unlikely inspiration for a jazz composer. But the trumpeter Dave Douglas's newest album serves as accompaniment, homage and apology to Arbuckle, whose career was destroyed when he was charged with rape and murder in 1921. "Keystone," set for release Sept. 20 on Mr. Douglas's own Greenleaf Music label (www.greenleafmusic.com), uses DualDisc technology in a multimedia package devoted to Arbuckle. The CD side of the disc includes 11 original songs; on the DVD side, five of those songs, in edited form, make up a new soundtrack for "Fatty and Mabel Adrift," a 1916 two-reeler that Arbuckle made, as director and star, for Mack Sennett at Keystone Film Studios. The DVD side also has a music video called "Just Another Murder," created from vignettes from another Arbuckle film, "Fatty's Tintype Tangle."

title: Lost in the Fog, 9-0, Keeps It Short and Sweet

Despite meeting Grade I competition for the first time in his career while coming off a minor foot injury, Lost in the Fog earned his ninth career victory, in a race that looked no different from his previous eight as he dominated six rivals to win the King's Bishop by four and three-quarters lengths over Social Probation.

title: I and You
description: Poets who write only poetry are like musicians who play only cowbell: oddly cool, but mostly just odd. More typically, poets work on their poems alongside an array of literary and quasi-literary projects, from novels (Hardy) to plays (Yeats) to libretti (Dryden) to art reviews (John Ashbery) to advertising slogans for Lay's Potato Chips (James Dickey). Marianne Moore even once spent a month helping Ford come up with names for the car that was eventually christened the Edsel. (Moore's suggestions included "The Intelligent Whale," so you can't say the company didn't get its money's worth.) Yet while poets have excelled at a number of sidelines, they've done some of their sharpest work in a genre that's often overlooked: the personal letter. Not all great poets are great letter writers, of course, but the correspondence of Pope, Keats, Rilke and many others is more than simply an interesting supplement to the poetic canon; without these letters, poetry as we know it wouldn't exist.

title: Wrist Factor
description: From the moment I saw it, I wanted an Herms Cape Cod watch, with its extra-long leather strap. That was seven years ago, when I was a journalist with the Financial Times. The watch was a prototype in the office of Herms's chairman, Jean-Louis Dumas. He was telling me about Martin Margiela, whom he had hired to design the Herms women's collection and who had hit upon the idea of making a very long leather watch strap that curled twice around the wrist. It reminded me of the watches on wide leather wristbands that I'd worn in my teens in the north of England during the early 1970's, when my bedroom was wallpapered with Roxy Music posters. It also evoked the raw elegance that I loved in Margiela's clothes. As soon as the watch went on sale, I dashed into Herms. The women's style looked clunky on my skinny arm, but the men's was perfect -- so big that the watch face covered the entire top of my wrist. Much as I loved it, the Cape Cod didn't seem like the most practical purchase. My wrist felt smothered by its bulk, and the double strap was so conspicuous that I thought I'd soon be bored by it. I've since worn the Cape Cod every day. The heft feels so comforting that other watches appear alarmingly light, and only the Cape Cod reminds me of Bryan Ferry. ALICE RAWSTHORN

title: Mother in the War Zone
description: As a convoy commander in Iraq, I had serious reservations about the effectiveness of a young single mother in my unit, but what really appalled me was the thought of her leaving a child orphaned. When she was assigned to a particularly dangerous convoy, I replaced her with an unmarried man. He didn't know why; I just said I was shorthanded and asked for volunteers. Did I act ethically? Ray Doeksen, Chicago You did the right thing for the wrong reason. If this female soldier was indeed unqualified for the assignment, she would be a danger to herself, her comrades and the mission. You could replace her on those grounds, but not because of her home life. Few commanders have sufficient knowledge of the private lives of all their troops to consider such a factor equitably. Perhaps one of your soldiers was a single dad. Another might care for a dozen siblings. And even if you knew all that, how would you balance such diverse circumstances?

title: How Nicolas Got His Groove Back
description: Nicolas Ghesquire likes his models at Balenciaga to race down the runway. He feels it gives his clothes the energy of sports, though Ghesquire, the son of a former swimming coach and golf-course manager, isn't athletic himself. He is slight of build, with black hair, fashionable stubble and light-blue eyes that essentially tell you everything, from intense interest to rapid disenchantment. Last March, after his fall show -- a streak of camel coats and jackets piped in fur that put editors in a good mood and announced a more mature sensibility -- Ghesquire was backstage greeting guests. Among the first to arrive was Franois-Henri Pinault, the chief executive of the French luxury and retail group Pinault-Printemps-Redoute and technically Ghesquire's boss. As a rule, backstage moments yield little information; if anything, they tend to reinforce the impression that the fashion world is insincere, the tepid congratulations offered in exchange for an advertising page. But in the several minutes that Ghesquire and Pinault talked with each other, with Pinault speaking quietly and without gesture, it was apparent that the warmth between the two men was genuine.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DE BARY, PATRICIA
description: de BARY--Patricia, noted community leader and beloved wife of Marquette de Bary, died peacefully, at her home in New York, Sunday, August 21, of natural causes. She was born on June 19, 1919, in Atlanta, Georgia, to Elizabeth Sturgis Murrill and Hugh Ambrose Murrill. She had three siblings: Tracy, Kathleen and Hugh II. She moved to Greenwich, Connecticut, when she was 13 years old, and was head of the Chapel Committee and Head Marshall of The Rosemary Hall School, from which she graduated. She attended Sweet Briar College and in 1938, married David DuVivier, an attorney. Her son, Jerome Sturgis DuVivier, was born on October 22, 1947, and her daughter, Eleanor Tracy DuVivier, was born on April 11, 1951. In the early fifties, she became one of the first women stockbrokers registered on the New York Stock Exchange. In 1956, she was divorced and in 1958, married Theodore Sauvinet Gary, an electronics entrepreneur. Ted's daughter, Laura Gary, became her daughter. The Gary's lived in New York, Miami Beach, Madeline Island, Wisconsin, and in Wayzata, Minnesota. In 1972 they were divorced. In 1977, she married Marquette de Bary, President of Marquette de Bary Co., an investment banking firm. Since then, they have lived in New York, Southampton and Paris. All her life, she was a dedicated leader and benefactor of charitable and community organizations. She founded the Madeline Island Public Library in Wisconsin and was an outstanding leader in Florida with the American Cancer Society. In New York, she was on the Women's Advisory Board of the Boys Club of New York for over 50 years, and devoted herself to boards and events for The Central Park Conservancy, The Southampton Hospital and the New York Botanical Gardens. She remained a stockbroker until 2002, and was a gracious hostess, as well as a social and community force. She will long be remembered for her elegance, her taste, her love of family, her loyalty to friends, her commitment to excellence, and her generosity to the nonprofit community in every place she found herself. She is survived by her devoted husband, Marquette deBary; her son, Jerome Gary; her daughters, Laura Gary Thorne and Tracy Gary; her sister, Kathleen Murrill Lee; and her grandsons, Jordan Lambert Gary, Edwin Thorne III and Hunter Gary Thorne, and her granddaughter, Melanie Thorne Wagner. Memorial contributions should be sent to the Boys Club of New York, The Central Park Conservancy, the New York Botanical Gardens, or the Madeline Island Public Library. A memorial service will be held, at 11 AM, at Saint Bartholomew's Episcopal Church, Park Avenue at 51st Street, Thursday, September 15th.

Whatever your medium, start with naked skin (a total maquillage can make a blushed cheek look too doll-like), and smile before applying to make the application appear as natural as possible. Buy something pinker than you think you will ever need; it will look right once it's on. title: Arts, Briefly; Grimm and Grimmer
description: The boyish good looks of Matt Damon and Heath Ledger, below, were not enough to unseat a reigning virgin at the box office this weekend or to stop the weekly decline in admissions. The R-rated "40-Year-Old Virgin" (Universal) took in $16.4 million over the weekend, retaining its No. 1 spot at the box office and bringing its cumulative sales to $48.7 million, according to studio estimates. Terry Gilliam's "Brothers Grimm" (Dimension Films), starring Mr. Damon and Mr. Ledger, opened at No. 2 with $15 million in ticket sales, according to Exhibitor Relations, which tracks box office admissions. Holdovers rounded out the Top 5: "Red Eye" (DreamWorks) dropped only 36 percent, to No. 3, with $10 million; "Four Brothers" (Paramount) dropped to No. 4, with $7.8 million, and "Wedding Crashers" (New Line) -- which last week surpassed the Will Smith movie "Hitch" to become the top-grossing comedy of the year -- took in $6.25 million over the weekend, bringing its cumulative sales to $187.7 million. This weekend's box office was down more than 16 percent from last weekend, more than doubling last weekend's 7 percent drop from the week before.

title: Arts, Briefly; 'Eyes' Nearly Free, at Last
description: More than 10 years after it last appeared on television, supporters of "Eyes on the Prize," the acclaimed television documentary series chronicling the civil rights movement, have raised enough money to attempt a break from copyright bondage, Sandy Forman, the attorney for the project said yesterday. A Ford Foundation grant of $600,000 and a check for an undisclosed amount from the New York-based money manager and philanthropist Richard Gilder will pay for efforts to secure the expired rights to the hundreds of copyrighted elements in "Eyes" -- before it can be shown again. First broadcast nationally on PBS in 1987 and most recently in 1993, the documentary has largely been absent from television and video rental shelves because of the copyright issues. "It's been very good for us," Ms. Forman said of the money, estimating that it could take up to a year to renew and pay for all the permissions. After copyright hurdles are cleared and the film is re-edited and digitized, she explained, it could be back on the air as early as next year. Discussions have already begun with officials at the PBS program "American Experience." FELICIA R. LEE

Gotti, the boss of the Gambino crime family, threatened violence against Jerry Capeci, a columnist who writes about organized crime, in a prison conversation on July 20, 1996, according to a video played yesterday in Federal District Court. "If I was home, I'd throw him off" a building, Mr. Gotti said about Mr. Capeci, who had recently published a book about the Gottis. Mr. Gotti was talking to his son, John A., over an internal telephone in the federal prison in Marion, Ill. The threat came four years after Gambino henchmen, on orders from both Gottis, abducted and shot Curtis Sliwa, the Guardian Angels founder who had criticized them on the radio, according to testimony in the racketeering trial of the younger Mr. Gotti. title: Corrections
description: Because of a transcription error, an article in Business Day on Saturday about a speech by Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve, in which he warned against making unrealistic assumptions about the economy, incorrectly rendered part of a sentence as a direct quotation. Mr. Greenspan did indeed refer to an increased willingness of investors to accept low "risk premiums," but he did not go on to say that this was a "willingness based on a complacent assumption that the low interest rates, low inflation and strong growth of recent years are permanent." Those words were the reporter's own.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: Police Torture Accusations
description: A group of 46 human rights organizations, lawyers and community activists asked the Inter-American Commission on Human Rights to investigate accusations that 135 black criminal suspects were tortured by the police on the South Side of Chicago from 1971 to 1992 in an effort to extract confessions. The torture was said to include electric shocks and burns. A special prosecutor who reviewed the cases in 2002 has not issued any findings or filed criminal charges. Jon Burge, the police commander accused of overseeing the torture, was fired in 1993. In 2001, Gov. George Ryan pardoned four black death row inmates after it was revealed that their confessions had been coerced. Gretchen Ruethling (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Vatican City: Pope Meets Excommunicated Group
description: Pope Benedict XVI met with the excommunicated leader of the traditionalist Roman Catholic group founded by the dissident archbishop Marcel Lefebvre, as the group hoped to resolve its modern-day schism with the Vatican. The pope's meeting with Bernard Fellay, the superior general of the Society of St. Pius X, took place "in a climate of love for the church," according to a Vatican statement. But Benedict did not offer the traditionalists reconciliation at this point. "While knowing the difficulties, the desire to proceed by degrees and in reasonable time was shown," the Vatican said. The society, based in Switzerland, was founded by Archbishop Lefebvre in 1970 in rejection of Vatican reforms in the 1960's. In 1988, he consecrated four bishops, including Mr. Fellay, against Pope John Paul II's orders. Archbishop Lefebvre, who died in 1991, and his bishops were then excommunicated. At the time, Cardinal Joseph Ratzinger -- now Benedict XVI -- worked to forestall the excommunications. Brian Wingfield (NYT)

description: HURRICANE RIPPLES With Hurricane Katrina pounding the New Orleans area yesterday, shutting airports from the western Florida Panhandle to Baton Rouge and creating mounting delays at Hartsfield-Jackson Atlanta International, a central connecting point for the South, here are some ways to plan ahead if you're traveling this week. A new Web service, www.flightstats.com, calculates status and delays for every domestic flight. (Click the link "Sample Aps" and then "Airport Status.) "You just drill in and see how your flight may be affected," said Meara McLaughlin, the head of business development and marketing for Flightstats. All major airline Web sites have a tool, usually called a flight tracker, that gives the real-time status of any flight, including anticipated delays. And the Federal Aviation Administration maintains a map showing real-time airport operating status at its Web site, www.faa.gov, under the Airport Status link. Individual airlines are also posting information about changing itineraries and canceling tickets on their own Web sites.

title: Arts, Briefly; Country Hall of Fame
description: The Country Music Hall of Fame's class of 2005 consists of the group Alabama, the country and pop star Glen Campbell and the Grand Ole Opry's first black superstar, the harmonica virtuoso DeFord Bailey, below, the Country Music Association announced on Monday in Nashville. Their formal induction will take place in New York on Nov. 15, during the CBS telecast of the association's awards show from Madison Square Garden. Unlike pop or rock groups, bands rarely achieve superstar status in modern country music, but Alabama (with Randy Owen, Teddy Gentry, Jeff Cook and Mark Herndon) was a notable exception. In the 1980's and 90's, the band amassed 42 No. 1 country singles. Mr. Campbell, a native of tiny Delight, Ark., was a recording, movie and television star in his late-1960's heyday. Mr. Bailey, who died in 1982, never grew beyond 4-foot-10 because of polio, but he was both a giant and a tragic figure in country music; the reasons for his departure from the Opry in the early 1940's have long been shrouded in controversy. title: World Business Briefing | Asia: China: Sinopec Profit Growth Slows
description: The China Petroleum and Chemical Corporation, Asia's biggest refiner, said that first-half profit rose at the slowest pace in three years as soaring costs of crude oil cut earnings from refining. Net income excluding minority interests increased 17 percent, to 19.65 billion yuan ($2.4 billion), or 0.227 yuan a share, the company, known as Sinopec, said in a statement. The rate of growth was the lowest since the first half of 2002. Higher oil costs and state controls on fuel prices to curb inflation are slashing margins at Chinese refiners and making some gasoline retailers limit sales, prompting shortages. "The refiners are being squeezed," Philip Niem, Asian investment strategist at Barclays Bank in Hong Kong, said. "Crude oil prices are increasing so rapidly, it's hard for the Chinese government to keep up." Snopec's refining business had an operating loss of 1.3 billion yuan, swinging from a profit of 4.3 billion yuan a year earlier. The profit from processing each barrel of oil fell to $2.32, from $4.07. Profit from oil exploration and production jumped 69 percent, to 17.8 billion yuan.

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: New Home Sales Fall Again
description: Dow Jones - New home sales in Australia fell for the third consecutive month in July, dropping 0.6 percent from June, as declines in the housing market in the most populous states more than outweighed increases elsewhere, a survey by the Housing Industry Association showed. The latest monthly decline in new home sales follows a 2 percent fall in June and a 4.6 percent drop in May. Australia's housing market has been coming off the boil in the last year as heated markets led by Sydney pushed up prices and reduced home affordability. The housing association's chief economist, Simon Tennent, said the decline in new home sales was still in line with an orderly slowdown that is creating pent-up demand for housing in Australia. But the July survey also showed that homebuying in some regions of Australia had all but stalled, Mr. Tennent said. In the major states of New South Wales and Victoria, new home sales fell 12.3 percent and 5 percent respectively, partly because of high land costs. These declines were partly offset by a 7.5 percent rise in Queensland, a 17.4 percent increase in South Australia and a 10.5 percent rise in Western Australia.

description: Public health departments remain unprepared to quickly respond to an outbreak of infectious diseases like bubonic plague or a bioterrorism attack, a new study has found. After clearing the test with health officials in 18 states, researchers posing as doctors and nurses repeatedly alerted health departments about outbreaks over 10 months to see how they responded.
