Paid Notice: Deaths   LEVESQUE, THERESE A., PH.D.
description: LEVESQUE -- Therese A., Ph.D. Died August 28, 2005 after a prolonged illness. Born May 8, 1917 in West Warwick, R.I. to J. Wilfred Levesque & Mathilda Smith Levesque. A longtime resident of Nyack, New York, she was predeceased by her brother Lucien of Coventry. R.I. and sister Vivian Heebert of Charlottesville, VA. Survived by Sister Blandine Levesque of the Grey Nuns of Montreal, Montreal, Canada, Claire Smith of North Charleston, S.C., brother Raymond of Mamaroneck, N.Y., Henriette Allen, Ph.D. of Clinton, Ms. Cecilia Mruk of Larchmont, N.Y. and Cecile Allen of Alpharetta, GA, and many nieces and nephews and grand-nieces and grand-nephews. Graduated with a BA degree, Magna Cum Laude, major in French and minor in Latin from Rivier College, 1938. Awarded her Master of Arts Degree in Latin, Fordham University, 1948, Ph.D. Educational Administration, Supervision and Curriculum, Fordham University 1961. Began her teachng career in Rhode Island and continued in New York. At her retirement she was Assistant Superintendent in the Orangeburg School District, Blauvelt, NY. Enlisted in the United States Marine Corps Women's Reserve in February, 1943. Received basic training at Hunter College, New York City. Graduated from Aerology/Meterology School, U.S. Naval Air Station, Lakehurst, NJ. Accepted for O.C.S. and won her gold bar. Retired in 1947 with a rank of 1st Lieutenant. Collaberated with her sister Henriette Allen in the writing of school textbooks. She was a Fulbright exchange teacher, Montpelier, France in 1953-1954. A communicant of St Ann's Church in Nyack, NY, she was active in many church activities but her main involvement was with the St. Vincent de Paul Society. Student, educator, administrator, author and patriot, she was an inspiration to her siblings and students. We have lost a fine, generous and thoughtful sister and friend. Wake to be held at Hannemann's Funeral Home, 88 South Broadway, Nyack, NY, on Tuesday, August 30 from 4 to 7PM. Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated at St. Ann's Church, 16 Jefferson Street, Nyack, NY, Wednesday, August 31 at 10 A.M. Interment will be private at a later date. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Therese A. Levesque, Ph.D. Scholarship Fund, Rivier College, 420 Main Street, Nashua, NH 03060.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Science Times last Tuesday about a climatologist's resignation from a panel advising the Bush administration on temperature changes in the atmosphere misstated his position on global warming. The scientist, Roger A. Pielke Sr. of Colorado State University, says warming is caused mainly by human activities; he does not disagree with that widely held view. Where he differs with many scientists is on the amount of warming from the accumulation of gases like carbon dioxide, as opposed to other factors; on the reliability of temperature measurements on the earth's surface; and on the value of computer projections that estimate future climate change.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Canada: Ontario Bans Pit Bulls
description: An Ontario law banning pit bulls in the province -- the first of its kind to apply across an entire province in Canada -- took effect amid protests by owners of the breed. It will now be illegal to breed pit bulls or to import them into the province. Owners held a candlelight vigil in front of the provincial legislature, claiming that their rights had been infringed. Pit bulls already in the province and puppies born over the next three months can remain as long as they are sterilized and kept leashed and muzzled in public. The law was passed after several highly publicized attacks by pit bulls on children. Clifford Krauss (NYT)

Mr. Jones told detectives that he had intended to use the pistol to threaten people outside who were being loud, and accidentally shot the child, the police said. They said other children were elsewhere in the apartment. William K. Rashbaum (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HOGUE, MITCHELL (MITCH) J.
description: HOGUE--Mitchell (Mitch) J., age 45 of Galena, IL formerly of New York City, NY died suddenly on Saturday, August 27, 2005 at Mercy Medical Center, Dubuque, IA. He was born on January 23, 1960 in Canton, OH. Mitch attended high school in Avon Lake, OH and then graduated Magna Cum Laude from Hunter College, N.Y.C. He earned a double major: English with Creative Writing and the History of Theater. Mitch was a playwright, producer, director and comedian. He was currently writing a column entitled "Primary Buzzard" for the bipartisan e-zine, "Primary Buzz". He was also working on a play, "400 Year Anniversary" about the founding of Jamestown. Mitch was a member of the Writers Guild of New York and was a staunch member of the Democratic Party. Mitch loved life--he enjoyed politics, traveling and movies. Listening to music, working crossword puzzles, reading and research kept him busy. Mitch's greatest joy was to be with his daughters and his granddaughter, Angelina. He is survived by his parents, Albert Hogue of Tucson, AZ and Antoinnette Hogue of Brook Park, OH, two daughters, Chrissy (Tim) HogueBauman of East Dubuque, IL and Jennifer Hogue of Dubuque, IA, granddaughter, Angelina Hogue-Bauman of East Dubuque, IL, Charlene J. (Michael Schenker) Hogue, NY, NY, Diane M. (A.J.) DeChiara and Kimberly A. Hogue of Estero, FL, a brother, Douglas E. (Terri) Hogue of Brunswick, OH, a half-sister, Katrina Hogue of Tucson, AZ and six nieces & nephews. Visitation from 3:00 to 8:00 PM on Wednesday, August 31 at Behr Funeral Home, 1491 Main St., Dubuque, IA. Services Thursday at the Mueller Memorial Chapel, 2735 Windsor Ave., Dubuque followed by interment at Linwood Cemetery. Contributions may be made to The Mitchell J. Hogue Memorial Fund, c/o Behr Funeral Home, 1491 Main St., Dubuque, IA 52001

World Briefing | Africa: Zimbabwe: Mugabe Risks I.M.F. Expulsion
description: President Robert G. Mugabe "simply does not care" whether the International Monetary Fund chooses to expel his nation because it is $290 million in arrears on payment of the more than $1 billion it owes the agency, the Johannesburg newspaper The Star quoted one of his top aides as saying. The aide said Mr. Mugabe refused to meet an I.M.F. team that visited Harare last week to gather information in advance of a meeting at which Zimbabwe could face expulsion for refusal to pay its debts. South Africa has been negotiating a bailout of Zimbabwe's debt with Mr. Mugabe, but his rejection of the fund has complicated those talks, the newspaper reported. He is said to have refused conditions, including movement toward political and economic reforms, that President Thabo Mbeki of South Africa hoped to place on the money.

title: Arts, Briefly; 'Monk' Leads So Far
description: "Monk" ended its fourth season on Friday, and according to Nielsen estimates, 5.28 million viewers watched the finale on USA. Among 25-to-54-year-olds, "Monk," starring Tony Shalhoub, below, was the No. 1 scripted series on cable this summer, though the second-place "Closer" on TNT has a chance to surpass it, as it is still broadcasting new episodes. On pay cable, HBO's "Rome" drew an audience of 3.8 million for the Sunday debut of the 12-episode series. Those ratings represented HBO's best premiere since "Six Feet Under" began its fourth season in June 2004. On the network side, Fox's "Prison Break" kicked off the beginning of the new television season on Monday night. Its two-hour broadcast, in which a man (Wentworth Miller) goes to prison to break out his brother, brought in 10.5 million viewers. Those strong numbers put Fox in first place among viewers and 18-to-49-year-olds, and in a tie with CBS in households. KATE AURTHUR

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CHEW, BEVERLY CORY
description: CHEW--Beverly Cory.Known to friends and family as Peter, died of lung cancer on Friday August 26, 2005 at Westminster Canterbury, in Charlottesville, Virginia, at the age of 77. Mr. Chew was born on June 18, 1928 in Rochester, New York, to Philip Frederick Chew and Jane Cory Chew. Raised in Syosset, New York, he was a 1947 graduate of St. Mark's high school in Southborough, Massachusetts, and a 1953 graduate of Trinity College, in Hartford, Connecticut. After college, Mr. Chew served in the U.S. Navy as an aviator and later moved to New York City where he worked as an investment counselor. There he was a member of the St. Nicholas Society of New York and the Society of the Cincinnati, an organization of the descendants of officers who served in the Revolutionary War. In 1989, Mr. Chew retired and moved to Charlottesville, VA, with his family. His wife, Constance DeWilde Chew preceded him in death in 2002. An avid outdoorsman, recreational artist and loving father, Mr. Chew is survived by his three children: Alexander Beverly Chew and his wife Renata Milare Chew, Frederick Chew DeWilde and his wife Michelle Dethier DeWilde, and his daughter Cory Livingston Chew. Memorial services will be held at 2 PM on Saturday, September 3rd at St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Ivy, VA. Family and friends will be received following the service. Memorial donations may be made to the St. Nicholas Society of New York and the Society of the Cincinnati. For more information contact Hill and Wood Funeral Home, Charlottesville, VA, 434-296-6148.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Man Charged In Mortgage Fraud
description: A grand jury has indicted a Brooklyn businessman on charges of defrauding mortgage lenders of more than $6 million by inflating the appraised value of dilapidated and abandoned buildings in Bushwick, Crown Heights and Bedford Stuyvesant, prosecutors with the Brooklyn district attorney's office said yesterday. The businessman, Owen Larman, who remains at large, was described by the authorities as the leader of a fraud ring that operated for six years. Prosecutors said Mr. Larman bought the buildings, often shells without plumbing, heating or interior walls, then convinced acquaintances to buy the properties or act as straw buyers in false transactions at inflated prices. He paid the buyers, then used high appraisal reports and photos of other buildings to resell them, prosecutors said. No charges were filed against the buyers, prosecutors said, because some were unwitting and those who seemed to understand the fraud had already been punished with ruined credit ratings. Mr. Larman also faces a charge of assault for threatening one buyer. Michael Brick (NYT)

description: Berlin's openly gay mayor, Klaus Wowereit, has come under criticism for extending the city's official welcome to a leather and latex fetish street fair that begins Saturday. "The first weekend in September will be marked by pure joie de vivre," Mr. Wowereit wrote in a message of greeting for the official program of the event, Folsom Europe. "A warm welcome to Berlin!" About 15,000 leather and latex enthusiasts from around Europe are expected at the event, which is being held for the second year in Berlin and was inspired by the long-running Folsom Street Fair in San Francisco. Politicians criticized the letter for not being in line with the dignity of the office of mayor, and the mass-market newspaper Bild accused Mr. Wowereit of transforming Berlin into a sex capital. World Briefing | Africa: Zimbabwe: Lawmakers Cut Rights
description: Parliament approved a widely criticized batch of constitutional amendments that solidify state power within the long-ruling ZANU-PF party, disenfranchising any citizen with at least one foreign parent and allowing the government to prohibit travel abroad by anyone deemed "anti-national." Another amendment bars legal action by the more than 4,000 white commercial farmers whose lands have been seized by the government and redistributed to peasants and ZANU-PF members in the last five years. Opposition legislators called the changes "the rape of democracy," and the union of white farmers charged that they had effectively legalized ethnic cleansing. The Zimbabwean justice minister, Patrick Chinamasa, said the changes would conclude the "decolonization" of Zimbabwe that began 25 years ago when it won independence from white rule. Michael Wines (NYT)

Invasion of the Isolationists
description: Washington - AS we mark four years since Sept. 11, 2001, one way to organize a review of what has happened in American foreign policy since that terrible day is with a question: To what extent has that policy flowed from the wellspring of American politics and culture, and to what extent has it flowed from the particularities of this president and this administration?

title: Pitting a Mango? Get Rid of the Guesswork, Too
description: I have little patience for single-use cooking tools -- the avocado slicer comes to mind -- but if you love mangoes Oxo's new pitter is worth owning.

title: Weiner Lists His Terms for Access to Housing
description: Representative Anthony D. Weiner unveiled a battery of proposals yesterday aimed at making housing more affordable for middle-class New Yorkers "and those aspiring to get there," putting down his marker on a major issue in the Democratic mayoral campaign as the Sept. 13 primary looms.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Bosnian Serb Sought By Tribunal Arrested
description: Russian investigators have detained a Bosnian Serb wanted by the international tribunal in The Hague, officials told news agencies. The suspect, Dragan Zelenovic, a paramilitary commander during Bosnia's civil war, faces 14 counts of rape and torture stemming from the Serbian seizure of the town of Foca in 1992. He reportedly lived for several years under an assumed name with a Serbian passport in Khanty-Mansisk, a region in western Siberia, where he was detained on Thursday, the region's police chief, Anatoly Vorotov, told the official RIA Novisti news agency. Steven Lee Myers (NYT)

title: Job Posting
description: LAST month, Nadine Haobsh, an associate beauty editor at Ladies' Home Journal, was about to resign and take a job at Seventeen, where she had been offered a similar position. Then the magazines discovered she was blogging about work, and her two jobs became none. Ladies' Home Journal asked her to leave immediately; Seventeen rescinded its offer.

title: In the Wake of Hurricane Katrina
description: To the Editor:

title: Chechen Leader Claims Help From Russians in School Siege
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 31 -The Chechen rebel leader Shamil Basayev, who masterminded last year's siege of School No. 1 in Beslan, asserted today that the takeover was made possible with the help of Russia's special services, who allowed the terrorists he sent there a safe passage near the school.

title: Judith Miller And a Free Press
description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: China: Cnooc Earnings Jump 69%
description: Cnooc, China's third-largest oil producer, said first-half profit soared 69 percent as the nation's economic expansion increased demand and fuel prices climbed to record highs. Net income rose to a record 11.8 billion yuan ($1.5 billion), or 0.29 yuan a share, from 7 billion yuan, or 0.17 yuan, a year earlier, Cnooc said in Hong Kong. Cnooc and its state-owned parent are leading an expansion of liquefied natural gas supplies in China, proposing seven plants from Guangdong province in the south to Tianjin, near Beijing. The chairman, Fu Chengyu, left, whose $18.5 billion bid for Unocal was rebuffed this month, may seek "opportunistic" acquisitions and stakes in L.N.G. fields, according to the earnings presentation.

title: Chacon Slips When Yankees Need Him Most
description: SEATTLE, Aug. 30 - For all that Shawn Chacon did in his first month with the Yankees, he can be excused for a start like Tuesday's. But in a tight pennant race and with the Yankees beset by another pitching injury, they cannot afford more games like this. Chacon gave up eight runs over the second and third innings at Safeco Field, dooming the Yankees to an 8-3 loss to the Seattle Mariners. His most important contribution was sticking around for six innings, keeping the Yankees' best relievers out of the game.

title: Bringing Thailand Closer to Home
description: Correction Appended

title: Splashing in the Waters of an Onstage Slum
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 30 - At a recent rehearsal in the cavernous auditorium of the Ahmanson Theater here, four teenage boys clambered out of the orchestra pit, all of them dripping, slithering and making a holy ruckus. That's because the musicians had been replaced with 10,000 gallons of chlorinated water.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about union members and officials who are running for the New York City Council misstated the name of the union to which one candidate, Darlene Mealy, belongs. It is the Transport Workers Union, not the Transit Workers Union.

title: Bank of America Dismisses Interpublic From Its Ad Account
description: The troubled Interpublic Group of Companies was dealt a serious blow today when one of its largest clients, Bank of America, dismissed Interpublic and shifted its consolidated advertising account, with total spending estimated at $600 million, to a bigger Interpublic competitor, the Omnicom Group.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   HIRSCHHORN, ROSE
description: HIRSCHHORN--Rose. Your birthday! Loving you, missing you and needing you more than ever! Herbert

title: James H. Scheuer, 13-Term New York Congressman, Is Dead at 85
description: James H. Scheuer, a fiercely liberal New York congressman who for 13 terms represented districts covering parts of the Bronx, Queens, Brooklyn and Nassau County as part of a post-World War II generation of political reformers, died yesterday at his home in Washington. He was 85.

title: Flooding Stops Presses and Broadcasts, So Journalists Turn to the Web
description: With their offices and presses flooded, news media outlets in New Orleans mostly abandoned newsprint and television broadcasts yesterday and set up shop on the Web.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: China: Western Investors Sign Deal For Bank Stake
description: Three Western financial institutions -- a Goldman Sachs private equity fund, Allianz of Germany and the American Express Company -- signed a preliminary agreement yesterday to pay more than $3 billion for roughly 10 percent of the Industrial and Commercial Bank of China, China's largest bank. While the precise terms are subject to negotiation, Goldman Sachs Capital Partners V and a group of institutions and wealthy individuals with ties to the fund will contribute $1.8 billion, Allianz will put in $1 billion and American Express will pay $200 million to $300 million. Keith Bradsher (NYT)

title: Seized $101 million may be part of hedge fund
Corzine Romance Makes Trouble for Union's Leader
description: TRENTON, Aug. 30 - While it is unclear whether United States Senator Jon S. Corzine's campaign for governor will be seriously affected by his former romantic and financial relationship with the leader of a state employees union, their entanglements have already become a political headache for the union leader, Carla Katz.

title: A Look at the South Through a Lens, Truly
description: "Why not be silent?" a filmmaker asks himself in the opening voiceover to the sublimely bleak documentary "William Eggleston in the Real World." After a few minutes of narration, that filmmaker, Michael Almereyda, establishes that being quiet is key to getting intimate with the hard-to-know pioneer of color photography. Mr. Eggleston is mostly mute while prowling for images of the Deep South's luxurious decay. But his mutterings become clear, in this look at tattered glory.

title: Observance
description: Annahir Cariello read the Book of Mormon in the stillness of a 10-acre wood in Palmyra, N.Y. She thought of the vision of God that Joseph Smith, the founder of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, said he had in the same grove in the spring of 1820.

title: Season Ends With a Feast In Bare Feet
description: THIS is the time of year, with family and friends thinking of getting kids off to school, packing up the summer house and going back home, that we all become a bit sentimental. We won't see one another again until Christmas, perhaps. So we get in the mood for a holiday that affirms our feeling of camaraderie: Thanksgiving.

Paid Notice: Deaths   BRICKNER, RABBI BALFOUR
description: BRICKNER--Rabbi Balfour. Survived by his loving partner Marcia Soltes, his sons Adam and Rabbi Barnett, his sister Joy Rabinowitz and his four grandchildren, Alexander, Eve, Eli and Hasina. Services Thursday, 11AM, Stephen Wise Free Synagogue, 30 W. 68 St, N.Y. Contributions may be made in his memory to the National Offices of Planned Parenthood and/or the Rabbi Balfour Brickner Early Childhood Center at the Stephen Wise Free Synagogue, in Manhattan.

title: Indonesia battling polio
You Want Meaningful? Try Castro's Late Homer
description: Jos Reyes stood on the top step of the dugout, jumping up and down and pumping his fist, trying to will the ball out of Shea Stadium. Beside him was Mets Manager Willie Randolph, who peered over the rail, wishing, hoping.

title: The Misery Is Spread Equally
description: WAVELAND, Miss., Aug. 30 - The storm was nothing if not equal opportunity in its misery.

title: U.S. and China Fail to Reach Agreement in Textile Talks
description: BEIJING, Aug. 31 - China and the United States failed to reach agreement in textile trade negotiations in Beijing today, deepening the dispute over China's surging clothing exports as President Hu Jintao prepares to travel to Washington next week. The two-day talks over American moves to impose quotas on Chinese-made garments ended with the sides sharply at odds over even the basics of an agreement, said Cass Johnson, president of the National Council of Textile Organizations, which represents many American clothing manufacturers.

title: China's next step in clothes: Design
Jets' Abraham Returns to Applause of Teammates
description: HEMPSTEAD, N.Y., Aug. 30 - How would he be received by his teammates, who had labored through three dozen practices without him? The question weighed more heavily on the Jets' John Abraham than his added bulk or Tuesday morning's onerous humidity.

title: Rein In the Lobbyists
description: To the Editor:

title: After Escaping New Orleans, a Long Wait
description: METAIRIE, La., Aug. 31 - During the long, hot afternoon and into the humid night, the crowd of refugees on the edge of Interstate 10 here swelled to 2,000 hungry, flood-weary people, residents of New Orleans' northern neighborhoods and St. Bernard Parish to the northeast, who had been plucked from their roofs and attics as the waters of Lake Pontchartrain rose to cover cars, stop signs and one-story houses.

title: The 'Cuban Nijinsky' Seeks Asylum and Stardom
description: In early July, Rolando Sarabia, 23, one of the Ballet Nacional de Cuba's leading dancers, sneaked across the border into the United States in the way, he said, that so many Cubans do: "Walking, walking, walking." His is the latest in a wave of defections that have hit the brilliant but beleaguered Cuban national ballet company since 2002.

title: Hundreds killed in Iraq stampede
U.S. Gets Lift in Lumber Fight With Canada
description: OTTAWA, Aug. 30 - The United States won a potentially major victory this week when the World Trade Organization ruled in an interim decision that the imposition of duties on Canadian softwood lumber did not violate international law.

Paid Notice: Deaths  MOOR, JANKOWSKI, JAN KAROL, M.D.
description: MOOR-JANKOWSKI--Jan Karol, M.D. Age 81 in NYC. World renowned scientist and Polish freedom fighter. Beloved husband of Deborah, mourned by his children Bernard, Sarah and Tadeusz, his former wife Catherine Blancpain, two grandchildren and two great grandchildren. Burial will be in Poland. A memorial mass will be held on Wednesday, August 31, at 11 A.M. at St. Stanislaus Bishop and Martyr Church, 101 East 7th Street, Manhattan. Donations in his memory may be made to the Jan Moor-Jankowski Memorial Fund, Kosciuszko Foundation, 15 East 65 Street, NYC 10021, to fund Polish medical students.

title: Sweet Water
description: Chatham, N.Y. - WHEN I think of the lakes of my childhood, the Great Lakes, they conjure a sense of both sweetness and wildness at once. Beyond Chicago and Buffalo and Detroit, this territory of the great freshwater reserves of the world is for the most part unsettled, and unsought, like a secret treasure long ago forgotten.

title: A 'Revolving-Door' Charge Is Called a First in Hartford
description: HARTFORD, Aug. 30 - Lawyers for former Gov. John G. Rowland said on Tuesday that the state's expected pursuit of charges that he violated lobbying laws was unprecedented and would prove futile.

title: In Search of a Place to Sleep, and News of Home
description: SARALAND, Ala., Aug. 30 - Hundreds of thousands of evacuees from the New Orleans area stranded in overcrowded hotels, motels and makeshift shelters and on highways across much of the South underscored a new reality on Tuesday: an extended diaspora of a city's worth of people, one rarely seen in the annals of urban disaster.

title: Geography Complicates Levee Repair
description: Until engineers can repair breaks in the huge levees that separate New Orleans from Lake Pontchartrain, the city will essentially be an arm of the Gulf of Mexico, subject to the ebb and flow of the tides.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KOSLOFF, ELLIOTT
description: KOSLOFF--Elliott. August 29, 2005. Beloved husband of Nancy Lupton, NY cityscape artist. Friends may call Wednesday, August 31, 2-5 and 7-9 PM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St., Service Thursday, September 1, 9:30 AM at Frank E. Campbell. Interment, Mt. Olivet Cemetery, Middletown, NJ.

title: Vermont Blends 'Green' Flush Toilets and a Greenhouse
description: SHARON, Vt. - It is a rare rest stop attraction, especially in Vermont, a humid greenhouse soon to be filled with orchids and other flora better suited to steamy jungles than snowy mountains.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a 22-year-old man who is being prosecuted for the statutory rape of the 14-year-old mother of his child, whom he later wed, misstated the baby's day of birth. She was born last Wednesday, not Thursday.

title: L Subway Line Will Regain Conductors
description: In a significant defeat for New York City Transit, an arbitrator has ruled that the removal of train conductors from the L subway line on nights and weekends violated a labor agreement and ordered that the conductors be restored immediately.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SCHWARTZ, JERROLD MI CHAEL
description: SCHWARTZ -- Jerrold Mi chael. With deepest love and affection we announce his death on August 30, 2005. Best friend and husband of Renee; beloved father of Robin Adelman (Barry), Richard Schwartz and the late Nancy Schwartz Schreier; adored grandfather of Lindsay, Travis, Amanda, Kathryn, Danielle, Jacquelyn and Brandon; devoted brother of Frances Pernick. Funeral services will be held at Ferncliff Cemetery, Hartsdale, NY, Thursday at 11 AM.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about a new study finding that the earth's inner core rotates faster than the earth itself gave an incorrect comparison for the core's size. Its diameter is about 70 percent of the moon's, not greater. (The whole core -- inner and outer -- is larger than the moon.)

title: Carriers Are Stricken by Cancellations and Lack of Fuel
description: The airline industry felt the brunt of Hurricane Katrina yesterday, with some airports running low on jet fuel and carriers canceling hundreds of flights. Meanwhile, Wall Street feared that the financial problems of the sickest airlines could grow worse.

title: Secrecy Veils China's Jailing of a Journalist
description: BEIJING, Aug. 30 - For the more than 11 months that he has been incarcerated, Zhao Yan has been held in one of the darkest corners of China's legal system because of the accusation against him: that he leaked state secrets to his employer, The New York Times.

title: National Briefing
description: WEST

title: The Mets Make the Most of Their Leftover Assets
description: OMAR MINAYA will always be known for becoming general manager of the Mets and immediately spending $172 million of Fred Wilpon's money to sign Pedro Martnez and Carlos Beltran. With the few dollars he had left, though, he also signed a platoon of bench players: Marlon Anderson, Miguel Cairo, Chris Woodward and Ramon Castro.

title: At 19, Hernandez Is a Rookie Without a Worry
description: SEATTLE, Aug. 30 - The Mariners rookie pitcher Felix Hernandez is all of 19 years old, and something is missing. With only five big-league outings, Hernandez is set to start Wednesday night against the Yankees. He will be opposed by the former Mariners icon Randy Johnson. The house will be full and the hope placed on Hernandez by this avid baseball community will be boundless.

title: Paychecks soar during wartime for defense firms' CEOs
Civil Liberty Report Assails Police Over 2004 Protests
description: A year after more than 1,800 people were arrested during protests at the Republican National Convention in Manhattan, the New York Civil Liberties Union issued a report yesterday criticizing the Police Department's handling of many of the demonstrations, and offering proposals intended to avert confrontations at the next large gathering in New York.

Corrections
description: A picture caption in Business Day yesterday with an article about the indictment of eight former KPMG partners in a tax shelter case misstated the role of Carl Rauh in some copies. He is a defense lawyer for KPMG, not a prosecutor.

title: Its other 2 jets are safe, Cypriot carrier says
German Leader Attacks His Rival as Election Nears
description: BERLIN, Aug. 31 - Chancellor Gerhard SchrAder, fighting for his political survival, delivered a scathing attack today against his main challenger, Angela Merkel, saying that a Germany under her watch would become a "cold and inhumane society without solidarity."

title: China in delicate trade game with U.S. and EU
What's the Matter With Kansas?
description: Matthew Koso, 22, and his wife Crystal, 14, are the parents of a newborn baby and the center of a controversy in their hometown, Falls City, Neb. The couple apparently started dating when Crystal was 12, and after she became pregnant, they crossed over into Kansas, where it is legal for even preteen girls to get married, and tied the knot. The Nebraska attorney general, Jon Bruning, has charged Mr. Koso with statutory rape. But he says a vast majority of the people who have written in to comment on the case say that Mr. Koso did the right thing and that the only fault here lies with the prosecutor, whom they see as a home-wrecker.

title: Hong Kong's Chief Executive Invites Entire Legislature to Visit Mainland China With Him
description: HONG KONG, Aug. 29 - The chief executive of Hong Kong invited the territory's entire legislature on Tuesday to travel with him to southern China next month, in what would be the largest visit of pro-democracy politicians from here that the Communist leadership in Beijing has ever allowed.

title: 5 Highly Placed Lebanese Detained in Ex-Premier's Death
description: DUBAI, United Arab Emirates, Aug. 30 - A United Nations team investigating the assassination of a former Lebanese prime minister ordered the detention on Tuesday of five high-ranking current or former Lebanese officials with close ties to Syria, citing them as suspects in the February killing and sending a message to Damascus and its allies that no one will be spared scrutiny in the inquiry.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BING, FRANZ JOSEF
description: BING--Franz Josef. 89, passed on August 28, 2005. Beloved husband of Jeanne, adored father of Lauren and treasured grandfather of Blake and Chase. Remembered for his generosity, his humor, his loyal friendships and his love of family. Memorial visitation on Wednesday, August 31, from 5 to 7 PM at William H. Graham Funeral Home, 1036 Boston Post Rd, Rye, NY 10580. Friends may send memorial donations to Pelham Public Library, 530 Colonial Ave, Pelham Manor, NY 10803.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FORGAN, MARIANNE
description: FORGAN--Marianne. Died August 27, 2005 at the age of 103. Mrs. Forgan (nee Pollak) was predeceased by her adoring husband of sixty years, the late Ernest Forgan, and her beloved daughter, the late Eva Merkel, and sonin-law, the late Edgar Merkel. Known as "Omi" to her immediate family, Mrs. Forgan leaves behind two grandsons and their wives: Stephen Merkel and Robin Shanus and Dr. Peter Merkel and Dr. Laura Dember, three great grandsons: David Edgar Merkel, Gabriel Evan Merkel, and Leo Shanus Merkel, sonin-law Herbert Salten, devoted nephew John Freund and his wife Nora, devoted niece Marian Landa and her husband Charles as well as the many children and grandchildren of the Freund and Landa families. Private graveside service, September 1, 2005, to be arranged by Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th Street, New York City (800-448-1939).

title: Adequate for Refugees, but Football?
description: With holes in its roof and thousands of people stranded inside, the Louisiana Superdome in New Orleans has become a large, leaky refugee center. But whether it will be ready to return to use as a football stadium anytime soon is a question.

title: Federated Will Sell 26 Stores as Part of Antitrust Agreement
description: Federated Department Stores will sell 26 stores in its purchase of May Department Stores as part of an antitrust pact with five states, the New York attorney general said yesterday.

title: Outback Steakhouse Hires Kaplan Thaler
description: Outback Steakhouse in Tampa, Fla., yesterday named the Kaplan Thaler Group in New York, part of the Publicis Groupe, to create campaigns for the Outback restaurant chain. The assignment, with spending estimated at more than $80 million, had been handled since 2002 by David and Goliath in Los Angeles.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Swaziland: King's Partying Daughter Beaten
description: An aide to the high-living King Mswati III said he beat the king's 17-year-old daughter with a cane after she attended a party with drinking and dancing to celebrate the end of her father's five-year ban on sex for girls under age 18. The aide, Ntfonjeni Dlamini, told Agence France-Presse that he was shocked to find Princess S'khanyiso Dlamini "amongst the people" on the eve of Swaziland's reed dance, in which tens of thousands of bare-breasted maidens dance before the king in a stadium. Swazi newspapers claimed that other girls at the party were also beaten, including the reigning Miss Swaziland beauty queen. Separately, a top Swazi official told the German news agency DPA that his country's citizens were offended by international ridicule of the reed dance and other Swazi customs. King Mswati, 37, has been frequently criticized for taking a teenage girl as his ninth wife in violation of his own ban on sex -- he paid a fine of one cow as punishment -- and for other excesses, like his recent purchase of a half million-dollar luxury sedan, in a nation where a quarter of the population depends on foreign donations for food. Michael Wines (NYT)

title: Giants' Feud With Xanadu Is About More Than Traffic
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Aug. 25 - If further evidence is needed that the car is king in New Jersey -- and that matters of traffic and roads trump most other issues -- look no further than the Meadowlands.

title: SAT Math Scores at Record High, but Those on the Verbal Exam Are Stagnant
description: This year's college-bound high school graduates reached a record-high average score on the SAT math test, but verbal scores remained flat, well below their historic high, the College Board said yesterday.

title: The Heat Proves to Be a Difficult Opponent for Players
description: The stifling humidity at the United States Open gripped three men's players in dramatic but different ways.

title: A Classic French Tale Echoes in the Gritty Paris of Today
description: Abdellatif Kechiche's first film, about a young North African immigrant's adventures in Paris, was called "It's Voltaire's Fault." His second, "Games of Love and Chance" (known in France as "L'Esquive"), takes place in the drab high-rise Paris suburbs (called banlieues) where many North Africans live. Its English title, and much of its inspiration, comes from a play by Voltaire's contemporary the 18th-century French writer Pierre Carlet de Chamblain de Marivaux. Mr. Kechiche's interest in connecting France's classical literary heritage with its contemporary social reality is intriguing, and it has resulted, in this case, in a spirited and insightful comedy of manners.

title: Casino Owners Look Toward Rebuilding
description: As Hurricane Katrina blew a destructive path through Biloxi, Miss., on Monday, the Grand Casino Biloxi, owned by Harrah's Entertainment, came unmoored and washed across U.S. 90. The giant casino, with its 134,200 square feet of gambling space, is probably a total loss, the company said.

title: No Quick Fix for Gulf Oil Operations
description: As the extent of the damage to offshore facilities in the Gulf of Mexico slowly became apparent a day after Hurricane Katrina's passage, oil prices soared above $70 a barrel and gasoline futures jumped by 20 percent yesterday on concerns it would take months to restore production to prestorm levels.

title: Sweet and Savory in Flatbush, By Way of Istanbul
description: Gulluoglu, a chain of pastry shops in Turkey, has specialized in baklava and other desserts made with phyllo for more than 100 years. Now, pastries shipped from the company's factory in Istanbul are being sold in New York at Gulluoglu Baklava and Caf, an elegant mahogany and marble store at 1985 Coney Island Avenue (Avenue P) in Flatbush, Brooklyn. (The bakery's name is pronounced julie-oo-OH-la.)

title: Corrections

She is associate director of marketing, not a curator.

title: Islanders Sign Nilsson
description: The Islanders said yesterday that they had agreed to terms with Robert Nilsson, a 20-year-old forward who was the team's first-round selection (15th over all) in 2003. Nilsson, son of the former N.H.L. player Kent Nilsson, agreed to the rookie maximum: a three-year, $2.86 million deal. Jason Diamos

description: MY friend reached our table in the dungeonlike hideaway of La Esquina's main dining room about 25 minutes late. Only 15 of those were her fault.

title: Worthwhile Fight Bloat Effort Needs a Booster Shot
description: Busy readers of The New York Times are getting some help from the Fight Bloat campaign that Bill Keller, executive editor of The New York Times, launched on April 11 to keep more front-page articles under 1,800 words. Bloated stories, he warned then, turn away readers who might actually be interested in a subject that got straight to the point.
